He ascended mountains with the lightness of flight, and in the depths of winter, he slept in the snow, snoring like thunder. He often told the villagers of Taihe: "This mountain shall one day achieve great renown."

The Daoist Qiu Yuanjing inquired about his origins and only then recognized him as the Patriarch Sanfeng. He begged to become his disciple, and Sanfeng transmitted to him the wondrous arts of the Dao.

*The Mirror of Divine Immortals* comments: "Heretical and peripheral teachings most easily delude people—like arrows shot into empty space, they inevitably fall back to earth. Only by finding the true seed, cultivating in secret, and refining until the elixir is complete and the fruit ripe, can one become impervious to cold and heat, beyond the reach of yin and yang, moving freely and coming and going at will. This is the true attainment." Those like Sanfeng are worthy of reverence.

**Letter to Chang Yuchun**
In the sixth month of the *jiyou* year of the Hongwu era (1369), Chang Yuchun advanced on Daxing Prefecture, captured Kaiping, and pursued the fleeing enemy for hundreds of *li*, achieving total victory and pacifying the north of Ji. In the seventh month, his army reached Liuhe Prefecture, where Yuchun fell ill. He addressed his generals: "When I was born, an old man came to my door and handed me a letter, saying: *'Radiant Tail Star, mighty tiger minister, harmonious meeting with the lord, beneath the willows the spirit returns.'* The envelope read: *'A letter from Zhang Zhenren Sanfeng of Wutai.'* These same words appear again—now that I have reached Liuhe Prefecture and fallen ill, I know my end has come." Soon after, he died in the army camp at the age of thirty-four.

The previous year, in *wushen* (1368), when the Emperor had just ascended the throne, he had respectfully inquired of the forty-second-generation Celestial Master, Zhang Chongxu: "What of the northern campaign?" The Celestial Master replied: "The court is blessed; the great general shall return to the Dao."

The Prince of Shu, Chun—twelfth son of the Grand Progenitor, enfeoffed as Prince of Shu—was also named Chun (or sometimes mistakenly recorded as Cao). During the Hongwu reign, the Grand Progenitor invested his son Chun as Prince of Shu. At that time, the Two Rivers region had long been pacified, its people tranquil and flourishing. Suddenly, an old man appeared, his spirit whole and visage ancient, moving as swiftly as if he flew. One day, clad in a formal cap and broad sash, he appeared before the prince with graceful ease and spoke of entering the Dao. The prince did not heed him, yet marveled inwardly at the elder’s vigor and wished to retain him. The old man laughed and recited:

*"Why seek the swift path of Zhongnan’s peaks?
To me, your longing weighs no more than goose down."*

The prince esteemed his resolve. One day, the old man said to him: *"Though your fief is fine, you must cultivate a retiring heart and empty mind to preserve yourself from misfortune. I am Zhang Sanfeng. Soon I shall wander the vast expanse with the immortals of the sea isles."* The prince composed a poem to send him off, including the lines:

*"My master has deeply grasped the art of the Marquis of Liu,
Nurturing stillness in the cinnabar field to guard the Valley Spirit."*

He did not detain him, and the Patriarch departed. Some say that among the later princes—such as Prince Gu, Sui, and Prince Liao, Zhi—many failed to retain their fiefs, while the Prince of Shu alone dwelled in peace and prosperity, all thanks to the Patriarch’s counsel.

After meeting the Prince of Shu, Chun, the Patriarch roamed the vast lands of Sichuan, Guizhou, and Yunnan, his cloud chariot unbound by fixed abode, his manifest traces most numerous, never lingering in stillness upon any single mountain. Some claim that upon first entering Chengdu and finding the Prince of Shu indifferent to the Dao, he withdrew to the Xiang-Ye region, dwelling on Mount Wudang for twenty-three years before one day setting forth on his wanderings, departing with a flick of his sleeve.

Yuantongzi, reading this passage, inscribed a quatrain:

*A white-haired immortal once entered the tent,
Met yet unrecognized—what could be done?
A few weighty words to the prince he imparted,
Preserving his fief in abundant repose.*

In the Hongwu reign, the Patriarch traveled to Shu and lodged at the residence of Commander Jiang of the Imperial Guards. His movements were enigmatic, yet none recognized him. He always wore a broad-brimmed bamboo hat, so large that it passed unimpeded even through narrow doorways, fastened with an iron-wire cord of exquisite workmanship. From dawn to dusk, he sat upon a flat boulder, and once, breaking a withered plum branch and planting it in the earth, it took root at once, its blossoms all drooping downward—hence the old name in Chengdu for such trees: "Water-Reflecting Plum."

At the Kaiyuan Monastery in Kuizhou’s western city, the former abode of Chan Master Liaoxiu of the Tang, the Patriarch arrived in the early Ming. Befriending the monk Guanghai, he stayed at the monastery for seven days. Upon parting, he presented a poem and left behind a pair of straw sandals and three pieces of aloeswood. Later, Guanghai offered the poem and these two items to Emperor Wen, who in return bestowed a jade ring and a *kāṣāya* embroidered with a thousand Buddhas. These remain enshrined in the monastery as treasures of the age.

Recorded in the *Gazetteer of Chengdu Prefecture* and the *Gazetteer of Kuizhou Prefecture*.

Three Times Declining the Imperial Summons.

In the seventeenth year of the Hongwu reign (1414), the Jiazi cyclical year, the Emperor, with all under heaven—both Chinese and foreign—having submitted, issued an edict to seek the Perfected One Zhang Sanfeng, yet none knew his whereabouts. The following spring, the court again pressed his disciple Shen Wansan to urge him, but he remained unattainable. The Emperor then summoned Qiu Yuanzhen to court. The Patriarch thereupon presented a poem and instructed Qiu, saying: *"Tell the Radiant Son of Heaven that I shall soon roam beyond the seas."* The poem read:

*"Flowing waters and drifting clouds heed no restraint,
Why must the court so earnestly pursue?
Henceforth I shall conceal my name and surname,
Roaming freely north and south of the mountains."*

The Emperor read it and released him. Soon after, he offered Qiu the post of Surveillance Commissioner and bestowed fine residences, all of which Qiu declined. Truly, he did not forget his master’s teachings. The *Mirror of Immortals* records the three imperial summons but omits the poem. Yuantongzi remarked: *"Was Yan Ziling not my master’s former incarnation?"*

**The Yunnan Rendezvous**
During the Hongwu reign, the city walls from Hongwu Gate to Shuixi Gate in the capital collapsed. Beneath them lurked a water spirit in its lair; every attempt to rebuild them crumbled anew. The Emperor, long resentful of Shen Wansan—whose age matched his own and whose wealth was vast—summoned him and said: *"Your household possesses a basin that gathers treasures. Can it also gather earth to rebuild this gate?"* Wansan dared not refuse. He accepted the command and began construction, but the foundations collapsed thrice. Only after secretly casting several pieces of cinnabar-gold into the earth did the walls stand firm, at a cost of untold thousands.

Once, the Emperor wished to reward the troops and summoned Wansan to lend him funds. *"My army numbers a million,"* he said. *"If each soldier receives but one tael, that will suffice."* Wansan delivered the sum in full. The Emperor, observing no sign of hardship in him, resolved to eliminate him, charging him on other grounds and sentencing him to exile in Lingnan. Wansan then abandoned his wealth, taking only his wife and servants, and fled, leaving his family’s fortune behind.

Before long, the decree came to banish him further to Yunnan. Upon arriving in Dian, Wansan, despondent, suddenly heard of an elder with the surname Gongchang who claimed: *"I have come to keep our appointment."* Wansan requested an audience and found it was none other than Patriarch Sanfeng. The Patriarch laughed: *"Do you still recall my words about the flourishing qi in the southeast and our meeting in the southwest?"* Wansan was enlightened. Thereupon, he practiced the *Tianyuan* alchemical arts and ingested the Great Elixir. By the following year, he had succeeded. Wansan and his entire household consumed it and all ascended as immortals.

Yuantongzi remarked: *"To cast aside wealth is to become a transcendent—his beneficence was already great."*

**Roaming Crane Cry Mountain**

In the final years of the Hongwu reign, a Daoist wandered to Crane Cry Mountain in Qiong. The mountain had twenty-four caves, corresponding to the twenty-four qi. When the Daoist entered the mountain, stone cranes cried out again, and all who witnessed it were astonished. After residing there for half a year, he entered Heavenly Valley Cave and did not emerge. On the cave door were inscribed four characters: *"Sanfeng roamed here."* At that time, he was already over a hundred years old. The *Comprehensive Gazetteer of Shu* records it as over three hundred years, which seems erroneous.

Yuántōngzǐ remarked: *"How extraordinary!"*

**A Poem to Warn of Disaster**
At the beginning of Emperor Jianwen’s reign, as dusk fell at the Ministry of Revenue’s gate, an old man strolled leisurely, resembling a local earth deity. When the wind passed, he suddenly vanished. The next morning, upon inspecting the double doors, a poem was found inscribed on the right panel:

*"Swallows build their nests in the pavilion,
The dragon’s heir is not in the deep.
Waves calm, yet winds rise again,
On the sea, inquire of the Three Threes."*

The last three characters were written at the meeting point of the double doors, leaving many perplexed. Zhuo, the Vice Minister of Revenue, saw it and realized that the three characters written across the door formed the central stroke of the character *fēng* (丰), signifying that it was the immortal Sanfeng. He also understood that *"swallows"* referred to the Prince of Yan, and *"dragon’s heir"* to Jianwen. The words were ominous, and the characters soon fell away. Zhuo secretly memorialized the throne, proposing to relocate and confine the Prince of Yan to Nanchang, so that if any upheaval occurred, it could still be controlled. However, his memorial was disregarded.

Yuántōngzǐ remarked: *"Vice Minister Zhuo was keen and admirable, yet loyal words grated on the ear, leading to the Prince of Yan’s usurpation. Was my master also compelled to inscribe this poem, or did he not already know that Jianwen would not heed the warning?"*

In the early years of the Yongle reign, a wandering scholar roamed the capital. His bearing was refined and lofty, his beard long and flowing, yet his attire and demeanor resembled that of a common traveler. He stayed in the capital for quite some time and formed a close bond with Hu Ying, a Supervising Secretary in the Office of Scrutiny for the Household. They often gathered for poetry and wine. The scholar enjoyed composing imitations of *Wen Xuan* but rarely kept drafts. When he heard that officials in the court, after finishing their duties, idly discussed matters of immortals and transcendents—and that the Reader-in-Waiting Hu Guang intended to recommend Zhang Sanfeng’s arts of immortality to the throne—he grew disdainful. One day, while drinking in Hu Ying’s study, he suddenly said, *"My friend serves a wise ruler well, but I shall withdraw deep into the mountains."* Startled, Hu Ying pressed him for the reason, but the scholar remained silent. After repeated questioning, he finally lifted his beard and laughed, *"I am Sanfeng."* With that, he departed abruptly, vanishing without a trace. Later, Hu Ying sought the Master Sanfeng and composed the lines: *"I recall my old friend who vanished thus—who now writes poems like Bao Canjun?"*

**A Single Encounter**
In the winter of the fourth year of Yongle, Zhang Chaoyong, a Registrar in the Court of the Imperial Stud from Nanyang, once saw a Daoist whose movements were extraordinary—his feet never touched the ground, his fingers twirled plum blossoms, and his lips murmured verses of *Autumn Waters*. Stepping forward to inquire, he discovered it was the immortal Sanfeng. The following year, the emperor ordered Hu Ying to search for him, and Hu recommended Zhang Chaoyong to accompany him, but Sanfeng had already vanished.

**Revealing the Way to Mingyu**
During the Yongle era, a Daoist traveler stayed in Neijiang at the home of the Daoist Mingyu. He claimed the surname Pang and subtly displayed his marvels—walking perilous heights without falling, wading through water without getting wet. Mingyu, skilled in talismans and incantations with many proven wonders, wished to transmit his arts to the traveler. The traveler smiled and said, *"I offer you the Way as tribute; how can you teach me your methods?"* He then presented Mingyu with a scroll titled *Memorial on the Convergence of Dao and Method*. Mingyu was astonished, knelt, and begged for his name, only then learning he was the Venerable Sanfeng. After residing there for over a year, Hu Ying tracked him down, but he would not stay. (The *Sichuan Gazetteer* records that he appeared before Hu with Mingyu, which contradicts the *Ming Records*; here, the latter is followed as correct.) Later, he wandered in and out of Mount Emei.

**Ascending in Broad Daylight at the Ming Palace**

Emperor Chengzu of the Ming, after encountering the Western monk Halima, began to nurture an inclination toward the Dao. Minister Hu Guang spoke of Zhang Sanfeng as one truly possessed of the Dao and its methods, presenting his *Essentials of Swift Attainment* for the Emperor’s perusal. Though the depths of Sanfeng’s mastery remained unfathomable, the Emperor sensed its resonance with profound mystery and dispatched envoys to seek him out.

In the spring of the *renchen* year, he further commanded Sun Biyun to journey to Mount Wudang to pay respects. On the sixth day of the third month, a letter was bestowed upon him. Three years later, Sun Biyun finally arrived at Wudang and presented the imperial missive. The Venerable Master read it, smiled, and replied with a single scroll. Biyun urged him to attend court, but Sanfeng would not remain indoors; when he ventured out, Biyun accompanied him, sending word to the Emperor.

In the spring of the *bingshen* year, the Emperor ordered a carriage to welcome him, yet Sanfeng had already departed elsewhere. The Emperor then reprimanded Hu Guang for his search, and Guang, greatly alarmed, hastened to Wudang to plead earnestly. Moved by his sincerity, the Venerable Master agreed to appear at court. He first vanished in a flight of his own, while the Emperor, seated in audience, suddenly beheld a tattered Daoist in a deerskin cloak standing before the steps, bowing with a cold smile. When asked if he was Sanfeng, the Emperor warmly invited him to sit and sought discourse on the Dao. The Venerable Master then chanted the tune *"Seeking the Dao and the Mysterious, I’ve Traversed the Ends of the Earth."* As the melody concluded, he descended the steps with unhurried grace. Suddenly, auspicious clouds and mist filled the palace hall, lingering for a long while before dispersing—Sanfeng was gone. The Emperor and his ministers marveled, now convinced of his true immortality. Upon Hu Guang’s return to court, the Emperor bestowed generous rewards upon him.

According to the *Ming Records*, in the *dinghai* year, the Emperor commanded Hu Ying and others to search for Sanfeng far and wide, returning only after a decade. Counting sequentially from *dinghai* to *bingshen* spans precisely ten years, during which, in the fifth month, the audience with the Emperor occurred. It remains unclear whether Ying and his party returned before or after the fifth month; if after, their paths would have crossed in vain.

The *Mirror of Immortals* comments: Some attain the Dao through marrow-washing and bone-changing without shedding their forms; others nurture an infant spirit to manifest their divine essence; still others refine their bodies in the Great Yin to achieve liberation through apparent death. All these serve as proofs of the Way. Yet the perfection of the unhewn jade in nurturing the fetal spirit, or Sanfeng’s ascension from the golden hall, could not have been achieved without rebalancing the Nine Cauldrons and reestablishing the cosmos. Thus viewed, the alchemical Dao is no trifling matter.

**Manifestations of Mysterious Radiance**
On the first day of the fifth month in the *bingshen* year of the Yongle reign, a grand assembly was held in honor of the Southern Pole Elder’s longevity. The Lord Lao commanded Yin Zhenren of the Grand Tenuity to transmit his decree to the assembled immortals. As Yin gazed northwest, he beheld a cluster of mysterious radiance descending from the sky. Drawing near, he saw it was Master Sanfeng. Yin conveyed the Lord Lao’s command, to which Sanfeng replied, *"I have already received the Jade Emperor’s summons."* With that, he departed. The Seven-Needle Master.

During the Tianshun era, there was a figure known as the Seven-Needle Master. He often carried seven medicinal needles to treat people’s sores and ailments, achieving many remarkable cures, and so people called him by this name. The Master also adopted it as his own. Skilled in painting landscapes, he soon gained the esteem of officials and nobles. Earlier, Zhang Sanfeng had been renowned for his immortal paintings, which the court repeatedly sought but failed to obtain. A court minister then brought the Seven-Needle Master to the emperor’s attention, and upon imperial summons, he presented a landscape painting that greatly pleased His Majesty. However, the Master was fond of wine and prone to cursing the powerful and favored. A corrupt official, coveting his skill, invited him to his home with lavish hospitality, hoping to secure paintings for personal gain.

One day, the emperor again bestowed fine silk for him to paint. By then, the Seven-Needle Master was drunk, lodging in a small attic. The corrupt official handed him the silk, which the Master left by his bedside. That night, the sound of violent retching filled the room. Anxious, the official lit a candle and saw the Master leap up, exclaiming, *"How exhilarating! How exhilarating!"* Looking around, he found sparrows hopping about, nearly ready to take flight—only their eyes remained unpainted. The official had no choice but to present the work to the emperor, who marveled at it and ordered the eyes be finished. The Master replied, *"If I paint the eyes, they will fly away."* The emperor did not believe him and pressed him. The Seven-Needle Master then took up his brush and hastily dashed in the eyes. The emperor, amused, remarked, *"Do these creatures truly wish to fly?"* As he spoke, countless sparrows soared into the clouds and vanished. They descended upon the corrupt official’s homeland, pecking every grain from his fields until not a single stalk remained—yet the neighboring lands were untouched.

The Seven-Needle Master also vanished. When the emperor learned of the affair, he issued another summons, but the Master could not be found. The emperor then consulted Minister of Rites Hu Ying, who replied, *"Could the Seven-Needle Master be Sanfeng in disguise? If you examine the characters for ‘Sanfeng’ (三丰) horizontally and vertically, they resemble seven needles (七针)."* The emperor was astonished. He posthumously honored him as the *"Master of Glutinous Rice Dumplings."*

During the Tianshun era, in Jianzhou, there lived an elderly man whose surname was forgotten. He made his living by selling glutinous rice dumplings daily. Whenever he saw a poor person pass by, he would give them a packet without asking for payment. If someone inquired about his reason, the old man would say, *"These are all weary travelers, their bellies empty. I sell dumplings each day only to secure my capital and earn a modest profit—this is enough. To share the rest with others is but a small kindness; why speak of it?"*

One day, as dusk approached, he had not sold all his dumplings. Suddenly, a Daoist passed by and begged for a packet. The old man gave him one, and after eating it, the Daoist asked for another. This happened dozens of times, and each time, the old man obliged. The Daoist laughed heartily and said, *"You are truly generous. I have no other skill, but in my pouch is a single purple pearl. Take it home and place it in your rice jar. When you open it the next evening, you will find something wondrous."* With that, the Daoist vanished like the wind.

The old man took the pearl home and did as instructed. At the time, his rice jar was nearly empty. The next morning, he opened it to find the jar full of rice. He smiled and said, *"So this is the ‘wondrous’ thing the Daoist spoke of."* He then used the rice to make dumplings, selling three parts and giving away seven. The next day, the jar was full again. He continued his work as usual, and those who benefited from his kindness all praised him with admiration.

Over time, the old man grew curious. He overturned the jar to inspect it, and the purple pearl was gone. From then on, the jar no longer produced rice. Some days later, the Daoist returned and said to him, *"I am so-and-so. You have shown great kindness. Would you like to transcend the world?"* The old man refused. The Patriarch then took out a pill and instructed, *"Eat this, and your lifespan will be extended."* The old man swallowed it and felt his chest and abdomen clear. After the Patriarch left, the old man lived to over a hundred years before passing away in perfect repose.

Master Yuantong remarked, *"It is a pity this old man did not seek the Daoist Way, yet his heart brimmed with compassion—surely he was destined for a long life."*

During the Chenghua era, occult masters flourished for a time, granted imperial patents and styled as "Perfected Ones" until nearly the entire capital was filled with them. Among them was the Western barbarian monk Zaba, who firmly propagated esoteric teachings and was favored with the title "Buddha of Great Wisdom." He rode in a lofty palanquin, and even high officials would clear the streets before his processional escort. One day, as Zaba returned to his bestowed residence, he suddenly saw a ragged Daoist inscribe a poem upon the mirrored wall:

*"Occult masters swarm the court in throngs,
A barbarian monk now overshadows the mighty.
Such slaves dare claim the names of Dao and Buddha—
The Venerable Lord smiles, the World-Honored One admonishes."*

The signature read: *"Broken Kun hexagram, supplemented."* Zaba, enraged upon seeing this, ordered his soldiers to seize the Daoist, but as dust and wind arose, the Daoist vanished. Some said, *"The broken Kun hexagram with supplementation forms the character 'feng'—thus all knew it was the true immortal Sanfeng."* Thereafter, Zaba’s influence gradually waned.

Master Yuantong remarked, *"Zaba lost face."*

In the Chenghua era, Daoist priests swarmed and bustled, entering and exiting the imperial court. The Patriarch deeply detested them. One day, encountering two alchemists surnamed Zhao and Wang, he knew their hearts harbored deceit and that they would soon journey north, wielding strange arts. Thus, he transformed into the guise of a religious master and deceived them, saying, *"I am Celestial Master Zhang. My flying talismans summon spirits—my methods are most efficacious. Would you two wish to learn?"* Zhao and Wang did not believe him. The Patriarch then traced symbols in the air, and suddenly, heavenly soldiers and generals appeared amidst the swirling clouds. The two men, astonished, knelt to beg for talismans. The Patriarch feigned secrecy as he instructed them, bestowing several talismans. The two laughed heartily as they departed.

At that time, Li Zixing had gained the emperor’s favor through the Five Thunder Rites. The two alchemists sought him out and thereby advanced their position. When the emperor inquired of their abilities, they replied that the Celestial Master had transmitted the talismans to them and requested the emperor to observe a three-day fast before witnessing their arts. The emperor followed their instructions. On the appointed day, a grand altar was erected, but after a full day of pretense, no magic manifested. Enraged by their deceit, the emperor ordered his guards to execute them on the spot.

Master Yuantong remarked, *"The true immortal’s loathing of alchemists is like a gentleman’s disdain for petty men. My master’s sevenfold mockery of alchemists used the orthodox Dharma to toy with heterodox arts, ensuring that all such sorcery would fail and their favor at court would wane. One such as my master should be enfeoffed as the Heavenly Master Who Sweeps Away Evil and Upholds Righteousness to Protect the State. Later, in the final years of the Chenghua era, the titles of Buddhist monks and Daoist priests were revoked—though this was at the urging of the Censorate, who can say it was not because my master had covertly exposed their arts, leading to their dismissal?"* The following six accounts should be viewed in this light.

**The Second Mockery of Alchemists**
The Patriarch once wagered with an alchemist surnamed Liu to command ghosts and spirits. When the alchemist first burned his talisman, the Patriarch secretly obscured it with his own power. When it came to the Patriarch’s turn, countless spirits and demons—fierce armored steeds and grotesque apparitions—appeared in the sky. The alchemist, astonished, knelt to beg for instruction. The Patriarch generously taught him, even revealing the wondrous method of beheading ghosts. Overjoyed, the alchemist carried his skills to the capital, where they were praised as highly effective—though he never employed the ghost-slaying technique.

Later, through the influence of Liang Fang and others, he gained entry to the inner court. One night, as a eunuch dallied with a palace maid, the emperor ordered Liu to burn a ghost-summoning talisman. Two ghosts arrived—a man and a woman—who flirted beneath the palace tower, gradually drawing near the emperor without reverence. Terrified, the emperor commanded Liu to draw his sword and strike them, only to discover they were the palace maid Yun’e and a certain eunuch. Enraged, the emperor deemed Liu’s actions an insult and had him executed on the spot.

Master Yuantong remarked, *"One talisman slew three evils—not because my master wielded a cruel hand, but because upholding righteousness to protect the state is true compassion."*

The fangshi Guo Chengxian was a rogue and a knave. Initially, he had some success with the Five Thunder Method and was on his way to the capital when Master Sanfeng intercepted him along the road. They met by the wayside, and the master concealed his true identity, calling himself the "Rival Celestial Master." He addressed Guo first: *"Do you carry the Five Thunder Formula on your person?"* Guo, astonished by his prescience, surmised he must be a divine being and dared not conceal the truth, answering repeatedly in the affirmative.

The Rival Celestial Master said, *"I possess an even greater Six Thunder Method to bestow upon you. Follow its practices, and you will be able to summon celestial maidens and ride the phoenix through the mortal realm. Recently, Li Zixing has wielded power both within and beyond the court. Present this method to him, and high office will be yours in an instant."* Guo rejoiced and begged to receive the transmission. After kowtowing in gratitude, he departed and sought out Li Zixing. First, he employed the Five Thunder Method before Zixing to gain his trust as a fellow practitioner.

Guo laughed and said, *"This is but a trifle. I possess the Six Thunder Method as well. The one who transmitted it to me said, ‘This method can summon celestial beauties.’"* Zixing leapt with excitement and urged Guo to demonstrate it. Guo, feigning importance, ordered an elaborate altar prepared—adorned with crimson lanterns and emerald curtains, transforming the setting entirely. Zixing’s concubines, dressed in their finest, leaned against the pavilion railings to witness Guo’s art.

Guo then followed the method, tracing talismans and circling the altar while chanting incantations. Sure enough, four or five celestial maidens descended gracefully, each riding a crimson serpent, and alighted upon the altar. Among them, two women were especially enchanting. Their twin voices wove a melody, clear as orioles, singing:

*"My lord holds the pass,
Discards his robes of office for crimson skirts.
This power, this fortune—how fleeting!
Leaning on the railing at dawn,
Tears stain the clouds’ song."*

The tune was crisp and delicate, at once mocking and admonishing, fearful and mournful. Zixing’s followers, at first captivated by the beauties, grew bewildered upon hearing the lyrics. The deeper they pondered their meaning, the more their dread mounted.

Suddenly, thunder and rain erupted in the sky, and windblown sand swirled violently. All the lanterns on the altar were extinguished, plunging the scene into chaos—fox dens and rat burrows seemed to collapse in a deluge of smoke and water. In an instant, the clouds dispersed, and a slender moon hung from the eaves. A groan arose from the depths of the darkened altar. When torches were relit, they revealed several of Zixing’s concubines, each straddling a dazed man, their naked bodies bent as if in a stupor. Upon closer inspection, these men were none other than the fangshi and disciples Zixing kept in his household.

Servants were forced to drag them away. When they searched for Guo Chengxian, he was still standing before the altar, muttering incoherent incantations, shaking his head, and counting on his fingers as if immensely pleased with himself. Overcome with shame and fury, Zixing drew his sword and struck him down, casting his corpse into the pond behind the garden. He forbade his household from speaking of the matter, yet that very night, the scandal spread far and wide. Zixing grew ever more uneasy, his terror deepening.

Master Yuantong remarked, *"The Six Thunder Method proves wondrous indeed—though I know not from whence my master obtained it. In the heyday of Han and Tang fangshi, such a text would have been invaluable."*

The Four Charlatans Fangshi

Peng Hua, having risen to the position of Vice Minister of Personnel, subsequently allied himself with Wan’an’s Zixing and thus gained entry into the Grand Secretariat, where he took part in the deliberations of state affairs. His power and influence grew daily, and he wielded authority as he pleased, banishing loyal officials and filling his household with fangshi.

One day, afflicted by a fever that proved resistant to cooling medicines, he ordered the fangshi Xiong Zhong to seek out a skilled physician. Xiong heard that beyond the capital gates there lived a certain individual well-versed in the arts of Qi Bo and the Yellow Emperor, so he set out to summon him. Along the way, he encountered a Daoist priest carrying a medicine satchel on his back and a painting board in hand, upon which were inscribed four lines:

*A single sheet of plaster,
mends wounds and sores.
Three doses of the Great Elixir,
ensnare the arts of fangshi.*

What was called "one sheet and three doses" was in fact a veiled reference to the priest’s own name. Taking it as a display of his medical prowess, Xiong paid it no further heed. The priest offered fever-relieving pills for sale, but when Xiong sought to purchase them, the priest deliberately inflated his price, claiming that his pills not only cured illness but also lightened the body. When Xiong expressed doubt, the priest swallowed one himself and hovered several feet above the ground without support. Xiong immediately prostrated himself, begging to buy a pill. The priest then cautioned, *"If consumed by a man of great nobility, this pill will enable him to ascend to the heavens in broad daylight. After his departure, securing a high position will be effortless."* Xiong, harboring no aspirations for immortality, merely wished to join the ranks of men like Peng Hua, holding power in key offices. He returned with the pill and recounted its marvels. Peng Hua, in his feverish delirium, swallowed it whole. His head soon throbbed as if poisoned, and he retched violently before succumbing to a wind-induced ailment. Xiong, seizing the opportunity, fled, and Peng Hua was later dismissed from office due to his illness.

Master Yuantong remarked, *"Fever rooted in the heart is difficult to cure with cooling remedies. Only by inducing vomiting to expel the fire and then afflicting him with wind could the heat in his heart be dispelled. As for the fangshi—his own heart burned far hotter than Peng Hua’s. Disdaining immortality, he craved only wealth and rank. Why wait for his master to ascend before fleeing?"*

The Five Charlatans Fangshi

In the western mountains of Taihang, there lived an immortal named Master Ma, famed for his divine arrows that could slay ghosts—many sought his aid, and none failed to see results. Daoist Deng Chang’en, who had long heard of his prowess, became a Minister of Rites and, being treacherous and ruthless, secretly murdered a man. Thereafter, the victim’s spirit haunted his residence as a malevolent force.

Deng dispatched his disciple Chen Wai’er to seek Master Ma’s art. On the road, Chen encountered a Daoist of towering bearing, bow drawn taut in hand, seven swords and three talismans at his waist. The stranger claimed to strike ghosts with unerring accuracy but refused to give his name. Suspicious, Chen traveled with him until dusk, when they took shelter in a ruined temple. As twilight deepened beneath the blackened boughs of ancient trees, ghostly wails arose. Terrified, Chen watched as the Daoist drew his bow through a crack in the window and loosed an arrow—the specter shrieked and fled. Chen, now filled with awe, begged to learn the skill the next morning. The Daoist readily imparted it.

Returning to the capital, Chen fabricated a tale: *"Master Ma has departed, but by good fortune, I obtained this divine archery—all thanks to Your Excellency’s blessings."* Delighted, Deng awaited nightfall. When the air grew thick with incense and the moon hung veiled, ghostly cries arose in the garden. He ordered Chen to demonstrate his newfound skill. Deng slipped behind the winding corridors to observe from a facing pavilion. Suddenly, a ghost flew into the building. Chen drew his mighty bow, loosed a flawless arrow—its fletching hissed through the air—and with a great cry, the target fell. Holding a candle, they saw it was Deng himself, struck in the left arm. Though spared his life, Chen fled at once.

Master Yuantong remarked, *"The crime of murder is grave enough, yet to seek the destruction of a man’s very soul—what cruelty could surpass this? Even had Chen truly learned Master Ma’s divine archery on Mount Taihang, who could say it would not turn against Deng Chang’en?"*

The Six Arts Charlatans

The grand secretary Wan An was inwardly cunning yet outwardly affable. At that time, Consort Wan’s favor was unrivaled, and the palace women addressed her kin as nephews and nieces. Her influence within and without grew ever more entrenched, so Wan An sought out alchemists and bedroom arts practitioners to present to her. The consort was overjoyed—yet before long, she died. Such was the consequence of Wan An’s pursuit of these arts.

The alchemist Lu Fengyuan, boasting of his mastery of the "art of plucking and battling," imparted his techniques to Wan An. Later, styling himself a Dharma Master, he ordered Wan An to receive the Dao on West Mountain. Lu arrived first and waited for him on the road for days, growing restless. Wandering the outskirts in boredom, he suddenly encountered a Daoist elder—pine-browed, crane-haired, with teeth tall and face ruddy, like the immortals Red Pine or Yellow Stone. When asked his surname, he did not answer; when questioned on the Dao, he remained silent.

The elder laughed and chanted:
*"Lu meets grievance, Lu meets grievance—
What fate brings you to Wan An today?"*
Then he vanished like drifting mist. Lu was stunned and hesitated to turn back.

By then, the sun had sunk behind the mountains, the forest darkened, and crows cawed in the gloom. Disoriented, he lost his way. Then he saw a woodcutter, a bundle of firewood on his back, who gave his surname as Zhang but would not disclose his given name. Lu begged for directions, and the old man pointed to a flickering lamp in the distance—there lay an inn. Bowing in thanks, Lu took his leave and sought lodging there.

Amid the creaking rafters, he heard sighs from the next room that night. Peering through a crack, he saw Wan An. His heart stirred with pity, and he longed to approach. He pried loose a rotting plank in the wall and slipped through, hoping to share a moment of intimacy.

Wan An, exhausted, had fallen asleep with his head propped on his hand. Hearing the wall creak, he suspected a bandit and seized a stool to strike—his assailant collapsed. His attendants rushed in with lanterns and found the man who had called himself Dharma Master Lu Fengyuan. When Wan An pressed him for an explanation, he learned it was merely a visit of concern. Lu prostrated himself in apology, and though in pain, Wan An returned the courtesy.

Lu asked, *"Why has Your Excellency not taken the main road, but come here instead?"*
Wan An replied, *"I followed my master’s command to journey to West Mountain. Last night, an immortal elder appeared in my dream and said:
*'Wan An, Wan An, seeking the Dao on West Mountain—
The great road there holds no fate for you.'*
So I took a side path by carriage, never expecting to meet you here—only to play this cruel jest."*

Master Yuantong remarked, *"To mistake a charlatan for a Dharma Master is foolishness indeed. A false master deserves a stool’s blow. Later, when Wan An still presented bedroom arts to the palace, Emperor Xianzong uncovered the scheme and dismissed him—leaving his disciple to miss his chance as well."*

At the close of the Chenghua era, the banished fangshi—Liang Fang, Li Zixing, Deng Changen, and Zhao Yuzhi—were successively pardoned. Yet the eunuch Jiang Cong insisted their crimes were beyond absolution, so while Liang and Li were left to die in disgrace, Deng and Zhao remained exiled to the frontier. During their initial banishment, travelers’ walls along the road bore verses in every place:

*"Li Zixing, Liang Fang—
their sins blazed bright.
Pardoned? No pardon is right.
Let them die in prison’s night.

Deng Changen, Zhao Yuzhi—
exiled to the western wilds.
Pardoned? No pardon smiles.
Forever parted from the Central Lands."*

The signature read: "Sealed by three sheets."

Master Yuantong remarked: *"These petty men, once disgraced, were already drained of life’s qi. Yet the hearts of small men are foolish—they still gazed back at the Three Terraces, hoping for restoration to power, much like Wan An when he was stripped of office. Thus my master inscribed these verses in jest, to settle the fate of their faction once and for all."*

**Poems on a Daoist Abbey’s Walls**
In the late Jiajing reign, an edict sought esoteric texts from across the realm. At Chongqing Abbey in the Nanjing Daoist precincts, four quatrains appeared on the walls, signed by the Reclusive Immortal Zhang Xuanxuan. A divine lamp would illuminate them by night, until one day, thunder and lightning snatched the characters away. The poems survive in the *Cloud and Water Collection*.

**Riot at Wei’s Shrine**
During the Tianqi era, shrines to Wei Zhongxian stood nearly everywhere under heaven, but none rivaled the splendor of the one outside Donghua Gate. One day, three ragged, mad Daoists strode in, stormed the shrine, and smashed Wei’s clay effigy, smearing its face with filth and mud. On the wall, they scrawled four lines:

*"A lewd shrine, decaying slow—
the royal house in ruins lies.
The brocade rivers and mountains
are left to ghosts to bestow."*

The character for "ghost" (*gui*) shared a radical with Wei’s name. The shrine’s guards, aghast, lunged to seize them—only for the three madmen to vanish. Fearing Wei’s wrath, the guards scrubbed the walls at once, yet the verses lingered with a faint fragrance, while the clay effigy reeked. That night, Wei’s entire body ached with pain.

Master Yuantong exclaimed: *"A joyous deed! A joyous deed! It should be added to the *History of Ming* to stir readers to roll up their sleeves and dance!"*

**Encounter with the Patriarch Lü**

In the early years of Shunzhi, as Qin and Shu remained unsettled, a Daoist roamed the land clad in furs, his comings and goings as elusive as mist. He would sigh as he walked, then suddenly laugh, then break into song:

*"Heaven and Earth—clear or not?
Leopards and tigers still prowl.
With a flick of my sleeve, I return to the Three Isles,
To gaze at Penglai’s limpid waters."*

Another Daoist approached, sword at his waist and whisk in hand, joining his voice to the song:

*"Before dawn’s fifth watch, the sky brightens,
Beyond the pass, clouds drift.
With you, I depart—
Heaven gains clarity through the One."*

Suddenly appearing, the sword-bearing Daoist addressed the fur-clad one: *"Master Sanfeng, now you may rest."* The other bowed in response, his words laced with Zen sharpness, beyond all unraveling. Then, in a burst of radiant light, crimson clouds swirled in the sky, weaving into the character *Lü*. The two Daoists ascended into the void and vanished. This account is recorded in *Ōu Yangzhen’s Miscellaneous Records of Chaos*. *"The withered plum blooms anew."*

During the Kangxi reign, along the road to Linyou at Ma Family Inn, stood a withered plum tree, its trunk gnarled and ancient, its planting year unknown. On a bitter winter’s day of snow and cold, a Daoist named Zhang, clad in tattered robes, arrived at dawn. He called for the innkeeper to prepare noodles, but before the dough had thickened, it was served to him. The Daoist said, *"I do not eat raw dough—give it to the withered plum instead, that it may rejoice."* He tossed the noodles onto the tree’s branches and, laying down his coins, departed. The innkeeper found this strange. The next morning, he looked and saw the withered plum had burst into bloom, its branches forming the character *feng* in abundance. The inn prospered greatly thereafter, and though the innkeeper often watered the tree with noodle broth, it withered once more.

Yuantongzi remarked: *"Lüzu revived the camphor, Qiuzu revived the cypress, and Zhangzu revived the plum—all may be said to have extended their virtue to the grasses and trees."*

---

*Green Clouds Ward Off Heat*

The Patriarch traveled through the Shu Mountains, where yellow brambles grew in abundance. At the height of summer’s heat, the village elders toiled in the fields, overcome by the scorching sun. The Master wove a circle from yellow bramble branches and placed it upon his head. Suddenly, green clouds like a parasol floated above him, drifting wherever he went. Many who witnessed this imitated him, finding great coolness and no heat-induced illness. The village elders composed a verse: *"Though yellow brambles crown the head, green clouds soon shade the brow; though the fields lie open to the sky, the blazing sun need not burn now."*

To this day, it remains a tale of the fields and gardens.

Yuantongzi said: *"Whether fashioned into a hat or brewed as tea, this plant is most excellent."*

---

*West Stream’s Feigned Slumber*

In Tongzhou there lived an old farmer, a man of considerable wealth who in life had been much inclined toward goodness. When he passed away, a Daoist came to offer condolences, introducing himself as the "Tianwai Sanren" (the "Untrammeled Man Beyond the Heavens"), a name he had taken from the Tang poem line *"beyond the heavens, three peaks."* He instructed the farmer’s son to bury his father in the Qinling Mountains, at a site where two earthen mounds like breasts stood with a pair of stones cradling between them. He further advised: *"When I select a burial ground for others, I require only that it be free of wind, water, mud, sand, and ants—nothing more. Never heed blind masters who urge you to relocate or alter the site."*

For ten years after the burial, all remained peaceful. Then, swayed by a certain geomancer’s persuasive talk of sealing and consecrating the grave, the son’s heart wavered, and he resolved to rebury his father. Hearing that the Daoist still resided at the West Stream Pavilion’s fields, he went to seek his approval. Upon arriving at the pavilion, he found the Daoist sound asleep upon a rock. The son pushed him repeatedly, but the Daoist, half-awake, murmured: *"Your father lies at rest—why disturb him?"* The son, failing to grasp the meaning, pushed harder, yet the Daoist only snored louder, refusing to answer.

The son returned home and, following the geomancer’s advice, had the grave opened. There, the old farmer’s bones gleamed like gold, and remorse struck him deeply. Though the geomancer insisted on his own reasoning, the remains were moved to another location. Within a decade, the family’s fortunes withered. When the son sought the Daoist again, he was told the man had departed the previous year for parts unknown. Later, he encountered the same geomancer—now blind and begging in the marketplace.

Yuantongzi said: *"The son of the old farmer was truly most unfilial."*

**Golden Foil and Radiant Dots**

In the early Hongwu reign, the Immortal Zhang Jinbo of Pingyang—so named for his family’s craft of gold-leaf paper—concealed profound Daoist arts while wandering among men. He often used gold foil as medicine to treat illnesses, and none failed to show miraculous results.

Then there appeared another man, Zhang Jindian, who wore a pale blue robe entirely adorned with golden dots, hence his name. Those who saw him were dazzled. Jindian declared: *"Let one who suffers illness take but a single dot of mine, and their malady will surely be cured."* When people sought to test him, the effects were as divine as promised, and he asked for no payment. At the time, epidemics raged through the southern provinces, and Jindian was mobbed daily by crowds clamoring for his dots, until his robe was stripped bare. Yet the next day, when he appeared in the marketplace, the dots were restored as before, and all bowed to him as a divine master. A month later, as the epidemics waned, Jindian said: *"My work here is done; I shall return to the cloud-wrapped mountains."* With that, he cast his golden-dotted robe to the ground. As people scrambled to seize it, Zhang transformed into a beam of golden light and soared into the sky.

Later, Liu Bowen heard of this and remarked: *"This must have been Zhang Sanfeng, who disguised himself as Jindian to complement Zhang Jinbo’s radiance."*

---

**Prescriptions from a Dream**

During the Ming dynasty, there lived a man named Zhu, a native of Yanzhou. Kind and filial, he suddenly developed an eye ailment that left him unable to see even those before him. Day and night, he prayed to Heaven, until one night he dreamed of a golden-hued divine figure with a beard like a halberd, his Daoist bearing ethereal. The figure beckoned Zhu forward and said: *"Your heart is sincere and reverent. I shall bestow upon you a wondrous prescription—one application, and your sight will be restored. Take one *liang* of fine saltpeter, melt it in a copper vessel, then add two *fen* of refined lead oxide and two *fen* of borneol. Stir swiftly with a copper spoon and store in a jar. Apply a small amount each time—the efficacy is beyond description."*

When Zhu awoke, he marveled at the dream and prepared the remedy as instructed. By the next day, his vision was restored. Overwhelmed with gratitude, he burned incense toward the heavens and prostrated himself in reverence. Later, while passing through Yuncheng, he stopped at Zhangxian Temple. Upon entering, he suddenly recognized the deity’s likeness as identical to the figure from his dream. Startled, he vowed to disseminate the prescription for the benefit of all. To this day, the formula remains recorded in the *Compendium of Materia Medica*.

**The Transcendence of Wang Mengjiu**

Wang Xiling, styled Mengjiu, was a native of She County in Huizhou. A Ming Jiajing-era *jinshi*, he was a descendant of the loyal and martyred Vice Censor-in-Chief. Though his family had long been prosperous, he upheld propriety and righteousness. After serving as an official in Jiangdu, Yangzhou, he settled there as a sojourner.

From birth, Wang possessed an extraordinary nature. As a child, he displayed precocious wisdom; in adulthood, he demonstrated administrative talent. He married a woman of the Liu clan, whose temperament was exceedingly serene. Once, she dreamed of the female immortal He Yiyang, who had a fondness for profound learning. For over twenty years, she and Wang recited verses together, until one day she passed away in meditation.

**The Transcendence of Wang Mengjiu (continued)**

Wang never remarried. Throughout his life, he rose from the position of *Biejia* official to become the Surveillance Commissioner of Jiannan in Sichuan, where he trained troops and cherished the people, earning their deep respect. After two years in office, Jiannan suffered from incessant rain. Wang cut his fingernails, walked barefoot to Meishan, and burned incense in prayer for seven days until the skies cleared—a response, it was said, to his benevolence. On his return journey via Shaluo Plain, he suddenly encountered the perfected master Zhang Sanfeng, who was traveling to Mount Emei. Though they had never met, their bond was as if of old. The master perceived his nature and said: *"Now the sagely Son of Heaven reigns above, aided by worthy ministers and noble officials. Do not forget the time we once shared in Penglai."* Wang then awakened fully: he had originally been a spiritual emanation of Shen Wansan, sent into the world, and now recognized Sanfeng as his true teacher. He sought further guidance, and the master imparted to him the essentials of the Golden Elixir.

In his leisure, Wang would sit in meditation between the towering peaks of Gaobiao and Lingyun. There, he built a hermitage and alchemical chamber, and on Jiuri Peak, he prepared his own coffin, naming it the *Hidden Release Abode*. By night, he communed with his immortal teacher. Under his governance, the land flourished, and the yamen gates grew over with grass—so little was there for him to attend to. Yet he could not yet depart, for his aged parents still lived. Later, when promoted to Yongbei in Yunnan, he requested leave to care for them, fearing entanglement in the mundane world. The appointment, however, fell on a *ding* year, which violated the established regulations, and his request was denied.

He was then appointed Vice Commissioner of River Conservancy for Henan Province. On his way to assume office, he passed through Yangzhou and crossed the Yangtze, where he again met Master Sanfeng, who transmitted to him a secret formula. Shortly after, he fell gravely ill and returned home. By then, his first wife, Madame Liu, had passed away years earlier. He instructed his son, Simin, to escort her coffin to Sichuan and inter it on Jiuri Peak. His own illness worsened, and for over a month, he abstained from grain, yet his complexion grew ever more radiant. One day, he said to his younger brother: *"Serve our father well. I am about to depart."* He bathed, dressed in formal attire, and as faint clouds descended from the sky, a single breath rose from his crown and he passed away.

This occurred on the seventh day of the second month in the *jiachen* year of the Yongzheng reign, at the *chou* hour. When his body was placed in the coffin, it was as light as a cicada’s molted husk—proof that he had attained the Dao and become a perfected being. His son, following his father’s last wishes, accompanied both coffins to Sichuan and buried them together on Jiuri Peak. Later, a woodcutter from Banan saw Wang on Mount Emei, accompanied by a towering Daoist master, traversing sheer cliffs in flight. His appearance remained as it had been in life, his beard and whiskers flowing in the wind.

**Postscript:**
This account is titled *The Transcendence of Wang Mengjiu*, yet it reads like a brief biography of Master Mengjiu. The reason is this: as Surveillance Commissioner of Jiannan, his virtuous governance and benevolent policies are still praised today. Moreover, his roots in the Dao and his vessel for immortality, combined with his fulfillment of both loyalty and filial piety, moved his ancestral master to descend and guide him. Here, I have gathered scattered records, selected forgotten anecdotes, and consulted inscriptions from his burial site to illuminate his life. In doing so, I also honor the diligence of his master in guiding the world, while chronicling Mengjiu’s own journey.

**Appendix: Master Mengjiu’s Self-Composed Record of the Hidden Release Abode**
The Daoist’s name is Xiling, styled Mengjiu, with the sobriquet Yuantong. A native of Shuijie Mountain in She County, Huizhou Prefecture, he sojourned in Jiangdu County, Yangzhou Prefecture. He served as *Biejia*, prefect, and in the Ministries of Revenue and Works, and as Surveillance Commissioner of Jiannan in Sichuan. He received the secret methods of self-cultivation from the school of Master Zhang Sanfeng.

Having admired the clear seclusion of Lingyun’s mountains and waters, he personally arranged his burial site, declaring upon its completion: *"Within these peaks lies a cavern shaped like the celestial seat of immortals. Aligned with the mountain’s *hai* direction, it shall serve as the future resting place for my bones."* He left behind a seven-character regulated verse, recorded here:

*"A propitious site to inter immortal bones,
Waters encircle, hills embrace—doubly kind.
Beneath the sun, pure springs bestow their virtue’s grace,
Crimson clouds and quiet chambers guard the sacred mound.
The Daoist long shed worldly burdens,
The filial son need not grieve the wind through trees.
Say not this old man was ever truly dead—
Why not display the tally plain for all to see?"*

On the third day of the fourth lunar month in the *guimao* year of Yongzheng’s reign (1723), Daoist Yuantong prepared his coffin and inscribed this record.

**Obscure Traces of Qin’an**
In Qin’an County, there was a man called Zhang Pengtou, who claimed to be from Zhongzhou yet also called himself *"a man from beyond the heavens."* His hair was coiled in a single topknot, and he wore the same tattered robe winter and summer, wandering the markets in a manner resembling madness. When well-meaning folk offered him food or drink, he would consume it all without regard for quality or quantity.

At first, no one ever saw him drunk or sated. Sometimes he would go without food or drink for days on end, yet showed no sign of hunger or thirst. At night, he would sleep on the open ground of temples or monasteries, often lying motionless for ten days at a time. The crowd, thinking him dead, would prod him with their feet, whereupon he would stretch, yawn, and open his eyes, saying, *"My sleep was not yet complete—why do you disturb me?"*

A local scholar named Cai had a villa west of the city at Stone Buddha Temple, where flowers and trees flourished in bright elegance, and winding railings enclosed the courtyard. He invited Zhang Pengtou to stay, and Pengtou accepted without hesitation. Cai, who delighted in social gatherings, used the villa as a retreat, daily hosting musicians to play bamboo flutes and pluck strings, while Pengtou remained utterly indifferent. Cai remarked, *"When evening falls, he lies stiff as a corpse, motionless through the night without so much as a breath."*

Once, Cai asked about his methods, and Pengtou replied, *"The foundational verses of the sacred texts are the gateways of the Three Teachings—Confucianism, Buddhism, and Daoism. The path begins with stillness, and only after mastering it do the ways diverge. The Confucian school grounds itself in all things, the Buddha empties itself of all things, and the Supreme One transcends all things. You are a man of learning—you should grasp this yourself."*

Cai’s wife was fiercely jealous, berating and cursing her in-laws. Cai feared her like a tiger. Learning that he and his friends were amusing themselves at the villa, she flew into a rage and stormed over to drive them out. Cai, trembling, told Pengtou, *"Do not worry. When she comes, I will handle it."* When she arrived, she found Pengtou sitting in the doorway. Her voice thundered with fury as she railed at him, then lunged forward and struck his cheeks with both hands. Pengtou sat unmoved, serene. She, however, felt her hands swell with unbearable pain, as if they were being crushed. She rushed home, her fingers swollen like hanging mallets, festering with boils. She wailed through the night and died by dawn.

By the forty-ninth year of Qianlong’s reign (1784), in the fourth lunar month, Pengtou suddenly urged Cai to return home. Cai, lost in revelry, resisted at first but eventually relented. On the fifteenth day of the first lunar month, the rebel Ma Xinming, leading his band from Fuqiang, fled back to Stone Peak Fortress, laying waste to everything along the way as they passed Stone Buddha Temple—yet Cai’s villa was spared.

Later, a man called Chen Yexian also came to wander in Qin’an. A native of Pingliang, he dressed in Daoist robes but drank wine, ate meat, and lived like an ordinary man. He built a hut on the sheer cliffs of Dragon Gate Mountain, where even birds could scarcely land, yet he ascended and descended with ease. Though his traces were not far from people, if one sought him at the foot of the peak and called *"Master Chen!"*, he would appear. When asked about fortunes or misfortunes, he would only say, *"Let it be! Let it be!"* He once helped villagers move boulders up a cliff, and another time, he spat water to extinguish a fire. His wondrous deeds were too many to recount.

Hearing of Yexian’s arrival, Cai invited him to his home to meet Pengtou. Yexian seemed deeply abashed in Pengtou’s presence. After three days, he took his leave. Cai asked Pengtou what he thought of Yexian, and Pengtou replied, *"There are two paths to immortality. The superior path begins with stillness—first, one must banish stray thoughts, then master embryonic breathing, and finally, practice the arts of subduing dragons and tigers. These are all simple matters; the true challenge lies in refining the Golden Elixir. Once the Elixir is complete, one may ascend at will, coming and going freely. Yexian, however, follows the talismanic school—stillness brings clouds and mist, action brings thunder and lightning. Yet if he receives proper transmission of the secret essence from an authentic master, he too may join the immortals of the Southern Palace. Otherwise, in five hundred years, he will not escape the thunder tribulation. Fortunately, Yexian’s heart is kind, and he often uses his arts to relieve suffering. Though he walks a different path, I shall pass on the Great Dao to him."*

Before long, Pengtou also departed, vanishing like a wisp. Yexian was stout and dark-complexioned, with impeccable manners. Pengtou, with his gaunt, ancient face and luminous spirit, came and went in an instant, like a soaring dragon.

Master Empty Boat said: *"Hai Ting spoke of Zhang the Perfected One, who often wandered through towns, feigning madness with disheveled hair, calling himself 'Pengtou the Spirit.' The Perfected One dwells in the world without displaying wonders, yet if he did not reveal himself as an immortal, he might be mistaken for someone like Yexian. Thus, he swept aside the side doors to uphold the true Way, and by slaying the shrewish wife to save Cai’s family, he subtly revealed the marvel of uniting Dao with method. Alas, Cai remained blind to it."*

**Postscript to *Hidden Mirror***

During the reign of the Qianlong Emperor of the Pure Dynasty, Grand Secretary Zhang Tingyu, Duke Wenhe, was commissioned by imperial edict to compile the *History of the Ming*. In the preface to the *Biographies of Immortals*, he wrote: *"At the dawn of the Ming, figures such as Zhou Dian and Zhang Sanfeng left traces so arcane and elusive that none could fathom them, yet they shook the Son of Heaven to his core—surely they were no charlatans currying favor. How true these words are!"*

**Biography of Chen Leigu**

The immortal Chen Leigu, styled Kefu, was a native of Dinghai. From birth, he was untrammeled and spirited, his bearing uncommon. From youth, he cherished the arts of immortality, harboring no ambition for official rank. He encountered Lin Quan, a Daoist of Pingjiang, who transmitted to him the method of summoning thunder.

At a time of severe drought, prayers went unanswered. Someone jesting said: *"The Daoist Chen can call forth thunder and rain."* He was summoned to the official court, where they awaited his failure to humiliate him. Kefu immediately invoked his method, and in an instant, clouds gathered, thunder and lightning crashed, and rain fell over a foot deep.

He often visited Tianqing Abbey in Yin. One Mid-Autumn, as a group of alchemists gathered to admire the moon, Kefu declined to join them. In jest, they sprayed ink-water into the air, and suddenly dark clouds blotted out the moon, raining black rain. The guests fled in alarm, their robes dyed black. Realizing it was his doing, they invited him to their table. The clouds dispersed, the mist cleared, and the moon shone bright once more. His responsiveness was ever of this kind.

During the Zhiyuan era, the Yuan Shizu summoned him to court and appointed him abbot of Changchun Palace. In his leisure, he would shut his door and sit in quietude, refusing to receive guests.

**Biography of Chen Zhongxing**
Chen Gong of Wenzhou, named Yu, styled Zhongxing, served as *shanzhang* of Mingdao Academy in Yuanjiang and *jiaoshou* of the Eastern Prefecture. A native of Jinling, he was gentle in demeanor yet resolute within, deeply versed in the great principles. When the Ming Taizu crossed the Yangtze, the censor Qin Yuan recommended him. The emperor summoned him with a letter, and upon their conversation, was greatly pleased. He was entrusted with military affairs and consulted on matters of secrecy, offered the post of *gongfeng*, which he declined. Later, he was successively appointed Academician, Left Assistant Director of the Secretariat, Grand Academician of Hongwen, Minister of Rites, and Minister of the Court of Imperial Sacrifices—all of which he refused. Even gifts of gold and silk were declined. The Gao Emperor visited his residence thrice, inviting him into the inner palace to be seated. When ill, he was sent imperial physicians and medicines. At seventy-two, he passed without illness. The emperor mourned deeply, thrice expressing his grief, and bestowed a coffin and silks. Among the officials and nobles of the time, none were thought to have received such favor. When the lord first met Taizu, he urged only restraint in killing, as the hope of the people. Asked about the governance of the Yuan, he could only weep. During his audiences, he would burn incense and sit solemnly, like an old mountain monk. Taizu repeatedly sent men to observe him, and he would simply recite from the *Vajracchedikā-sūtra*: *"Thus should one subdue the mind, thus should one subdue the mind."* Thus, he was never suspected from beginning to end. Yet his refusal of office may also be called loyalty to the Yuan. As *The History of the Yuan* does not record him, I have here set forth his memory.

**Biography of Wanpuzi**
Wanpuzi, surnamed Cheng, named Yao, styled Guangbiao, was a native of Xin’an. The son of the reclusive scholar Tuanxiao, he was of imposing stature and bold temperament.

His mother, née Ni, dreamed of a divine being presenting her with a red jade before giving birth to him. As a child, he possessed extraordinary intelligence, reciting classics and histories as if already well-versed. When Lady Ni passed away, he mourned with the grief of a grown man. From then on, he studied diligently each day, mastering what was transmitted from the hearts of Confucius and Mencius, as well as the essential teachings of the *River Chart* and *Luo Writing*. In adulthood, he married Lady Zhou, whose given name was Xi and courtesy name Yuanji. She was deeply learned, able to discern discrepancies in the *Comprehensive Mirror* and historical records, earning the title of "Scholar of the Boudoir." Though born in the same year, he came into the world on the Winter Solstice, while Yuanji was born on the Summer Solstice—one embodying minor yang, the other minor yin.

He served his father-in-law, Jingfu, with filial devotion; in leisure, he listened to Guangbiao’s recitations and often engaged in discussions of principle. After Tuanxiao’s death, he observed mourning rites with strict adherence to propriety. Upon completing the mourning period, he journeyed north. Song Lian, upon meeting him, marveled, saying, *"Beyond the dust of the world, Tuanxiao lives on."* Soon after, he departed to study swordsmanship under Wu Zhen, mastering its techniques within a single month. He then girded his sword and set out to wander. Encountering Wang Zhongdu in Juqu, he received instruction in the Great Dao and was told to choose a place for cultivation. Returning to Mount Bei, he secluded himself for twelve years, achieving Daoist mastery at the age of thirty-six. Only then did he return home to see Yuanji and instruct their son in reading.

Thereupon, he slept alone in the central hall. Yuanji secretly observed him and saw him seated cross-legged upon the bed, a golden radiance emanating from his crown, illuminating the entire chamber. The next morning, she entreated, *"Why do you not transmit the Dao to me?"* Guangbiao replied, *"I intend to deliver all under heaven—how could I withhold it from you? Yet I have not yet repaid my master’s grace, and thus dare not do so."* He then journeyed to Mount Dahe, where he paid homage to Perfected Wang, who bestowed upon him the title *Wanpuzi*. After offering his thanks, he departed, carrying his sword to roam Jinyang. Turning toward Jing and Chu, he encountered Yao Guangxiao, who had left the household life at Miaozhi Hermitage under the Dharma name Daoyan. Though ordained in the Buddhist teachings, he delighted in discussing military strategy. Once, while traveling in Xinye of Nanyang, he visited the relics of the Reclining Dragon and composed a poem at the temple, taking great pleasure in it. Suddenly, a man seated beside him shouted, *"What monk are you, daring to mock the Martial Marquis?"* Startled, Daoyan saw a Daoist in robes, girded with a sword, his countenance refined and extraordinary. He bowed and said, *"An unintended sigh in verse—why does the Daoist master reproach me so severely? Pray, whence do you come?"* The Daoist replied, *"I am called Wanpu. I wander as I please, for the verdant forests and azure peaks are all my dwelling."* Then, laughing heartily to the heavens, he departed. Later, when Daoyan became the trusted advisor of the Prince of Yan and aided his usurpation of the throne, Wanpu thus shamed him for it.

In the early years of the Jianwen reign, when the Prince of Yan attended the imperial funeral and returned as far as Huaiyin, his second son, Gao Xu, led troops to meet him. Suddenly, a great storm arose, with sand and stones whirling in chaos, leaving no path of escape. Then a fierce shout rang out: *"For now, I spare you!"* At once, the sky cleared. A Daoist was seen, hand resting on his sword, smiling faintly.

The prince sought to question him further, but with a gust of wind, the Daoist vanished. Upon returning, he ordered Daoyan to divine the matter. Daoyan said, *"This is but the playful trick of an immortal."*

For after shaming Daoyan, Wanpu had already learned of the Prince of Yan’s journey to court and thus appeared midway, displaying his arts of concealment and warning him. In the fourth month of summer, during the minor memorial rites for the late Emperor Taizu, the Prince of Yan dispatched his heir and others to attend. The Duke of Wei, Xu Huizu, secretly memorialized the throne to detain them. The prince entered Huizu’s stables, stole a fine steed, and fled first.

At that time, Wanpu was visiting me on Mount Wudang. From afar, he saw the prince approaching, drew his sword, and pointed it at him. The horse reared in terror, whinnying and bolting uncontrollably, unable to be reined in until it reached the riverbank—where it seemed to plummet from the clouds and mist.

Later, when the Prince of Yan besieged Jinan, Magistrate Tie Xuan ordered his troops and people to feign surrender, defeating the prince beneath the city walls. Daoyan was also among the army, inspecting the camp when a man approached him and said, *"I possess the strategy to breach the city."* He handed over a sealed letter and departed at once. Daoyan opened it to find these words:

*"Advising on military affairs,
Yet failing to recognize feigned surrender’s ploy—
Your army’s fortunes at Jinan will wane.
How does this compare to Liu Chengyi?
Not at all."*

Daoyan read it, shame and fear mingling within him. Recalling the man’s features, he realized it was the very one he had encountered before the shrine of Zhuge Liang.

Wan Puba once more journeyed to the Huai region, where he encountered the Yan army advancing to attack Cangzhou, with Gao Xu guarding the rear. Suddenly, a violent hailstorm erupted, striking the northern forces and scattering them in retreat, leaving Gao Xu severely wounded as he fled. By chance, Master Zhou Yin of Yaozhen met him and, astonished, asked, *"The Prince of Yan is a ruler ordained by the Mandate of Heaven—why have you thwarted him?"* Puba replied, *"Sir, you are mistaken! The Prince of Yan, Zhu Di, is today’s Guan and Cai. Had there been no Duke of Zhou, he would have carried out his ambitions. Yet you ascribe the Mandate of Heaven to him—if this were so, then every powerful vassal who rebels against the state could claim the Mandate, and the moral order would collapse entirely. I have pondered this deeply and cannot yield to vulgar opinion. Thus, I twice shamed Daoguang and thrice humiliated Gao Xu, all to uphold the great ethical principles, preserve the teachings of propriety, and ensure that posterity knows the Yan prince’s army was intolerable even to recluses of the mountains and forests—proving he was no ruler ordained by Heaven. Since ancient times, when true men arise, they must eliminate the cruel and expel the violent. The highest, like Tang and Wu, or the next, like Gaozu and Guangwu, may then be called ordained by Heaven. In recent times, the Taizu Emperor founded the dynasty, pacified the rebels, and succeeded the Great Yuan—he too may be deemed ordained. Yet Heaven bestowed the realm upon the Ming, and we must honor as the Mandate of Heaven that which our ancestors transmitted. Had the Prince of Yan not usurped the throne, how could we know that Jianwen’s descendants would have lacked an heir? Moreover, since his enthronement, he has governed with filial piety and benevolence—Heaven originally had no intention of altering the succession. The Prince of Yan’s coercion of the weak was no different from a village bully seizing his clansman’s property—what has this to do with the Mandate of Heaven? Now Gao Xu is violent toward all things, aiding his father in rebellion, while Daoyan, that treacherous slave, abets his ambitions. Even those of shallow understanding are indignant—how much more so the heroic! I have heard, sir, that you are a worthy descendant of the Jiao-Li Duke. Yet recalling the Four Elders of Mount Shang’s assistance, why did they favor the younger son over the eldest? Even Lady Qi’s son once occupied the throne as Emperor Hui—would you, sir, acknowledge him?"* Zhou Yin of Yaozhen was left speechless and soon took his leave.

Puba returned to his mountain dwelling, where Yuan Ji paid him a visit, saying, *"The matter of marriage has been settled on your behalf. Shall I now transmit to you the Way?"* Thereupon, she taught him the secret of returning to the origin and restoring the primordial, and he cultivated it day and night. His son, too, nurtured the fetal embryo through inner alchemy, and after nine years, a grandson was conceived in the womb, capable of dividing his form to respond to phenomena and journeying in spirit a thousand *li*. Meanwhile, Yuan Ji’s countenance grew ever more youthful, as she awakened to past causes, and together with Puba’s son, they ascended the Jasper Isle.

**Eulogy:**
Cheng Wanpu was a loyal and righteous immortal. His shaming of Guangxiao, his thwarting of Gao Xu, and his remonstrance with Yin of Yao—bold indeed! Yet was his dragon-like nature not still untamed? Later, hearing of the nurturing of the grandson and his entry into the *Fu* Tower of Baoshan to compile the *History of Immortals* alongside Master Xu, he became most refined and scholarly.
