**Biography of Huizhongzi**

Huizhongzi, surnamed Xu, named Renrui, and styled Jiwu, was the son of Xu Jingfu, the Marquis of Dianchi. His mother, née Hong, first bore a daughter named Dagu, then Huizhong, on the eighth day of the fourth month in the first year of the Hongwu reign. In his infancy, he died and revived, suddenly awakening to divine wisdom. Earlier, the Marquis of Dianchi had been bold and ambitious, spurring himself to military service and being transferred to distant posts, never able to return—Huizhong was still young at the time. He once studied under Professor Han, mastering the classics and histories, earning the local reputation of a child prodigy. Yet Huizhong’s nature was serene and detached, ever drawn to the cultivation of the mysterious. Each day, returning from the academy, he encountered a red-bearded Daoist who beckoned him forward and said, *"Young one, if you have the heart to learn the Dao, do you know that the Way is not far from man? Loyalty, filial piety, benevolence, and righteousness are its foundation."* He then transmitted a wondrous method, vanishing into the deep forest. Huizhong returned home and resolved to repay his origins, vowing loyalty and sincerity. Reflecting on his aged father’s long absence in the army, with no news for years, he wished to search for him everywhere. Yet his mother was alone and frail, with no one to attend her, so he dared not depart hastily. His elder sister had married Zhu Yunzhang of Loujiang, who devoted himself to knight-errantry, vowing to serve the court and seek official rank. Huizhong sighed upon hearing this, thinking, *"Brother Zhu harbors such ambitions!"* He kept his concern to himself, never speaking of it to his mother.

He married Tao Shi, whose childhood name was Zhonggu and later changed to Fu, styled Yugen. She was quick-witted and perceptive, able to read ancient classics. Though a year younger than Huizhong, they shared the same month, day, and hour of birth. She served her mother-in-law with devotion, earning the praise of being a "dual paragon of filial piety." With such a virtuous and compliant wife, Huizhong gathered disciples to teach, using his stipends to support his parents. Later, as his family grew, making a living became difficult, so he studied the arts of medicine, specializing in the treatment of smallpox and epidemic diseases. The people of the land whose lives he saved were beyond count.

Hearing that Zhu Yunzhang had died in battle while aiding the king, he prepared a boat to console his elder sister. Reflecting on his father’s military service, with no news of his fate, his resolve to seek him grew even stronger. He vowed to traverse the ends of heaven and earth to find him. At thirty, with a long beard of five strands, a river-like mouth, sword-like brows, a fine nose, and bright eyes, he favored sky-blue robes and pale yellow skirts, his bearing ethereal, like that of an immortal. Accompanied by two young attendants, he boarded a boat. In Jiangxi, children afflicted with illness sought his healing, and he distributed all gifts and surplus provisions to the poor. Wandering through Chu and Shu, he reached the Qutang Gorge and the Three Gorges. Learning that the Marquis of Xu was in southern Yunnan, he set out to find him. Upon arriving in Shufu and inquiring, he discovered that his father had once garrisoned Dali but had passed away two years prior.

Grieving to the point of near-collapse, he set out that very day, weeping as he rushed to Dali. After searching, he found the grave just outside the northern gate in Heping Ward. Stepping into the courtyard, his heart heavy with sorrow, he suddenly saw two youths rush out and stare in astonishment. Both sides were shocked and doubtful, for the Marquis of Xu, having heard that Hong’s son had died, had taken two concubines, the Ladies Yan and Tang, to continue the ancestral line, and these two sons were theirs. After exchanging glances and questions, they realized they were half-brothers by different mothers, and so he asked the two ladies to come forth and pay their respects. He then had his brothers lead him to the grave, where he built a hut and stayed for seven days, mourning with such grief that he wasted away in proper observance of ritual.

At this time, thoughts of returning home arose, and he wished to take the two ladies and his brothers back east with him. But as their marital ties were here, they were unwilling to relocate, so he bid them farewell and set out on his journey home. Upon first arriving at his residence, he entered the central hall to pay respects to his mother, only to see a mourning canopy. Lifting it, he found a coffin before him, and cried out in shock, “What is this?” The household gathered, weeping as they bowed. Lady Zhong said, “Ever since you left, the old lady was consumed by longing, and suddenly collapsed.” Hearing this, Huìtōng was overwhelmed with grief. He performed the rites of sacrifice and burial, then deepened his mourning at the grave.

One day, the red-bearded man from before arrived and said, “I am a hidden immortal of the Western Mountains. I have heard that your filial virtue has moved Heaven, and you are destined for eternal life and transcendence.” He then summoned Huìtōng and Lady Zhong before him and transmitted the secret of the Great Elixir. Huìtōng and Lady Zhong bowed and took the immortal as their master. After the immortal departed, they each swept the alchemical chamber clean and diligently cultivated their practice. In less than a year, the Golden Elixir was complete.

On another day, while traveling in the Western Mountains, he again met the immortal master, who transmitted the Divine Elixir. They then set up a furnace in the Grotto-Heaven of the Forest Chamber to refine it further. White clouds filled the sky, and crimson radiance covered the earth. From that moment on, the entire household ascended together.

When Huìtōng first entered the Western Mountains, he saw a stone gate in the depths of a perilous cliff. Bending low, he entered and crawled for a long time until faint light appeared. Striking a jade chime once, all things became luminous, and within the cavern, another world unfolded—a scene of transcendence. There, forests and springs stretched boundlessly, clouds and waters soared, and apes and cranes called to one another beyond the mist. Yet pavilions and towers were no different from those of the human realm. As he wandered through the courtyards, he saw halls named “Hall of Halls,” pavilions called “Pavilion of Pavilions,” verandas titled “Veranda of Verandas,” and towers inscribed “Tower of Towers.” Huìtōng nearly lost all sense of where he was.

Suddenly, two officials approached to welcome him, saying, “By the command of the Mysterious Sage, we have been awaiting one of immortal talent.” They led Huìtōng to a stone tower, its plaque reading “Jeweled Tower of the Flower Treasury.” The two officials left him inside and locked the door behind them. Huìtōng sat in quiet contemplation. An attendant served a meal, with a zither and books on the table and fragrant tea before him. Upon examining the tower’s walls, he found an edict from the Most High, ordering him to carefully examine the jade scrolls and compile the *History of Immortals*. Upon completion, he would be permitted to reunite with his entire family.

Thereupon, he took up the immortal brush, smoothed the cloud-silk, and diligently researched each day with meticulous care. All the immortal traces of past and present, the transmission of the Great Dao, were arranged and recorded in brilliant clarity, shining like stars and sun. Time passed uncounted—days and nights blurred together. Then, an elder appeared, unlocking the gate and entering. Huìtōng bowed to him, and the elder said, “I am Língwēizǐ, master of this grotto. Your achievement of such rare merit brings fortune to both immortals and mortals.” Huìtōng expressed his gratitude and requested leave to wander freely. The elder replied, “You may now go forth and observe. Your family has already been moved to the front residence. Please go and see them.”

With the joy of reunion between infant and maiden, Huìtōng descended the Jeweled Tower. A blue-clad youth led the way, first through the Gate of Wù and Jǐ, then to the Eastern Hall, where he glimpsed Lady Zhong in official attire. She curtsied and said, “You may now go and see your parents.” Entering the inner courtyard, he saw his mother seated beside a majestic, bearded elder on a carefree couch—his father, now a perfected immortal. Huìtōng wept as he bowed before his mother and asked how she had come to be there. She said, “After my passing, the red-bearded Daoist sent a vajra guardian to protect me day and night, saying they awaited your Daoist attainment so we could ascend together. The one seated beside me is your father.” In that moment, parents, wife, and children were all reunited in the Grotto-Heaven of the Forest Chamber.

Alas! Huìtōng’s immortal rank brought such honor to his entire family. Possessing the art of healing others, he had journeyed ten thousand *li* to seek his kin—truly a paragon of benevolence and filial piety. Yet when he departed, his father had already passed, and he could not see him; when he returned, his mother had died, and he could not send her off. No sorrow of a child surpasses this. But upon compiling the *History* in the Jeweled Tower and transcending with his whole family, he understood that Heaven’s reward for benevolence and filial piety is never amiss.

Later, he was enfeoffed as Grand Scribe of the Celestial Convergence and Universal Relief Envoy, while Lady Zhong was named Lady Yìyǐn of Pure Chastity. This account wondrously harmonizes with the alchemical classics and immortal brush.

**Eulogy:**
Xu Huìtōng was a benevolent, filial immortal. He sheltered and supported his mother, used medicine to seek his father—his learning and many talents shaping his character. Yet it is lamentable that in his distant search for his late father, he could not be present for his living mother, leaving this lingering regret. For a child in such a plight, only by leaving the household to seek the Dao could he hope for his family’s shared ascension. Had he not possessed immortal talent to complete the *History of Immortals*, how nearly impossible it would have been!

**A Short Biography of Shěn Xiànyáng**
Shěn Xiànyáng was the eldest daughter of Wànshān.

Her voice was resonant, her frame robust—she bore no semblance of a woman’s form. At three years of age, she vanished, and none knew where she had gone.

When Wànshān journeyed to Yunnan with his disciples, I went to meet him in Diān, where together we refined the Great Elixir of Heavenly Origin. Only after a full year did it reach completion. Later, Xiànyáng came to see me—more than thirty years had passed since our parting. Father and daughter met again, yet neither recognized the other. Only after careful inquiry did we realize she was his eldest daughter.

Separated from her kin in infancy, it nearly became an eternal farewell, though in her tender youth she remained unaware. At the moment of her departure from the inner chambers, she encountered Xuē Zhēnyáng, the one anciently called the Mysterious Maiden of Zhōngtiáo. She was given the name Yùxiá and the style Xiànyáng, entrusted with the divine sword and charged with guarding the myriad secret methods of the Jade Casket. Thus she received the transmission of the Great Dao of Spiritual Penetration.

While Wànshān and I were refining the Elixir of Heavenly Origin, she came to Yunnan at Zhēnyáng’s instruction to partake of the completed medicine together. Overjoyed, Wànshān produced the finished elixir, and the entire family consumed it, ascending in transcendence.

Xiànyáng’s boundless compassion moved her to a vow of universal salvation for all beings. She often declared, *"Those who endure aid the Dao; those who delight in killing必 lose their primordial essence."* Thereafter, she wandered the four directions with her father, transforming and liberating wherever she went.

Alas!

The lady may well be called a hero among female transcendents.

The Yu family father and daughter spread their teachings across the southeast, where many possessed immortal talents, yet only the Shen household could receive their alchemical secrets. Yu Shíshě, son-in-law to Wànshān, was a man of youthful generosity; Wànshān gave him his youngest daughter in marriage and transmitted the wondrous Dao of cinnabar, so that his wealth and prosperity rivaled that of his father-in-law. When Wànshān journeyed to Yunnan, Shíshě inevitably followed—no mere coincidence. Upon arriving in Yunnan, Xīpíng Marquis Mù Chūn treated him with deep kindness. Observing Yu’s daughter—her bearing refined and serene, her demeanor truly that of a transcendent—he wished to take her as a concubine for Shíshě, to which Shíshě consented. Yet upon entering the Xīpíng residence, the marquis, finding her dowry meager, treated her with scant courtesy. The Yu lady said, *"What you value is wealth—easily provided."* She instructed that mercury be heated, then cast her gold ring into it; a sound like a cicada’s cry arose, the true mercury evaporated, and the ring remained unchanged. When she used the mercury to polish copper and iron, all transformed into boundless golden treasures, much to the marquis’s delight.

During his seven-year governorship of Yunnan, the Xīpíng Marquis greatly expanded military colonies, and much of his success was owed to Lady Yu. Later, he sought a Daoist name from me and became my junior disciple, henceforth called Huìgāng, styled Jiànyáng. Together with her parents, she consumed the great medicine of Elder Wànshān and ascended in transcendence above the Kūnmíng Lake.

*Reed Bank Night Conversations*
The moon pale over the Yangtze, frost and dew blanketing the islets—did Master Wànshān’s disciples wish to hear of my origins? At my birth, a crane descended from the sea and sky, and all said it was Língwēi incarnate. Later, learning that Master Dīng still dwelled in the numinous realm, I thought: *He is human, and I am human—why should I not attain what he has?* Ever lamenting the fleeting nature of time and the impermanence of life, where wealth and honor are as transient as wind, lamp-flame, grass, or dust, I yearned day and night for the Great Dao. I abandoned fame and profit, renounced power and gain, and wandered rivers and lakes, seeking renowned masters. Though I received many teachings, all were peripheral minor arts, at odds with the true Dao, and my efforts were in vain.

In the first year of the Yányòu era, at sixty-seven years of age, my heart and fate grew anxious. Fortunately, Heaven took pity: upon first entering Zhōngnán, I encountered Master Fire Dragon, a lofty disciple of Elder Tú Nán, his bearing beyond the mundane. Kneeling, I sought the Dao, and moved by my sincerity, the master first instructed me in the work of refining the self, then revealed the oral formula for obtaining the medicine, and finally expounded on the subtleties of firing times, the nurturing of the embryo, and the principles of emptiness and completion. All was made clear. Thus I understood that to advance in the Dao, one must employ both method and resources. Though I had traveled widely and was inclined toward goodness, I had exhausted my coffers and emptied my chests—how could I fulfill my long-held vow? Unconsciously, my distress showed upon my face. The master, sensing something amiss, questioned me, and I, tears streaming, grasped his knee and confessed.

Having received the master’s gracious bestowal of the cinnabar-transmuting elixir, I was commanded to leave the mountain and cultivate it. I took leave of my benevolent teacher, veiling my light to mingle with the world, and set out to seek eight ounces of true lead and half a catty of true mercury. Together they entered the alchemical furnace, where through firing, refinement, and cyclical transformation, the nine revolutions were completed. With these resources, I would fulfill the great work.

Thereupon I built a crucible chamber, sat upright in solitude, emptied my heart to nurture qi, and stilled my qi to nourish spirit. As qi grew luminous, spirit became clear. I gathered medicinal ingredients far and wide, sipped wine of coiled peaches, and drank morning dew from the Jade Pool. Drunken yet lucid, I replenished qi and blood. Once half a catty of mercury was secured, eight ounces of lead would follow. As the lunar cycle neared completion, golden blossoms appeared of themselves. With ten hands I seized the tiger and captured the dragon, obtaining the primordial qi. Gradually I regulated the firing times, adding and withdrawing, naturally aligning with the celestial revolutions. I knew when to advance the fire at *fù* and retreat at *gòu*, and guarded against peril at *mǎo* and *yǒu*. After ten months, the sacred embryo manifested its form. Nine years of wall-facing, and I merged with the Dao in truth—just as the saying goes: *“Riding a crane through the azure vault as though on a broad highway, careless even if the blue seas turn to mulberry fields.”*

Such, in broad strokes, has been my journey.

Now let us take up the oars and sing together, to make this night’s joy complete!

The Four Elders of Shangshan—all were those who fled the chaos of Qin. The first was the Duke of Eastern Garden, surnamed Tang, named Bing, styled Xuanming, a native of Xiangyi. He maintained his lofty purity and secluded himself in gardens and hills, thus taking this as his title. The second was the Yellow Elder of Summer, by nature stern, named Kuo (or Guang in some texts), styled Shaotong. He withdrew to dwell in Xia Village to cultivate the Dao, hence styling himself the Yellow Elder of Summer. The third was the Master of Jiaoli, a man of Wu. A descendant of Taibo, surnamed Zhou, named Shu, styled Fudao. He roamed freely and contentedly, once residing in Henei, and later took the title Master of Bashang. These three are recorded in the *Records of Chenliu*, while Qi Li Ji remains unattested. Upon consulting Huangfu Mi’s *Biographies of Lofty Scholars*, I learned that the Elder of Qi Li was surnamed Zhu, named Hui, styled Wenli. He cultivated lingzhi to nourish life and dwelt among springs and rocks to preserve his true nature. Such was the pure breeze of the Four Elders!

**Preface to the Eight Ways of Reclusion**
Master Sanfeng, though repeatedly summoned by the imperial court, feigned reclusion to conceal himself deeply. With a sigh, he declared: “How wondrous is the use of reclusion! The Son of Heaven cannot make one his subject, nor the feudal lords his friend. One does not pay homage to lords and dukes, nor encounter the powerful and noble.”

He did not employ the arts of longevity to distract the sovereign’s resolve in governing with diligence. He sought for himself, applied for himself, attained for himself, and delighted in himself. From afar, he seemed like the white clouds drifting in the sky, ever-shifting in form; up close, he was like the bright moon reflected in water, rippling and elusive. Some concealed themselves amid the marketplace, others dwelt in mountain forests, still others mingled unseen among the common throng. Since the founding of the Great Ming, neither Taizu’s summons nor Chengzu’s search could reach him—was he a transcendent? A lofty sage? Or one who had attained the Dao and ascended as an immortal?

In his lifetime, he revered eight figures, once painting their portraits on scrolls and bowing before them. From the Han: Yan Guang and Fa Zhen; from the Jin: Tao Qian and Dai Kui; from the Tang: Lu Hong and Xuanyuan Ji; from the Song: Chen Tuan and Lin Bu. The *Yijing*’s *ninth line of the hexagram Dun* states: *“Abundant reclusion—nothing is not favorable.”* Could this refer to these eight masters?

Yan Ziling declined Emperor Guangwu, saying: *“When Yao of Tang embodied virtue, even Chaofu washed his ears. A scholar has his own aspirations—do not press me.”* Emperor Shun summoned the eminent Fa Zhen, who refused to appear. Guo Zheng remarked: *“His name may be heard, but his person is hard to meet. Fleeing fame, fame follows; shunning fame, fame pursues. He may serve as a teacher for a hundred generations.”* Dai Andao declined imperial appointments and fled into Wu; Tao Yuanming, of serene disposition, abandoned office to return to the wilderness. Emperor Xuanzong sought Lu Hong, offering rank to no avail, and Lu ultimately recluded himself on Mount Song. Emperor Xuanzong of Tang welcomed Xuanyuan Ji from Luofu and inquired about the Dao of immortality. Xuanyuan replied: *“A true king curbs desire and exalts virtue, naturally enjoying long-lasting blessings—why seek longevity further?”* Emperor Taizong of Song said to his ministers: *“Chen Tuan of Mount Hua cultivates himself alone, untouched by power or profit—he may truly be called a man beyond the world.”* When Song Qi and others asked him about the Dao of self-cultivation, Master Chen replied: *“A rustic like me is of no use in these times. You, sirs, should unite in virtue, promote culture, and govern well—this is the truest practice of cultivation.”* Lin Bu built his hut on Solitary Mountain and never left it, later receiving the posthumous title *Hereditary Tranquility*. These men were praised in the *Comprehensive Mirror* and commended in the *Outline of History*—unlike those who feigned reclusion on Zhongnan or fled to the northern mountains for mere show, they truly grasped the meaning of reclusion!

Now, those capable of lofty reclusion are themselves lofty immortals. Yet the alchemists and Daoist adepts of today clamor and jostle for advancement, flaunting their golden elixirs to deceive the sovereign. In the end, their fleeting delusions cannot escape swift heavenly judgment. Emperor Wu of Han favored immortals, and Li Shaojun gained entry—yet when his arts were exhausted, his head was displayed on a pike, and when Luan Da’s schemes failed, he was beheaded. Emperor Xianzong of Tang favored immortals, and Huangfu Bo prospered—yet before long, the Lis were executed, and shortly after, Liu Bi was put to death. As for Lin Lingsu and Wei Hanjin, who boasted of yellow and white (alchemy) and moved freely in and out of the palace—what became of them in the end under Emperor Huizong of Song? How grave it is! Petty men crave advancement, and mediocre rulers are often foolish.

How excellent were the words of Li Fan: "When the Dao flourishes and virtue abounds, the people are at peace and the state is well-ordered—what need is there to fret over the absence of a Yao or Shun’s longevity?" How excellent were Zhang Gao’s words to Emperor Muzong: "When the spirit is serene, blood and qi harmonize; when desires run rampant, illness and affliction arise. Medicine is for attacking disease—without illness, one must not partake of it." How excellent were Wang Zhaosu’s words to Emperor Taizu of Song: "To govern the world, nothing surpasses loving the people; to cultivate the mind, nothing surpasses reducing desires." How excellent was Pei Lin’s memorial to Emperor Xianzong, in brief: "Alchemists cannot be trusted. If true immortals exist, they must dwell deep in cliffs and ravines, ever fearful of being known. Those who hover at the gates of power, flaunting their strange arts, are all lawless men driven by profit."

Master Sanfeng was a true recluse, a true escapee. In conduct, he aspired to emulate Yan, Fa, Dai, Lu, Tao Qian, and Lin Bu; in admonition, he sought to follow the Yellow Emperor and Master Xiyi, embracing their loftiness. He wished only that those who sought him would forget him, and those who summoned him would abandon the summons. Thus would he vie with the Eight Recluses of old in transcendent withdrawal, becoming the great hermit of this sagely dynasty.

**Postscript to *The Imperial Edict Enfeoffing the Perfected Man of Penetrating Mystery and Manifest Transformation***

Since antiquity, those called "Perfected Men" must outwardly embody true qi, inwardly contain a true heart, uphold true integrity in society, and maintain true discipline in seclusion—only then do they truly attain it. The true Dao abandons the world without clinging to it, avoids people without being seen by them, is not shackled by power or profit, and does not deceive sovereigns with alchemical gold and silver. How could it resemble those practitioners of minor arts who falsely seek imperial decrees without shame?

From the Han to the Song, among those who grasped the subtle mechanisms—like the Eight Recluses I revere—their pure winds and towering integrity led them to flee fame, decline appointments, retire after accomplishing great deeds, or hide in times of decline. Their true essence remained concealed; how could they ever peddle longevity elixirs to the court?

From my youth, I was devoted to the profound principles of the Dao; in later years, I attained its true essence. Wild and unrestrained, I truly despised the vulgar. I hold that Perfected Men and True Lords, enfeoffed by the Supreme Emperor, are precious—what value is there in human imperial decrees? Only Emperor Yingzong of the Heavenly Compliance era, both enlightened and decisive, bestowed upon me this august mandate, which I accepted with utmost reverence.

Yet in the reigns of Chenghua and Jiajing, Tibetan monks like Zaba and the sorcerer-monk Jixiao were enfeoffed as National Preceptors and Chan Masters; alchemists such as Deng Changen, Li Zixing, Shao Yuanjie, Tao Zhongwen, Tang Zhi, and Liu Wenbin, along with hundreds of Daoist adepts, were all base and petty men—crafty, greedy, and treacherous. Falsely styling themselves as Dharma Masters and indiscriminately titled Perfected Men, they became laughingstocks in the historical records. At that time, worthless jade was confused with true gems, and fish eyes were mixed with pearls—I would never have accepted such a decree. Later, some were executed, others dismissed, their former titles revoked, leaving none unexposed. How gratifying! Was this not the Supreme Emperor’s solemn regard for imperial decrees, refusing to recklessly bestow them upon the unworthy, and silently stripping away their hollow titles?

**Written by the Old Daoist of the Great Yuan, Sanfeng**

**Memorial on the Concordance of Dao and Method to *The Ice Mirror of Ming***

I prostrate myself before the Great Dao, which is vast and relies on the Most High to transmit its mechanisms; its subtlety is most profound, and I hope the Quanzhen school will expound its teachings. Methods without the Dao lack their fundamental source; the Dao without methods cannot manifest its wondrous functions. Only when Dao and method are both complete do essence and function achieve perfect harmony.

I recall my time lodging with the Mingyu family, where I deceptively called myself Pang Dongchun, a wandering cloud from Tianshui, drifting through rivers and lakes. Lamenting the swift passage of days and months, I sighed over my advanced age; reflecting on my conduct, I found myself in the twilight of life. Sometimes I lingered in forests and valleys, sometimes I roamed secluded cliffs and streams. The books of Zhou and Kong I casually perused in my youth; the *Daodejing* of Laozi I loosely applied in my old age. With cloud companions and misty friends, I often set my mind on wandering beyond the world; with transcendent and extraordinary men, I received compassion for my constrained existence in the mundane. They pointed me toward the subtle and profound, obtaining the bellows of decay reborn; I trod this path, witnessing the unyielding blade of kalpas in the *Juan’e*.

Red lead and black lead, refined and tempered to form echoes and shadows;
Golden liquor and jade liquor, in sitting and lying, slightly attain free flow.
Though I have not yet reached the shore of the Dao’s completion,
I have surely galloped upon the track of the primordial origin.

Dragging my staff of bramble, I entered the grotto-heaven of Central Yang;
Inquiring of this Hua-Feng, it is the finest retreat of Inner Jiang.
Yesterday, Master Ice-Pot deigned to lower himself to seek the Dao,
presenting me with a jade-sealed letter, wholly devoted in sincerity,
and unfolding offerings of paper currency.
Though I first met his noble countenance,
I had long been familiar with his pure and refined voice.
The winds and thunders of the Six Jia he suddenly concealed within talismans and scripts;
The generals and officers of the Three Heavens were readily subject to his command.
Rescuing the distressed, aiding the imperiled, benefiting people and things.

You wish to bequeath this wondrous method to me—
how could I not offer you the primordial mechanism in return?
One text states: *"I was fortunate to encounter the crane’s neck and fish’s gills;
you, too, have met the calf’s nose and mouse’s ears."*
Like glue and lacquer, we are bound—how could parting be our fate?
With Dao and method conjoined, we forge an extraordinary bond.

Turning the body, I traverse the jade gourd,
heedless of east, west, south, or north!
Casually plucking the golden lotus,
ever abiding in spring, summer, autumn, and winter.

Since the immortal’s promise is granted,
I am deeply honored by your radiant discernment.

**Postscript to the *Preface to the Convergence of Dao and Method***

In my wanderings through the mountains of Inner Jiang,
I heard of the "Celestial Pass and Earthly Pivot,"
believing it must contain secret classics and numinous texts—
the very essence of nurturing nature and establishing destiny.
Yet upon ascending the Celestial Pass, it proved but a trifling mechanism of three pushes.
And when I sought the Earthly Pivot, it was merely Stone Bamboo Mountain.
Thus I sighed: *"Are not the world’s famed yet hollow things just like this?"*

I had heard that Master Ming was quite devoted to the Dao,
but upon accompanying him, found him utterly unremarkable.
He even wished to teach me talismans and incantations,
oblivious to the existence of the Golden Elixir—
how could this be called the Dao?
The Dao is inherent in the human body,
not some heterodox left-hand path.

First, learn stillness;
next, learn awakening;
then, learn refinement;
then, learn nurturance.
Only at the end does one emerge into the Qian and Kun,
coming and going to rescue and deliver,
diligently establishing merit and conduct,
awaiting the celestial mandate.

Thus, the Dao may encompass method,
but method cannot encompass the Dao.
Even if one employs wondrous arts to aid others,
it must be with the heart as method,
the spirit as talisman,
and qi as the force of water—
then, nothing applied will fail to be efficacious.
If one merely drives talismans and dispatches incantations,
restlessly and without cease,
sometimes effective, sometimes not,
bewildering the hearts of people,
the discerning will surely call one a mere "master of techniques."
When one day a yaksha comes to press,
and life hangs by a thread,
if talismans prove ineffective and incantations fail,
though one has long been called a Daoist,
where, then, is the Dao?

Therefore, those who wish to learn the Dao
must seek the Dao within the Dao itself,
and not mistake method for the Dao.
Preserve the spirit and transcend transformation—
then, there is no Dao that is not method.

The *Immortal Chess Game of Penglai* was composed by Longyangzi,
Leng Qian of Huxiang.

In the early years of the Zhongtong era,

The monk Haiyun traveled widely. He read voraciously, with particular mastery of the *Book of Changes* and Shao Yong’s *Book of Supreme World-Ordering Principles*, and was versed in astronomy, geography, music, calendrics, and all manner of arts. In the mid-Zhiyuan era, when Bingzhong was appointed Grand Guardian and joined the Secretariat, Qian abandoned his Confucian studies. He roamed Xiaochuan, where he met Zhao Mengfu (styled Ziyang), a former Registrar of the Song dynasty, at the residence of Prince Shi Wei in Siming. There, they beheld a painting by the Tang general Li Sixun, which stirred something deep within Qian’s breast. He set about emulating it, and in less than a month, his landscapes, figures, and rock formations were indistinguishable from the general’s. His brushwork and coloring were even more delicate, conjuring a transcendent vision—thus, he gained renown in his time as a master of ink and color. While serving in Huaiyang, he encountered an extraordinary figure who transmitted to him the Great Elixir of the Central Yellow, revealing the profound insights of Peng Xiao’s *Awakening to Reality*. Qian grasped them instantly, as if they were his own creation. By the Zhizheng era, he was already over a hundred years old, yet his hair remained black and his complexion youthful, as if he were still in his vigorous prime. When the Red Turbans rose in rebellion, he took refuge in Jinling, dedicating himself daily to aiding others and benefiting all beings, his medical prescriptions and remedies working like miracles. After the founding of the new dynasty, he was falsely accused of painting a crane—a crime—and vanished into the wall as a transcendent. From that moment, no trace of his ink remained. This scroll was painted for me on the fifth day of the fifth month in the sixth year of the Zhiyuan era. I treasure it as if it were a jade of unparalleled value, never showing it lightly to others. Now, as I prepare to seek Master Leng among the Ten Continents and Three Isles, I fear that later generations may not recognize the sublime mastery of the landscapes and visions within his heart. Should they mistake this divine and extraordinary brushwork for that of some ordinary artist, I record this here. I now present it to the venerable Grand Preceptor Qiu, Duke of Qi, that upon viewing this scroll, his spirit may be refreshed and his qi invigorated, his thoughts drifting to the isles of Penglai. I urge him to treasure it well, as a token of our future reunion.

Signed on the third day of the first lunar month in the renchen year of the Yongle era by the Recluse of Sanfeng.

[Seal of Sanfeng appears below, as recorded in *Records of Extraordinary Figures of the August Ming*.]

According to the postscript in *Immortal Chess Game of Penglai* (also found in Caoqiao’s *Qixiu Leigao*), some have strenuously argued its inauthenticity, claiming: In the second year of the Yongle era, the scroll was presented to the Duke of Qi, a trusted minister of the Yongle Emperor—would Sanfeng have dared to conceal his visit? Further, the postscript states that Leng was from Wuling, yet he was in fact from Qiantang. Liu Bowen once met Qijing in Hangzhou, and even the *Gazetteer* records him as a native of Qiantang. Moreover, the postscript claims that after viewing Li Sixun’s painting, Leng mastered his technique and produced transcendent works, becoming renowned for his ink and color—why then does none of Liu Bowen’s poetry mention this, referring only to his skill in music and numerology? Additionally, if Sanfeng was a solitary wanderer, how could he have carried this painting to present it in the Yongle era? The postscript also states that Leng was already several hundred years old during the Zhizheng era—by the Hongwu era, he would have been over a hundred and twenty. Could one so old still serve as a minister? Even if he did, like Jiang Ziya or Fu Sheng, surely it would have been recorded—why does no text mention it?

Changyi responds: All five of Ying’s objections are groundless. This postscript’s language is lofty and untrammeled, unmistakably the hand of the immortal Sanfeng. As for its presentation to the Duke of Qi, it was merely to leave behind Leng’s painting. At the time, Sanfeng must have appeared and departed swiftly, like a crane’s elusive trace. The Duke of Qi had no need to conceal his visit, nor could the Yongle Emperor have hoped to detain him. First, immortals wander without fixed abode—if he was in Qiantang, he was a man of Qiantang; if in Wuling, then of Wuling. Why insist on a single origin? Second, though Liu Bowen met Leng, they were not constant companions, nor did he linger long. Even if he wrote poems, how could he have commemorated every encounter? Moreover, ink and color are minor arts—why would he praise them upon first sight? Third, a painting is not a cumbersome object, and presenting it was a gesture of respect. The Duke of Qi’s household was noble—surely he would have treasured it. Fourth, for immortals, a century is but an ordinary span. Serving as a minister in old age is no different from serving as an aged official—what doubt is there? ...

To Yuan Pu,

When your crane-borne carriage once visited me on Wudang, we sat upon my couch and spoke from the heart, utterly oblivious to the dusty world beyond. Yet my nature is restless, my heart set on saving the world, and like an untethered boat, I drift through the clouds and waters. You, too, had long been away from Mount Bai, and so you sheathed your sword and departed. Recently, I met your teacher, Master Wang Zhongdu, who praised your exceptional talent and keen insight, calling you the foremost among his disciples. He urged me, should I encounter you, to impart to you the true teachings. Alas! How could I presume to be your teacher? Yet I see in you a vessel of rare birth, destined to be guided by a host of immortals to become a leading figure of Penglai’s first rank. Your heroic spirit soars above the common, your ambitions towering—with the Green Snake in hand, you traverse the Nine Provinces, though I fear this may disrupt your tranquil cultivation. Mount Bai’s lofty depths are ideal for nurturing the embryo. If you can beget a son in the womb, and he in turn begets another, you may divide your body to serve the world without limit. Your wisdom is vast—I trust you will not find my words presumptuous. This humble advice, though slight, is meant as earnest counsel. If you deem me an old friend, that is enough.

The Cloud-Water Daoist Zhang Sanfeng bows in respect.

[Recorded in the *Yongle Encyclopedia*]

The earlier Confucians said: in reading, to take much is not as good as to take precisely. From the Son of Heaven down to the common scholar, the pursuit of learning is the same.

At the beginning of the Yongle reign, the court commanded Minister Hu Guang, Lecturer Wang Hong, and others to compile a work titled the *Great Encyclopedia*, comprising 22,879 juan in 11,095 volumes, with a sixty-juan catalogue. Its memorial text was once recorded in the *Cicada’s Refined Writings*. The *Imperial Digest* and the *Prime Tortoise* each contain no more than a thousand juan, yet those who seek abundance can only sigh in vain at the vastness. The *Great Encyclopedia* numbers in the tens of thousands—how could it ever be disseminated throughout the realm?

**Explanation of the Characters in *Awakening to Reality***
Alas! How is reality to be awakened? All in the world wish to awaken to reality, yet if their awakening is not real, it is no awakening; if reality is not awakened, it is no reality. Let us now clarify the meaning of the characters.

*Awakening* (悟) means to awaken and to seek. *Reality* (真) means the true and the correct. This much is known to all. But do they know that the written meaning of *awakening to reality* runs deep?

The character for *awakening* (悟) is composed of *I* (吾) and *heart* (心), teaching that cultivation must begin with refining the heart. As the Most High said: “Since time immemorial, I have observed the heart to attain the Dao.” Such is the way.

What, then, is *reality* (真)? The *Six Writings* state: “When a person receives qi at birth, the eyes form first, and where the spirit gathers, there is nothing that is not real.” Thus, the character is formed from *eye* (目) and *化*. *化* means transformation. It also takes the sound *hao* (浩), where *亠* represents the form of qi. From this, we know that those who seek to refine the Dao must first refine the eyes. Refining the eyes gathers qi, and refining the eyes also collects the heart—this is what is meant by “the mechanism lies in the eyes.” Recognizing this mechanism is true mechanism; recognizing this mechanism is knowing how to still the mechanism; recognizing this mechanism is entering the wondrous mechanism. To awaken thus is to be real thus. Let this be told to all in the world who seek to awaken to reality.

**Ode to the Knife and Ruler**
Master Sanfeng often carried a knife and ruler as he roamed, vast as the two great forces, boundless as the ten continents. A guest, perplexed by this, asked the reason, and the Master composed this ode:

This knife can cleave chaos;
This ruler can measure Penglai.
Thus they follow me without fail,
Knowing the tailoring of creation.

Behold its hundred points,
Twin forks like bright stars,
Its cord as white as snow,
Its edge sharp and true.
When it divides, it is swift as lightning;
When short, it fits just right—
Cutting water like clouds,
Swift as the decisive moment.
Its use is without limit,
Not confined to the small or fine.

To carve subtle principles,
To pare away the dust of clamor,
To measure the length of dawn and dusk,
To temper inch by inch with fire,
To gauge the breath of wind,
To nurture the embryo moment by moment,
To don a feathered robe and drift—
Scaling the Dragon Gate’s ten-thousand-foot height,
Like twin tiger swords.
Dreaming of Yizhou,
Yet unwilling to ascend with Fangzhang,
It soars beyond.

O knife! O knife! Wondrous beyond wonder!
O ruler! O ruler! Essential beyond essential!
Not Ou Ye’s smelting could forge it,
Not Gongshu’s craft could shape it.
It goes with me, heedless of mockery,
To seek the Weaver Girl’s cloud-silk,
And stitch the robes and hats of immortals.

Song:
A knife and ruler traverse the ends of the earth,
Homeless yet at home in the four seas.
A patched robe matches the drifting clouds,
While cinnabar is held within the sleeve.

**Preface to *The Essentials of the Mysterious***
Xuan Su laments that the span of human life is limited, while wealth and honor are fleeting—like a lamp in the wind or dew on grass, existence and extinction come in an instant. From ancient times to the present, this has ever been so, deeply worthy of alarm and reflection.

Thus, day and night, I yearned for the Great Dao, abandoned fame and profit, wandered lakes and seas, and sought out renowned teachers. Though I received much instruction, it was all from side doors and minor methods, bringing no benefit to body or mind. When I examined the alchemical classics, they too did not align, diverging from the Dao. My efforts were in vain, my nature and life in turmoil, and I never encountered a perfected one to fulfill my lifelong wish.

During the Yanyou era, by heaven’s grace, I first entered Zhongnan and met Master Fire Dragon, a senior disciple of Tu Nan. His temples were green, his complexion ruddy, and he stood apart from the world like a transcendent, his age unknown. Struck by wonder, I bowed and served him as my teacher, kneeling to inquire about the Great Dao. Moved by my sincerity, he first instructed me in the work of refining the self, then transmitted the oral formula for obtaining the medicine, and further revealed the subtleties of the firing process, along with the methods for warming and nurturing, the principles of embryo transformation, and the consummation of emptiness—all explained in full. Truly, this was mouth-to-mouth transmission, heart-to-heart instruction. To have heard such a teaching—what fortune could surpass it?

He also said that to achieve this Dao, one must employ both method and resources. Yet I, diligent in my travels and fond of good deeds, had emptied my purse and overturned my coffers—how could I accomplish this Dao? Unaware, my worry showed on my face, and the Master, sensing this, questioned me. I knelt again, weeping, and once more he took pity, teaching me the art of transmuting cinnabar and bestowing the medicine for quicksilver to stand firm. Thus, I left the mountain to dual-cultivate nature and life, then bowed in farewell to my benevolent teacher.

Thereafter, I blended with the world, seeking eight ounces of true lead and half a catty of true mercury. Together, they entered the furnace of creation, where I smelted the sun’s essence and the moon’s spirit, gathered the five phases, harmonized the four images, paired water and fire, balanced metal and wood, and congealed true earth. Through union and nurturing, transformation and division, three transcendences, and nine revolutions, I beheld yellow sprouts and white snow, bright mercury and transmuting elixirs—wonders beyond words. At this stage, how could I lack the means to complete the great work?

I chose a favorable site, built a thatched hut, and sat upright in a quiet chamber. Emptying my heart, I nurtured my spirit; calming my spirit, I cultivated my qi. When qi was refined and spirit clear, I then sought the crucible and vessel.

At dusk, I drank wine of pān-táo; at dawn, I feasted on waves of jade nectar. Drunken yet dazed, like an infant or newborn babe, I replenished qi and blood, warmed the cinnabar field, and reversed aging to reclaim youth—naturally sensing half a catty of mercury within. Only then did I await the eight ounces of lead. These measures required the moon’s full brightness, for the lead blossoms would then naturally reveal themselves. Seizing the moment, I captured the dragon and subdued the tiger, gathering that primordial speck of true lead to swallow into my belly, where it could dry my mercury. Gradually, with measured fire-tending, the proper weights and measures were observed. Once aligned with the celestial cycle’s count and the hexagrams’ unerring calculation, I advanced the fire and withdrew the talisman, knowing the return and union, guarding against peril by discerning the mao and you hours. After ten months, the sacred embryo manifested; after nine years of wall-facing, I merged with the Dao in truth. Mounting a crane, I ascended the azure heavens as though on a broad road, heedless of the seas’ transformation into mulberry fields—this was the hour of a great man’s accomplishment and renown.

Only then did I truly believe in this method of transcending the world. Though one might possess treasures like jade discs or outpace steeds with four horses, how could they compare to sitting and advancing in this Way? All this came from amassing hidden merits, repeatedly performing acts of kindness, and encountering a perfected being who brought it to fruition. By the grace of heaven, I, Xuán-Sù, was fortunate to achieve this. Though I dare not recklessly divulge the true transmission, neither dare I seal it in silence. Thus, I composed verses and discourses on the inner and outer elixirs of cultivation, compiling them into a record to awaken later learners, naming it *The Mysterious Essentials* and *The Essential Excerpts*. No other work more precisely captures the labor of practicing the Way, the oral instructions for attaining it, or the essence of its realization.

Should a determined scholar encounter this book, though they receive no direct transmission from Xuán-Sù, how would it differ from face-to-face instruction?

Written on the day after the full moon in the first autumn month of the guǐ-sì year of the Yǒnglè reign (1413), by the carefree Daoist Zhāng Sānfēng, styled Xuán-Sù.

In the mountains of Húnán, conversing with Attendant Hú by night:

Wāng Yuántōng said: "For nine years, Hú Yíng traveled on inspection, and while passing through Húnán, he rested in the mountains. One night at the third watch, when all was still, the tea had cooled and the lamp burned low, he suddenly heard a knock at the door. Presently, the door’s shadow opened of its own accord, revealing a Daoist whose appearance resembled Master Sānfēng. Hú was about to cry out in alarm, but the master swiftly covered his mouth and, brushing the table, spoke softly before departing. This matter was unknown to anyone in the Ming dynasty until yesterday, when the master descended to my summer retreat and recounted it. I now dip my brush to record it."

He said:

In his long sojourn through the realm, the venerable master has seen neither the dragon of Dǐnghú nor the steed of the empty valley—has not this journey been in vain? Yet moved by the bond of an old friend, I make bold to seek you out on this snowy night, arriving unannounced; pray do not be startled. Now the moon fills lake and mountain, the wind is pure in the lodge, the bell of the southern temple has faded, and the smoke at the western window has chilled—at this moment, does the master recall whether the old monk of Tiānchí was your former self? Say no more! Return to the court, and for my sake, conceal what should be concealed: what was seen, treat as unseen; what is known, treat as unknown. Thus may you avoid the exhaustion of carriage and steed, and spare yourself the toil of another ten-thousand-li journey. When you report back to the north, plan for next year. Along the way, present the people’s conditions to the imperial ear—this too shall be counted among the master’s virtues!

**Master Zhāng Sānfēng’s Four Principles for Recording the Recluse**
1. Those who conceal themselves in literary arts and Dao-learning, delighting in seclusion without emerging, are recorded as *chǔshì* (reclusive scholars), honoring their pure Confucian devotion.
2. Those who conceal themselves amid springs and rocks, their aspirations unwavering, are recorded as *yìshì* (recluses of leisure), honoring their steadfast integrity.
3. Those who conceal themselves amid times of order and change, resigning office without serving again, are recorded as *dáshì* (enlightened gentlemen), honoring their wisdom.
4. Those who conceal themselves in the gates of the mysterious and the pure land, unmoved by fame or profit, are recorded as *jūshì* (lay practitioners), honoring their pure cultivation.

The above four principles for recording the recluse truly capture the subtleties of appraisal—this is praise distilled into a single word. Some may ask: "Are not all four types recluses? Why distinguish them?" The answer lies in their *qi*-manifestations—whether in Dao-learning or refined leisure, in early retirement or shifting circumstances—each differs. Without such distinctions, their spirit and essence cannot be conveyed. Beyond these, categories like *gāoshì* (lofty scholars), *zhēngshì* (summoned scholars), *jiéshì* (principled scholars), and *yìshì* (righteous scholars) may all be subsumed under these four.

**General Assessment**
The calligraphic style of *Yǐn Jiàn* is pristine and archaic in every piece, its words simple and unadorned. It may be read as a brief biography of recluses—there is no need for exhaustive commentary.

*Yǐn Jiàn* by Master [Sānfēng]

The Master of Non-Existence
The Master was a great recluse of the Great Yuan, his conduct and concealment unfathomable—now absent, now present—hence his name. Born in the Yuan, he wandered through the Ming, his spirit roaming into the Qing. For six hundred years, he did not perish with the transformations of things.

Having traversed many ages and observed countless people, whenever he encountered those of lofty and steadfast aspiration, he delighted in commending them to others—not to compose a chronicle of recluses, but to weigh with those who wander freely among springs and rocks the proper balance of advance and retreat, of opportunity and timing.

The Master said: "The Dao of reclusion has two aspects. To withdraw in an age of decline is incompatible with serving a flourishing dynasty; to withdraw in a flourishing age is incompatible with exploiting reclusion to seize fame as a shortcut to office. Only thus do action and withdrawal align with propriety, and purity and loftiness find their record."

Hermits and rustics, as described above, were compiled into this volume, forming *Yǐn Jiàn*.

Liu Mengji
The Recluse Liu Mengji, styled Mengji, was a native of Rongcheng in Baoding.

Endowed with a nature of keen intelligence, he read books once and never forgot them. Initially devoted to classical studies, whenever he perused commentaries and exegeses, he would sigh, saying: "The profound subtleties of the sages cannot be exhausted here!" Upon encountering the teachings of Zhou, Shao, Cheng, and Zhu, he rejoiced, declaring: "I knew there must be such truths!" In daily life, he cherished Zhuge Kongming’s words, *"In stillness cultivate the self,"* and named his dwelling *"Jingxiu"* (Quiet Cultivation).

In the nineteenth year of the Zhiyuan era, an imperial edict summoned him to court, where he was appointed Left Rectifier of the Imperial Grand Secretariat. Citing his mother’s advanced age, he firmly declined, refusing even a single measure of the stipend. Later, when summoned again, he remained in reclusion and never emerged.

**Recluse Xiao Yizun**
The Recluse Xiao Yizun, a native of Fengyuan, initially served as a clerk in the prefectural office. When his words clashed with those in power, he promptly withdrew. For thirty years, he devoted himself to study without seeking official advancement. Once, a villager traveling at dusk encountered bandits; he deceived them, saying, *"I am Master Xiao,"* and the bandits, startled, released him and fled.

During the reign of Shizu, he was appointed Commissioner of Confucian Studies in Shaanxi but did not assume the post. Later, he was repeatedly offered the positions of Academician of the Jixian Institute and then Academician Reader-in-Waiting of the Jixian Institute, but he declined them all.

After some time, he was again appointed Right Mentor to the Crown Prince. Despite illness, he traveled to the capital and presented himself at the Eastern Palace, offering a calligraphic copy of *The Wine Admonition* as a gift, for the court at that time indulged excessively in drink. Soon after, he claimed illness and requested to resign, but his plea was denied. Shortly thereafter, he was promoted to Academician of the Jixian Institute and Libationer of the National University, while retaining his previous title of Right Mentor to the Crown Prince. He again pleaded illness and firmly declined, then returned home. His friend Zhang Silian, upon hearing this, sighed and said, *"Unsullied and steadfast in his principles, worldly success and fame cannot sway his heart—Xiao may truly be called a man of lofty aspirations."*

**Recluse Qiu Shancun**
The Recluse Qiu Shancun, styled Yuan, was a native of Qiantang. He withdrew to wander rivers and lakes, mastering the classics and histories. During the Zhiyuan era, he was recommended as Instructor of Liyang, then transferred to Professor of the Baoqing Circuit, but he did not accept either post. Later, he was appointed Gentleman for Fostering Merit and Registrar of the Hangzhou Circuit Intendant’s Office, but he declined these as well. He lived beneath the western wall of Qiantang, composing under a thatched roof, secluding himself to craft verses. Sometimes he sat among flowers, speaking to himself and drinking alone. Once, his *Ten Poems on Leisurely Living* revealed a talent truly refined and self-possessed. Here are two of them, to glimpse the recluse’s spirit:

*Composing beneath the roof, my brush lacks strength,*
*Shutting the door to seek lines, my mind toils in vain.*
*Better to sit in silent darkness among the flowers,*
*Watching dragonflies and butterflies drift and glide.*

*Tea bowl and gauze hat—accustomed to greeting guests,*
*If not a poet, then surely a Daoist sage.*
*In slanting wind and fine rain, do not venture out,*
*Beyond the green shade at the gate, red dust swirls.*

**Free Spirit Qiu Yuanliang**
The Free Spirit Qiu Yuanliang, styled Wanqing, was a native of Huaihai. From youth, he embraced the aspiration to master the Dao, intending to achieve success and renown before withdrawing to seclusion. At the beginning of the Yuanzhen era, high officials recommended him as Rectifier of Omissions. After a long tenure, he lamented the constraints of office and abandoned all thought of official advancement, returning to Weiyang. A thatched cottage of a few rafters, pines planted and bamboo cultivated—he found the joys of a hermit’s life. One day, while gathering herbs in a deep ravine, he discovered a thousand-year-old *huangjing* root. After steaming and eating it, he felt his spirit and strength invigorated, able to ascend lofty peaks as if walking on level ground.

**Free Spirit Wu Boqing**
The Free Spirit Wu Boqing, styled Cheng, was a native of Chongren.

From childhood, he devoted himself to diligent study, composing works to expound the great Dao, and was truly a leading Confucian scholar of his age. He served the Yuan as a Hanlin Academician. At the beginning of the Taiding era, he claimed illness and returned home, shutting his door to lecture on the Dao. Though repeatedly summoned, he refused to serve, his reclusive virtue worthy of praise. Yet some criticized him for having been a provincial graduate of the Song dynasty. He was styled *Master Thatched Hut*.

**Chen Maoshu**
The Free Spirit Chen Maoshu, styled Li, was a native of Xiuning. By nature upright and filial, he devoted himself to the learning of the sages. At the beginning of the Yanyou era, he passed the provincial examination but did not proceed to the Ministry of Rites, instead teaching at home. For decades he never left his courtyard—was this not one who valued virtue and lightly esteemed fame?

**Du Boyuan**
The Recluse Du Boyuan, styled Ben, was a native of Qingjiang. Broadly learned and skilled in composition, he was once summoned to the capital during Emperor Wuzong’s reign but immediately sought to return, withdrawing to seclude himself in the Wuyi Mountains of Jianning. When Emperor Wenzong heard of his reputation, he was summoned but refused to come. During the Zhizheng era, the Chancellor Tuotuo recommended him, and he was appointed Hanlin Compiler. The emissary hastened to Hangzhou, but he again claimed illness and firmly declined. In daily life, he was serene and desireless, never speaking harshly or displaying anger. In his dealings with others, he was steadfast in Dao and righteousness. Scholars called him *Master Clear Jade*.

**Dai Ruyi**
The Recluse Dai Ruyi, styled Yu, was a native of De’an in Jiujiang. He lived in seclusion, accumulating learning, and declined all official summonses. He once said: *"Simplicity clarifies the will; tranquility attains the distant—this was Kongming’s lifelong study."*

Dai Ruyi accordingly composed *A Comprehensive Biography of Zhuge Liang* in three fascicles.

**Wu Bowei**
The Recluse Wu Bowei, styled Ke, was a native of Xuande. He was fond of reading the *Book of Changes* and would sit upright in solemn stillness each day. When asked, *"What do you take as the foundation of your learning?"* he replied: *"Stillness is the foundation."* His *Collection of Water and Clouds* circulated in the world.

**Zhang Guangbi**
The Perfected Zhang Guangbi, styled Yu, was a native of Luling. During the late Yuan, he served as Vice Director of the Bureau of Military Affairs and Vice Director of the Zhejiang Branch Secretariat, but when usurpers sought to recruit him, he refused to go. He passed his days in poetry and wine, styling himself *The Laughing Recluse*. In his *Spring Day* verse, he wrote:
*"A gust of east wind, a gust of chill—
the banana’s fronds outgrow the stone balustrade.
Just a few bouts of drowsy drunkenness,
and I watch spring’s light reach the peonies."*
This foretold the certain downfall of Zhang Shicheng. He once said: *"When I die, bury my bones by West Lake and inscribe: ‘Here lies the poet Zhang Guangbi’—that will suffice."* Later, it came to pass as he had said.

**Wu Yuanying**

**Wu Yuanying**
The Recluse Wu Yuanying, styled Lai, was a native of Jinhua. He lived in seclusion, never entering official service, and built his dwelling deep in the mist-laden mountains. Mastering the classics and histories to their utmost, he found contentment in quietude. Skilled in discoursing on literature, he once declared: *"Writing is like waging war—there must be both the orthodox and the extraordinary. The orthodox is method and discipline, like infantry ranks in clear formation; the extraordinary is unbound by method, endlessly transforming, with sitting, rising, striking, and thrusting all arising at once. Yet when the moment to cease arrives, each unit returns to its place, and never once is there disorder."* Those who heard him were convinced. His fellow townsmen Huang Jinqing and Liu Chuandao, also renowned for their literary prowess, were held in equal esteem by their age.

**Xu Baiyun**
The Recluse Xu Baiyun, styled Qian, was a native of Jinhua. From youth he devoted himself to study, apprenticing under Jin Renshan of the late Song, and after several years had plumbed the depths of his master’s teachings. Withdrawing into the Huashan mountains, he concealed his traces, nurturing his resolve in seclusion, seeking neither fame nor advancement. Though recommended by both court and countryside, he firmly declined all summons. Truly, he was at peace with fate and principle, no feigned recluse trading on reputation as a shortcut to office. In teaching others, he prioritized the cultivation of an enlightened mind and the transformation of one’s qi, yet never instructed them in examination essays, saying: *"Here lies the division between principle and profit."*

**Wang Yuanzhi**

The Scholar Wang Yuanzhi, styled Feng, was a native of Jiangyin. During the Zhizheng era, he was repeatedly summoned but declined all appointments. Fleeing turmoil, he settled in Wujing of Shanghai, where he built a thatched cottage and styled himself *"The Most Leisured Gardener."* He was the one the world called *"The Recluse in a Woven Hat."*

The Recluse Tao Zongyi, styled Zong, was a native of Tiantai. During the Yuantong era, he took refuge in Jilinli, south of Songjiang city. Fond of writing, he tilled the fields himself yet always kept brush and inkstone by his side. Beneath a tree, he placed an urn; whenever an insight came, he would write it down and toss it inside. Over time, these accumulated into volumes, which he titled *Nanjian Niegeng Lu*. During the Zhizheng era, he repeatedly declined official recommendations. In the sixth year of the Hongwu reign, he was summoned to the capital for his talents but firmly declined and was permitted to return home.

The Recluse Cai Qingzhen, styled Wei, was a native of Qiongshan. Well-versed in classics and history, he loved springs and rocks and remained in reclusion at the end of the Yuan. He built his dwelling deep in the mountains, and when scholars sought his instruction, they would bring a jar of wine and a pig’s shoulder to visit—he never refused to explain. People said no Confucian scholar in Hainan could surpass him.

The Recluse Gu Zhongyin, styled Dehui, was a native of Kunshan. Gifted with extraordinary talent and grace, he was generous with his wealth and fond of befriending guests. He built a villa west of Qianjing, constructing thirty-six pavilions and halls, which he named *"Jade Mountain’s Finest."* There, he gathered men of letters from all directions, hosting them with wine and poetry. After returning to Chuoxi for his mother’s mourning, Zhang Shicheng summoned him, but he shaved his head and built a hut by her grave, styling himself *"The Daoist of Golden Millet."* At the beginning of the Ming, hearing that the Taizu emperor was harsh and intended to suppress the wealthy clans of Jiangnan, he disguised himself as a monk and fled. His writings include *Jade Mountain’s Unpolished Drafts*, and he compiled over forty collections of poems by his acquaintances, titled *Elegant Gatherings of the Thatched Hall*, both of which circulated in the world.

The Recluse Li Gaogang, styled Mingfeng, was a native of Wu. Generous with his wealth and hospitable to guests, he was on par with Gu Zhongyin, and the scholar-officials of the southeast all held him in high esteem. Once, he supplied Zhu Yuanzhang’s army with twenty thousand *hu* of grain, yet remained indifferent, seeking no favor in return.

At the beginning of the Ming, due to the severity of the state’s laws, he arranged with the wealthy man of Jiading, Fang Erlang, to take their wives, children, and family wealth, and sail away by boat across the rivers and seas.

**Yang Lianfu**
The eminent scholar Master Yang Lianfu, styled Weizhen, was a native of Shanyin. He had passed the imperial examination in the previous Taiding era and was appointed magistrate of Tiantai. Later, he moved to reside in Songjiang, where he built the Yuanpu Lotus Terrace upon the waters of Songjiang. Scholar-officials from across the land and the talented literati of the southeast all deferred to him, flocking to his gate in droves. Once, he played an iron flute, performing *The Plum Blossom Melody*, and those who heard it took him for a transcendent being. The world called him *"Master Iron Cliff."* He wrote *On the Orthodox Lineage*, and readers universally regarded it as a just argument.

**Wang Shannong**
The recluse Master Wang Shannong, named Mian, was a native of Kuaiji at the end of the Yuan. Tall and heavily bearded, he had studied the classics in his youth but met with no success, so he burned his books. He read ancient military treatises, wore a tall hat, draped himself in a green straw cloak, donned long-toothed clogs, and wielded a wooden sword, singing as he walked through the marketplace. People took him for a madman of great talent and spirit, and they vied to associate with him. All his life, he was fond of painting plum blossoms, and whenever he finished a painting, he would admire it himself. When the Ming Taizu emperor heard of him and summoned him, he was served coarse rice and vegetable broth, which Shannong ate as he talked. The emperor was pleased and said, *"This is a man with whom I can share great affairs."* He offered him the post of Consultant Military Advisor, but Shannong declined.

One evening, he dreamed that the immortals of Mount Luofu summoned him. Upon waking, he seized his brush, cried out wildly, and painted a great plum tree. He inscribed a poem upon it, which read:

*"The tree by my ink-washing pool at home,
Each blossom blooms in pale ink’s trace.
Let no man praise its fair hue—
Only let its pure qi fill heaven and earth."*

The next day, he passed away. At the same time, the monk Pu’an, upon seeing his heart and seeing his work, declared, *"Wang Mian of Kuaiji is the Plum Blossom Immortal."*

The eminent scholar Ming Tianyuan, whose given name was Jun, was a northerner. During the reign of Emperor Shizu, he was a descendant of the Ming’an clan. His beard grew past his belly, and he carried himself with lofty elegance, standing apart from the crowd. He served the Yuan as a scholar-official, but when the dynasty fell, he shaved his head to become a monk—though his beard remained as before. In the early Hongwu era, Emperor Taizu, having heard of his reputation, summoned him and asked, *"You do not serve me, and I shall not compel you. But why shave your head yet keep your beard? Is there a reason?"* He replied, *"Shaving the head removes afflictions; keeping the beard marks a true man."* The emperor laughed and let him go. His writings, including *The Collected Works of Pu’an*, circulated in the world. He was one loyal to the Yuan yet attained the Dao.

The reclusive scholar Zhang Boyu, whose given name was Tianyu, was a native of Hangzhou and a descendant of Song Grand Tutor Zhang Jiucheng. His bearing was solemn and refined, and he excelled in both poetry and prose. He shared a literary friendship with Yang Zai and Yu Ji.

Later, he entered Mount Mao to study the Dao, where he encountered Chen Shangyang, who transmitted to him the teachings of pure cultivation. Inwardly serene, he gained realization and styled himself *"Outer Historian of Mount Juqu."*

The eminent scholar Yu Bogeng, whose given name was Ji, was a native of Linchuan. Endowed with divine intelligence, he could read by the age of three. In his prime, he bore a reputation for talent and served as Academician of the Kuizhang Pavilion, but soon resigned on grounds of illness. He admired Tao Yuanming and Shao Yaofu, and so constructed two study chambers: on the left wall of one, he inscribed Tao’s poems, calling it *"Tao Hermitage,"* while on the right wall of the other, he inscribed Shao’s poems, naming it *"Shao Hermitage."* Serene and untrammeled, he chanted verses in contentment. Contemporaries called him *"Master of the Two Hermitages"*—or simply *"Shao Hermitage."*

The eminent scholar Zhao Zichang, whose given name was Fang, was a native of Xiuning. At the end of the Yuan, he assisted Marshal Wang Tong in raising troops to defend their homeland and was appointed Director of the Jiangnan Branch Secretariat. In the second year of the Hongwu era, he was summoned to compile *The History of the Yuan*. After its completion, he declined office and retired to East Mountain. There, with one or two reclusive companions, he built a retreat by Clear Stream, moored his boat on sandy islets, and lived free of worldly dust. His classical scholarship was widely transmitted, and he was known as *"The Recluse of East Mountain."*

The eminent scholar Wang Defu, whose given name was Kekuan, was a native of Qimen. In the late Yuan, he lived in seclusion at Huangu Valley. At the beginning of the Hongwu era, he was summoned to compile *The History of the Yuan*. Upon its completion, he firmly declined office and retired as a Daoist recluse in the cliffs of Daoren Rock, where he delved deeply into classical studies. In teaching his disciples, he always emphasized stillness of mind and the cultivation of fundamental strength.

The reclusive scholar Xie Zilan, whose given name was Yingfang, was a native of Wujin at the end of the Yuan. He styled himself *"Old Man of the Tortoise Nest."* There were two Tortoise Nests—one by Lake Ge, the other on Mount Heng—each commemorated in his records. In summary, he wrote: *"A thousand-year-old tortoise nests in lotus leaves, using the leaves as its dwelling, requiring no effort of construction. At leisure, it wanders with farmers and rustics through mulberry and ramie gardens, past peach and plum paths, sharing earthenware bowls of unstrained wine, singing and dancing in exchange—like one dragging its tail through the mud."* Elsewhere, he wrote: *"Throughout my life, wherever I have gone, I have named my dwelling 'Tortoise Nest,' for I do not take beams and rafters as my nest, but the heavens and earth. Towering halls and carved walls know not their splendor; humble gates and earthen windows know not their simplicity."* Reading his words, one may sigh in admiration at his enlightened perspective.

The Old Man had once served the Yuan, but after its fall, he refused office. In his *Letter to Zhang Yunmen*, he wrote: *"A catfish on a bamboo pole—how laughable were the achievements of former years; a tortoise in lotus leaves—how fleeting this recent life has become. Compared to my mountain retreat and small garden, yours is far more transcendent."*

She Yuanji
Recluse Master Shen Yuanji, styled Zhen, was a native of Changxing. At the end of the Yuan, he withdrew to Mount Hengyu, styling himself *"Old Man of Tea Mountain."* At the founding of the Ming, he refused office, taking the yellow stones as his disciples and the white clouds as his companions, never emerging. Compared to those who come when beckoned and go when waved away, how vastly different was his character.

Xu Zhongyou
Eccentric Master Xu Zhongyou, styled Wei, was a native of Chunan. At the end of the Yuan, he was recommended as a *xiucai*, but at the founding of the Ming, he refused office, styling himself *"Resident of Pine Nest."* His mastery of song composition and tonal prosody rivaled the ancients. Once, in his *Man Ting Fang*, he wrote: *"Clear frost on the wattle fence, red leaves in the forest hills."* After Tao Yuanming of Pengze resigned his post, he no longer served princes or lords. His lofty integrity was as if measured out through the hole of a flute.

Huang Ziyun
Recluse Master Huang Ziyun, styled Shu, was a native of Xiuning at the end of the Yuan. At the beginning of the Hongwu era, he was summoned but exempted due to a lame foot, earning the nickname *"Master Clever Limp"* among his fellow villagers. At the same time, there was Lü Buyong, styled Zegeng, a native of Xinchang. In the second year of the Hongwu era, he was recommended as *jiaoyu* of his local school but declined due to deafness, styling himself *"Deaf Man of Stone Drum Mountain."* Both gentlemen were untrammeled by worldly conventions, embodying the noble spirit of mountains and forests.

Zhang Weizhong
Recluse Master Zhang Weizhong, styled Yong, was a native of Cixi. At the end of the Yuan, during the chaos of war, a usurper appointed him as *shanzhang* of Shangyu, but he refused. At the founding of the Ming, he was repeatedly summoned but never emerged, vanishing into the rivers and mountains, singing freely among the white stones. He exchanged poetry and wine with the scholar-officials of his time, but when urged to enter office, he politely declined. People said of him that his integrity did not sever him from the world, nor did his reclusion betray his kin—he was a man in the mold of Guo Linzhong.

Wang Zhongguang
Recluse Master Wang Zhongguang, styled Bin, was a native of Changzhou. Together with Han Yi of Wu County and Wang Lü of Kunshan, he was known as one of the *"Three Eminences of Wu."* His secluded heart was as desolate as drifting clouds, his resting mat set by the misty river. Once, in a linked verse with Gongwang, he wrote: *"I know my nature’s eccentricity resists following the vulgar, yet I rejoice in my idleness, unbound to others."* From these lines, one may glimpse their shared affinity for moss-covered peaks.

Chen Kechang
Recluse Master Chen Kechang, styled Zhou, was a native of Min County.

At the end of the Yuan, a commoner, he recluded himself at Stone Pool. Once, leaning against bamboo, he composed a song to express his aspirations. The song went:

*"Slender bamboo, so verdant,
Hollow within, upright without.
Unblemished integrity, steadfast bearing,
Unchanged through cold and heat.
Gurgling streams at dawn and dusk—
Where else could I find such fitting abode?"*

Liang Buyí
Recluse Master Liang Buyí, styled Lan, was a native of Taihe. He styled himself *"Master of Pleasant Fields."* Zou Zhongxi remarked that his reclusion delighted in the Dao, while Wang Xifan praised his nurturing of resolve amid gardens and hills. I see in him a self-contentment in his western fields, a leisurely air akin to Tao Qian, and a boundless spirit reminiscent of Wei Ye.

Cheng Tuanxiao
Gentleman Cheng Tuanxiao, styled Xiang, was a native of Xin’an at the end of the Yuan. After the Dao was made manifest, the transmission of Learning of the Way spread through the world. At the beginning of the Hongwu era, an edict was issued to seek out recluses far and wide. Some recommended Master Cheng, but he declined to rise. In the second year of Hongwu, the court again sought elders from the mountains and forests to compile *The History of the Yuan*. Once more, he was nominated, yet he never attended. Later, when an imperial decree summoned Confucian officials to compile ritual texts, Song Lian said, *"None but Tuanxiao is capable."* The memorial was submitted, but the Emperor, unwilling to compel him, ordered that he be consulted at his home. When urged to serve, he merely smiled without reply, saying only: *"An earthly rank cannot compare to the nobility of Heaven’s rank; what are achievements and fame beside the loftiness of the Dao’s name?"* Thereafter, he concealed himself deeply and never emerged, drawing comparisons from the court to the recluses of Shangshan.

Xu Fangzhou
Recluse Master Xu Fangzhou, styled Fang, was a native of Tonglu at the end of the Yuan. Fond of poetry and lyrics, he built a hut by the riverbank, where water, bamboo, clouds, and mist aided his chanting and whistling. When Liu Bowen was summoned, he invited Fangzhou to accompany him. Fangzhou, clad in a straw raincoat, met him, and they drank wine and composed poems before parting.

Han Gongwang
Gentleman Han Gongwang, styled Yi, was a native of Wu. Born during the Zhishun era of the Yuan, he grew to love reading, perusing all manner of texts. In his youth, he suffered from an eye ailment. Casting a divination, he drew the *Meng* hexagram and knew his illness could not be cured. Thus, he named his chamber *"Meng Studio."* During the Hongwu era, he abandoned all thought of official service. When the prefect, Yao Shan, pressed to meet him, Yi set sail into Tai Lake, drifting among the misty waves at his leisure. Yao sighed, *"This is what is meant by a man whose name may be heard, yet whose person cannot be seen."*

Jiao Shimou
Recluse Jiao Shimou, styled Mou, was a native of Jiangyin. He had been an old acquaintance of the Hongwu Emperor of the Ming. When the emperor established his capital at Nanjing, he thought of him daily and repeatedly summoned him, but Shimou did not come. Preparing to send envoys to fetch him, Shimou suddenly appeared, carrying chickens and pork, along with village wine, entering by the imperial road. Delighted by his arrival, the emperor entrusted the provisions to the Court of Imperial Entertainments to prepare a feast, and they drank together with great joy. Before the feast, three belts—one of gold, one of silver, and one of horn—were presented, and Shimou was bidden to choose one as a token of official appointment. He took the horn belt and was thereby granted the rank of *qianhu*. Shortly after, he walked straight out of Gaoqiao Gate, hung his official cap and belt on a tree, and departed.

Sun Taichu
Recluse Sun Taichu, styled Yiyuan, was a man of the early Ming. His bearing was elegant and luminous, his movements strange and elusive. He wore an *yuan* cap and a white unlined robe, always accompanied by an iron flute and a gourd ladle. Wherever his lofty spirit alighted, scholars and officials were moved by him. He once dwelled on the summit of Mount Taibai, calling himself the "Taibai Mountain Man." He also journeyed west to Mount Hua, south to Mount Heng, east to Mount Tai, and north to Mount Yi. In the south, he wandered through Wu and Kuaiji, lingering long without departing. Together with Liu Lin, Long Kuan, Lu Kun, and Wu Xuan, he was known as one of the "Five Recluses of Tiaoxi."

Wang Tinggui
Recluse Wang Tinggui, styled Gong, was a native of Changshu in the early Ming. He built his home north of Mount Yu, beside Xiaoxi Stream, where he planted ten thousand bamboo stalks and roamed leisurely among them. His carefree spirit was as cool and refreshing as his poetic sensibility was ethereal and distant. People said he was like autumn moonlight or spring clouds, inspiring reverence.

Master Wang
Recluse Master Wang, whose name was concealed out of loyalty and integrity...

In the early Yongle reign, he took up residence on East Mountain in Dongyang County of Jinhua Prefecture, styling himself "The Great Fool." His bearing was striking and majestic, his wit and understanding extraordinary. Clad only in hempen robes and a bamboo hat, he refused conventional attire, wandering daily among the villages south of the mountain, singing wildly to his own contentment. Those who feasted and roamed with him knew not his surname. Only when in the company of those surnamed Wang would he address them as "elder clansman," and so he came to be called Master Wang.
