**Annotations on the Venerable Master Zhang Sanfeng’s *Lyrics of the Rootless Tree***

**Liu Wuyuan of Yunqi Mountain, notes**
**Li Hanxu of Changyi Mountain, expanded explanations**

**[Liu’s Notes]**
*The Rootless Tree* is the title of these lyrics. All trees require roots to grow; without roots, they cannot endure. Human life in this world—birth, aging, illness, death—appears and vanishes in an instant. A century passes like a spark or lightning flash, much like a rootless tree. The Immortal Elder’s twenty-four lyrics, titled *The Rootless Tree*, awaken the world, urging people to see through the illusory dream of floating life and swiftly cultivate their nature and destiny.

**[Li’s Explanations]**
*The Rootless Tree* refers to the *qi* of the human body. All the body’s meridians arise from *qi*, which itself emerges from the realm of emptiness and nothingness—hence, "rootless." The alchemist nurtures roots within this empty realm, where both pre-heavenly and post-heavenly *qi* arise from nothingness. Thus, the rootless is the origin of the rooted. Those refining the post-heavenly must enter nothingness to seek being, then merge being into nothingness; those refining the pre-heavenly must merge being into nothingness, then return from nothingness to being. Such is the cultivation of the root’s cause. However, the *qi* of the human body differs in youth, prime, and old age, just as the *qi* of refinement varies in the early, middle, and late stages. The twenty-four chapters correspond to the year’s seasons, all urging one to observe the flowers beneath the rootless tree in due time—this is the perfection of the Dao’s sentiment.

---

**1.**
**[Liu’s Note]** Lamenting the world.
**[Li’s Note]** Urging people to nurture the hidden flower.

The rootless tree,
Its flowers deeply secluded—
Who would cease their craving for glory and splendor?
The affairs of floating life,
A boat upon the sea of suffering,
Tossed to and fro without freedom.
No shore, no bounds, no place to moor,
Ever drifting through perilous waters of fish and dragons.
If one turns their head,
There lies the shore—
Do not wait for the storm to wreck your boat.

**[Wu Yuan’s Note]** "I do not know to what tune this belongs."
**[Hanxu’s Note]** "Those who sing *Daoist sentiments* call it *Pulling Back the Black Clouds*."

**[Liu’s Notes]**
Flowers are the radiant essence of the tree.

The human body is like a tree, and the human true spirit is like the tree’s flower. All trees have roots, thus they can grow and bloom. Only the human body has no root—life and death are impermanent, wholly dependent on the movement of that single point of true spirit’s qi. When the true spirit flourishes, the body endures and lives; when the true spirit decays, the body perishes and dies. Human survival or demise, life or death, rests entirely on the flourishing or decay of this true spirit. Though it is the flower of the human tree, it is in truth the root of the human tree.

Master Yuyang called this true spirit the "Yellow Sprout"; Master Boyang called it the "Golden Flower"; Master Chunyang called it the "Spiritual Root"; Master Ziyang called it "True Gold"; Yaofu called it the "Heavenly Root"; the Immortal Elder called it "Golden Essence." The various alchemical classics also refer to this true spirit as the "Primordial Unity Qi." Though its names are manifold, they all describe this one thing.

This thing is born of the Primordial, concealed within the Later Heaven. It positions Heaven and Earth, governs yin and yang, moves the Five Phases, and nurtures the myriad things. Vast, it has no exterior; minute, it has no interior. Released, it fills the Six Directions; gathered, it retreats into secrecy.

In terms of its essence: in Confucianism, it is called the Supreme Ultimate; in Daoism, the Golden Elixir; in Buddhism, Perfect Enlightenment. In terms of its function: in Confucianism, it is called Illustrious Virtue, the Heart-Mind of Heaven and Earth; in Daoism, the Numinous Treasure, the Mysterious Pearl of Millet; in Buddhism, the Treasury of the True Dharma Eye, the Wondrous Heart of Nirvana.

The human true spirit is originally round and complete, radiant and luminous, pure and bare, unadorned and free—neither born nor destroyed, neither form nor emptiness. In the sage, it does not increase; in the ordinary person, it does not diminish. Yet through interaction with the Later Heaven, the common people lose it, while the noble person preserves it—thus arises the distinction between sage and ordinary.

The common people lose it by forsaking this true spirit and pursuing the false spirit. The noble person preserves it by retaining this true spirit and not chasing the false spirit. Because the common people cling to the false spirit, the true spirit becomes dim and obscure. Following their desires, they crave glory and splendor, vie for fame and profit, never ceasing. Mistaking the false for the true, a hundred worries disturb their hearts, ten thousand affairs weary their forms—like a boat upon the sea of suffering, tossed to and fro, ever drifting through the perilous waters of fish and dragons.

If one can suddenly awaken and turn back, they instantly transcend to the other shore. Do not wait for the storm to wreck your boat and lose your life. Once the human form is lost, escape is impossible for ten thousand kalpas.

**Li’s Exegesis**

For years, this mountain dweller has secluded himself beneath the *Rootless Tree*, ever desiring to expound its profound mysteries and summon those of like kind. One day, strolling through the mountain garden, I beheld the serene seclusion of flowers and trees, their natural abundance overflowing—suddenly grasping that this character *you* (幽, "seclusion") is the wellspring from which the twenty-four chapters of the *Rootless Tree* arise. *You* means depth, the realm of emptiness and nothingness. All such realms of emptiness are the sacred precincts where Daoists cultivate flowers and trees. Thus, my mountain teacher inscribed upon the *Bamboo-Embracing Studio*:

*"Three paths of secluded blossoms, fragrance at ease,*
*Four gardens of cultivated bamboo, shadows intertwined."*

How wondrous these words, harmonizing perfectly with this truth! Without deep seclusion, flowers cannot exude their fragrance freely; amidst the red dust of worldly affairs, peace is unattainable day or night. As for *"shadows intertwined"*—this is the hollow heart and tranquil *qi* depending upon one another, whereby one’s *qi* nourishes the heart, and the heart nourishes the *qi*. When *qi* flourishes and principle abounds, the heart is at peace and the spirit whole, preserving one’s true nature and containing one’s numinous essence.

Wu Yuan was right to take *"true spirit"* as the root and flower of the human tree. The *true spirit* is true knowing and numinous knowing. Numinous knowing pertains to *yin* nature, true knowing to *yang* emotion. When nature and emotion remain uncorrupted, the true spirit is complete. Yet alas, the seven emotions and six desires erode and deplete it, inwardly damaging one’s nature and outwardly harming one’s emotions—until the true spirit vanishes. With the true spirit gone, the tree has no flower, no root.

Wu Yuan’s essential meaning is thus. Yet I have more to say: flowers grow from the tree, the tree from the root, the root from nothingness. The essence of the true spirit is indeed conceived within the womb of emptiness—hence the phrase *"the flower is truly secluded."* This conception within emptiness is none other than humanity’s primordial wisdom, the *empty numinosity* within each person—formless and traceless, yet containing all principles and responding to all affairs. Sages and worthies employ it with abundance, immortals and buddhas cultivate it to perfection, but it must never be entangled with emotions and desires. Once entangled, one daily extracts *being* from *non-being* to meet worldly needs, and in daily extracting *being*, one daily loses *non-being*. In daily losing *non-being*, one daily loses the root; losing the root, one loses the tree; losing the tree, one loses the flower. The common saying goes: *"When people grow old, they go senile; when trees grow old, their hearts hollow."* Wisdom is exhausted, empty numinosity scattered—where then is the true spirit?

All this comes from clinging to glory and splendor, refusing to rest, daily engaging in the affairs of fleeting life. They never consider that a hundred years pass in an instant, that upon death all matters are abandoned, and the body sits in the boat upon the sea of suffering. Nor do they consider that when impermanence strikes, the nature sinks with the capsized boat—boundless and shore-less, mooring and anchorage lost. Drifting and wandering through the perilous waters of fish and dragons, they rush about in endless toil, vainly wounding their wisdom and shackling their empty numinosity. What benefit is there in this?

The Immortal Master, moved by profound compassion, steers the compassionate vessel to ferry them, saying: The reason worldly people sink deeply into the sea of suffering and struggle to escape is simply that they refuse to turn back and do not recognize the shore. If they would but turn back, that is the shore. The shore is the path of awakening. Those who ascend this path find wisdom restored, empty numinosity enduring, past errors amendable, and future truths still attainable. Though spirit and *qi* may have declined, there is still a way to return. Do not wait until the storm’s surging waves shatter your boat—only then may the boat and its passenger be preserved, serving as provisions for the other shore and aid in emerging from the abyss.

**Liu’s Note:** Exhort the diligent learner.
**Li’s Note:** Urge people to graft and cultivate.

*The Rootless Tree, its flower now faint,*
*The aged tree must graft fresh branches anew.*
*Plum on willow, mulberry on pear—*
*Pass this on as a model for those who cultivate the truth.*
*Since ancient times, immortals have had their grafting methods;*
*When people grow old, there is medicine to heal them.*
*Seek a wise teacher, inquire of the method—*
*Begin swiftly, for even then it may be too late.*

Wu Yuan’s annotated edition renders *wei* (微) as *wei* (危, "perilous"), which also aligns with the sense of decline. **Liu’s Commentary:** Many doubt that when old age arrives and vitality wanes, the spirit is limited—like a tree’s flower withering in peril, unable to return to its origin or restore its root. Thus, they abandon themselves to despair, awaiting death. Yet observe how in the world, old trees grafted with tender branches flourish anew—plum on willow, mulberry on pear. These are inanimate things, yet they can revive. How much more so for humans, the most numinous of all beings, endowed with heaven and earth’s upright *qi*? Can the old truly lack medicine to heal them? What is this healing medicine? It is the method of grafting in old age. To know this method, hasten to seek a wise teacher and inquire of the true formula. Once obtained, begin swiftly—for even then it may be too late.

**Li’s Exegesis:** *Wei* means decline. When people grow old, their primordial *qi* declines, and they must urgently graft and replenish. Observe the examples of plum on willow and mulberry on pear—these serve as models. *Ji* ("to lodge") corresponds to the alchemical method of dwelling in the *dui* trigram’s gate or lodging in the western neighbor’s body; *jie* ("to graft") corresponds to the alchemical method of joining nature with life or oneself with another. Thus, plum on willow and mulberry on pear are precisely the models for modern truth-cultivators and the grafting methods of ancient immortals. Grafting is the medicine for old age.

The method of grafting trees has its fine techniques. Speaking of plum, willow, mulberry, and pear, these are of the same kind. When grafting, split the old branch, insert the tender shoot, bind and secure it, pack it with good soil, and let *yin* and *yang* interlock—this is the method of grafting trees. The medicine for old age must likewise employ like with like, blending with wondrous soil, only then can one return to youth and restore the origin. This method is known to wise teachers—it remains for people to seek them out.

Swift cultivation may still be too slow, for time waits for no one—impermanence arrives in an instant, and if one’s nature remains unenlightened while life remains unestablished, one strays into the vast and desolate realm of ghosts. Immortal He the Maiden said: *"In the Gardens of Lang, peach trees bear drooping willow branches; on Fusang’s boughs, intertwined pears take form—this is the alchemical method revealed by the Eastern King and the Queen Mother of the West."* The words of Zhang Sanfeng are not without foundation.

Further, as Liu observes, the work of refining the self. As Li notes, the marvel of flowers and willows. *"The rootless tree, its blossoms fresh and green—flower-wine immortals from ancient times to now. In the brothel’s den, the meat-and-wine grove, one neither shuns flesh nor transgresses lust. To transgress lust is to lose the treasure of long life; meat and wine pass through the gut, yet the Dao abides in the heart. Open the gate and I shall tell you: without flowers and wine, the Dao cannot be achieved."*

In Wu Yuan’s annotated edition, *"green"* is rendered as *"pure,"* yet *"green"* signifies the freshness of new growth, akin to purity untainted. Liu comments: The path of the Golden Elixir takes absolute purity—utterly free of dross—as its destination. Yet to attain such purity, one must first emerge from the depths of turbidity. Only by remaining unstained amid the deepest murk does true purity arise. Thus it is said: *"The rootless tree, its blossoms pure—flower-wine immortals from ancient times to now."*

How can one see that flowers and wine may forge immortality? The brothel’s den and the meat-and-wine grove are the very snares that beguile mortals. Yet if one can perceive color without being ensnared by it, resisting the allure of sensual pleasures, and if one can wander through the grove of wine and meat without being burdened by them—neither abstaining from flesh nor indulging in lust—then the appetites of food and desire are transformed. The heart of the Dao remains constant, the human heart fades away, the true spirit suffers no harm, and the great Dao may be attained.

When it says *"not abstaining from flesh,"* it does not mean clinging to it, but rather letting meat and wine pass through the body while the heart remains untroubled. To refrain from lust is to have no brothel in the heart; to consume meat and wine is to have no wine or meat in the heart. Without the brothel in the heart, the immortal blossom of long life naturally blooms; without wine and meat in the heart, the wine of extended life naturally flows. With the immortal blossom and immortal wine, one arrives at the realm of pure truth. Those in the world who shun brothels and avoid meat and wine—how could they know that immortals emerge from the midst of mortal flowers and wine? How could they know that without flowers and wine, the Dao cannot be achieved?

The *"Song of Knocking on the Hexagrams"* says: *"Wine is a good friend, flowers a companion; seek the true person in the willow lanes and flower streets—the true person is found only in the play of flowers."* This harmonizes with the marvel of *"blossoms pure."*

Li explains: The appetites for food and desire weigh heaviest upon mortals. Immortal Zhang Sanfeng used flowers and wine as metaphors. Many crave flowers and wine, but who knows of the flower-wine immortals? The primordial *qi* within the body is fresh and verdant. If one can consume it, harness it, drink it, and adorn oneself with it, the spirit becomes clear and the *qi* invigorated—this is the flower-wine immortal, present from ancient times to now. Yet this is not the brothel’s den or the meat-and-wine grove of the world.

Brothels and wine-meat dull the spirit; the *qi* of meat and wine is turbid, and brothels stir lust. Both are harmful, but lust is the greater danger. Those who refine themselves well eat when they encounter food, without seeking more, so they do not abstain from flesh yet forget it entirely. They see color as no-color, do not cling to beauty, and thus do not transgress lust, for lust is extinguished. Otherwise, essence scatters and fluids leak, causing no small harm. As the *Yellow Court Classic* says: *"Leaves fall, the tree withers, losing its verdant hue; only by sealing and guarding the light can one attain lasting peace."* Thus, to transgress lust is to lose the treasure of long life.

Meat and wine pass through the gut, yet the Dao remains in the heart—how could flowers and wine delude one? It is people who delude themselves with flowers and wine! Seek not mortal flowers and wine, and you will find immortal blossoms and wine. Immortal blossoms and wine aid the attainment of the Dao—they are the fresh, verdant flowers on the rootless tree, rich in flavor and vibrant in hue, most nourishing.

The immortal master opens the gate of the primordial and tells you: without such flowers and wine, the Dao is difficult to achieve.

Further, as Liu says, severing the side doors. As Li laments, solitary cultivation. *"The rootless tree, its blossoms solitary—pray tell, does yin and yang find their kind? The hen’s egg, though laid, cannot hatch a chick, for it has turned its back on the furnace of yin-yang transformation. A woman without a husband is a resentful maiden; a man without a wife is a widowed bachelor. Alas for the deluded, so utterly confused—sitting in stillness, cultivating alone, their qi withers away."*

Liu comments: The path of cultivating truth requires yin and yang to find their kind, only then can the treasure of the true spirit be perfected. If there is yin without yang, or yang without yin, this is a solitary blossom without its counterpart—the true spirit cannot form, just as the hen’s egg cannot hatch a chick. For it has turned its back on the furnace of yin-yang union and transformation. Likewise, a woman without a husband or a man without a wife—how can they bear offspring?

Those blind fools of the world, who do not fathom the principles of yin and yang or trace the source of transformation, muddle through their practice—some contemplating emptiness, some regulating breath, some visualizing spirits, some guarding cavities, some circulating *qi*—all are solitary cultivation in stillness, yin without yang. Not only do they fail to benefit nature and life, but they harm them, growing ever more desiccated with each passing day.

Li explains: *"Solitary"* refers to inner cultivation. Cultivating nature alone cannot establish life, for it is solitary and without a counterpart, failing to give rise to the treasure of life. It is like a hen without a rooster—though it may lay eggs, it cannot hatch chicks. Those today who cultivate nature to nurture *qi* do not realize their *qi* is but solitary yin.

To avoid desiccation, one must pair true yang with true yin—only then are they of the same kind. I ask those who cultivate the Dao: have you attained this pairing? Now, true yang is *yi* (righteousness), and true yin is the Dao. When *yi* and the Dao are paired, they are no longer solitary.

Yet within this lies three layered stages: first, true yin generates true yang; next, true yang pairs with true yin; then, from the intercourse of yin and yang, the true numinous *qi* of vastness is born. How could this be like the hen’s egg, difficult to hatch? Those who cannot hatch the chick have turned their backs on the principle of yin and yang and the furnace of creation.

Yin and yang are husband and wife. The Dao of the sages begins with husband and wife, and through them, the myriad things are transformed and born. The same holds for the men and women of the world. If a woman has no husband, she is solitary yin that cannot give life and becomes a resentful maiden. If a man has no wife, he is solitary yang that cannot be nurtured and becomes a widowed bachelor. This principle is clear and easy to understand, yet the deluded disciples of the world remain utterly confused. They believe that solitary cultivation in stillness can clarify the mind, reveal the nature, and allow one to ascend directly—all while neglecting the pairing of yin and yang. I fear that with each day of sitting and cultivating, they wander the halls of empty nothingness and play in the sea of extinction, until their *qi* grows ever more withered.

**Liu’s Note:** The pairing of yin and yang.
**Li’s Note:** The inversion of yin and yang.

The rootless tree, its flowers askew—
Departed from yin and yang, the Dao is incomplete.
Gold parted from wood, mercury parted from lead,
Yang widowed, yin solitary, each to one side.

In the world, yin and yang—man paired with woman—
Bear sons and grandsons, generation after generation.
Following the sequence makes one mortal; reversing it, immortal—
The difference lies solely in this inversion.

**Liu’s Commentary:**
The *Book of Changes* states: *"The alternation of yin and yang is called the Dao."* The *True Sayings of Awakening* says: *"When yin and yang find their kind, they unite in intercourse; when the two eights correspond, they naturally join in kinship."* If yin and yang are each askew—if yang stirs but yin does not respond, if yin seeks but yang does not beckon, if yang exceeds and yin falls short, or if yang flourishes while yin is deficient—then the flower of true numinosity is askew, neither centered nor upright, and the Dao remains incomplete.

A person’s true passion is like gold, true knowing like lead—both are firm. Numinous nature is like wood, numinous knowing like mercury—both are yielding. True passion and true knowing, firm yet prone to sinking; numinous nature and numinous knowing, yielding yet prone to floating. If nature seeks passion and passion returns to nature, if the true governs the numinous and the numinous returns to the true, then firm and yielding respond, yin and yang harmonize, and they transform into a single *qi*, with life’s mechanism enduring unceasingly.

But if passion does not return to nature, if the numinous does not return to the true, this is what is meant by *"gold parted from wood, mercury parted from lead, yang widowed, yin solitary, each to one side."* How then can one return to the root and revert to the origin, coalescing the elixir of true numinosity? Observe the world: when man and woman pair, they bear sons and grandsons, generation after generation, perpetuating the lineage. Thus, in the Dao of cultivating the true, when yin and yang unite, they give birth to immortals and sages, also perpetuating the lineage without end. The difference lies only in whether one follows the sequence or reverses it—mortals follow, immortals reverse. The distinction rests solely in this inversion.

This *"middle"* is profound in principle and most subtle in practice. It is not the middle between inner and outer, nor the middle of the body’s upper and lower. It is the middle of yin and yang’s intercourse, formless and imageless, called the root of heaven and earth, the cavity of yin and yang, the abode of life and death, the Gate of the Mysterious Female. Birth and death occur here; sagehood and worthiness are determined here; whether one becomes human or beast depends on this. If cultivators can plant their feet firmly here and reverse the flow, then in the space of inversion, calamity transforms into fortune, punishment into virtue. This is what is meant by *"the elixir is completed in a single hour."*

Alas! The *"middle"* is not easily known, and the *"inversion"* is also difficult to comprehend. The sexual arts take the place of man and woman’s union as the *"middle"* and the man’s absorption of the woman’s essence as *"inversion."* The circulation schools take the Yellow Court as the *"middle"* and the ascent of *qi* and descent of blood as *"inversion."* All these are but the beginnings of error—how could they fathom the meaning of the *"middle"* and *"inversion"* in the Dao of immortals? Diligent learners should discern this early.

**Li’s Explanation:**
*"Askew"* refers to yin and yang being parted, unable to complete the elixir. When yin and yang unite in the middle, the knife and spoon congeal, and the Dao’s arts are fully realized. Gold and wood, lead and mercury—these are yin and yang. The essence of wood and the nature of mercury belong to yin; the *qi* of gold and the passion of lead belong to yang. Essence and *qi* depend on each other, nature and passion unite in intercourse. Gold cherishes wood’s benevolence, wood loves gold’s righteousness; mercury goes forth to welcome lead, lead comes to join mercury. Only then is there no illness of separation, and the great medicine’s true body is born.

If yin is solitary and yang widowed, each to one side, then yin and yang do not pair, remaining askew and incomplete. How can they transform and give life to the utmost reality, perpetuating it for ten thousand generations? The method of pairing is similar for immortals and mortals—only mortals use the sequence, while immortals use the reverse.

Master Wu Yuan said that the *"middle"* and *"inversion"* are beyond people’s understanding; I say that even the *"reverse"* is unknown to them. To grasp the *"middle"* and *"inversion,"* one must first know the wondrous use of *"reverse."* If one knows *"reverse,"* then gold, wood, lead, and mercury are all within it, yin and yang, *qian* and *kun* are entirely inverted, and all events revolve within the *"reverse."* The medicine is obtained, the elixir returned—success may be expected in an instant.

**Liu’s Note:** When the medicine is born.
**Li’s Note:** The principle of *kun* and *shen.*

The rootless tree, its flowers renewed,
Born in the *kun* direction—*kun* is the person.

Pluck the flower and wear it, gather the flower’s heart,
Layer upon layer, its pistils glow with spring’s radiance.
The world does not fathom the principle within the flower—
A single secret of heaven’s mechanism is worth ten thousand gold.

Borrow the flower’s name, embody the flower’s form,
Each line of the *"Knocking on Hexagrams"* speaks truly.

**Liu’s Note:** *"New"* refers to the original substance long buried, suddenly reappearing. When the flower is renewed, its brilliance revives. Like the moon emerging in the southwest *kun* direction, beneath pure yin, a speck of subtle yang unfurls—akin to emptiness giving birth to light, the true spirit revealed, the original face restored. This original face is the undying true person within me. With this person, one is human; without it, one is not. It is what I receive from heaven to be human. Yet this true person rarely appears, not to be seen at will. Only in utter emptiness and profound stillness, when all conditions are stilled, does a fleeting image arise. Utter emptiness and profound stillness are the image of pure yin in *kun*, hence *"born in the kun direction—kun is the person."* This person has long been buried beneath dust and grime, leaving no trace. Once its image appears, it is the new flower—timing must not be missed. One must swiftly act, plucking and gathering it for oneself. *"Pluck the flower and wear it"* means to pluck the flower of this true person. *"Gather the flower’s heart"* means to gather the heart of this true person. Gradually plucking and gathering, from little to much, accumulating depth and radiating light, the true spirit remains undimmed. Then the flower’s pistils unfold layer by layer, all principles become luminous, following the heart’s intent wherever it leads, every step the Dao. Its splendor is like spring, yang qi spreading across the earth, flowers blooming everywhere. Yet this flower is possessed by all, seen by all, yet none comprehend it. Most let it slip by before their eyes. If one does grasp it, transcending the mundane to enter sagehood happens in an instant—hence *"a single secret of heaven’s mechanism is worth ten thousand gold."* The immortal elder, in compassion, borrows the flower’s name and embodies its form, now tangible, now intangible. Each line of *"Knocking on Hexagrams"* expounds the subtleties of the primordial, wishing for all to attain the Dao and each to become an immortal. Alas, the world does not fathom the principle within the flower, and some still wildly speculate with misguided practices like *"guiding the woman"* or *"chamber elixirs."* Even the immortal elder can do nothing about this—how lamentable!

**Li’s Explanation:** Master Wu Yuan speaks of the *"person"* as the original face, having once glimpsed this person, his words flow at length and his heart bears deep compassion, seeking to awaken both self and others. Yet the *"is"* in *"kun is the person"* remains obscure. The flower is likened to the person, and the person borrows the flower as metaphor. *"The flower is renewed"* is like a person returning to the root, cultivating emptiness and stillness, observing the solitary yang’s return—unawares, spring’s colors renew. This flower appears in the *kun* direction, meaning *kun* sees the flower, the flower sees the person, where the flower is born is where the person is born—hence *"kun is the person."* In elixir methods, lead is planted in the metal village, mercury sown in the fire land. Metal and fire reside in the southwest; the southwest gains its companion. Where metal and fire unite is precisely above the *kun* direction. This person is a golden body and fiery form, a mass of pure yang—our true qi, also called true emotion. Vague yet distinct, within it lies an image, hot as fire, radiant as a flower. The flower’s fragrance intoxicates like wine—obtaining it is like being drunk. At this moment, one must pluck and wear it without delay. One must further gather its heart, swallowing it whole. From flower to pistil, penetrating layer upon layer, truly it is a spring palace of splendor. The world knows only the exterior, not the interior, and thus cannot grasp the wondrous principle within the flower. The wondrous principle within the flower is pure heavenly mechanism. When the heavenly mechanism flows forth, a single secret is worth ten thousand gold. The fourth, fifth, sixth, and seventh lines here are all from Lü Zu’s *"Knocking on Hexagrams Song."* Master Feng said: *"Lü Zu borrows the flower’s name for the human body and the flower’s form for the person’s form. Each line I use from 'Knocking on Hexagrams' speaks with utmost truth and savor."* **Liu’s Note:** Seize the moment to gather it.

**Li’s Note:** Before the furnace, settle into stillness.

The rootless tree blooms in full profusion,
Fair features and delicate charm outshine powdered faces.
Guard against the monkey and horse, stubborn and unruly—
Raise the iron mask your mother bore.
Draw forth the true treasure-sword of the Azure Dragon,
Pluck every fresh blossom from the wall’s edge.
Catch the wind’s sail, return fully laden—
How could one pass the mountain of treasure empty-handed?

*"Wall’s edge"* may be rendered *"jade blossoms,"* and *"jade blossoms"* as *"wall’s edge"*—I have seen both. This annotation takes *"wall’s edge"* as more evocative, so I follow it.

**Liu’s Annotation:** When the primordial true spirit shines forth, one root branches into ten thousand forms. Gazing upon images in their season, nothing exists that is not a flower in full bloom. At the height of its flourishing, its splendor is fully revealed, its essence spent outwardly, easily drawn into rivalry and vanity, flaunting its allure. Hence it is said: *"Fair features and delicate charm outshine powdered faces."* At such a time, one must guard against peril and contemplate danger, firmly tether the monkey and horse, raise the iron mask your mother bore, and grasp the treasure-sword of the Azure Dragon. In the face of phenomena, forget emotion, pluck every fresh blossom from the wall’s edge, allowing not the slightest attachment to form or dissipation of true qi.

The *"iron mask your mother bore"* is the unfeeling, unknowing iron visage. The *"treasure-sword of the Azure Dragon"* is the true nature, unstained and unattached. The iron mask your mother bore is the treasure-sword of the Azure Dragon—both emerge from the same source but bear different names. In terms of essence, it is the iron mask your mother bore; in terms of function, it is the treasure-sword of the Azure Dragon. The iron mask is the settled body; the treasure-sword is the instrument of wisdom. Settling gives rise to wisdom; wisdom perfects settling. Settling and wisdom depend on each other, essence and function never parted.

The primordial true spirit is form yet emptiness, ever-responsive yet ever-still, without leakage or loss. This is what is meant by *"pluck every fresh blossom from the wall’s edge."* The blossoms at the wall’s edge have just emerged but not yet left the wall, when true qi has not yet dispersed. Plucking them at this moment leaves no dross, pure as heaven’s truth. Gradually they grow, gradually they are gathered; gradually they are plucked, gradually they are reaped—one must pluck until nothing remains to be plucked.

Alas! The great medicine is hard to encounter; the great method is hard to meet. Fortunate to have met it, the moment must not be missed. Catch the wind’s sail, swiftly gather the fresh blossoms, return fully laden—how could one pass the mountain of treasure empty-handed, only to regret it later?

**[Li’s Exegesis]**
"Abundance" refers to the moment of fullness. The beauty of a fair face and delicate features is likened to the primordial unity of qi—just as the Immortal Elder’s *Five Watches’ Daoist Ballad* says: *"When the host of yin is spent, the radiant yang season arrives, / A branch of spring’s hue, golden blossoms resplendent."* The "powdered-cluster contest" marks the birth of the medicine, the very hour when the Flower Demon vies in beauty. Ancient immortals warned: *"When the primordial appears, the Medicine Demon easily arises."* Without refining the self to utter purity—seeing beauty yet unmoved—who could seize the golden blossom in but half an instant? Thus it is said: *"Guard against the ape and horse, ever more stubborn."* This echoes the *One Branch Flower* ballad: *"Her celestial form, her ten delicate fingers, / Could never stir my intent-horse or heart-ape."* Don the iron mask of your innate face, summon your power of stillness, and *"Let her try—she’ll not sway you in the slightest."* Draw forth the true treasure-sword of the Azure Dragon, pluck every fresh blossom from the wall’s edge—this aligns with *"Repel the demon horde, / Angrily raise the keen-edged sword of wisdom, / Dare to gather / The blossoms newly emerged beyond the wall."* Wu Yuan equates the iron mask with *ding* (stabilization) and the treasure-sword with *hui* (wisdom), a true connoisseur’s insight. Yet unless *ding* and *hui* arise from self-refinement, they are not true *ding* or true *hui*—useless when the moment demands. The *One Branch Flower* says: *"Moment by moment, guard the intent-horse; / Instant by instant, lock the heart-ape. / Day and night, sleepless, / Refine the self without cease."* Only when you’ve forged yourself into *"a sea of purity, unstained by a single mote"* have you attained true *ding*. Only when you’ve become *"a night-shining pearl, suspended in the void"* have you attained true *ding*.

The "wall’s edge" describes blossoms that have emerged beyond the wall yet remain upon it—these are the "emerged blossoms," where the fire is purest and the timing most precise. Without a master’s transmission, none can comprehend this; without having traversed the path, none can know it. If you recognize the moment the flower-branch emerges beyond the wall and act to gather it, you wield the immortal’s skill. "Plucking every one" means drawing it all in with a single breath, swallowing it whole into your own domain—not the gradual gathering and gradual reaping. Gradual gathering and reaping belong to the later work of nurturing, drawing out, and replenishing. Seizing the wind’s sail, returning fully laden, the four signs converge in the elixir—swiftly set the River Chariot in motion to bear it back. How could one pass the mountain of treasure empty-handed? That mountain is the birthplace of the primordial.

In the alchemical method, what is refined becomes medicine; what is gathered becomes medicine; what is nurtured becomes fire. Yet where there is medicine, there is fire—not the fire of gentle nurturing. This chapter’s annotation rightly interprets the gathering of medicine.

**[Liu’s Exegesis]** Advancing and retreating yin and yang.
**[Li’s Exegesis]** Nurturing and returning the elixir.

*The Rootless Tree, its blossoms in flight—*
*Once shed, they reopen on a fixed date.*
*When the Lead Blossom appears, at the exhaustion of gui,*
*Once more the Western Garden’s branches bloom full.*

*Just as the moon’s waning light was gathered away,*
*Swiftly turn to the morning sun to mend the monk’s robe.*
*This mystery—rarely known in the world—*
*Must be pondered with immortals, in careful detail.*

In Wu Yuan’s annotated edition, *"swiftly turn"* replaces *"again toward,"* differing in word but not in meaning. However, *"just as"* is rendered as *"waning,"* and *"gathering away"* is misconstrued as the removal of the human heart’s selfish desires—thus expelling the thief—leading to a double error.

**[Liu’s Annotation]**
When a person’s spirit declines and true numen dissipates, it is like blossoms scattering and withering. Yet even fallen blossoms have their season of return; so too does the enfeebled person have a path of restoration. What is this path of restoration? It is the path of returning yang within yin, of reopening what has withered. The "Lead Blossom" is the radiance of the Dao-heart’s true knowing. "Gui water" is the selfish desire of the human heart’s guest qi. When the Lead Blossom appears, the Dao-heart remains undimmed; when gui water is exhausted, the human heart abides in stillness. With the Dao-heart undimmed and the human heart still, the original numen suffers no loss or harm—its inherent perfection is restored, and the blossoms, once shed, bloom anew upon the branches.

Because gui water must be exhausted, *"just as the moon’s waning light was gathered away."* Because the Lead Blossom must appear, *"swiftly turn to the morning sun to mend the monk’s robe."* The human heart’s selfish desires are like an intruding guest qi, like the moon’s waning light. The Dao-heart’s true knowing is the original vital qi, like the sun’s radiance. Gathering the waning moonlight sweeps away the human heart’s selfish desires—thus retreating yin. Turning to the morning sun to mend the robe gradually augments the Dao-heart’s true knowing—thus advancing yang. Retreat yin until yin qi is utterly gone—only then is the waning light fully gathered. Advance yang until yang qi is wholly pure—only then is the robe fully mended. With yin exhausted and yang complete, one returns to the origin and restores the root. The original face is fully revealed—how could the promise of reopening after withering be mere words? This celestial mechanism of withering and reopening is scarcely known in the world. To grasp it, one must ponder it with immortals, tracing its beginning and end.

**[Li’s Exegesis]**
Wu Yuan’s annotation is excellent in principle, yet it does not address this chapter’s core meaning. Here, the discussion concerns the nurturing and returning of the elixir. "Flight" signifies ascent and descent—the morning advance of yang fire and the evening retreat of yin tally. "Shedding" refers to the elixir’s attainment, the leaf’s return to the root, precisely denoting the restoration of life. After life is restored, one draws upon the external furnace’s metal-water, extracts lead to replenish mercury, and nurtures the spirit-embryo. As *Awakening to Reality* says: *"The external furnace’s increase and decrease require effort."* As the *Triplex Unity* says: *"Observe and tend with care, / Discern and regulate cold and warmth. / Cycle through the twelve nodes, / And when each is complete, begin anew."* Master Feng says: *"At midnight and noon, focus the fire-tally; / At dawn and dusk, bathe the golden elixir."* Thus it is said: *"They reopen on a fixed date."* Seizing the wind’s sail, returning fully laden—when the four signs converge in the elixir, swiftly set the River Chariot in motion to bear it back. How could one pass the mountain of treasure empty-handed? That mountain is the birthplace of the primordial.

The "reopened" entity refers to the flower branches of the Western Garden mentioned below. When the lead-flower appears at the exhaustion of *gui*, the great medicine of the returned elixir arises after *gui* is born—once lead is born, it must be gathered. Gold, when distant from the full moon, is unfit for consumption; only after the initial surge of *gui*-water on the 5,048th day does one deliberate and apply effort, seizing the foremost treasure of the first meridian—this is the supreme method. *Gui* is born on the fourteenth day and exhausted on the fifteenth, when a single ray of yang light emerges—this is the precise moment. In terms of the human body, it is nothing but the great movement within great stillness. Gather and ingest it, and the returned elixir is formed. Yet once the great elixir is obtained, external lead is born anew, and the alchemist must take it for nurturing purposes, hence the saying: *"Once more, the Western Garden’s branches bloom with flowers."*

*"Just as the moon is faced, it is gathered away"*—this refers to drawing lead. *"Then toward the morning sun, the mendicant’s robe is patched"*—this refers to replenishing mercury. The method of gathering requires clarity on the moon’s waxing and waning, hence the reference to "facing the moon." The method of patching requires the sun’s dawn and dusk, hence the metaphor of "morning sun." Such are the subtle meanings of the mysterious arts. These profound subtleties are rarely known in the world; to understand them, one must seek the meticulous guidance of realized immortals, lest error arise.

**Liu’s Verse:**
The rootless tree, its flowers in full bloom,
Plucked within the crescent-moon furnace.
Prolonging life, dispelling illness and misfortune,
Best to forge good companions and prepare the *dharma-wealth*.

From this, the celestial treasure may be attained—
Let the deluded masses mock my folly.
I urge the worthy: cease your cunning,
Without an enlightened teacher, do not force guesses.

**Liu’s Annotation:**
The treasure of primordial true spirit is formless and imageless, without direction or location—how then is it gathered to form the returned elixir? Though formless and imageless, without direction or location, it too has a time of flowering. When it blooms, within the indistinct arises form; within the profound obscurity, essence appears. This essence is utterly true, containing within it a sign, its symbolic form resembling a crescent moon. Ordinary practitioners, unaware of the ancients’ intent in taking this image, variously misidentify it as the space between the kidneys, the bright hall between the brows, or the stubborn fleshly heart. Even worse, some demonic impostors point to a woman’s birth passage—grievously mistaken!

What is meant by the "crescent moon"? It is the moon in its reclining aspect. In the heavens, on the third day of each lunar month, beneath the dark body of the southwest *kun* earth, the crescent’s light emerges (●), its glow reclining—hence the name "crescent moon." In the hexagrams, it is the faint yang beginning to stir beneath pure yin (☷), forming *Fu* (復). In the human being, it is the movement after extreme stillness, the white arising in an empty chamber, the heart of heaven and earth stirring to life. This heart contains a single point of primordial ancestral *qi*, faintly revealing its traces from the depths of darkness, resembling the light of a crescent moon. Because this single point of ancestral *qi* is the root of heaven and earth, the origin of the five phases, capable of creating immortals and buddhas, sages and worthies, and securing nature and life, it is also called the "crescent-moon furnace."

This heart of heaven and earth aligns its virtue with heaven and earth, its brightness with the sun and moon, its sequence with the four seasons, and its auspices with spirits and deities—rarely encountered, difficult to meet. If one is fortunate enough to chance upon it, the moment must not be missed. One must swiftly act to pluck it, sealing and guarding it carefully to prevent leakage. Thus can life be prolonged and illness and misfortune dispelled. Yet such matters of prolonging life and dispelling misfortune cannot be undertaken by those without great merit and conduct, nor accomplished by those without great resolve and strength. One must externally cultivate good affinities to refine virtue, and internally prepare *dharma-wealth* with sincerity, only then can the imperial ultimate be moved to bestow the celestial treasure.

*Dharma-wealth* is not worldly wealth, but the wealth within the Dao—namely, single-minded devotion, true practice, and unwavering resolve, the *good-wealth* of an undivided mind. As the Perfected One of Upper Yang said: *"If heaven resists, one must seek it with *dharma-wealth* and utmost sincerity. To obtain the celestial treasure, human affairs must be fully exhausted. If human affairs are not exhausted, there is no *dharma-wealth*; without *dharma-wealth*, to vainly desire the celestial treasure is difficult."* How can one seeking the celestial treasure fail to first prepare *dharma-wealth*?

The celestial treasure is no other thing than the golden elixir refined from true spirit, the returned elixir restored to the heart of heaven and earth. Called "true spirit" or "heart of heaven and earth" when speaking of the unrefined state, it is termed "celestial treasure" or "golden elixir" once refined and matured. With the celestial treasure obtained, the ten thousand existences are emptied, root and dust are transformed, and one enters the state of unknowing, without self or others—let the deluded masses mock my folly. This folly requires the oral transmission and mind-to-mind instruction of an enlightened teacher; it cannot be known through forced guesswork. As the immortal elder said: *"I urge the worthy: cease your cunning, / Without an enlightened teacher, do not force guesses."* His warnings to later generations are many.

**Li’s Explanation:**
"Opening" refers to the initial sprouting of the jade bud. The crescent-moon furnace has no fixed location or time within the human body, for it arises with the first stirring of yang *qi*, light within stillness—hence the comparison to the new moon born from extreme darkness. This moon in the heavens has its *geng* direction and its third-day timing, both place and time identifiable. But within the human body, the place it appears is the *geng* direction, the moment it appears is the third day—neither can be predetermined.

What is the form of the crescent moon? It is as depicted in Liu’s diagram. "Crescent" implies both reclining and facing: nine parts dark, one part light, the yang *qi* newly born, thus white light appearing above as a crescent. What people today describe, having such a shape, is a facing moon, not a crescent moon—how then could it be "plucked down"?

Those who speak of "plucking it down" refer to its *qi* being in the void. When alchemists (*dan* practitioners) perceive this single thread of white light, they must not rashly set the *heche* (River Chariot) in motion. Instead, they should employ a spirit of serene detachment and an intention of harmonious equilibrium, gathering it from where the *qi* arises—hence the saying, *"Pluck it down into the reclining-moon crucible."* At the moment when spirit and *qi* unite, suddenly the yang light manifests in full, resembling the full moon of the fifteenth night—this is the Mid-Autumn Moon, the moment when *qi* is abundant and the tide surges. Only then should one drive it along the Yellow Path, escort it to the Yellow Court, whereby longevity may be extended and illness and calamity diminished.

"Good companions and *fa-cai*" refer to those of like mind who cherish the Dao and willingly offer their wealth to protect the Dharma and assist others in attaining the Way. In his commentary on this chapter in *Cultivating Reality*, Wu Yuan mistakenly interprets *fa-cai* as something within the body—this is merely a corrective against greed. Speaking impartially, *fa-cai* has two aspects: the inner *fa-cai*, which is true gold, and the outer *fa-cai*, which is a provisional treasure. Though borrowing the provisional to refine the true is indispensable, one should not covet it excessively. When the Heavenly Treasure is refined, one may feign foolishness and conceal brilliance, holding jade within and bearing uncut gems—though the deluded masses may mock one as a fool, all such matters may be dismissed without concern.

Yet how easily can the Heavenly Treasure be refined! Without an enlightened master, one cannot know its secrets.

**Liu Guan’s verse:**
*The Reverted Elixir ripens to perfection.*

**Li Zhi’s verse:**
*The Reverted Elixir enters the mountains.*
*The rootless tree—its blossoms now full,*
*Bearing fruit, its flavor complete.*
*Like the crimson tangerine, round as a pellet,*
*Guard its embankments, never neglect its care.*
*Learn the method of plants gathering their essence,*
*Return to life, revert to the root, restore the origin.*

**Liu’s commentary:**
The treasure of true numen departs but returns, the old made new again, unharmed and undiminished, restored to its original state—this is the blossom’s fullness. "Fullness" speaks of the fruit’s ripening, its flavor complete. When the Golden Elixir is accomplished, the Five Agents converge, the Four Images harmonize, benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom, and trust merge into one principle, essence, spirit, ethereal soul, corporeal soul, and intention return to a single *qi*. Further refined by the firing of the talisman, it transforms into a purely yang substance, vibrant and fluid, red as the crimson tangerine, round as a pellet. At this time, one must guard its embankments, never neglecting its care for even a moment, concealing brilliance and nurturing obscurity. Learn the method of plants gathering their essence, return to life, revert to the root, and restore the origin, awaiting the stillness that gives rise to movement, uniting with the primordial to complete the Great Reversion.

This speaks of the Reverted Elixir’s accomplishment and the subsequent pursuit of the Great Elixir. For the Reverted Elixir merely restores the original substance of the present life—an affair of transcending the mundane, as Lü Zu said: *"With three leads, only one lead is obtained; the golden fruit and immortal sprout have yet to take form."* The Great Elixir, however, builds upon the Reverted Elixir to undertake the work of ascent—an affair of entering sagehood, as Lü Zu said: *"Reinstall the furnace, reset the tripod, ride the tiger and mount the dragon to leave the mortal realm."*

If one only refines the Reverted Elixir without further pursuing the Great Elixir, one merely completes the initial stage of the Dao, becoming nothing more than a whole person—how could one enter the realm of the sages? The so-called "selecting a numinous site" and "establishing a Dao hermitage" refer not to external locations but to the numinous site and Dao hermitage within. When cultivation reaches the stage of reverting to the root and restoring life, the work of the Reverted Elixir is complete. Nurturing and warming it, spirit and *qi* become abundant, and the elixir becomes numinous—this is the Numinous Elixir. From this numinous site, reinstall the furnace and reset the tripod—this is establishing the Dao hermitage. "Selecting a numinous site" means awaiting the arising of the first yang. The first yang is the yang born from extreme stillness within the primordial—unlike the Reverted Elixir, which arises from the primordial within the postnatal. Though both are primordial, there is a distinction of before and after. To complete the Great Reversion, one must unite with the yang within the primordial—hence the saying, *"Uniting with the primordial completes the Great Reversion."* Only when the Great Elixir is accomplished does one enter the foundation of sagehood. If the Great Elixir remains unaccomplished, it is but a halfway endeavor, not the full achievement of Dao cultivation.

The Buddhist scriptures say:
*"The unmoving man at the hundred-foot pole—though he has entered, it is not yet true. Advance another step at the hundred-foot pole, and the ten directions become his entire body."*
Does this not refer to the completion of the Great Reversion?

**Li’s explanation:**
"Full" refers to the Reverted Elixir, signifying the unity of nature and emotion. Its method lies in attaining emptiness and guarding stillness. Observing the moon’s arising in the *geng* direction, likened to the first stirring of yang *qi*, one mobilizes one’s mercury to meet it. External contact sparks internal resonance, and internal touch evokes external response—like a magnet attracting iron, it is drawn into the Elixir Field, becoming the External Elixir. This method is supremely simple and easy, as the ancient immortals said: *"It can be accomplished in less than half a watch."*

The Elixir has two grades, which may be divided into three vehicles. The three vehicles of elixir refinement all gather the lead blossom and are called Reverted Elixirs, differing only in scale, sequence, and priority.

The first is the Initial Vehicle, called the Coagulated Elixir, also known as the Jade Liquid Reverted Elixir. Within the postnatal, it returns to the primordial, departing *gui* to take *ren*, nurturing it with jade liquid to round the Internal Elixir—this is the study of fulfilling one’s nature, the Immortal of Human Rank.

The second is the Upper Vehicle, named the Reverted Elixir, also called the Sevenfold Return. Using the primordial returned from the postnatal, it plants the seed of the primordial, establishing the Elixir Mother—this is the study of establishing life, the Immortal of Earth Rank.

The third is the Great Vehicle, named the Ninefold Cyclically Transformed Great Reverted Elixir. Its medicine is likened to the full moon of the fifteenth night, primordial within the primordial. When the fire arrives, it moves, transforming into white liquid, which is swallowed into the abdomen and congealed to utmost hardness—this is the Golden Liquid Reverted Elixir, supremely numinous and wondrous, attaining sagehood and becoming a perfected one. This is the study of uniting nature and life, the Immortal of Heaven Rank.

When the flower is perfectly round, this speaks of the foundation of the Upper Vehicle’s elixir. The reckoning has borne one fruit, gathered one harvest—yet in its method of refining lead, the two substances mutually ingest each other, and the Five Phases are all complete. This is called "the fullness of flavor." Though this elixir is not the Great Vehicle’s elixir, it is already radiant as a red tangerine, round and smooth as a pellet. At this stage of practice, one must silently attend to it, continuously preserving it as if it were ever-present. Otherwise, if one’s embrace grows distant, it may easily scatter and be lost. Thus, one must guard and protect the embankment, never allowing the immortal leisure to slip away.

Learn the method of gathering the heads of grasses and trees—what the *Book of Changes* calls "with this, wash the heart and retire to concealment." Returning to life, reverting to the root, and returning to the original source—what the *Cantong Qi* calls "the true dwelling in whiteness, square and round, a mere inch in diameter."

Choose a numinous site and establish a Dao hermitage. Wu Yuan explains that the numinous site and Dao hermitage reside within the human body, yet they also have both inner and outer applications. For the inner numinous site and Dao hermitage, one must seek the purity of the numinous terrace, the harmony of spirit and qi, and therein establish the "Peaceful Hermitage of the Daoist’s Heart." For the outer numinous site and Dao hermitage, one must seek a numinous mountain and blessed land, free from the disturbance of worldly dust, and therein establish the "Thatched Hermitage of the Daoist’s White Clouds." In this way, both the heart and its traces are purified, true power fills to the brim, yang is born within lead, and when gathered and united, the Dao is accomplished in the Ninefold Cyclically Transformed Great Reverted Elixir—then the sagely work is complete.

**Liu’s Saying:** The qi of True Unity.
**Li’s Saying:** The place of intercourse.

The rootless tree—its flower flourishes.
Speak of "rootless," yet it has a root.
The three talents’ aperture, the two and five’s essence:
When Heaven and Earth unite, the myriad things are born.
When the sun and moon unite, cold and heat follow in order.
When man and woman unite, conception begins.
How clear it is—told to you,
Yet still, I fear we may meet and not recognize it as true.

**Liu’s Commentary:**
The treasure of the primordial true numen possesses all principles and responds to the myriad affairs. Still and unmoving, yet when stimulated, it penetrates all—nowhere is there obstruction, nowhere does it fail to succeed. This is the flourishing of the flower. Since the flower flourishes, though the tree is rootless, the flower has a root. What root is this? It is the aperture of the three talents that generate Heaven, Earth, and Man, the essence of the wondrous union of yin-yang and the Five Phases. Because it is the aperture of the three talents and the essence of the two and five, it is born prior to Heaven and Earth yet hidden within them. One qi divides into yin and yang, and yin and yang unite to form one qi. Thus, when Heaven and Earth’s yin and yang above and below unite, they merge into one qi and the myriad things are born. When the sun and moon’s yin and yang come and go in union, they merge into one qi and cold and heat follow in order. When man and woman’s yin and yang unite, conception begins. Observing Heaven and Earth, the sun and moon, man and woman—only when one yin and one yang unite is there creation. From this, we know that the Dao of nature and life cannot be completed without the union of yin and yang into one. This one qi is the root of nature and life, the aperture of life and death. With this aperture, yin and yang unite and generate life; without this qi, yin and yang turn away from each other and bring death. Human life and death lie solely in the presence or absence of this qi. Yet people do not know what this qi is or where it resides. Some mistake it for the qi of breathing, or circulate it upward and downward in the Yellow Court, or gather it in the Cinnabar Field, or between the brows, or in the Heavenly Valley, or behind the brain—endless strange and bizarre notions, all ultimately leading to emptiness and loss.

What they do not realize is that the primordial qi of True Unity is invisible, inaudible, and intangible. The sage shapes the real into the formless and the existent into the nonexistent. What is real and existent are true yin and true yang; what is formless and nonexistent is the qi of the two eights’ waxing and waning. When these two are shaped, one qi resides in the center, congealing into the elixir—this is the work of the empty void. How can it be guessed at with things of form and image? How can it be made with apertures that have location and direction? Since the immortal elder saw that people did not recognize this one qi, he pointed to the aperture of the three talents and the essence of the two and five, and further illustrated it with the union of Heaven and Earth, the sun and moon, man and woman—clearly indicating this one qi to people, only fearing that they might meet it yet fail to recognize it as true.

Wu Yuan, boldly and unafraid of blame, now transmits the immortal elder’s spirit and intent, clearly explaining it to all. Know that the primordial qi of True Unity is no other thing—it is the qi of a single point of true numen. Because this qi is firm, strong, centered, and upright, it is called True Unity; because this qi is easily known and simply capable, it is called true numen. True Unity and true numen, utterly devoid of dross, are thus called primordial things. True Unity and true numen emerge from the same source with different names—they are not two separate things. Does anyone recognize the true?

**Li’s Explanation:**
"Flourishing" means thoroughfare. The thoroughfare of one qi emerges from the word "union" below. Flowers grow on trees, trees grow from roots, and roots grow from nothingness—thus, the rootless has a root. The rootless root is the root that generates Heaven, Earth, and Man. This root is a single aperture of emptiness and nothingness, hence called the aperture of the three talents. This aperture is the place of intercourse, thus it is said, "the three talents’ aperture, the two and five’s essence." The two and five: Heaven’s five is one five, Earth’s ten is another five—thus, the two and five are two earths. When the two earths unite, the "knife-point" elixir is formed. The *Mud Pill* says: "The Mysterious Pass’s one aperture—none recognize it. This is the knife-point elixir, most wondrous and rare."

Here is the translation:

---

For the place where the two and five unite in essence is the very source from which the elixir is born. The great practitioner, recognizing this aperture of emptiness and nothingness as the site of intercourse, must be able to draw the primordial qi from the void, where its function in union is most profound! Thus, when Heaven and Earth unite, the myriad things are born; when the sun and moon unite, cold and heat follow in order; when man and woman unite, conception begins—all these are proofs of intercourse. This principle is perfectly clear, easily understood by all, yet no one understands it. The immortal masters, in their vast compassion, explain it to you: you need only meet at the place where the two eights converge, merging the two qi into one mass—then the great elixir may be born. Yet one fears that when dragon and tiger meet, they may exhale the qi of the two bowstrings, and the alchemist may fail to recognize it truly.

Another [Liu’s] saying: *"The golden essence blooms in splendor."*
[Li’s] saying: *"Recognize the golden essence."*

The rootless tree—its flowers are most fine,
Facing the scene, forget emotion, and play in the moonlight’s glow.
When the golden essence flourishes, its radiance dazzles the eye—
Do not mistake the melon in the garden.

The five metals and eight stones are all false,
The myriad herbs and thousand formulas are all amiss.
The golden toad, the jade crow—
Recognize them truly, and you are a master.

The *Wu Yuan* annotated edition reads *"when the moon opens month by month"* for *"facing the scene, forget emotion."*

[Liu’s commentary:] The primordial numinous treasure is firm and strong, centered and upright, pure and refined—its flowers are most fine. When they are at their finest, like the moon’s radiance unfolding, the golden essence flourishes, and one should contemplate it, lest it be missed before one’s eyes. *"Month by month it opens"* means it opens in due season, not out of season, following the moon’s fixed cycle, with movement and stillness in constant order, never deviating by the slightest.

The golden essence is the luminous essence of metal; in the moon, it is called moonlight; in man, it is called true essence. True essence is the essence of true numinosity, never dimmed, hence likened to moonlight and golden essence. The true numinosity of man is not easily known, but observing the moon’s truth reveals it; the true numinosity of man is not easily seen, but observing the moon’s radiance and the metal’s essence makes it visible. The essence and splendor of all things decay over time, yet the moon’s radiance opens month by month, and the golden essence never diminishes for ten thousand years. Just so is man’s true essence—though at times it may seem unrefined, this is due to the obscuring of postnatal yin qi, while its original substance has never perished.

When the golden essence flourishes, true essence flourishes; when true essence is at its peak, it illuminates the world, its qi filling the cosmos. White snow flies in the sky, yellow sprouts cover the earth, golden light dazzles the eye—left and right, everywhere are flowers. Yet this true essence has no form, no image, neither color nor emptiness. It cannot be sought with intention, nor guarded without intention; it can only be apprehended by spirit, not spoken by the mouth. Though it is bright and clear, manifest and complete, seen by all yet recognized by none, it is most difficult to recognize truly. The cultivator must delve deeply, investigating the subtlest principles with true knowledge and clear insight, before taking action—lest one mistake the false for the true, or seize upon what seems right but is not, and thus pluck the wrong melon in the garden.

Those blind practitioners of the world, who mistakenly believe the golden essence to be a tangible thing, may refine the five metals and eight stones or ingest the myriad herbs and thousand formulas—yet these are not of our kind. How could they form the elixir and extend life? Are they not greatly mistaken?

The toad is a creature of water, belonging to yin; yet when called *"golden,"* it is the yang within yin, the white within black—this is my true knowing. The crow is a creature that flies above, belonging to yang; yet when called *"jade,"* it is the yin within yang, the feminine within the masculine—this is my numinous knowing. Only true knowing and numinous knowing are of the same kind as myself, the treasures of my nature and life. Taking these two and uniting them to form the elixir, true yet utterly numinous, numinous yet utterly true—when true and numinous do not scatter, they merge with the heavenly principle, neither color nor emptiness, neither born nor destroyed. What is called moonlight is this; what is called golden essence is this. When the moon’s radiance opens and the golden essence flourishes, how could one not attain longevity?

Yet most people do not recognize what true knowing and numinous knowing truly are. If one recognizes them truly, one is a seasoned master of the Dao—none who do so fail to attain the Way. Alas! In the path of the golden elixir, a hair’s breadth of error leads one a thousand miles astray. How many truly recognize it?

**[Li’s Explanation]**
"Excellent" signifies beauty—the designation for the golden flower. Alchemists call true lead the "beautiful golden flower." As the *Cantong Qi* states: *"Lead’s body is black without, yet harbors a golden flower within."* From this black lead, one extracts white gold, pairs it with cinnabar mercury, and produces the primordial qi. This is precisely the beautiful golden flower. Returning it to oneself forms the returned elixir, yet the returned elixir must first refine the self. When self-refinement is pure, the returned elixir comes easily.

*"Facing scenes yet forgetting emotion"* describes the state after self-refinement is perfected: all beautiful sights stir no desire, and one’s sole focus is this single point of true qi. This true qi is called "moon radiance." Why is it also named "moon radiance"? Because the moon’s fullness reveals the timing of qi. As the *Wuzhen Pian* says: *"On the fifteenth of the eighth month, admire the toad’s glow—precisely when golden essence flourishes."* This aligns with the method of admiring moon radiance.

The moon waxes from the third day, which immortals compare to tender qi; by the fifteenth, it is full, which they liken to qi at its peak. When qi is full, golden essence thrives. Golden essence is the manifestation within moon radiance—same origin, different names. When it flourishes, yellow sprouts fill the crucible, and white snow suffuses the sky. The enlightened eye sees it blazing like a flower. The alchemist gathers it with the sword that reaches heaven, seizes the moment to stoke the fire, and refines it into the returned elixir. This flower alone is the true prize. Never discard the real flower to pluck false gourds from the garden, lest you lament your error.

Not only are gourds mistaken—even the five metals and eight minerals are false, not true; the myriad herbs and thousand formulas are all deviant, not correct. What seeks neither falsity nor deviation? Only this golden essence. Where does this golden essence arise? Observe the golden toad and jade crow—these are its birthplaces. The toad, a yin creature of water, is called "gold," for it is true yang within Kan; the crow, a yang creature of the sky, is called "jade," for it is true yin within Li. True yin and true yang interact, generating the qi of the two crescents, which in turn produces the true unity of qi. Moon radiance and golden essence are both this substance—only one must recognize it truly. If one does, one is a seasoned master, clear in fire timing and discerning of lead.

**[Liu’s Note]**
Gathering the medicinal ingredients.

**[Li’s Note]**
Plucking the yellow flower.

The Rootless Tree blooms with abundant flowers,
Scattered across the earth yet barred by the River of Love.
Hard to pluck, what can be done?
Step by step, tread into the Dragon-Tiger’s den.

Once the yellow flower is gathered and borne back to the cave,
One’s name is inscribed in the Purple Palace, never to fade.
Laughing heartily, amidst the white clouds,
Prepare the celestial ladder to ascend the Great Luo.

**[Wu Yuan’s Note]**
Taking *ài* (love) as *ài* (obstacle) is mistaken.

**[Liu’s Note]**
Throughout the cosmos, the qi of the Dao fills all;
where the light of true spirit shines, there the flowers bloom—
so many, scattered across the earth.
Yet though flowers bloom everywhere, people fail to recognize them,
as if blocked by a river’s barrier.
Though one may wish to pluck them, it is most difficult,
and nothing can be done.
This difficulty arises because all in the world are bound by fame and profit,
entangled in love and affection,
abandoning the true to grasp the false,
taking suffering as joy.
Step by step, they walk into the perilous lair of Dragon and Tiger,
opposing the Way of life and destiny—
thus the flowers are hard to pluck.
But if one is a courageous man, resolute and decisive,
casting off worldly ties at once,
seeking a teacher’s oral instructions,
using the false to cultivate the true,
then among the myriad flowers, one may select and gather
the most central and upright yellow flower,
bear it back to the cave,
nurture it into the elixir,
prolonging life and enhancing vitality.
Thus one’s name is inscribed in the Purple Palace, never to fade.
The yellow flower is the flower of central hue in the central earth of *wù-jǐ*,
pure and upright, brimming with vital force,
free of杂气.
When this vital force returns to the cave,
spring endures through all seasons,
as if dwelling in a nest of white clouds,
carefree and at ease—
another realm beyond the human world.
How could one not laugh heartily, knowing such joy?
At this stage, the Returned Elixir is attained.
Then, setting up the furnace anew and reestablishing the crucible,
one undertakes the work of ascent,
preparing the celestial ladder to become a Great Luo Heavenly Immortal.

**[Li’s Explanation]**
The innate substance of the primordial,
unaugmented by the worthy, undiminished by the foolish,
is possessed by all, born in each—
thus the flowers bloom in abundance.
Yet they are obstructed by the River of Love,
causing the original to be buried.
Though flowers bloom across the earth,
how can they be reached when the River of Love stands between?
The River of Love is the human heart of the posterior world of desire,
which obstructs the heart of the Dao of the prior heavens.
Once the Dao-heart is blocked,
plucking the immortal flower becomes difficult.
What, then, can be done?
The immortal master tells the seeker:
One must step by step seek, journey by journey inquire,
crossing one mountain after another, fording one river after another,
entering the Dragon-Tiger’s den—
only then may one glimpse the original.
This Dragon emerges from fire,
this Tiger arises from water and within it.
From the posterior heavens, they exhale the qi of the prior heavens.
The Dragon hides in yin, the Tiger in yang;
yin and yang unite, giving birth to Dragon and Tiger.
Dragon and Tiger unite, producing the golden flower.
This golden flower lies in the southwest, the *kūn* direction,
where earth is yellow—thus the flower is also yellow.
If one can gather this yellow flower and carry it back to the cave,
forming the golden elixir,
then one’s name is inscribed in the Purple Palace, never to fade.
Laughing heartily—profound mastery attained.
Amidst the white clouds—deeply settled in tranquility.
Should one wish to advance further toward Heavenly Immortality,
one must again set up the furnace and crucible,
erect the celestial ladder—
only then can one become a Great Luo Heavenly Immortal.
Those who aspire to Heavenly Immortality
may thus prepare the celestial ladder.

**[Liu’s Note]**
Yang arises within yin.

**[Li’s Note]**
The medicine is produced within the crucible.

The Rootless Tree blooms with fragrant flowers,
In the lead crucible, warm and luminous, the treasure appears.
Upon the golden bridge, gazing toward the winding river,
Within the moon, the sun is clearly seen.

Swallowing the raven’s liver and hare’s marrow,
Exchanging all the dust-laden, old intestines.
In the realm of fame and profit, the land of love and affection,
Never again will one turn back, futilely toiling in vain.

**[Liu’s Annotation]**
The primordial true spirit gathers all virtues, unifying myriad perfections—its qi is most fragrant. At the moment of its purest fragrance, it is the time when the lead crucible glows warmly with treasure-light. The "lead crucible" is true knowing. Through this true knowing, one can cast off the old and embrace the new, cultivate immortality and attain truth—hence it is called the lead crucible. The "treasure" is the treasure of true spirit; without true knowing, true spirit does not manifest. For true knowing embodies the heart-mind of the Dao, and within the heart-mind of the Dao resides the primordial true unity of qi—this is called true spirit. The "warmth of the lead crucible" signifies the balance of firmness and softness, neither leaning nor bias, thus establishing the crucible. When the crucible is established, the heart-mind of the Dao emerges; as the heart-mind of the Dao emerges, the light of true spirit gradually arises—this is called the manifestation of treasure-light.

The "golden bridge" is metal; the "winding river" is water. Ascending the golden bridge to gaze upon the winding river reveals the image of metal within water. Metal within water is yang arising within yin—this is the sun seen within the moon, which is also the warm glow of the lead crucible manifesting treasure-light. When the light of the lead crucible appears, yin and yang unite in virtue, spirit and qi ride the moment in harmony. Thus, one enters the womb of creation, holding it fast without letting it depart—this is called "swallowing the raven’s liver and hare’s marrow." The raven’s liver is blue-green, the essence of the sun, symbolizing the numinous nature of numinous knowing; the hare’s marrow is white, the radiance of the moon, symbolizing the true emotion of true knowing. Swallowing the raven’s liver and hare’s marrow unites nature and emotion, so that emotion does not stray from nature, and nature does not stray from emotion—true to the point of numinosity, numinous to the point of truth. When nature and emotion become one, true spirit remains undimmed: round as a pearl, radiant as flame, bare and pure, unadorned and free. All postnatal accumulations are purged, the heart-mind of the Dao abides forever, the human heart is extinguished for good—thus the dust-laden, old intestines are wholly exchanged. With the intestines renewed, all things become empty; fame, profit, love, and affection—what is there to cling to?

**[Li’s Explication]**
The fragrance is neither perceptible nor foul—utterly pure and pristine, the fragrance of the primordial first appearing, unstained by the postnatal. The "lead crucible" is the external crucible. The method of refining lead requires establishing the external crucible in the southwest, called the "Land of Kun" or "Mother Kun." The mother’s body is inherently empty and must rely on the father’s solar essence to produce lead. The solar essence is dragon mercury—here, the "raven’s liver" below. The dragon is the eldest son, who takes the father’s place and enters the mother’s embrace, where qi and essence intermingle, and the crucible of primordial true lead is thus established. Ancestor Zhong said: *"The great yang moves into the bright moon"*—this is the method of establishing the crucible. The line below, *"Within the moon, the sun is clearly seen,"* refers to this moment of warmth. When the lead crucible glows warmly, the treasure-light appears. The "treasure-light" is the light of the treasure of life; when this light manifests, it is the primordial qi, its white image emerging from between the brows. Ancestor Lü said: *"The warm lead crucible, its light piercing the curtains,"* and also: *"Examine the space between the brows—there lies the sign."* This describes the same vision.

The "golden bridge" is the magpie bridge below, located on the path of the southwest, where the radiance of metal qi shines. The "winding river" is the qi encircling the magpie bridge, its light reflected in the southwest. Some past commentators, glossing Ancestor Lü’s line *"Upon the winding river, the moon’s radiance gleams pure,"* mistakenly identified the winding river as the twelve curves of the small intestine, straying into demonic delusion. Others pointed to the space between mouth and nose—an even graver descent into delusion. Only Master Chen Niewan said: *"On the southwest path, the moon’s radiance shines bright; the great medicine returns, born from this place. I recall an ancient verse: ‘Above the winding river, the magpie bridge spans.’"* This truly captures the essence.

Why is this so? The southwest corresponds to *kun* (☷), and *kun* represents the abdomen. Where the precious radiance appears, the moon’s brilliance shines clearly; where the moon’s brilliance shines, the metal *qi* emerges in full. Thus, upon the golden bridge, one gazes upon the winding river, where the moon above the river shines directly upon the golden bridge.

The moon’s radiance gleams bright, and within yin, yang is born—hence the saying: *"Within the moon, the sun is clearly seen."* The sun is *taiyang*; the three-legged crow within it is the essence of the sun. To swallow the crow’s liver is to ingest the solar essence of the eastern direction; to consume the hare’s marrow is to partake of the lunar radiance of the western direction. When essence and radiance are combined, the great medicine is born; when sun and moon are both swallowed, the golden elixir takes form—thus the line: *"Swallow the crow’s liver and hare’s marrow, and all the dusty, old intestines are replaced."*

How then could love, fame, or profit disturb one’s pure heart? To turn back and dwell on such thoughts would be to waste the entire day in vain.

**Liu’s Verse:**
