At the furnace, the work begins.

**Li’s Verse:**
The work of gentle nurturing.

The rootless tree blooms fresh and bright,
as talisman and fire refine mercury and lead.
At the furnace’s edge, the scene appears—
gathering all depends on the Dharma-boat.
A master’s hand grips the helm firm,
letting the vast waves churn beneath the sea.
Passing the three barriers, piercing the Mud Pill,
soon the nine apertures of the body are all opened.

**Liu’s Annotation:**
The treasure of true love, once all dust and grime are swept away, becomes utterly pure and pristine—how could its flower not bloom fresh? Yet its freshness depends entirely on the refining work of talisman and fire upon lead and mercury.

True numinosity is the essence of true knowing and numinous knowing; true knowing and numinous knowing are the functions of true numinosity. True numinosity divides into true knowing and numinous knowing, while true knowing and numinous knowing unite to form true numinosity. Refining the lead of true knowing and the mercury of numinous knowing is to refine true numinosity itself.

Refining means using true knowing to govern numinous knowing, and numinous knowing to align with true knowing. When true knowing and numinous knowing congeal, they restore the treasure of true numinosity—its flower’s freshness defies description. Yet while true numinosity is easily formed, the firing times are most difficult. As Master Ziyang said:
*"Though you recognize cinnabar and black lead,
without knowing the firing times, it is all in vain.
All depends on the power of cultivation—
a hair’s breadth off, and no elixir is made."*

The Dao of the golden elixir requires gathering the medicine at the proper time and refining it with the proper method. Without knowing the time or the method, even if the great medicine is within sight, it will not belong to you. Thus, when working at the furnace, within the indistinct there is form, and within the profound there is essence—a single spark of true numinosity’s light emerges from the formless, seeming to exist yet not, neither form nor emptiness. The scene appears before you: this is the moment when the great medicine arises.

At this time, even the Three Corpses, Six Thieves, Five Aggregates, and Seven Emotions—all manner of illusory scenes—may manifest. One must steady the Dharma-boat, grip the helm firm, forget all attachment to appearances, and let the waves churn beneath the sea without wavering. Through such effort, gradually gathering and refining, supporting yang and restraining yin, the longer one persists, the stronger the power. When the work is complete, essence naturally transforms into *qi*, *qi* into spirit, and spirit into emptiness. Passing these three barriers, the wind stirs in the Mud Pill Palace, the Dharma-body manifests, and the yin *qi* of the nine apertures throughout the body is all transmuted.

The three barriers are not the tailbone or spine of the artisan’s school, but the three stages of refining: refining essence into *qi* (the first barrier), refining *qi* into spirit (the middle barrier), and refining spirit into emptiness (the upper barrier). Passing these three, spirit merges with the Great Void, moving freely without obstruction—this is called "piercing the Mud Pill," for the Mud Pill Palace is where spirit is stored.

The nine apertures refer to the illusory body. After passing the three barriers and piercing the Mud Pill, the Dharma-body is accomplished, and the nine apertures and hundred channels of the illusory body, their yin *qi* transformed into yang *qi*, all shine with light. Even the million and four thousand hairs on the body become guardian spirits. Scholars must not let words obscure the meaning.

**Li’s Explanation:**
This chapter speaks of gentle nurturing. Wuyuan’s interpretation—that passing the three barriers, piercing the Mud Pill, and opening the nine apertures refers not to the tailbone or spine of the artisan’s school but to the three refinements, after which spirit merges with the Void and moves freely, illuminating the nine apertures of the illusory body—is valid. However, the preceding lines, if not understood in the context of gentle nurturing, would mix the stages of entering the chamber to return the elixir, gentle nurturing, and shedding the embryo into a single passage, which does not align with the immortal masters’ intent of providing step-by-step guidance. Here, we focus solely on gentle nurturing.

"Fresh" means radiant and bright—the deepening of the nurturing work, the image of daily renewal and monthly flourishing. "Talisman and fire" refer to the cyclical tasks of *zhun* and *meng*: at dawn, advancing the yang fire; at dusk, retreating the yin talisman.

The *zi* hour (11 p.m.–1 a.m.) is when yang is born, and advancing fire should begin at *zi*. By dawn, it is the *yin* hour (3–5 a.m.), yet fire is advanced at *yin* because yang’s fire is born in *yin*, and yang *qi* flourishes at this time. The *wu* hour (11 a.m.–1 p.m.) is when yin is born, and retreating the talisman should occur at *wu*. By dusk, it is the *xu* hour (7–9 p.m.), yet the talisman is retreated at *xu* because the fire’s storehouse resides in *xu*, and yin *qi* governs storage.

Retreating the talisman nourishes mercury; advancing the fire draws out lead. Lead governs mercury, and mercury embraces lead—lead diminishes day by day while mercury increases. Hence the line: *"Talisman and fire refine mercury and lead."*

"At the furnace" refers to the external furnace, not the furnace used when entering the chamber. When entering the chamber to refine lead, a crucible is necessary; for gentle nurturing, a furnace is used, but no crucible. Yet the furnace may be external or internal. As Master Ziyang said: *"Within, there is the natural true fire—
in the furnace, a blazing, enduring red."* This is the inner furnace.

Moreover, it states: *"For the external furnace, diligent effort in increasing and decreasing is essential—nothing surpasses the true seed."* This refers to the external furnace.

At the moment of tending the furnace, a wondrous scene appears before one. This is neither the manifestation of precious radiance nor the arising of illusory visions, but rather the civil fire of the inner furnace and the martial fire of the outer furnace. Through the interplay of civil and martial fires, one gradually gathers and refines, gradually refines and replenishes. During the period of gentle nurturing, the work must not be interrupted. It wholly depends on the master craftsman steering the Dharma-boat, undisturbed by wind and waves, lest they disrupt one’s primordial work. Only then can the Dharma-boat ferry abundantly, traversing ceaselessly—like Bodhidharma carrying gold across the sea, directly transcending to the other shore. Hence the lines: *"Gathering and refining rely entirely on steering the Dharma-boat; the master craftsman’s skillful hand firmly grasps the helm—heedless of the surging waves churning beneath the sea."* The latter three lines have already been clarified in Liu’s commentary, and thus will not be further explained here.

**Liu’s Words:** Recognize the true lead.
**Li’s Words:** The singular true lead.

The rootless tree’s blossoms bloom in full splendor—recognize the true lead as the primal ancestor.
Essence, *qi*, and spirit refine in one crucible; the woman transforms into a man, the old reverts to youth.
To capture the White Tiger in the West, first subdue the Green Dragon in the East.
Like attracts like—apply effort well: when the external medicine flows, the internal medicine flows as well.

In the *Wu Zhen Pian* annotated by *Wu Yuan*, *"splendor"* is written as *"lush,"* *"capture"* as *"lead,"* and *"West"* as *"garden"*—all without difference.

**Liu’s Commentary:** *"Lush"* denotes flourishing abundance. When the blossoms are at their peak, among them are both beauty and ugliness, partiality and uprightness intermingled. Only the true immortal blossom may be gathered and employed. What is this true immortal blossom? It is the true lead. The true lead is the true emotion of true knowing, the manifestation of true numinosity. As true knowing is outwardly yang yet inwardly yin, outwardly black yet inwardly white, it is called true lead, also known as *gold in water*, *lead from the watery realm*, or *the flower of the moon*—its names are manifold, all symbolizing this single entity of true knowing. Only this true knowing contains the primordial true unity’s initial *qi*, the root of yin and yang, the source of the Five Phases, the seed of immortals and buddhas, the lineage of sages and worthies—it is the rightful primal ancestor for those who cultivate the Dao. Once this ancestor is recognized and brought home, revered and upheld without the slightest lapse, then essence, *qi*, and spirit naturally gather in one crucible, without need for force. For when the father returns, where can the child go? With the added work of talisman and fire refinement, even a woman may transform into a man, and the old may revert to youth. *"The woman transforms into a man"* does not mean a change in physical form, but rather that a woman, being purely yin, through cultivation and refinement, transmutes yin into yang, becoming like a man. *"The old reverts to youth"* does not mean a reversion in appearance, but rather that the old, whose *qi* is withered, through cultivation and refinement, returns to the root and reverts to the origin, becoming like a youth. However, the way for a woman to transform into a man or the old to revert to youth, though it begins with recognizing the true lead and true knowing, also requires first mastering the refinement of the self. If the refinement of the self is not thorough, true knowing will not come; even if it comes, it will not stay. Hence the line: *"To lead the White Tiger in the western garden, first subdue the Green Dragon in the east."* The White Tiger belongs to the west and metal, symbolizing true emotion; the Green Dragon belongs to the east and wood, symbolizing true nature. True emotion and true nature are originally of one family—why the need for leading and subduing? Because after their entanglement in the postnatal realm, the true becomes mixed with the false. True emotion turns into false emotion, kindness intermingled with harm—like a tiger leaving its den, rushing west to injure others, no longer belonging to oneself but instead residing in another’s home. Once true emotion becomes false, true nature is likewise obscured, transforming into false nature. With the false in control, the true retreats, and nature and emotion fall out of harmony—like the dragon in the east and the tiger in the west, never meeting. To restore the true, one must first eliminate the false; to lead emotion, one must first harmonize nature. The work of harmonizing nature is the work of refining the self. Refining the self means refining one’s temperament-nature. When the temperament-nature is transformed, true nature naturally manifests. With true nature manifest, it remains unshaken, and true emotion likewise emerges. With true emotion revealed, false emotion does not arise, allowing one to lead back the White Tiger to unite with the Green Dragon, where emotion and nature become mutually enamored. The White Tiger is the true lead, the primal ancestor—merely a different name for the same entity. Because true knowing is unyielding and strong, it is called the White Tiger; because true knowing is soft yet conceals strength, it is called true lead. *"Leading the White Tiger"* means obtaining the true lead. *"Leading"* does not imply force, but rather a leading without leading—when nature is settled, emotion naturally returns. This is simply the principle of like attracting like, the resonance of yin and yang within and without. Nature governs the interior and belongs to yin—it is the internal medicine; emotion governs the exterior and belongs to yang—it is the external medicine. Yin and yang are originally one *qi*, and nature and emotion are fundamentally of the same root. When the internal medicine flows, the external medicine cannot but flow as well. With internal and external communication, nature seeks emotion and emotion longs for nature. When nature and emotion harmonize, true numinosity congeals, and the Returned Elixir takes form. The Pure Yang Elder said: *"When nature abides, *qi* returns of itself; when *qi* returns, the Elixir naturally forms."* The Purple Yang Elder said: *"To refine the Nine Revolutions, first refine the self and hold the mind."* Both speak of the necessity of refining the self before the Returned Elixir. Alas! The true lead is easy to obtain, but refining the self is most difficult—the work of refining the self is truly great!

**Li’s Explanation:** *"Lush"* refers to the intensity of emotion. Lead is the true lead of the person. When true lead manifests, its emotion is at its peak. As long as one recognizes the true and obtains it, the Golden Elixir is immediately accomplished. For this true lead is the embodiment of the central yellow, the primal ancestor of the Great Elixir.

To obtain it and restrain mercury, the Three Families meet to form the Infant. Extending this further, thousands upon thousands, sons and grandsons, all trace their lineage from this true lead—hence it is called the Ancestor. Essence, *qi*, and spirit are refined in a single crucible; this is the state after lead returns and mercury is subdued, the Three Families having met.

Yet to create true lead, there first exists the wondrous method of the female transforming into the male, the old becoming the youth. Originally, the fire of the *Li* Palace is true essence; the water of the *Kan* Palace is true *qi*; between *Kan* and *Li*, there is the marvelous earth in use—true spirit, also called true intent. When *qi* and essence interact, with spirit presiding, then gold is born beneath the water, and mercury descends within the fire. Again, with spirit maintaining balance, regulating dominance and submission, through fierce refining and extreme tempering, the fire steams and the water boils, and the gold too ascends with the water—this is the power of essence, *qi*, and spirit refined in a single crucible. When it enters the *Li* Palace, the fire of *Li* is extinguished by the water of *Kan*, no longer flying nor fleeing. *Qi* is stabilized by spirit, essence is congealed by spirit, lead and mercury both die, merging into the fertile earth. The Three Families gather in the Central Palace, refining into a single Purple Gold Elixir—this is the marvel of essence, *qi*, and spirit refined in a single crucible.

Initially, the son of the Eastern House lodges in the West. The *Dui* of the West is precisely the Young Maiden, who acts in place of Mother *Kun*. Within the female crucible appears the *Zhen* male—this is the female transformed into the male. This male is called the Third Nine Young Lord, young in years, yet truly the Dao Father of Wood Duke, born by entering the womb of the child. Thus, Wood Duke is renamed the Young Master—this is the old transformed into the youth. This Young Master rides a white tiger, roaming the West with great ferocity. A Daoist once saw him and asked: *"You, the youth riding the tiger, were you transformed from Wood Duke?"* The Young Master, knowing the man’s heart held true awareness, dared not conceal the truth and answered: *"Yes."* The Daoist then turned and smiled, saying: *"The lead of the water region is but one taste. Master Cui’s words are true indeed."*

Now, to summon back the Young Master, one must first capture his white tiger, for the white tiger is the steed transformed from the Young Master’s primordial *qi*. If you wish to go to the West to capture his white tiger, you must first subdue the green dragon in the Eastern House. For the white tiger is the emotion of metal, and the green dragon is the nature of wood. When wood interacts with metal, fire arises within wood, and the fire in turn compels the metal to return. When metal merges with wood, water surges within metal, and the water in turn extinguishes the fire to stabilize it. These four, though distinct, are in truth the same; though of different kinds, they are in essence alike. Since they are of the same kind, it is fitting to employ my mysterious skill to bring them together. Thus, inner and outer unite, the outer returns and is subdued within, the external medicine connects with the internal medicine, and the internal medicine likewise connects with the external medicine. This passage speaks only of true lead, not of true mercury, for where there is lead, there is mercury—though mercury is unspoken, it is already within. Hence it is said: *"When the external medicine flows, the internal medicine flows."*

Lead, *qi*, male, youth, tiger—these are the external medicine. Essence, female, old, dragon—these are the internal medicine. As for spirit, it resides between the internal and external essence and *qi*.

**Liu’s Explanation:** Gathering the firing times.
**Li’s Explanation:** The six gates of firing times.

The Rootless Tree, its blossoms radiant,
Heaven responds with stars, earth with tides.
The Dragon-Slaying Sword, the Tiger-Binding Sash,
Revolving the Celestial Stem, wielding the Dipper’s handle.
Tempering a furnace of true sun and moon,
Sweeping away three thousand six hundred paths.
Ascending the clouds, roaming freely,
All sins, filth, and mundane dust vanish in a stroke.

**Liu’s Annotation:**
The true numen lies concealed within the postnatal, obscured by accumulated habits and guest *qi*. Its blossom is most difficult to unfurl. Should it chance to bloom, a single gleam of radiance pierces through the void—like a pearl, like dew—tender, delicate, and resplendent. Its appearance is most exquisite, as if half-opened, merging with the primordial *qi*. In heaven, it responds to the stars’ brilliance, yet not in full splendor; on earth, it responds to the tides’ swell, yet not in saturation. The stars’ brightness and the earth’s moisture are both signs of *yang qi* in its first stirrings.

When *yang qi* first stirs, it is the moment the true numen’s blossom is at its most tender. At this very peak of delicacy, it is easy for the conscious spirit to usurp its luminosity and spawn delusion, for nature to be disturbed and passions to shift. One must swiftly forge and temper with urgency, nip deviations in the bud, and uphold *yang* while suppressing *yin* to safeguard the treasure of life.

The Dragon-Slaying Sword serves to curb the *qi*-nature; the Tiger-Binding Sash serves to restrain wayward passions. When *qi*-nature does not flare, the true numen manifests; when wayward passions do not arise, true feeling is born. When true nature appears and true feeling arises, one revolves the Celestial Stem and wields the Dipper’s handle, turning killing into life and transforming punishment into virtue—thus may one temper a furnace of true sun and moon.

The sun is the image of *yang* containing *yin*, an analogy for the numinous awareness within true nature. This awareness is the feminine within the masculine, true *yin*. The moon is the image of *yin* containing *yang*, an analogy for the true knowing within true feeling. This knowing is the white within the black, true *yang*. Forging and tempering true *yin* and true *yang*—the two great medicines—into a single *qi*, they congeal into the elixir. Swallowed and ingested, it extends life and reverses destiny. This is the most sublime and wondrous Dao, not the three thousand six hundred heterodox paths that cling to emptiness or fixate on forms.

For when the Great Dao is accomplished, one ascends the clouds and roams freely, and all sins, filth, and mundane dust are swept away in a single stroke. Those three thousand six hundred heterodox paths, however, toil upon the stinking skin-bag, only inviting more sins, filth, and mundane dust—how could they ever dispel them?

**Li’s Exegesis:**
“Exquisite” describes its tender delicacy, the moment when the first *yang* germinates. Heaven corresponds to above, earth to below. When *yang* is born, a speck of starlight glimmers upon the brow—what the ancients called “heaven responding with stars”—and a vast tide of *qi* surges within the abdomen—what the ancients called “earth responding with tides.” Such are the portents of the medicine’s birth; they are no falsehood.

Master Wuyuan likened heaven’s stellar radiance and earth’s tidal moisture to the first stirrings of *yang qi*, neither vast nor saturated—another valid interpretation. Some also cite *The Mirror of Entering the Medicine*, where “heaven responding with stars” refers to the upper Magpie Bridge, and “earth responding with tides” to the lower Magpie Bridge, both holding profound principles.

Yet I have privately heard that “responding with stars” and “responding with tides” pertain to aligning with the moon and the hour—awakening to the moon through the stars, awakening to the hour through the tides. This is precisely the crucial firing time of the Great Return Elixir. I excerpt several lines from the *Can Tong Qi* as corroboration:

> *The metal reckoning is fifteen,*
> *The water number is the same.*
> *Before the furnace, fix the weights:*
> *Five parts water, with some to spare.*
> *These two are deemed authentic,*
> *The metal’s weight as in its prime.*
> *The third does not enter—*
> *Two parts fire accompany it.*

This is the true meaning of “responding with stars” and “responding with tides.” The metal must weigh fifteen taels, for metal corresponds to the moon’s number, signifying the metal essence’s vigor. Over five thousand forty-eight days, the celestial true *qi* is first complete. Fifteen taels of metal can generate fifteen parts of water—this is the first half of the month, the fifteen days. The water number matches the metal number, just as the tide number matches the star number.

If metal and water are insufficient, true water will not be born—this is what it means for heaven not to respond with stars or earth with tides. How then can one fix the weights? To align with stars and tides, take the first fifteen days of the month as the standard. From new moon to full, count one and a half days as one part. Two such periods—three days—usher in *geng*. Only then are there two parts of true water: heaven responds with stars, and earth with tides.

By the fifth day, it is three parts—three parts are not to be used. By the eighth day, it is five parts—five parts are even more excessive, neither responding with stars nor tides. Only two parts of water paired with two parts of fire constitute the true response to stars and tides. These two are the true signals of *kan* water. When metal first generates water, just at the two-part stage, the water source is utterly pure, possessing *qi* but no substance—this is the White Tiger’s first channel. As the tiger exhales *qi*, the dragon meets it with two parts of true fire, refining it into the elixir’s foundation.

As for the metal that generates two parts of water, it must wait until the fifteenth day, when the metal essence is at its peak and the water tide is born. This is the “second seven’s period,” when true lead first descends—this is responding with stars and tides.

One might ask: Why must the fire be two parts? The answer: In one hour’s work, divided into three *fu* and six *hou*, only one *fu* and two *hou* of fire are used. Thus, dragon and tiger are balanced, mutually consuming and merging. When the time arrives, one must wield the sword to subdue the dragon and grasp the sash to tame the tiger, revolving the Celestial Stem and wielding the Dipper’s handle to return to the Central Palace. When sun and moon conjoin their essences and are forged and tempered, the true Dao is attained.

My teacher from Wushan Mountain offered an even more precise and illuminating discourse, which I now elaborate in full:

*Qian* heaven is *yang*; the stars are heaven’s fire essence, *yin* within *yang*. *Kun* earth is *yin*; the tides are earth’s water *qi*, *yang* within *yin*. Essence is the father of fire; *qi* is the mother of water. When *qian* father and *kun* mother unite, *li* fire and *kan* water are born. Hence it is said: “Heaven responds with stars, earth with tides.” “Responding” denotes the mutual resonance between them.

The *Cantong Qi* states: *"Without the stars and moon, how could the square vessel yield water?"* From this we know that when celestial light illumines the earth, it responds with stars; when earth’s *qi* bears the heavens, it responds with tides. The immortals liken the stars of heaven to the fire within the human heart—fire being one’s nature, and nature belonging to the dragon. If not subdued, the stars scatter and fire disperses. Thus one must grasp the dragon-slaying sword to subdue it, the sword being great wisdom. They liken the tides of earth to the water within the human body—water being one’s emotions, and emotions being the tiger. If not tamed, the tides overflow and water flows unchecked. Thus one must hold the tiger-binding sash to tame it, the sash being great insight. Profound skill appears clumsy; great wisdom seems foolish. When insight and wisdom merge into darkness, the wondrous mind arises. To revolve the Celestial Stem and wield the Dipper’s handle requires the power of this wondrous mind. The Celestial Stem is the Northern Dipper, which governs life through its handle. Wherever the Dipper’s handle points, there life’s *qi* arises. When the wondrous mind within the human body moves the Dipper’s handle, it can transform death into life. As the Dipper’s handle revolves, the golden elixir enters within; when the golden elixir enters within, the wondrous mind returns to me. The wondrous mind is the true body of neither birth nor death, its virtue merging with heaven and earth, its radiance conjoining with sun and moon—it is the true sun and moon within the human body.

To seek the wondrous mind, one must return from the posterior heaven to the prior heaven. First, let the external sun and moon exchange their light externally, master the firing times, and know the cyclical signs; only then can it be attained. Upon returning, one must also let the internal sun and moon exchange their light internally, maintaining brightness day and night, harmonizing and nurturing—thus forging and tempering a furnace of true sun and moon. This is the wondrous essence of the golden elixir’s great Dao, the profound mystery of the seven returns and nine refinements. It sweeps away the three thousand six hundred heterodox paths, allowing one to ascend the clouds and roam freely, erasing all karmic dust and worldly defilements with a single stroke. Without understanding this great Dao, there will never be a day of liberation; karmic dust and worldly defilements will only accumulate daily. How can one fail to awaken?

Moreover, **Liu’s Pointer** states: *"Invert the mechanism of qi."*
**Li’s Saying** states: *"Skillfully employ the thief’s mechanism."*

The rootless tree blooms high,
Ocean waves surge to the sky as the moon plays with the tides.
The Silver River’s path pierces the nine heavens,
The raft’s shadow spans the void, moored to the Dipper’s tip.
Touching the Weaving Maid’s shuttle stone,
Treading the Cowherd’s magpie bridge,
Entering the immortal court with bold courage,
Stealing the Queen Mother’s peach from Jasper Pool.

In the *Wu Zhen* annotated edition, *"moored"* is written as *"dry,"* and *"stealing"* as *"pilfering."*

**Liu’s Annotation:**
The prior-heaven great Dao encompasses heaven and earth, moves the sun and moon, and transcends the ten thousand existences. Its blossoms open exceedingly high—so high that the moon in the sky casts its light to the ocean’s depths. Though ocean waves surge to the heavens, water cannot drown the moon’s light; instead, the moon plays with the tides. This is like a person in the sea of suffering: circumstances cannot harm their true nature but instead refine it through those very circumstances. The Silver River’s path is distant, piercing straight through the nine heavens, yet difficult for mortals to cross. However, with a celestial raft spanning the void and revolving the Dipper’s tip, one can traverse it—as Zhang Qian once rode a celestial raft across the Silver River and witnessed the meeting of the Cowherd and Weaving Maid stars, a proven example. In principle, other rafts in the world can also cross the Silver River. What, then, is this celestial raft? It is the great Dao of the golden elixir. The great Dao of the golden elixir operates within the void, transforming the cosmos, reversing yin and yang, seizing creation, and transcending the mundane to enter sagehood—it is indeed a celestial raft. Yet the raft’s wonder lies in the operation of the Dipper’s tip. The Dipper’s tip is the seventh star of the Northern Dipper, *Yaoguang*, also called the Celestial Stem. Where it points is auspicious; where it rests is inauspicious, for life’s *qi* resides where it points. In an instant of turning the Dipper’s tip, yin and yang unite, and life’s sprouts emerge effortlessly. Thus it is said: *"Touching the Weaving Maid’s shuttle stone, treading the Cowherd’s magpie bridge."* The Weaving Maid belongs to yin; the Cowherd to yang. The magpie bridge is where they meet. Touching the shuttle stone and treading the magpie bridge, yin beckons yang, and yang comes to meet yin. When yin and yang unite, the golden elixir takes form. This principle is enacted within the waves, its workings performed in the void. Thus one can enter the immortal court with bold courage, pilfering the Queen Mother’s peach from Jasper Pool. Jasper Pool lies in the west; the Queen Mother is the old yin, the *Kun* mother. The peach is the elixir, the single yang of *Zhen*. The Queen Mother’s peach symbolizes *Kun* nurturing *Zhen* within. When the elixir in the west is stolen and returned to the east, it becomes one’s own, and the elixir is restored. Yet the wonder of this restored elixir lies in the union of yin and yang; the wonder of their union lies in reversing the *qi* mechanism amid the ocean’s waves, remaining unmoved and unshaken. To remain unmoved and unshaken amid the ocean’s waves is truly the courage of a great man. What heaven among the nine cannot be ascended? What Silver River cannot be crossed? What Queen Mother’s peach cannot be stolen? Those who cultivate stillness and forget form, acting only in quiescence, how could they know of this?

**Li’s Explanation:**
*"High"* refers to the void. *"Ocean waves surge to the heavens"* is what Master Ziyang called the time when *"the winds and waves are rough, giving birth to the mysterious pearl."* The winds rise and waves surge, their sound shaking the void—hence *"surge to the heavens."* Yet the mysterious pearl, like a full autumn moon, appears upon the sea—hence *"the moon plays with the tides."* Reversing the Silver River to pierce the nine heavens resembles Zhang Qian riding the raft, its shadow spanning the void, the *qi* mechanism reaching its zenith.

Yet before the river raft advances, there must first be a guide, lest the waters flow wantonly, straying from their course—this is why the tip of the Dipper serves as the mooring. The character *"moor"* here is most subtly chosen. For mortals, mooring a boat means resting for the night; but for the immortal voyager on the river raft, the Dipper’s tip is the only anchorage. To proceed straight and true, the momentum allows no mooring—yet to speak of mooring at the Dipper’s tip is precisely to moor where mooring is impossible, where mooring cannot be. Following the Dipper’s revolution, movement contains stillness, and within destruction, life arises. This is like the hero or bold knight who acts with unbridled resolve, riding the wind without mooring—such is the moment of grand culmination, of great flourishing. Not mooring surpasses mooring, and mooring is as good as not mooring. Such is the mooring at the Dipper’s tip.

The Weaving Maid and the Cowherd are the yin and yang stars of heaven, meeting once a year on the seventh night. The Weaving Maid belongs to yin, her loom’s shuttle likened to mercury; the Cowherd belongs to yang, and the Magpie Bridge is where the Cowherd and Maid reunite—this is the direction where metal and mercury converge. Above, the Dipper’s tip is mentioned; here, the Maid and Cowherd—thus the Dipper serves as their matchmaker. Without the Dipper, the Cowherd cannot meet the Weaving Maid; when the Dipper turns, the Cowherd crosses the river, and metal unites with mercury. As Patriarch Lü said: *"In the fire-advancing work, the Cowherd and Dipper are perilous."* Niwan remarked: *"The wonder lies in the Tail, Winnowing Basket, Dipper, Maid, and Cowherd."* Both express the same idea. Grasping the shuttle’s stone, mercury welcomes lead; treading the Magpie Bridge, lead and mercury become one. From this, heavenly fate is secured, ambition fulfilled, and one may encounter the immortal court with bold spirit. Why is this? Because they have stolen the Queen Mother of Jasper Pool’s peach.

Wu Yuan explained that Jasper Pool lies in the west, the Queen Mother is the Mother of Earth, and the peach symbolizes the yang embryo nurtured within earth—elixir is in the west, yet stolen and brought east to form the Returned Elixir. His annotation is clear, but *"steal"* does not match the immediacy of *"plunder."* Plundering the peach in the east is one; the hexagram *Kan* as plunder is two. Plundering the peach in the east is precisely going west to seize metal; *Kan* as plunder is precisely seeking lead from the water’s depths. How wondrous is the meaning of plunder!

**Liu’s Note:** Yin and yang strike and bind.
**Li’s Note:** Giving birth to the mysterious pearl.

The rootless tree, its blossoms in pairs,
Dragon and tiger mount the altar for battle.
Lead enters mercury, yin and yang conjoin,
Its form mirrors the priceless mysterious pearl.

This is the true seed of the homeland,
Returning the old to youth, life prolonged.
Ascend to heaven, to the realm of utmost bliss,
Spare yourself the wheel of rebirth and the sight of Yama.

**Liu’s Commentary:**
The Golden Elixir is formed when yin and yang forces clash and take shape—thus the blossoms must be paired to be of use. Yin and yang are one dragon and one tiger, one lead and one mercury. The dragon is true nature, mercury is numinous awareness, also the primordial spirit, both belonging to yin; the tiger is true emotion, lead is true knowing, also the primordial essence, both belonging to yang. The dragon and tiger in battle: nature and emotion held in tension. Lead entering mercury: spirit and essence congealing. When nature and emotion are bound, spirit and essence congeal, yin and yang unite, and the *qi* blends into one—true numinosity becomes perfectly luminous, the Dharma-body takes form, round and radiant, like a single mysterious pearl, a priceless treasure. This treasure is not an external thing but the true seed of our homeland, originally possessed but lost to the delusions of the postnatal world. Now, with yin and yang harmonized, what was lost is regained, what departed returns. Planted in the homeland, the root established, the Dao generates, generating without end—returning the old to youth, extending life without limit. Ascending to the heavenly realm of utmost bliss, one escapes the suffering of rebirth.

**Li’s Explanation:**
"In pairs" refers to the *qi* of the two crescents. When the *qi* of the two crescents unite, dragon and tiger mount the altar, devouring one another—battle means devouring. After a great battle, dragon and tiger are balanced. When the tiger battles the dragon, lead enters mercury; when the dragon battles the tiger, yin conjoins yang. When yang lead and yin mercury unite, the priceless treasure is born. As *Awakening to Reality* says: *"Tiger leaps, dragon soars, winds and waves surge—at the central true position, the mysterious pearl is born."* The mysterious pearl is the primordial unity of *qi*, the original source of immortals and buddhas, the true seed of our homeland, not an external thing. Veiled by the postnatal, it long ceased to manifest. Now, on the dragon-tiger altar, yin mercury and yang lead unite as true husband and wife, returning from within the postnatal Kan and Li to the primordial. Thus it is said: *"Its form mirrors the priceless mysterious pearl."* From this true seed of the homeland, those who obtain it return to youth, prolong life, ascend to heaven, reach utmost bliss, and escape the wheel of rebirth. This speaks of the method of dragon and tiger, yin and yang battling and uniting—one must seek the firing times in the commentary on *"When the blossoms are most fair."*

**Liu’s Note:** The Elixir returned in an instant.
**Li’s Note:** The Returned Elixir’s nurturing.

The Rootless Tree bears wondrous blossoms,
Cultivated in the moon for but a fleeting moment.
With hands that grasp the clouds, one ascends the cloud-ladder,
Plucking the first primordial branch.
Drinking wine and wearing flowers, the spirit soars,
Laughing at the immortal elders sunk in drunken stupor.
Entrusting to the knowing heart, guard it with care,
Lest the furnace’s firing times take flight.

**Liu’s Note:**
The primordial true spirit, though non-existent, can become existent; though deficient, can become whole—how wondrous the blossom! Yet what makes it wondrous is this: the primordial is veiled by the postnatal, utterly without trace. If one wishes to cultivate it, within a fleeting moment it can restore spring. The marvel of this restoration lies in plucking the first primordial branch’s blossom. This first branch is the ancestral qi of all life, the numinous root that gives birth to heaven, earth, and humankind. It does not fall into form, nor does it fall into emptiness; when contained, it is true emptiness, and when expressed, it is wondrous being. Utterly centered, utterly upright, utterly refined, utterly pure, it flickers in the indistinct and obscure like dewdrops, like lightning. It cannot be sought with intention, nor can it be preserved without intention. To seek it with intention is to cling to appearances; to preserve it without intention is to cling to emptiness. It lies in the stillness of nature and the forgetting of emotion, in turning the light inward and reflecting back, in utter emptiness and profound tranquility. Without plucking, it is plucked; without taking, it is taken. Naturally, the primordial true unity of qi arises from the formless, congealing into a pearl the size of a millet grain. Within and without, all is luminous—like wearing immortal blossoms, the spirit is refreshed, like drinking immortal wine. Wearing flowers and drinking wine, joy abides within, unknowing and unaware, following the decree of the Emperor. One enters the realm of intoxication. At this moment, the Returned Elixir has formed, and the original face is once more revealed. There is no need for external furnace adjustments; one must swiftly nurture it within the inner furnace, silently moving with numinous awareness, guarding it with vigilance. The mind must not scatter, ever wary of missteps in the firing times. The "knowing heart" is not an external knower but the heart that knows itself. The pacing of the firing times is known by the heart; if the heart knows without obscuring itself, the firing times will not err, and the Golden Elixir will ripen.

**Li’s Explanation:**
"Wondrous" means beyond human comprehension. Not only can humans not fathom it, but even yin and yang cannot. If it could be fathomed, yin and yang would not intermingle in the obscure and indistinct—how then could the primordial be cultivated?

Cultivating within the moon’s cycle begins when the third day yields the *geng* phase, where the medicinal material is fresh and tender. Within this *geng*-direction moon, the golden flower is cultivated by blending two parts fire with two parts water, stewing in primordial chaos for a moment—then the first primordial sprout emerges within the crucible. This is the work of a fleeting instant.

In that instant, when the first primordial sprout truly appears, the wondrous heart takes charge, immediately reversing the celestial course, soaring back to the Han River’s source. This is the hand that grasps the clouds, the ladder that ascends them—gathering the first primordial sprout.

To "drink wine" is to imbibe this first immortal elixir, where the primordial transforms into white nectar. To "wear flowers" is to don this first immortal blossom, where the primordial revives the spring of yang. Flower is wine, wine is flower; drinking and wearing them, wine becomes a loyal friend and flower a companion, filling one with harmonious spirit and qi, merging into a drunken haze. Thus it is said: *"Drinking wine and wearing flowers, the spirit soars—mocking the immortal elder, drunk as mud."*

The "knowing heart" is the shared heart, the selfsame wondrous heart. "Vigilant guarding" means observing the firing times with this wondrous heart. Yet guarding has many aspects, and the furnace’s fire has two extremes.

If the firing time is insufficient, one must adjust with *zhun* and *meng* to supplement and refine, requiring external furnace adjustments. If the firing time is complete, one guards it day and night with inner radiance, needing no external furnace adjustments. When the ten-month count is full and nine years have passed, the true person emerges from the crown of the head.

Otherwise, if the external furnace is removed prematurely when it should remain, the firing time will be incomplete and the elixir will not mature. If the external furnace lingers when it should be removed, the firing time will be excessive and the elixir will be harmed. If the inner furnace is abandoned too soon when it should persist, the firing time will lack purity and the elixir will not be efficacious. If the inner furnace remains when it should be released, the firing time will stagnate like ignorance and the elixir will not manifest. All these are errors in the furnace’s firing times.

This is why the knowing heart must guard with precision and care to avoid such missteps. "Flying" here signifies deviation—compare it with the earlier chapter *"When the Flower Takes Flight."* Further:

**Liu’s Explanation:**
Harmonizing yin and yang.

**Li’s Explanation:**
Obtaining the medicine and returning the elixir.

The Rootless Tree’s blossoms turn golden true,
Born in the central land of Wu and Ji’s hue.
The eastern maiden, the western man,
As husband and wife, they enter the nuptial chamber’s span.
The Yellow Matron urges them to drink the ghee’s wine,
Each day they grow drunk in warmth divine.
This immortal recipe, this soul-returning brew,
Revives the dead and restores life anew—such is the Medicine King’s due.

**Wu Yuan’s Annotated Edition:** *"Born in"* is rendered as *"color true."*

**Liu’s Annotation:**
Yellow is the true color of the central Wu and Ji. Wu, as yang earth, governs movement; Ji, as yin earth, governs stillness. Wu and Ji, dwelling at the center, unite to form true sincerity—also called true intent. When the blossom’s color is truly golden, the true spirit enters the central, upright position. Yet for the true spirit to be centered and upright, nature and emotion must be as one. The eastern maiden is the nature of Wood; the western man is the emotion of Metal. One nature, one emotion—paired as husband and wife, they enter the secluded chamber. With the Yellow Matron urging them to drink the ghee, harmonizing the firing times, what was disharmonious must harmonize, and harmony endures. The ghee wine is not the dregs of the mortal world, nor is it the tangible essence, fluids, or blood within the body. It is the qi of harmonious intermingling between yin and yang, coalescing into the true unity of essence, flowing as the true unity of water. Its flavor is sweet, its fragrance rich—ancients called it jade liquid, nectar, dew, or ghee, all metaphors for this single point of harmonious qi. To "urge drinking" is to refine what is not harmonious until it attains perfect balance. In the practice of the Dao, when yin and yang achieve harmonious union, one remains responsive yet serene. Gazing afar, phenomena dissolve into non-phenomena; observing closely, the body dissolves into non-body; turning inward, the heart dissolves into non-heart. Unknowing and unperceiving, one follows the Emperor’s decree, drinking the ghee daily and entering the realm of intoxication. This intoxicated delight is the immortal’s recipe, the soul-returning brew—able to revive the dead, restore life, the great Medicine King.

The Center, Wu-Ji, the Yellow Matron—all are alternate names for true sincerity. In terms of yin-yang harmony, it is called the Center; in terms of yin-yang movement, Wu-Ji; in terms of yin-yang harmonization, the Yellow Matron; in terms of action, true sincerity; in terms of stillness, true intent. Thus, one thing bears many names, but in essence, it is simply true sincerity. Recognize this sincerity, and upon it, apply steadfast effort. First, seek emotion through nature; then, return emotion to nature; next, harmonize nature and emotion; finally, merge them into oneness, forming the true spirit’s supreme treasure. From beginning to end, all success hinges on this single sincerity—how vast is sincerity’s power! Returning to the practical, when the true spirit is centered and upright, it is nature and emotion in harmony. When nature and emotion harmonize, true sincerity resides within. When true sincerity manifests, nature and emotion naturally remain inseparable, and the true spirit is inherently centered and upright. These three interdepend yet remain mutually reinforcing.

**Li’s Explanation:**
Yellow is the true color, the right awakening of Buddhism, the right qi of Confucianism and Daoism. In Buddhist scriptures, it is called the yellow flower; in immortal classics, the yellow sprout. Yet the yellow sprout has two kinds: one is the new medicine of the third day, the other the great medicine of the fifteenth. As *Awakening to Reality* states: *"Where the yellow sprout grows, Kan and Li intertwine"*—this is the new medicine of the third day. Where the yellow sprout grows is where Kan and Li should unite to cultivate the second yellow sprout. *Awakening to Reality* says: *"Plant the yellow sprout, and it gradually matures"*—this is the second yellow sprout, the great medicine of the fifteenth day. The yellow sprout’s maturation arises from Kan and Li’s union. Their union occurs in the central land of Wu and Ji. The Center is where essence and qi coalesce; the land of Wu-Ji is where movement and stillness harmonize. Once harmonized and coalesced, in an instant, the yellow sprout emerges from within—hence *"born in the central land of Wu and Ji."* This yellow sprout has many names; in this chapter, it is the western man. The western man is the qi of Metal; the eastern maiden is the essence of Mercury. Gathering the Metal qi to subdue the Mercury essence—this is the path of returning Metal and Mercury, the union of husband and wife entering the nuptial chamber. Once in the chamber, the Yellow Matron must guard them. The Yellow Matron is the "knowing heart" mentioned in the previous chapter. If the couple fears discord, their spirit, intent, and qi will struggle to reach the state of harmony, and the elixir will not form. Thus, the Yellow Matron attends them, urging them to drink the ghee. The ghee is the essence nurtured externally, the harmonious qi ingested internally. The Yellow Matron is the intimate confidante—naturally, the furnace’s firing times will not err. Between dawn and dusk, she urges them to drink frequently, each day growing drunk in warmth—a true delight. This wine is not of the mortal world but an immortal’s recipe, called the soul-returning brew. It can revive the dead, restore life—no minor or external medicine compares; it is the Medicine King. This chapter describes the work after the second firing’s quest for Lead and the fourth firing’s return of the elixir. Seeking Lead is an external affair: on the third day, when the moon emerges in Geng, one applies effort—called pairing water with fire, the Dragon approaching the Tiger, yin meeting yang, Li uniting with Kan, nature merging with emotion, Mercury investing Lead, the maiden marrying the man. All these describe the generation of the precelestial from the postcelestial, the union of essence and qi—an external medicine. Its work lies without, requiring but one talisman and two firings to establish the elixir’s foundation.

Returning the elixir is an internal affair: on the fifteenth day, when the moon is full, one applies effort—called extinguishing fire with water, where water is the celestial water of Tian Gui; the Tiger marrying the Dragon, where the Tiger is the Tiger of the Western Direction; yang subduing yin, where yang is the yang containing the true; Kan filling Li, where Kan is the precelestial Kan; emotion returning to nature, where emotion is the emotion of metal; Lead restraining Mercury, where Lead is the Lead of True Unity; the man pairing with the maiden, where the man is the man of pure yang. All these describe the precelestial governing the postcelestial. In sum, it is the union of true qi with true essence—an internal medicine. Its work lies within, requiring two talismans and four firings to congeal the golden elixir.

All this the ancients left undifferentiated; here I set it forth in detail, that when reading the elixir classics, one may clearly distinguish the two medicines.

**Liu’s Saying:** Congealing the sacred embryo.
**Li’s Saying:** Capturing and subduing the fire-medicine.

The rootless tree, its blossoms radiant bright,
The moon’s yin soul presses close the sun’s yang spirit.
Golden Crow’s marrow, Jade Rabbit’s essence—
These two seized and simmered in one vessel.
Yang fire and yin talisman divide at midnight and noon,
Bathing added at dawn and dusk’s gates.
Guard the Yellow Court, nurture the Valley Spirit—
A man with child! How the world laughs!

**Liu’s Annotation:**
The precelestial true spirit, its original luminosity,
Pierces heaven and earth, illuminating all—this is the blossom’s radiance.
What makes it radiant? The harmony of yin and yang qi.
Man’s singular self is pure yin, like the moon’s darkness without light,
Yet must borrow another’s deathless method to generate yang,
As the moon borrows the sun’s light to shine.
The moon’s yin soul pressing the sun’s yang spirit—
Yin and yang unite, their brilliance at heaven’s heart,
This is true knowing and numinous knowing conjoined,
The image of true spirit undimmed.
The Golden Crow’s marrow is the sun’s spirit,
In man, the feminine within the masculine—
The true yin of numinous knowing.
The Jade Rabbit’s essence is the moon’s soul,
In man, the white within the black—
The true yang of true knowing.
Earlier I spoke of Crow’s liver and Rabbit’s marrow;
Here, Crow’s marrow and Rabbit’s essence—
A great distinction, not to be conflated.
For Crow’s liver and Rabbit’s marrow are the medicine of the returning elixir,
True knowing and numinous knowing,
Yin and yang not yet united but on the verge of union—
Thus, the liver of the Crow, the marrow of the Rabbit.
Crow’s marrow and Rabbit’s essence are the medicine of the great elixir,
True knowing made numinous, numinous knowing made true,
Yin and yang already united and harmonized—
Thus, the marrow of the Crow, the essence of the Rabbit.
Not yet united but on the verge of union: forced effort,
The false restored to the true.
Already united and harmonized: natural function,
The true made truer still.
Take these two true medicines,
Knead them into one, refine the yang within yang,
Then apply the fire-times of midnight, noon, dawn, and dusk,
To complete the great elixir of golden liquid.
Yet this midnight, noon, dawn, and dusk—
Not the midnight, noon, dawn, and dusk of the horizon,
But the midnight, noon, dawn, and dusk within the body.
When true knowing appears, it is midnight—
One must use firm advancing fire to stir true knowing from the mysterious.
When numinous knowing arrives, it is noon—
One must use gentle retreating talisman to draw numinous knowing into the feminine.
When true knowing advances to the central balance, it is dawn—
One must ice-bathe this central balance to prevent over-advance.
When numinous knowing retreats to the central balance, it is dusk—
One must ice-bathe this central balance to prevent over-retreat.
This is the way of talisman, fire, and ice-bathing—
An unchanging method through the ages.
To apply effort by the horizon’s midnight, noon, dawn, and dusk is utterly mistaken.
When talisman and fire are unerring, bathing timely,
Yin and yang respond without bias,
The Mysterious Female is established, and the Valley Spirit arises within it.
The Yellow Court is the central rightful position,
The single aperture at the center of yin-yang union,
Also called the gate of the Mysterious Female.
When the Mysterious Female is yang and the Mysterious Male yin,
Yin and yang unite, and this aperture exists;
When yin and yang are biased, this aperture vanishes.
With this aperture, there is a valley; with a valley, there is spirit.
Without this aperture, no valley; without a valley, no spirit.
The valley is the Yellow Court.
Yellow is the color of the center;
Court means emptiness.
Because it is empty at the center, it is named the Yellow Court.
Empty, it is numinous; numinous, it is spirit—
This is the Valley Spirit.
Observe the mountains: two cliffs stand facing,
Between them a valley—
Call out, and the valley echoes—
This echo is the Valley Spirit, commonly called the cliff baby.
When man’s yin and yang unite,
Within them is spirit—
Just so.
Yet without reaching the state of yin-yang union,
There is no center, no valley—
How could spirit dwell there?
Only when yin and yang truly unite
Is there a center, a valley,
And spirit naturally arises—
This is what is meant by “the precelestial qi comes from the midst of emptiness,”
By “true emptiness containing wondrous being,”
By “to keep the Valley Spirit ever undying, rely on the Mysterious Female to establish the root.”
When yin and yang unite as one qi,
The Valley Spirit abides in the Yellow Court—
This is called a man with child.
“Guard the Yellow Court” means guarding the center.
“Nurture the Valley Spirit” means embracing the One.
Guard the center, embrace the One—
Ten months’ work complete,
A body beyond the body,
One who endures as long as heaven and earth.
Such true and real dharmas are the work of emptiness,
Not wrought from form.
Those who fiddle with circulating work on the stinking skin-bag,
Falsely hoping to congeal the sacred embryo—
How could they know what makes the Valley Spirit the Valley Spirit?

**Li’s Explanation:**
Brightness is the arising of the great medicine,
The empty chamber generating whiteness,
Radiating great light,
The time of great awakening, great enlightenment.

The great medicine is the yang within lead, the gold within cinnabar—prior to the prior Heaven. Like the lunar essence dwelling in the heart of heaven, pressed close to the solar spirit, it forms a radiant orb of light, unlike the slender crescent of the third day, distant as the horizon, near as the moth-browed moon.

The word *pressed* is crucial—it means intimate closeness, the two refining each other in one place. When sun and moon conjoin as one, the solar spirit pours entirely into the lunar essence, illuminating ten thousand miles, the heart of heaven gleaming bright as snow. The two are captured and refined together—not seizing the golden crow first, then the jade hare, but seizing the golden crow to grasp the jade hare. Capturing one is capturing both.

At the moment of capture, there are the four fire phases of zi, wu, mao, and you, entering the gates. Thus the golden crow flies into the Palace of Broad Cold, and with the marrow of the golden crow, the essence of the jade hare is harmonized. Then the essence of the jade hare is entirely transformed into the marrow of the golden crow—this is the lunar essence pressing the solar spirit, skillfully refining them in one place.

At this time, the yang spirit is complete, the yin essence formless. The two become one, and within the one, the two remain. Yin is exhausted, yang is whole, and great light radiates forth. Thus it is called the yang within lead, the gold within cinnabar—prior to the prior Heaven. At this stage, it becomes the great medicine of golden liquid. Following the four fire phases of zi, wu, mao, and you in ingestion, this is the nine-times-cycled great returning elixir.

What is *zi*? The arising of yang is *zi*, so advance the yang fire.
What is *wu*? The descent of yin is *wu*, so withdraw the yin tally.
*Bathing* means natural regulation, neither hasty nor slow. This work should be applied when the yang fire arrives at mao and the yin tally arrives at you, so that yang is not too rigid, yin not too yielding—rigidity and softness balanced, ingress and egress harmonized.

Formerly, Master Tao Cuncun elucidated the secret of firing in the *Cantong Qi*, including his teacher’s *Song of Fire Phases* in his commentary. I deeply admire it and append it here for verification:

*I recall my immortal master’s Daoist method,*
*All belongs to our own that-move.*
*Originally no zi or wu to withdraw or add,*
*How could there be hare or fowl, punishment or virtue?*
*Ask when is my zi?*
*I say: at the time the medicine arises.*
*Ask when is my wu?*
*Nothing more than the medicine facing the golden gate.*
*Ask when is mao?*
*The red child arrayed in Fire Cloud Cave.*
*Without Guanyin the Savior,*
*The great medicine would surely burst.*
*This is the hour of bathing,*
*Beyond this, the boat crosses the Yellow River.*
*Again ask what is the you gate?*
*It is when the Conception and Governor merge.*
*Without the Yellow Skirt at this time,*
*How could the medicine be perfectly auspicious?*
*Beyond this is the xu treasury—*
*Seek the message within the treasury.*
*This is the mind-to-mind transmission,*
*The supreme Dao needs no other search.*

When the medicine arrives at the mao gate, one must employ the stillness of Guanyin. Guanyin’s stillness governs with strict control, preventing the red child from acting recklessly, so that sweet dew arises. At the you gate, one wraps it in the Yellow Skirt, preventing the primordial pearl from spilling, so that the white liquid congeals—this is the wondrous use of bathing.

The Yellow Court is the center. The Valley Spirit is the empty numen. Guarding the center and nurturing the empty numen, the Dharma-body manifests its image—a man resembling a woman with child, both amusing and endearing.

**Liu’s Explanation:**
The true emptiness Dharma-realm.

**Li’s Explanation:**
Perfect penetration, self-so ease.

The rootless tree, its flowers crimson red—
Pluck all the red flowers, and the whole tree is empty.
Emptiness is form, form is emptiness—
Discern true emptiness within form.
When true emptiness is fully realized, form vanishes,
Yet the Dharma-realm endures, never falling into emptiness.
Called perfect penetration, named great hero,
Nine generations ascend to the ninefold heavens.

Wu Yuhuan’s annotated edition writes *golden flowers* as *red flowers*, which is better, so I follow it. The character *vanishes* was mistakenly written as *Dharma*.

**Liu’s Commentary:**
The great Way of the golden elixir takes transcending all phenomena—soundless and scentless—as its ultimate goal. How could flowers have a red color? If there is even a trace of color, the post-Heaven qi and temperament are not yet fully transformed, and the great Way is not achieved. The ancient immortals said: *"Not an iota of yin qi unexhausted, not an immortal."* For if even an iota of yin qi remains, there is an iota of yang qi incomplete. The true spirit still has moments of damage—this cannot be called the Way of the nine-return, seven-reversion golden liquid great elixir.

Cultivators must pluck all the red flowers, eliminating the adventitious dust-roots accumulated since the beginningless kalpas, returning to the state where all things are empty, reverting to the soundless, scentless visage before parents were born. Yet this *emptiness* is not the same as the insensate extinction of wood or earth. There is a Way of borrowing the false to complete the true, of using the true to transform the false. Thus it is said: *"Emptiness is form, form is emptiness—discern true emptiness within form."*

If one is single-mindedly without thought, one clings to emptiness; if there is even a hint of thought, one clings to form. To say *"emptiness is form"* is not emptiness; to say *"form is emptiness"* is not form. Neither emptiness nor form, yet both emptiness and form—this is true emptiness abiding within form.

To say *"when true emptiness is fully realized, form vanishes, yet the Dharma-realm endures, never falling into emptiness"* means that true emptiness, once fully realized, is originally without form. Without form, there is the Dharma-realm; with the Dharma-realm, it does not fall into emptiness. Because it is true emptiness, there is the Dharma-realm; because there is the Dharma-realm, there is no form. Without form, with the Dharma-realm—thus emptiness is true, and truer than emptiness.

Cultivating the Dao to the point of true emptiness yet possessing Dharma-aspects—Dharma-aspects yet abiding in true emptiness—this singular, wondrous existence pervades the Dharma-realm with perfect interpenetration, forming an indestructible vajra-body. Neither water nor fire can assail it, blades nor weapons can strike it, tigers nor rhinoceroses can harm it; this is called the Great Hero. Not only does one’s own body ascend to the ranks of immortals, but even nine generations of ancestors are liberated together, rising to heaven and becoming divine.

Formerly, when Śākyamuni Buddha cultivated the sixteen-foot golden body, his Dharma-aspect resided in the Mahāvīra Hall—this is precisely that Dao.

**[Li’s Explanation]**
The red is the great elixir’s symbolic form. The *Daoist Sentiments Song* and *The Rootless Tree* by the Immortal Master are both essential works; through them, one may perceive this truth. The *Daoist Sentiments Song* says:
*"Of ten thousand images, none are of the same kind;
A single crimson radiance is the utmost reality."*
When the red radiance manifests, the flower is truly red. Once the red flower is obtained, the true elixir is secured—apart from this red flower, there is no medicine to be gathered. When the nurturing process is complete and the furnace and cauldron are set aside, all those flowering trees are no longer discussed. Thus it is said: *"Plucking all the red flowers leaves the tree empty."* Once the flowers are empty, my Dao is attained; once my Dao is attained, emptiness is no longer empty. Since emptiness is no longer empty, emptiness is form; yet this form is not the form of form-aspects—it is the form of Dharma-aspects. Penetrating true emptiness as non-empty, true emptiness resides within form. When true emptiness is fully realized, form-aspects vanish entirely; when form-aspects vanish entirely, Dharma-aspects endure forever. The enduring of Dharma-aspects is true emptiness as non-empty.

Perfect interpenetration means that merit and practice are complete, all dharmas are mastered, and the substance and function of true emptiness are fully possessed. Once called "perfect interpenetration," one must be called "Great Hero"; once called "Great Hero," one must become a patriarch of immortals. How could the nine generations of ancestors not ascend together, rising to the ninefold heavens?

**[Liu’s Words]**
Return to utter vacuity.

**[Li’s Words]**
Attain the rank of the Three Purities.

*The Rootless Tree*:
*"The flower is truly without root,
Formless and shapeless, hard to depict.
Nameless, yet heeding the call,
Seized and placed within the alchemical furnace.
Circulating the samādhi fire of the microcosmic orbit,
Tempering true emptiness to return to the Great Vacuity.
Visiting the immortal capital, receiving the celestial talisman—
Only then is one a true man, a great hero."*

Wu Yuanben interprets the word *"middle"* as *"three fields,"* yet still understands it as the wondrous aperture of the middle.

**[Liu’s Commentary]**
The treasure of the primordial true spirit is fundamentally empty in substance, coalescing as a single qi—how could there be a flower? Since there is no flower, no form or image, it is difficult to depict or illustrate. If it cannot be depicted or illustrated, how could it have a name or surname? Yet though nameless and surnameless, it is utterly empty and utterly numinous—silent and unmoving, yet responsive when stimulated, like an echo answering a call in a valley: within true emptiness lies wondrous existence. With this marvel of responsiveness, one seizes the opportunity at the point of resonance, capturing it and placing it within the alchemical furnace of the three fields, using the true fire of samādhi to temper and refine it into reality. From true emptiness, one may return to the Great Vacuity. When the Dao returns to the Great Vacuity, emptiness is no longer empty—only the One Real remains, with nothing else. The three fields are not the common Daoist terms for the *qihai*, *jiangong*, and *niwan*; rather, they are the cinnabar field where the three treasures—essence, qi, and spirit—converge. This is called the Gate of the Mysterious Female, also known as the Mysterious Pass, the Central Yellow Court, the Alchemical Furnace, the Altar of Taiyi, the Gate of Wuji, or, in sum, the Aperture of Vacuity. The treasure of the primordial true spirit governs the three substances—essence, qi, and spirit. Once the true spirit is restored, the three substances are all restored, self-generating and self-transforming, harmoniously blending in primordial unity. First, from non-being it creates being; then, from being it transforms into non-being. Tempering true emptiness is the marvel of transforming from being into non-being. Once being is transformed into non-being, both form and spirit attain perfection, becoming one with the Great Vacuity. With merit and practice complete, one visits the immortal capital and receives the celestial talisman, becoming a Perfected One of the Ten Poles and Great Loftiness—the great man’s work is accomplished.

**Eulogy:**
Revealing the secrets of Laozi and Zhuangzi,
Continuing the heart-transmission of Zhong and Lü.
Unveiling the wondrous principle of the primordial,
Cleaving open the tangled paths of the void.
Distinguishing true and false in the crucible,
Clarifying genuine and spurious in the medicine.
Emptiness and form blend into a single qi,
Hard and soft pair like two strings.
Hark!
The entire process of the elixir method is fully disclosed,
The fire phases of advance and retreat are wholly inscribed.
The *Twenty-Four Songs of Longevity*—
Whoever understands them becomes an immortal, never to die.

**[Li’s Explanation]**
The word *"non-being"* carries forward the meaning of *"emptiness"* from the previous chapter, advancing the idea to conclude the twenty-four songs. Refining the elixir to the point of emptiness is already perfect, yet if there remains a thought of true emptiness, then there arises a thought of Dharma-aspects—emptiness still falls short of non-being. Laozi said: *"Observe emptiness as empty; emptiness is no longer empty. What is emptied is already non-existent; even non-existence is non-existent—profoundly still and eternally quiescent."* This alone is great transcendence, great awakening, great purity, and great perfect enlightenment. Why? The wondrous existence of profound stillness appears as emptiness, yet is emptiness and non-being—it cannot be sought through form or image, nor depicted through illustration. Because it is formless and imageless, it is difficult to depict or illustrate; one can only abide in its profound stillness. Previously, when gathering the primordial, there were names like *"gold"* for essence, *"yellow"* for the sprout, and *"white"* for the primordial. But this profound stillness of the true has no name or surname. Though nameless and surnameless, it heeds the call—an echo in an empty valley, each sound answering the last. Questioned, it responds as if commanded; it is the utmost subtlety of heaven and earth.

Silent and unmoving, yet responsive and instantly penetrating—this is the utmost spirit of heaven and earth. Why is this so? Because the profound stillness of the true is concealed within nothingness. The principles of sages, immortals, and buddhas deeply penetrate creation, hiding existence within non-existence. At this level, the uncanny and wondrous manifest, as seen in figures like Leng Qijing, Zhang Jinghua, and Zhou the Mad Immortal.

Our Master Sanfeng, embodying the Dao as his essence, must grasp nothingness with nothingness to enter the intermediary realm of emptiness and non-being. There, great creation and transformation unfold: within the crucible, the true fire of the Zhou Tian Samadhi is stirred, refining and forging until the Dharmakaya of emptiness returns to the Great Non-Being. The Great Non-Being is the realm of the sagely and true—it is the Jade Purity’s Chaos of Great Non-Being and the High Purity’s Crimson Chaos of Great Non-Being.

Those who refine themselves into immortality receive only the ranks of the Grand Purity. Yet if one can return to the Great Non-Being, they first pay homage to the Dao and its virtue, then to the Jade Emperor, and finally to the Primordial Beginning, attaining the fruition of the Three Purities. This "return" signifies that all foolish men and women are originally beings of the Three Purities. However, due to errors in past thoughts, they descend through kalpas, remaining as foolish men and women, unable to regain the realm of the sagely and true. If they turn their hearts toward goodness, seek the Dao, and find a teacher, progressing from foundational cultivation to self-refinement, undergoing the seven returns and nine restorations, refining until emptiness and returning to non-being—from non-being, they return to the Great Non-Being—then they are once more guests of the Three Purities.

Yet to forge the true emptiness, the fire of the Zhou Tian Samadhi must be employed. The Zhou Tian is not the "River Chariot" but rather the movement within heaven, its coils unfolding across the void, deeply penetrating the subtle transformations of the Dao’s natural law. Samadhi is not the "yang fire" but rather the union of heaven’s one and earth’s two into three. Within the midst of heaven and earth, I establish the tripod and arrange the furnace, where spirit and qi merge in obscurity—this is the immortal’s fire for refining immortals, the celestial elixir of primordial spirit.

When merit is complete and conduct perfected, one ascends to pay homage to the Three Heavens, visits the immortal capitals, receives celestial decrees, and may be enfeoffed as a True Lord, an Imperial Lord, a Heavenly Venerable, or appointed to offices such as the Five Peaks, renowned mountains, grotto-heavens, or blessed lands as a master of immortal selection. Only then is one a true man, the greatest of great men—divine to the utmost degree!

In praise:
Scattering the flower-rain that fills the sky,
Spreading golden earth across the land.

With hands striking the fish-drum and clapper,
With mouth singing the immortal melodies of the Upper Grotto.
The Four Continents all receive the teaching,
The Dao’s sentiment spans ten thousand ages.

Ah!
Wherever the Primal Awakening speaks, true numina abide—
First hold fast to the intent of our school.
This mountain dweller proclaims the true instructions by the book,
Broadly opening the Non-Dual Gate to deliver the world.

Master Zhang Sanfeng’s *Wúgēnshù* ("Rootless Tree") commentary,
*Dàoqíng* ("Dao Sentiments") in twenty-four songs—
The complete scroll concludes.

chunks.original_text: 三丰祖师全集 序 古来一隐一见，而不失其正道者，其惟至人乎？ 能隐而不能见，则闲冷之意深，于世无益也； 能见而不能隐，则消磨之日甚，于己无成也，虽然，出而霖雨，入而烟霞，岂遂枯寂无为乎？ 抑非也？ 上真隐世复度世； 见人不附人，是又隐见之神奇者耳。 我三丰祖师，具知几之明，存正谊之理。 其为儒道也，身可进亦可退； 其为仙道也，身能飞亦能潜。 进退飞潜之间，即犹龙之大道也。 锡龄风尘俗吏，未省根源，幼读儒书，只期用世。 今倦矣，将长往云山，与安期、羡门游矣。 曩者官剑南，擢水北，宦潮迭起，尘海忧劳，幸遇我祖师，名言提警。 招龄至前而语之曰：『方今圣人在上，下有贤宰辅、名公卿相与佐治，子无忘蓬山共处时也。 』退而思之，始大觉焉。 夫当此昌期，讵甘瓠落？ 但念九州岛驰驱如龄等辈者，得之不多，失之不少，何苦长罹世网也。 因将我祖师丹经二卷。 诗文若干篇，夙夜寻求，以图解脱。 暇则梦寐间、山水间、鸾鹤间，复蒙祖师面示。 谓其道始于太上，而祖于希夷，隐则隐，见则见，有隐中之见，有见中之隐，斯无隐之非见，无见之非隐，总不趋谒君公、高谈金石，而为方术者流也。 龄乃记祖师显迹三十余则藏之，其伭机妙旨，有所亲得者，存其文而略存口诀，恐其即于漏泄也； 他日龄凌风万里，跨鹤三山，此书又付何人哉？ 雍正元年小阳之月诰授通议大夫河南全省河道副使梦九汪锡龄稽首熏沐谨撰 序 有明之初，仙人辈出，南昌周颠仙、临川张景华、协律郎冷启敬，是皆默观景运，翊赞奇勋者； 然其嬉笑神奇，震动天子，方士即沿此欺人也。 张三丰先生跨辽东鹤，摄蓟北云，以文学才识受知廉平章，奏补县令，旋复致仕归家，从赤松子游。 至正间，先生已浩然有得矣。 道光初，余归自浙，于今秉铎嘉阳，每当课土之暇，辄爱养生之书。 常于李子斋头，得故剑南观察汪梦九先生所藏《三丰全集》，然后知文章出处，清矫不群，是亦嫏嬛中秘典也。 李生以其书历年既久，腐不堪披，亟欲梓而存之，并搜名山碑版、道院抄存者，以补其阙，由是郁郁然成一家言也。 昔宋太宗谓诸臣曰：『华山陈抟，独善其身，不干势利，可谓方外士矣。 』三丰其能绍希夷之风者欤？ 赐进士出身翰林院庶吉士知浙江青田县事嘉定府教授董承熙撰 叙 尝读《吕祖全书》，自全唐诗律及历朝遗迹、厘然备载，所以振元风而诏后学也。 张三丰先生道德崇高，元微莫测，文章浩翰，利济无方，与吕祖无异者也，其书曾刊于前明永乐时，久而版坏，然其散见于他书者，亦不少矣。 夫吕祖之书，成于涵三。 岂先生之书，竟听其散佚乎？ 或者时之未至也。 国初汪公梦九观察剑南时，先生显化于署中。 其辑兵爱民诸善政，得之先生者为多。 梦九藏旧本，拾遗文将付梓，并欲与巡抚奏请立祠，均未果，盖其时亦将至矣。 长乙山人、遁园居士，忘名利者也。 得先生书于梦九六世孙名昙者之家，十存七八。 因采诸书以补之，寿诸梨枣，以成梦九欲遂之志焉。 虽斋居弦诵，未徧历武当，宝鸡诸名胜，搜罗真迹，纤悉弗遗，然观集中本末终始，郁郁大成，实与《吕祖全书》相伯仲，即有遗佚，无妨续补也。
chunks.translated_text:
**Preface to *The Complete Works of Patriarch Sanfeng***

Since ancient times, those who could alternately conceal and reveal themselves without straying from the true Dao—were they not the perfected ones? Those who could conceal but not reveal sank deep into seclusion, benefiting the world not at all; those who could reveal but not conceal wore themselves away day by day, achieving nothing for themselves. Yet when they emerged, they brought timely rain; when they withdrew, they dwelled amid mist and clouds—how could they be barren and inactive? Surely not. The highest immortals conceal themselves in the world yet deliver the world; they appear to others without clinging to them—this is the marvel of concealment and revelation.

Our Patriarch Sanfeng possessed the clarity to perceive subtle signs and upheld the principle of righteousness. As a Confucian, he could advance or retreat as circumstances demanded; as an immortal, he could soar or remain hidden. In the interplay of advance and retreat, flight and concealment, he embodied the great Dao of the dragon.

I, Xi Ling, a humble official mired in the dust of the world, once failed to grasp the root of things. In my youth, I studied the Confucian classics, hoping only to serve the age. Now, weary, I long to wander forever among the clouds and mountains, to roam with Anqi and Xianmen. Formerly, when I served as an official in Jiannan, then in Shuibei, and later in Chaozhou, the cares of office and the sea of worldly troubles weighed heavily upon me. Fortunately, I encountered our Patriarch, whose enlightening words awakened me. He summoned me and said: *"Now that a sage rules above, with worthy ministers and renowned officials assisting in governance, do not forget the days when you dwelled with me on Penglai."* Reflecting on this afterward, I was profoundly enlightened.

In this flourishing age, how could I willingly fade into obscurity? Yet when I consider the countless officials like myself—few who attain, many who lose—why should I remain entangled in the world’s net? Thus, I took the two volumes of the Patriarch’s alchemical classics and his various poems and essays, studying them day and night to seek liberation. In moments of leisure, whether in dreams, among mountains and rivers, or in the company of phoenixes and cranes, I was again favored with the Patriarch’s direct instruction. He taught that the Dao originated with the Most High and was transmitted by Master Xiyi. To conceal is to conceal; to reveal is to reveal. There is revelation within concealment and concealment within revelation—nothing concealed is not revealed, and nothing revealed is not concealed. In all this, he never sought audience with lords or engaged in lofty discourse on gold and stone, nor did he belong to the school of mere techniques.

I have recorded over thirty instances of the Patriarch’s miraculous manifestations and preserved them. The profound subtleties I personally received, I have kept in written form while omitting the oral instructions, fearing their premature disclosure. One day, when I soar ten thousand miles on the wind and ride a crane to the Three Mountains, to whom shall I entrust this book?

Written in the first month of the minor yang of the first year of Yongzheng’s reign, by Wang Xiling, *Tongyi Dafu*, Vice Director of River Conservancy for Henan Province, with reverence and purification.

---

**Preface**

At the beginning of the Ming dynasty, immortals appeared in great numbers: Zhou Dianxian of Nanchang, Zhang Jinghua of Linchuan, and Leng Qijing, the *Xielü Lang*—all silently observed the trends of the age and aided in extraordinary achievements. Yet their playful miracles, which astonished even the Son of Heaven, were later imitated by charlatans to deceive others.

Master Zhang Sanfeng rode a crane across Liaodong and gathered clouds in Jibei. Recognized by Minister Lian for his literary talent and insight, he was recommended for the post of county magistrate, but soon resigned to return home and wander with Master Chisong. By the Zhizheng era, the Master had already attained profound realization.

In the early years of Daoguang, I returned from Zhejiang and now serve as an instructor in Jiayang. In my spare time from teaching, I have come to cherish books on nourishing life. Once, at the study of Master Li, I obtained *The Complete Works of Sanfeng*, preserved by the late Inspector Wang Mengjiu of Jiannan. Only then did I learn of the Master’s conduct in literature and withdrawal—his purity and loftiness, unmatched by others. This is indeed a secret treasure from the celestial library.

Master Li, finding the book decayed beyond use after many years, was eager to have it printed and preserved. He also gathered inscriptions from famous mountains and copies from Daoist abbeys to fill its gaps, thus compiling it into a coherent and distinctive work.

Formerly, Emperor Taizong of Song said to his ministers: *"Chen Tuan of Mount Hua, who cultivated himself in solitude without pursuing power or profit, may truly be called a transcendent scholar."* Could Sanfeng be the one to carry on the legacy of Xiyi?

Written by Dong Chengxi, *Jinshi*, Hanlin Bachelor, and Instructor of Qingtian County, Jiaxing Prefecture.

---

**Introduction**

I have read *The Complete Works of Patriarch Lü*, which meticulously compiles his regulated poetry from the Tang dynasty, his traces through successive dynasties, and serves to revive the primal wind and instruct later generations. Master Zhang Sanfeng’s virtue was lofty and profound, his writings vast and boundless, his beneficence universal—no different from Patriarch Lü. His works were once printed during the Yongle era of the former Ming, but the blocks decayed over time. Yet many of his writings survive in other collections.

Patriarch Lü’s works were compiled by Han San. Could Master Zhang’s works be allowed to scatter and vanish? Perhaps the time was not yet ripe. At the beginning of this dynasty, when Inspector Wang Mengjiu served in Jiannan, the Master manifested himself in his official residence. Many of Mengjiu’s virtuous policies in military and civil governance were inspired by the Master. Mengjiu preserved the old edition, gathered lost texts, and intended to print them, even planning to petition the governor to establish a shrine—yet none of these came to fruition. The time, it seems, was still not at hand.
