The Recluse of Changyi Mountain and the Hermit of Dun Garden, who have forgotten fame and profit, obtained the Master’s writings from the home of Mengjiu’s sixth-generation descendant, Wang Tan, with seven or eight parts out of ten preserved. They supplemented it with texts from other sources and had it printed on pearwood blocks, fulfilling Mengjiu’s unaccomplished wish.

Though I have not yet traveled extensively to Wudang, Baoji, or other famous sites to collect the Master’s authentic traces in exhaustive detail, upon examining the beginning and end of this collection, I find it a rich and complete work, comparable to *The Complete Works of Patriarch Lü*. Even if some parts are missing, they can be supplemented later.

chunks.original_text: 前明之访先生也，侧席旁求，十余年而不得。 先生独以隐世济世，维气运于人所不知之地，纤尘不染，高不可攀，高真上圣，莫过于此，明君且以『通微显化』封之，《明史》竟以方伎末流例之，误矣。 读此集者，见先生于文字中，复见先生于文字外，已飘飘乎欲仙也，会心人自领之耳。 赐进士出身内阁中书改保宁府教授致仕西来李迦秀谨叙 叙 程子谓却病延年则有，白日飞升则无。 欧阳公谓养生之术则有，神仙之事则无。 余以为却病、养生，即仙道也。 《黄庭经》云：『仙人道士非有神，积精累气以成真。 』诚平允之论哉！ 今夫谷，虚境也； 神，灵觉也。 虚灵不昧则成儒，谷神不死则成道，仙何异焉？ 三丰先生在元、明鼎革间，独全性命于乱世，不求闻达于诸侯，深造以道，欲其自得。 默念州县劳人币书招我，皆所以蔽虚灵而损谷神也，屏之弃之，避之藏之。 真所谓世有神仙，彼必深潜崖壑，惟畏人知者，先生之节贞矣。 风雪可眠，非徒却病； 须眉不老，何但养生！ 光之有日月之明，大之有沧海之水，又安知不有脱壳生翰、白日飞升、成仙于青霄之外者哉？ 雍正初，汪公梦九观察剑南，先生以法身显化其署，即谓五百年犹在人间可也。 公知神仙之道信而有征，于是以先生文章出处，辑为成书，盖欲与却病延年者大其观也。 卓庵刘君得汪书而补纪之，刊版传世。 后之颂其诗、读其书者，应知仙道之不虚也夫。 道光甲辰七夕长乙山人涵虚生叙 张三丰先生全集卷一 汉嘉长乙山人李西月重编　　张道渊子深氏敬书 阆中朱道生晚成子敬刊 侄　瑛春城 朱瓒素园仝校字 男　璜蟠溪 明天顺皇帝敕封诰命

In the late Ming dynasty, the search for the Master spanned over a decade, yet he remained elusive. Alone, he concealed himself in the world while aiding it, sustaining the qi and the fortunes of the age in a place unknown to all. Unsullied by even the faintest dust, he stood so lofty as to be beyond reach—no transcendent immortal or sagely being surpassed him. The enlightened Ming sovereign bestowed upon him the title *"Penetrating the Subtle, Manifesting Transformation,"* yet *The History of the Ming* mistakenly relegated him to the ranks of minor occult practitioners. Such an error!

Those who read this collection will encounter the Master within its words and again beyond them, feeling as though they too might ascend, light as a feather, toward immortality. Those with true understanding will grasp this of their own accord.

Respectfully inscribed by Li Jiaxiu of Xilai, former Hanlin Bachelor, Inner Court Secretary, and retired Professor of Baoning Prefecture.

---

Chengzi said: *"There are methods for warding off illness and prolonging life, but none for ascending to heaven in broad daylight."* Ouyang Xiu said: *"There are arts of nurturing life, but no such thing as immortals."* Yet I hold that warding off illness and nurturing life *are* the Dao of immortality. As *The Yellow Court Classic* states: *"Immortals and Daoists possess no divine powers; they accumulate essence and amass qi to attain perfection."* How just and balanced a view!

Now, the valley is emptiness; the spirit is numinous awareness. When emptiness and numinosity remain undimmed, one becomes a Confucian; when the valley spirit does not perish, one attains the Dao. How then is immortality different?

During the transition between the Yuan and Ming dynasties, Master Sanfeng alone preserved his nature and life amidst the chaos of the world. He sought no recognition from lords and princes, delving deeply into the Dao to realize it for himself. He silently reflected: when officials of prefectures and counties, burdened by toil, sent letters and gifts to summon him, these were but distractions that obscured his numinous awareness and harmed his valley spirit. Thus, he rejected them, cast them aside, evaded them, and concealed himself. Truly, as the saying goes: *"If there are immortals in the world, they must dwell deep in cliffs and ravines, fearing only that others might know of them."* Such was the Master’s steadfast integrity.

Amid wind and snow, he could sleep undisturbed—not merely warding off illness. His beard and brows remained unaged—far beyond mere life nurturance! Just as light is inseparable from the brilliance of sun and moon, and vastness from the waters of the sea, how can we deny the possibility of shedding the mortal coil, sprouting wings, ascending in broad daylight, and attaining immortality beyond the azure heavens?

In the early years of the Yongzheng reign, when Magistrate Wang Mengjiu governed Jiannan, the Master manifested his dharmakāya in the magistrate’s residence. One might well say he remained in the world even after five hundred years. Recognizing the truth and evidence of the immortal’s Dao, Magistrate Wang compiled the Master’s writings and deeds into a book, intending to broaden the perspective of those seeking to ward off illness and prolong life. Scholar Zhuo’an Liu obtained Wang’s compilation and supplemented its records, carving it onto printing blocks for transmission to later generations. Those who chant his poems and read his works should understand that the Dao of immortality is no empty claim.

Inscribed on the Seventh Night of the Seventh Month, Jiachen year of the Daoguang reign, by Hanxu Sheng of Changyi Mountain.

---

Respectfully transcribed by Zhang Daoyuan, styled Zishi
Carved by Zhu Daosheng, styled Wanchengzi, of Langzhong

chunks.original_text: 奉天承运皇帝制曰：朕惟仙风道骨，得天地之真元，秘典灵文，集阴阳之正气。 顾长生久视之术，成超凡入圣之功。 旷世一逢，奇踪罕见。 尔真人张三丰，芳姿颖异，雅志孤高。 得仙箓之秘诀，饵金鼎之灵膏。 去来倏忽，实得造化之机； 隐显微芒，吻合乾坤之妙。 兹特赠尔为通微显化真人，锡之诰命，以示褒崇。 尚期指教，式惠来英。 宝诰一 元朝名士，天师后昆。 鹤骨珊珊，龙髯拂拂。 非百里之小才，得一官而勇退。 出辽东而访道，入终南而遇师。 笠穿衲敝，寒暑不侵； 果熟丹成，纵横自在。 托歌词而谈道，响彻云霄； 藉尘垢而隐真，人称邋遢。 玉枢宣诏，金殿飞身。 玄妙无方，隐显莫测。 大忠大孝大慈大悲南极会上群仙领袖玄玄演正武当继武真君。 宝诰二 始青一炁，教阐十方。 积功勋于大明，度众生于廛市。 遇火龙而细参至道，入武当而调养谷神。 混俗和光，经纬五载； 入山面壁，考验九年。 大廷朝驾显飞升，名山古洞留仙迹。 方方开化，处处设坛。 演金科流传万世，证金丹度尽后学。 大悲大愿大慈大仁至灵至圣至公至明群真一元始祖广慈普度真君通微显化天尊。 宝诰三 中山旧令，上清律仙。 广三千之功行，证十二之圆通。 擅神灵变化之奇，精符篆龙蛇之体。 道高德重，炼人元而兼统地元； 和光同尘，潜玩世而即行度世。 寻有德之人，人人得度； 种无根之树，树树皆空。 讲先天之妙旨，为后进之梯航。 大悲大愿大圣大慈武当继教掌法仙师灵宝真人天雷主宰玄玄演道飞龙济世真人通微显化天尊。 宝诰四 至真传道，太清选仙。 居武当而启教，为文始之正传。 如痴如醉，混仙迹于丽春； 教孝教忠，阐玄风于华夏。 度万三于滇海，壻女同升； 续龙虎之神通，道法兼备。 十方宝筏，三教宗师。 大悲大愿大慈大仁至玄至妙至奇至神东华首相三清外臣雷霆神吏灵宝天师太和一炁始祖道通文远真君通微显化天尊。 宝诰五 玉虚上相，金阙高真。 德畅人神，经开井鬼。 广三千之功行，醒亿万之沈迷。 昔从元岳而成真，今继玄天而阐化。 扶正教无党无偏，辟旁门有声有色。 诛杀乾坤之方士，挽回道德之宗风。 指先天而对月，招后进以升云。 道妙无方，玄微莫测。 至灵至圣至大至尊体合自然神凝般若三教真宰一气权衡参法天师洞玄帝君犹龙六祖隐仙寓化虚微普度天尊。 参礼如来宣赐佛号并赞 神光熙照，性海澄清。 在尘出尘，隐世度世。 现医身而扶危拔困，偈众而阐道传经。 果证大罗金仙，道比达磨尊者。 大仁大愿大慈大悲三丰真师救难天尊邋遢静光佛菩萨摩诃萨。 列传 张三丰，辽东懿州人。

By the Mandate of Heaven and the Grace of the Emperor, a Proclamation is issued:

We reflect that those of immortal bearing and Daoist essence embody the true primal qi of Heaven and Earth, while secret scriptures and numinous texts gather the upright qi of yin and yang. They hold the arts of longevity and enduring vision, achieving the merit of transcending the mundane and entering sagehood. Such rare encounters across the ages, their wondrous traces seldom seen.

You, True Man Zhang Sanfeng, possess a refined countenance of exceptional brilliance and a noble aspiration of lofty solitude. You have mastered the secret formulas of the immortal registers and partaken of the numinous elixir from the golden crucible. Your comings and goings swift as lightning, you have truly grasped the mechanism of Creation; your concealment and manifestation subtle as a glimmer, perfectly aligning with the marvels of Heaven and Earth. Hereby, We specially confer upon you the title of *Tongwei Xianhua Zhenren* (True Man Who Penetrates the Subtle and Manifests Transformation), bestowing this edict of enfeoffment to express Our esteem and veneration. May you continue to guide and instruct, thereby benefiting the worthy of future generations.

**Precious Edict I**
A renowned scholar of the Yuan dynasty, descendant of the Celestial Masters.
With crane-like bones and dragon-like whiskers,
Not a petty talent for a hundred leagues, yet retiring boldly after a single office.
Leaving Liaodong to seek the Dao, entering Zhongnan to meet his master.
Tattered hat and patched robe, unharmed by cold or heat;
Fruit ripened, elixir perfected, roaming freely at will.
Expounding the Dao through song, his voice resounding through the clouds;
Concealing truth beneath dust and grime, men called him the Unkempt One.
Proclaiming the jade decree, his body soared in the golden hall.
Profound and boundless, his concealment and manifestation unfathomable.
*Great Loyalty, Great Filial Piety, Great Compassion, Great Mercy—Leader of the Assembly of Immortals at the Southern Culmen, Perfected Lord of Mysterious Mystery, Successor of the Martial Dao of Wudang.*

**Precious Edict II**
The Primordial Qi of the First Azure, teaching disseminated across the ten directions.
Accumulating merit and achievement for the Great Ming, delivering sentient beings in the marketplace.
Encountering the Fire Dragon and delving deeply into the Supreme Dao, entering Wudang to nurture the Valley Spirit.
Blending with the world while concealing one’s radiance, weaving through five years;
Entering the mountains to face the wall, undergoing trials for nine years.
Ascending in broad daylight at the imperial court, leaving immortal traces in ancient mountain grottoes.
Spreading transformation everywhere, establishing altars in every place.
Transmitting the Golden Regulations for ten thousand generations, verifying the Golden Elixir to deliver all later disciples.
*Great Compassion, Great Vow, Great Mercy, Great Benevolence—Most Numinous, Most Sacred, Most Impartial, Most Illuminated—Ancestral Founder of All Perfected Ones, True Lord of Vast Compassion and Universal Salvation, Heavenly Worthy of Penetrating the Subtle and Manifesting Transformation.*

**Precious Edict III**
Former magistrate of Zhongshan, Discipline Immortal of Shangqing.

**Names and Epithets**
His given name was Quanyi. Another name, Junshi; Sanfeng was his sobriquet. For his refusal to cultivate mere worldly blessings, he was also called Zhang Lǎtā. Of joyous and towering bearing, his form resembled a tortoise’s, his back a crane’s—great ears, round eyes, a beard bristling like halberds. Through winter and summer he wore but a single patched robe and straw raincoat. What he ate—whether a sheng or a dou—he consumed entirely; sometimes he ate but once in several days, sometimes not for months. Whatever he read, he never forgot. His wanderings knew no fixed abode; some said he could cover a thousand li in a day. Fond of jesting, he acted as if no one else were present.

Once, roaming the cliffs and ravines of Mount Wudang, he told people, “This mountain shall one day flourish greatly.” At the time, the Five Dragons, South Cliff, and Purple Cloud temples had all been ravaged by war. Sanfeng and his disciples cleared the brambles, removed the rubble, and built thatched huts to dwell in—only to leave soon after. The Taizu Emperor had long heard of his name, and in the twenty-fourth year of the Hongwu reign dispatched envoys to seek him, but they did not find him.

Later, he resided at Golden Terrace Abbey in Baoji. One day, he announced his impending death, left a gatha, and passed away. The county’s people prepared a coffin and laid him to rest. As they were about to inter him, sounds came from within the coffin. Opening it, they found him alive. He then traveled to Sichuan, where he met the Prince of Shu. Returning to Wudang, he journeyed through Xiang and Han, his traces ever more wondrous and elusive.

During the Yongle reign, the Chengzu Emperor sent the Supervising Secretary Hu Ying, accompanied by the eunuch Zhu Xiang, bearing an imperial edict, incense, and silks to seek him. They scoured the wild frontiers for years but did not encounter him. The emperor then commanded the Vice Minister of Works, Guo Jin, and the Marquis of Longping, Zhang Xin, to oversee over three hundred thousand laborers in the grand restoration of Wudang’s temples and abbeys, expending millions. Upon completion, the mountain was bestowed the name “Mount Taihe Taiyue,” and officials were appointed, seals cast for its governance. Thus was Sanfeng’s prophecy fulfilled.

Some say Sanfeng was a man of the Jin dynasty, that in the early Yuan he studied under the same master as Liu Bingzhong, and later learned the Dao at Upper Clarity Abbey in Luyi—yet none of this can be verified. In the third year of the Tianshun reign, the Yingzong Emperor conferred upon him the posthumous title “Perfected of Penetrating Mystery and Manifest Transformation,” though none could fathom whether he still lived.

**Further Biographical Account**
The Recluse of the Jetavana Grove records: Zhang Lǎtā, named Junshi, styled Xuan’yi; also called Xuanxuan. A native of Yizhou in Liaodong, he was the fifth son of Zhang Zhong’an. Of stalwart and imposing bearing, his form resembled a tortoise’s, his bones a crane’s—great ears, round eyes, a beard bristling like halberds, his topknot bound in one coil. He styled himself “Master Sanfeng of Preserving Harmony and Enduring Patience,” ever carrying a blade and measuring square. Through winter and summer he wore but a single patched robe. Sometimes he dwelt in desolate seclusion, sometimes wandered the marketplaces, vast and unconstrained, as if no one else were present. When questioned, he might remain silent all day; yet when discoursing on the Three Teachings and their scriptures, his words flowed ceaselessly, all rooted in the Dao, virtue, loyalty, and filial piety. He often foreknew events. Sometimes he ate but once in three to five days, or even once in two or three months—yet he could scale mountains as if flying. In the depths of winter, he might sleep in the snow, snoring like thunder. The people of his time marveled at him, hence his sobriquet, Zhang Lǎtā.

At the end of the Yuan, he resided at Golden Terrace Abbey in Baoji. One day, he announced his departure from the world and passed away. His followers prepared a coffin and laid him to rest, but when they opened it before burial, he had revived. He then entered Sichuan, reached Qin, traveled through Xiang and Deng, wandered Chang’an, and traversed Long, Min, and Gansu. In the early Hongwu reign, he entered Wudang, ascended Heavenly Pillar Peak, and visited all its famous sites. He had his disciple Qiu Yuanjing reside at Five Dragons, Lu Qiuyun at South Cliff, and Liu Guquan and Yang Shandeng at Purple Cloud. He himself built a thatched hut north of Banner Peak, naming it Encountering Perfection Abbey, and a grass hermitage at Earthen Wall, calling it Meeting Immortals Lodge, entrusting his disciple Zhou Zhide to guard it.

In the *gengwu* year of the Hongwu reign, he departed with a flick of his sleeve, vanishing without a trace. The next year, the Taizu Emperor sent Daoists from the Three Mountains to summon him to court, but he was nowhere to be found. Some said he dwelt in Cloud Gate Grotto in Qingzhou. In the early Yongle reign, the emperor dispatched the Supervising Secretary Hu Ying and the Commander Yang Yongji to seek him, but they did not find him. In the second month of the tenth year, the Chengzu Emperor wrote a letter and sent the Daoist Yuanxuzi to Wudang, where he built an altar at Xuanxuan’s old haunts, burned incense, and prayed for word of him—but to no avail. The emperor then composed a poem and bestowed it upon him, containing the lines: *“If you meet the true immortal Zhang Youdao, / Tell him I await him with longing.”*

By the end of the Tianshun reign, he appeared and disappeared at will.

From *Qixiu Leigao*
By Ming dynasty scholar Lang Ying

The immortal Zhang, styled Junshi, was called Quanyi. A native of Yizhou in Liaodong, he was also known as Xuanxuan, or by the sobriquet "Three Peaks Master of Preserving Harmony and Enduring Patience." In his time, people also called him "Zhang the Unkempt." In the third year of the Tianshun reign, he once came to pay homage to the emperor. I have seen his portrait: his beard and temples bristled upward, a single topknot hung down his back, his face was ruddy and his belly large, and he carried a bamboo hat. The emperor composed an edict for him, granting him the title *"Grand Perfected One of Penetrating the Subtle and Manifesting Transformations."*

From *Huaihai Zaji*
By Ming dynasty scholar Lu Xixing

The old immortal Three Peaks was a descendant of the Dragon-Tiger lineage. His ancestor, Lord Yuxian, was learned and skilled in astrological divination. He moved his family to Yizhou in Jin territory and lived among the common folk with his son, Chang. Only after Yizhou was taken by the Yuan did their names gradually become known, though Lord Chang remained one who roamed beyond the world. His wife, née Lin, had previously given birth to four sons in two pregnancies—Ao, You, Xiao, and Yao—all of whom died young. Later, she bore two more sons: Tong and Da. Tong was the old immortal. On the night of his birth, Lin dreamed that the Dipper Mother, the Primordial Sovereign, beckoned a great crane to alight upon the roof, where it let out three long cries before she awoke in startlement—only to find herself in labor. From childhood, he possessed extraordinary qualities, and in adulthood, he carried himself with talent and skill. While traveling in Yanjing, his old friend Liu Bingzhong saw him and marveled, saying, *"Truly, he is a celestial talent."*

He withdrew in silence, eventually securing a minor post in the bitter cold of Zhongshan, but upon returning home for mourning, he never again took office. He once remarked, *"Wealth and honor are like the wind-blown lamp or morning dew on grass; time passes like lightning or fleeting bubbles in rain."* Thus resolved, he dedicated himself to seeking the Dao. He sought masters on Mount Zhongnan and there received the wondrous teachings of the Fire Dragon. Gradually, he feigned madness and filth, so that none could recognize him. Throughout his life, he composed poetry and prose on tree bark, moss, tea dregs, spoons, and chopsticks—accumulating decades of work that he could still recite from memory, though he never transcribed it to show others. Thus, no one in the Yuan dynasty’s literary circles knew of him.

His son was Daoyi; his grandsons, Mingluan and Minghe. Luan, in the early Ming, relocated to Huaiyang. His sixth-generation descendant, the Daoist Huagu, was Luan’s direct grandson and a friend beyond the world to me. His family possessed a garden of exquisite beauty, where the old immortal once stayed. When questioned about past anecdotes, he presented several hundred poems of his travels, several precious scriptures, and a single scroll of alchemical secrets, commanding that they be preserved. Whenever Huagu spoke of these things to me, it stirred boundless reverie.

*Biography of Master Sanfeng*
Respectfully recorded by Wang Xiling

Master Sanfeng’s surname was Zhang, his given name Tong, and his courtesy name Junshi. His ancestors hailed from Longhushan in Jiangxi, and he often referred to himself as a descendant of the Celestial Masters. His father, Lord Yuxian, was learned in astrology and mathematics. At the end of the Southern Song, foreseeing that the imperial *qi* would rise from the north, he led his clan to Yizhou in Liaoyang. He had a son named Juren, also called Chang, with the courtesy names Zian and Zhongan, and the sobriquet Baishan—this was the Master’s father. In his prime, he possessed extraordinary talent, and when the Yuan Emperor Taizong summoned men of ability, dividing the examinations into three categories, Chang passed the policy essay section. Yet his nature was inherently indifferent to officialdom, and he spent his life in reclusion.

In the summer of the *dingwei* year of Emperor Dingzong’s reign, the Master’s mother, Madame Lin, dreamed of a primordial crane flying from the sea and sky—whereupon she gave birth to the Master on the ninth day of the fourth month, at the hour of *zi*. His appearance was striking, with the form of a tortoise and the bones of a crane, large ears, and round eyes. At five, his eyes were afflicted by a strange malady, and over time, his vision gradually dimmed.

chunks.original_text: 其时有张云庵者，方外异人也。 住持碧落宫，自号白云禅老。 见先生奇之曰：『此子仙风道骨，自非凡器，但目遭魔障，须拜贫道为弟子，了脱尘翳，慧珠再朗』，即送还。 太夫人许之，遂投云庵为徒。 静居半载而目渐明，教习道经过目便晓，有暇兼读儒、释两家之书，随手披阅，会通其大意即止。 忽忽七载，太夫人念之，云庵亦不留，遂拜辞归家，专究儒业。 中统元年，举茂才异等； 二年，称文学才识，列名上闻，以备擢用，然非先生素志也。 因显扬之故，欲效毛庐江捧檄意耳。 至元甲子秋，游燕京。 时方定鼎于燕，诏令旧列文学才识者待用，栖迟燕市。 闻望日隆，始与平章政事廉公希宪识。 公异其才，奏补中山博陵令，遂之官。 政暇访葛洪山，相传为稚川修炼处。 因念一官萧撒，颇同勾漏，予岂不能似稚川？ 越明年而丁艰矣，又数月而报忧矣。 先生遂绝仕进意，奉讳归辽阳，终日哀毁，觅山之高洁者，营厝甫毕，制居数载，日诵洞经。 倏有邱道人者，叩门相访，剧谈玄理，满座风清，洒然有方外之想。 道人既去，因束装出游，田产悉付族人，嘱代扫墓，挈二行童相随。 北燕赵，东齐鲁，南韩魏，往来名山古刹，吟咏闲观，且行且住。 如是者几三十年，均无所遇，乃西之秦陇，挹太华之气，纳太白之奇，走褒斜，度陈仓，见宝鸡山泽幽邃而清，乃就居焉。 中有三尖山，三峰挺秀，苍润可喜，因自号为三丰居士。 延祜元年，年六十七，始入终南，得遇火龙真人，传以大道。 更名玄素，一名玄化，自号玄玄子，别号昆阳。 山居四载，功效寂然。 闻近斯道者，必须法财两用，平生游访，兼颇好善，囊箧殆空，不觉泪下，火龙怪之，进告以故，乃传丹砂点化之诀，命出山修炼。 立辞恩师，和光混俗者数年。 泰定甲子春，南至武当，调神九载而道始成。 于是湘云巴雨之间，隐显遨游又十余岁，乃于至正初，由楚还辽阳，省墓讫，复之燕市，公卿故交，死亡已尽矣。 遂之西山，遇前邱道人，谈心话道，促膝参同，方知为长春先生符阳子也。 别后复至秦蜀，由荆楚之吴越，侨寓金陵，遇沈万三，传以丹道，事在至正十九年。 临别，先生预知万三有徙边之祸，嘱曰：『东南王气正盛，当晤子于西南也。 』仍还秦，居宝鸡金台观。 九月二十日，阳神出游，士人杨轨山以先生辞世，买棺收殓。 临窆之际，柩有声如雷，启视复生。 盖其阳神出游，朴厚者见之，以为宛其死矣。 后乃携轨山遁去。

At that time, there was a certain Zhang Yun’an, an extraordinary figure beyond the mundane world. He presided over the Biluo Palace and styled himself the White Cloud Chan Elder. Upon seeing the Master, he marveled, saying, "This child possesses the bearing of an immortal and the bones of a Daoist adept—truly no ordinary vessel. Yet his eyes are afflicted by demonic obstruction. He must take this poor monk as his master to dispel the dust-born veil and restore the radiance of his wisdom-pearl." He then sent the Master home. Madame Lin consented, and the Master became Yun’an’s disciple. After half a year of quiet seclusion, his eyes gradually brightened. He was taught Daoist scriptures, which he grasped upon a single reading. In his spare time, he also studied the books of the Confucian and Buddhist traditions, perusing them at will and comprehending their essential meanings before setting them aside. Seven years passed in this manner until Madame Lin grew homesick for him, and Yun’an did not detain him. Thus, the Master took his leave and returned home to devote himself to Confucian scholarship.

In the first year of the Zhongtong era, he was recommended as an exceptional talent; in the second year, his literary ability and erudition were noted, and his name was submitted to the throne for potential appointment. Yet this was not his true aspiration—he had merely sought to emulate Mao of Lujiang, who accepted an official post to honor his parents. In the autumn of the *jiazi* year of the Zhiyuan era, he traveled to Yanjing. At that time, the court had just established its capital there, and a decree summoned those previously listed for their literary talent to await employment. He lingered in the markets of Yanjing, his reputation growing daily, until he became acquainted with the Grand Councilor, Lord Lian Xixian. Struck by the Master’s talent, Lord Lian memorialized the throne to appoint him magistrate of Zhongshan and Boling, and the Master assumed office.

During his leisure from official duties, he visited Mount Gehong, said to be the place where Zichuan had cultivated the Dao. Reflecting on his own post, as desolate as the Goulou region, he mused, "Could I not follow Zichuan’s example?" The following year, however, he encountered the mourning of his father’s passing, and soon after, news of his mother’s death arrived. The Master then renounced all thought of official advancement. Observing the mourning rites, he returned to Liaoyang, where he grieved day and night. Seeking a lofty and secluded mountain, he arranged for his parents’ burial. Once the tomb was completed, he remained there for several years, reciting the *Dongjing* scriptures daily.

Suddenly, a certain Daoist adept named Qiu arrived at his door. Their profound discussion of metaphysical principles filled the room with a breeze of clarity, evoking in the Master a longing for the life beyond the world. After Qiu’s departure, the Master packed his belongings and set out on his travels, entrusting his fields and property to his clansmen with instructions to tend the graves. He took two young attendants with him and wandered north to Yan and Zhao, east to Qi and Lu, and south to Han and Wei, visiting famous mountains and ancient monasteries, composing poetry, and observing the world at leisure, sometimes staying, sometimes moving on. For nearly thirty years, he encountered nothing of significance.

Then he turned westward to Qin and Long, drawing in the qi of Mount Taihua and absorbing the marvels of Mount Taibai. He traversed the Baoxie Road, crossed Chen Cang, and found the valleys and marshes of Baoji Mountain deep and serene. There he settled. Within the mountain stood Three-Peak Mountain, its three summits towering and verdant, a delight to behold. Thus, he styled himself the Layman of Three Peaks.

In the first year of the Yanyou era, at the age of sixty-seven, he entered the Zhongnan Mountains and encountered the Fire Dragon Perfected, who transmitted to him the Great Dao. He changed his name to Xuansu, also called Xuanhua, and adopted the sobriquets Master Xuanyuan and Master Kunyang. After four years of dwelling in the mountains, his cultivation yielded no visible results. Hearing that those who pursued this path required both method and resources, and recalling his lifelong travels and generosity had nearly emptied his purse, he could not help but shed tears. The Fire Dragon, surprised, inquired into the matter and then transmitted to him the secret of transmuting cinnabar. He commanded the Master to leave the mountains and refine the elixir.

The Master took leave of his benevolent teacher and lived among the common people for several years, blending in without drawing attention. In the spring of the *jiazi* year of the Taiding era, he traveled south to Wudang, where he refined his spirit for nine years before finally achieving the Dao. Thereafter, he wandered in seclusion and openness for over a decade between the clouds of Xiang and the rains of Ba.

In the early years of the Zhizheng era, he returned from Chu to Liaoyang to visit his parents’ graves, then went back to Yanjing. There, he found that all the high officials and old acquaintances he had known were gone. He then retreated to the Western Mountains, where he encountered the Daoist adept Qiu from before. As they spoke of the heart and conversed on the Dao, sitting knee to knee in deep exchange, he realized Qiu was none other than Master Fuyang, the Perfected of Everlasting Spring.

After parting, he journeyed again to Qin and Shu, then from Jing and Chu to Wu and Yue, sojourning in Jinling. There he met Shen Wansan and transmitted to him the Dao of the Elixir. This occurred in the nineteenth year of the Zhizheng era. At their farewell, the Master foresaw that Wansan would face exile and urged him, "The royal qi of the southeast is still flourishing—we shall meet again in the southwest." He then returned to Qin and resided at the Golden Terrace Abbey in Baoji.

On the twentieth day of the ninth month, his yang spirit departed on a journey. A scholar named Yang Guishan, believing the Master had passed away, purchased a coffin and prepared his remains. As the coffin was about to be interred, a sound like thunder erupted from within. When opened, the Master was found alive. It turned out that his yang spirit had departed, and those of simple and honest nature had mistakenly believed him dead. Later, he took Guishan with him and vanished.

and he spent his life in reclusion.

In the summer of the *dingwei* year of Emperor Dingzong’s reign, the Master’s mother, Madame Lin, dreamed of a primordial crane flying from the sea and sky—whereupon she gave birth to the Master on the ninth day of the fourth month, at the hour of *zi*. His appearance was striking, with the form of a tortoise and the bones of a crane, large ears, and round eyes. At five, his eyes were afflicted by a strange malady, and over time, his vision gradually dimmed.

chunks.original_text: 又二年，沧桑顿改，海水重清，元纪忽终，明运又启，先生乃结庵于太和，故为疯汉，人目为邋遢道人。 道士邱元靖，安静可喜，秘收为徒。 他日入成都，说蜀王椿入道，不听，退还襄邓间，更莫测其踪迹矣。 洪武十七年甲子，太祖以华夷宾服，诏求先生，不赴。 十八年，又强沈万三敦请，亦不赴。 盖帝王自有道，不可以金丹金液分人主励精图治之思。 古来方士酿祸，皆因游仙入朝为厉之阶，登圣真者，决不为唐之叶法善、宋之林灵素也，前车可鉴矣。 二十五年，乃遁入云南，适太祖徙万三于海上，缘此践约来会，同炼天元服食大药。 明年成，始之贵州平越福泉山，朝真礼斗，候诏飞升。 建文元年，完璞子访先生于武当，适从平越归来，相得甚欢。 永乐四年，侍读学士胡广奏言先生深有道法，广具神通。 五年丁亥，即命胡濴等遍游天下访之。 十年壬辰，又命孙碧云于武当建宫拜候，并致书相请。 直逮十四年，并不闻有踪迹。 帝乃怒谓胡广曰：『卿言张三丰蕴抱玄机，胡弗敢来见朕也？ 』斥广寻觅之。 广大惧，星夜抵武当，焚香泣祷。 是年五月朔，为南极万寿，老君命诸仙及期大会，时先生亦在诏中，遂与玄天官属御气同行，适见胡广情切，乃按云车，许以陛见入朝后，即赴上清之命，飘然而去。 明年，胡濴等还朝，终末得见先生也。 吾师乎！ 吾师乎！

Two years later, the world underwent sudden upheaval—seas cleared anew, the Yuan dynasty’s reign abruptly ended, and the Ming’s fortune dawned. The Master then built a hut on Mount Taihe, feigning madness; people called him the "Slovenly Daoist." A Daoist named Qiu Yuanjing, serene and admirable, secretly took him as his disciple.

Later, he entered Chengdu and urged King Chun of Shu to embrace the Dao, but the king refused. Retreating to the region between Xiang and Deng, he vanished without a trace. In the seventeenth year of the Hongwu era, as the emperor saw all under heaven submit, he issued an edict seeking the Master, who did not respond. The following year, Shen Wansan was pressed to extend another invitation, but again, the Master declined. For emperors possess their own Dao—golden elixirs and liquid gold cannot divert a sovereign’s resolve to govern with diligence. Since ancient times, alchemists have courted disaster by entering court as immortals; those who ascend to sagehood and perfection never become like Tang’s Ye Fashan or Song’s Lin Lingsu—past missteps serve as warning enough.

In the twenty-fifth year, he vanished into Yunnan. Coincidentally, the emperor had exiled Wansan to the coast, and thus the Master fulfilled their pact, meeting him to refine the Great Medicine of Heavenly Primordial ingestion. The following year, the work complete, he first traveled to Fuquan Mountain in Pingyue, Guizhou, where he paid homage to the Perfected and worshipped the Dipper, awaiting the imperial summons to ascend.

In the first year of the Jianwen era, Wanpuzi sought the Master on Mount Wudang. Arriving just as he returned from Pingyue, they rejoiced in their reunion. In the fourth year of the Yongle era, the Academician Reader Hu Guang memorialized that the Master possessed profound Daoist arts and wondrous powers. In the fifth year, the emperor dispatched Hu Ying and others to search for him across the realm. In the tenth year, Sun Biyun was ordered to build a palace on Wudang and await his arrival, even sending a letter to invite him. Yet by the fourteenth year, no trace of him had been found.

Enraged, the emperor rebuked Hu Guang: *"You claimed Zhang Sanfeng harbored arcane mysteries—why does he dare not come before me?"* He commanded Guang to seek him out. Terrified, Guang hastened to Wudang by night, burning incense and weeping in prayer. On the first day of the fifth month that year, as the Southern Culmen celebrated the myriad longevity of the Old Lord, the immortals gathered at the appointed hour. The Master was among those summoned, and with the officials of the Dark Heaven Palace, he rode the qi in unison. Noticing Guang’s earnest plea, he halted his cloud chariot and promised that after an audience at court, he would fulfill the command to ascend to the Upper Clarity. Then, he drifted away like mist.

The following year, Hu Ying and his party returned to court, having never glimpsed the Master. *O my teacher! O my teacher!*

chunks.original_text: 其隐中之仙乎！ 其仙中之神乎！ 其神仙而天仙者乎！ 继荷玉诏，高会群真，位列兑宫，身成干体，故能神通变化，济世度人。 四围上下，虚空处处，皆鸾骖所至，将所谓深藏宏愿，广大法门者，吕祖之后，惟先生一身而已。 锡龄风尘俗吏，几忘去声本原，观察剑南，又鲜仁政，滥叨厚禄，辜负皇恩。 两年来曦天少见，水潦频增，龄乃跣足剪甲，恭祷眉山之灵。 拈香七日，晴光普照，画景遥开，奇峰异水间幸遇先生，鉴龄微忱，招龄入道，并示《丹经秘诀》一章，及《捷要篇》二卷，照法修炼，始识玄功。 因此悔入宦途。 游情山水，迩乃自出清奉，结庐凌云，未知何年何日蝉脱尘网，采瑶花、奉桃实敬献先生也。 龄侍先生甚久，得悉先生原本又甚详，爰洗浊怀，恭为纪传，以付吾门嗣起者。 三丰先生传　　　　　　　　　圆峤外史 先生辽阳懿州人也，史号屡更，游行无定，人多不测其踪，刘秉忠同师。 于前至元间以廉希宪荐剡，于后至元间以宰官致仕。 洪武初年，太祖屡诏不出，盖其托仙远遁，以全仕元之节者也。 故尝自称曰：大元遗老，又尝自赞曰：大元逸民。 君子深慨其神仙名重，遂至掩其孤忠耳。 平生访道，历尽艰辛，终南遇师之后，觅侣求铅者足遍天涯，乃于武当山修成大道。 所可异者，先生未降世，而武当一席，早为安排。 昔希夷先生游太华，遇异人孙君访曰：『武当九室岩深静可居，君后有徒孙。 更能发迹此山，君光大张。 』盖已知名山有主人，大道有法嗣也。 岂不异乎！ 尝闻苦竹真君传记于锺离云房，谓他日有两口者为汝弟子，而其后竟遇吕祖。 夫岂至人降灵，必先有年月日时、里居姓氏，预定于大罗天上耶？ 不然何言之验也。 圆通真人为先生弟子，亦不能请究其故。 《本传》一篇，记叙精详，《仙鉴》、《明纪》，考政皆合，然后知先生之籍贯生成。 修真得道，有如是其全备者。 道派 大道渊源，始于老子，一传尹文始，五传而至三丰先生。 虽然，老子之所传亦甚多矣，其间杰出者，尹文始、王少阳，支分派别，各有传人，今特就文始言之。 文始传麻衣，麻衣传希夷，希夷传火龙，火龙传三丰。 或以为隐仙派者，文始隐关令、隐太白，麻衣隐石堂、隐黄山，希夷隐太华，火龙隐终南，先生隐武当，此隐派之说也。 夫神仙无不能隐，而此派更为高隐。 孔子曰：『老子其犹龙乎』？ 言其深隐莫测也，故又称犹龙派云。 按老子之道，文始派最高，少阳派最大。 少阳传正阳，正阳传纯阳，纯阳首传王重阳，重阳传邱长春，开北派； 纯阳又传刘海蟾，海蟾传张紫阳，开南派。 再按文始一派，至麻衣而传希夷； 少阳一派，刘海蟾亦以丹法传希夷，两派于斯一汇。 是三丰先生，谓为文始派也可，谓为少阳派也亦可，特其清风高节，终与麻衣、希夷、火龙相近云。 前历祖传 太上老君，其详不可得闻，累世化身，未有诞生之迹。 尝与文始言：『吾姓字渺渺，从劫至劫，不可具述，非虚语也』。 逮商阳甲时，分神化燕，始寄胎于玄妙玉女八十一年。 至武丁庚辰岁，二月十五日卯时，降生在苦县之赖乡曲人里李树下。 指李为姓，名耳，字伯阳。 生时白首，人号为老子； 又长耳，号称老聃。

O hidden immortal among the reclusive! O divine being among the immortals! O celestial immortal among the divine transcendents! Having received the Jade Edict, he ascended to the grand assembly of the perfected, ranked among the Palace of Dui, his body refined into a celestial vessel—thus could he wield divine transformations, succoring the world and delivering its people. In every direction, above and below, wherever the void extended, his simurgh-drawn chariot arrived, for he embodied the profound vow and the vast Dharma-gate. Since Lüzu’s time, none but the Master alone had borne such a mantle.

I, Xi Ling, a dust-bound official of the mundane world, had nearly forgotten my original tone and root. While inspecting Jiannan, I seldom practiced benevolent governance, yet undeservedly enjoyed rich emoluments, thus betraying the imperial grace. For two years, the sun had rarely shone, and floods had repeatedly risen. Thereupon, I bared my feet, pared my nails, and reverently prayed to the spirit of Mount Mei. For seven days I offered incense, until radiant sunlight bathed all, and distant vistas unfolded—amidst wondrous peaks and strange waters, I fortunately encountered the Master. Discerning my humble sincerity, he summoned me into the Dao and bestowed upon me a chapter of the *Secret Formulae of the Elixir Canon* and two scrolls of the *Essentials of Swift Attainment*. Following his method in cultivation, I first glimpsed the mysterious workings. Henceforth, I repented my entry into officialdom. My spirit roamed mountains and rivers, and soon I resigned my post, built a hut beneath Lingyun, yet know not in what year or day I may shed the net of the worldly, gather jade blossoms, and offer peach fruits in homage to the Master.

Having served the Master for long, I learned his origins in great detail. Thus, purifying my turbid heart, I reverently compile this account to pass on to those who shall succeed in our lineage.

---

**A Biography of Master Sanfeng**
*By Yuanqiao Waishi*

The Master was a native of Yizhou in Liaoyang. His sobriquets changed repeatedly, and his wanderings knew no fixed abode, so that many could not fathom his whereabouts. He shared a teacher with Liu Bingzhong. During the early Zhiyuan era, he was recommended by Lian Xixian and appointed to office; in the later Zhiyuan era, he retired from his official post. In the early Hongwu reign, the Taizu Emperor repeatedly summoned him, but he never emerged, for he had concealed himself as an immortal to preserve his loyalty to the Yuan. Thus, he once styled himself "A Remnant Elder of the Great Yuan" and also praised himself as "A Recluse of the Great Yuan." Gentlemen deeply lamented that his renown as a divine immortal had overshadowed his solitary loyalty.

In his lifelong quest for the Dao, he endured countless hardships. After meeting his teacher on Zhongnan Mountain, he sought companions and the "lead" elixir across the ends of the earth, ultimately attaining the Great Dao on Mount Wudang. What is most extraordinary is that before the Master’s descent into the world, a place on Wudang had already been prepared for him. Formerly, Master Xiyi, while traveling on Mount Taihua, encountered the extraordinary figure Sun Jun, who inquired: "The Nine-Chambered Cliff on Wudang is secluded and tranquil—fit for dwelling. Your later disciple shall arise from this mountain, and your glory shall greatly flourish." For he already knew that the famous mountain had its master, and the Great Dao had its Dharma-heir. Is this not extraordinary?

I once heard in the records of the Venerable Kuzhu that Master Zhongli Quan had foretold: "One day, a man with two mouths shall be your disciple," and later he indeed met Lüzu. Could it be that when a perfected one descends, their birth year, month, day, hour, native place, and surname are predestined in the Great Luo Heaven? Otherwise, how could such words prove so accurate? Even Yuantong Zhenren, a disciple of the Master, could not inquire into the reason.

This *Primary Biography*, meticulously recorded, aligns with the *Immortal Mirror* and the *Ming Annals* in its investigations. Only then did I learn the Master’s native place and birth, his cultivation of truth and attainment of the Dao—so complete was he in all these.

---

**Daoist Lineage**
The wellspring of the Great Dao began with Laozi, who transmitted it to Yin Wen-shih. After five transmissions, it reached Master Sanfeng. Though Laozi’s transmissions were many, among the most eminent were Yin Wen-shih and Wang Shaoyang. Branching into various lineages, each had its own heirs. Here, I shall speak only of Wen-shih’s line.

Wen-shih transmitted to Ma Yi, Ma Yi to Xiyi, Xiyi to Huolong, and Huolong to Sanfeng. Some regard this as the "Hidden Immortal Lineage": Wen-shih concealed himself as a magistrate and on Mount Taibai; Ma Yi hid in Shitang and on Mount Huang; Xiyi on Mount Taihua; Huolong on Zhongnan; and the Master on Wudang. This is the theory of the Hidden Lineage. While all divine immortals can conceal themselves, this lineage is especially profound in its reclusion.

Confucius said: "Laozi is like a dragon!"—referring to his deep concealment beyond fathoming. Thus, this line is also called the "Dragon-like Lineage." Of Laozi’s Dao, Wen-shih’s line is the highest, while Shaoyang’s line is the greatest. Shaoyang transmitted to Zhengyang, Zhengyang to Chunyang, Chunyang first to Wang Chongyang, and Chongyang to Qiu Changchun, establishing the Northern Lineage. Chunyang also transmitted to Liu Haichan, Haichan to Zhang Ziyang, establishing the Southern Lineage.

Tracing Wen-shih’s line, it passed to Ma Yi and then to Xiyi; tracing Shaoyang’s line, Liu Haichan also transmitted the elixir method to Xiyi, where the two lineages converged. Thus, Master Sanfeng may be called of Wen-shih’s line, or of Shaoyang’s line—yet his pure wind and lofty integrity ultimately aligned him more closely with Ma Yi, Xiyi, and Huolong.

---

**Succession of Former Ancestors**
The details of the Most High Lord Lao are unknowable. Across kalpas, he manifested in countless incarnations, leaving no trace of birth. Once, he told Wen-shih: "My surname and given name are boundless, spanning kalpas beyond recounting—this is no empty speech." By the time of King Wu Ding of Shang, he divided his spirit to transform into a swallow, first gestating in the womb of the Mysterious Wondrous Jade Maiden for eighty-one years. In the gengchen year of King Wuding’s reign, on the fifteenth day of the second month at the hour of mao, he was born beneath a plum tree in Lai Village, Quren Hamlet, in Ku County. Taking the plum as his surname, he was named Er, styled Boyang. Born with white hair, he was called "Laozi"; his long ears earned him the name "Laodan."

**Eleven Later Records of Immortals: Accounts of Reclusive Worthies**

**Master Sanshan** was surnamed Shen, named Wansan, also called Wanshan, and styled himself the Daoist of Sanshan. A native of Jinling, he was a great fisherman of the Qinhuai, kind-hearted and fond of almsgiving. He encountered Master Sanfeng, from whom he received the method of elixir refinement. After further cultivating the Great Medicine of Heavenly Origin, he consumed it and ascended with his entire household. At times he concealed himself on Tianmu Mountain, at others on Wudang, with no fixed abode. Like Master Sanfeng, he appeared and vanished at will, transcending the world. He was imperially bestowed the title "Perfected of Vast Vows." Born in the first year of the Tianli reign of the Yuan dynasty, on the eighteenth day of the ninth lunar month, at the hour of *wei*.

**Qiu Yuanjing** was a Daoist of Wudang. In the early Hongwu reign, Master Sanfeng wandered to Wudang, where Yuanjing met him and became his disciple. Sanfeng transmitted to him the wonders of the Dao and instructed him to reside at Five Dragons, where he built a hut to cultivate and fulfill his great task. In the spring of the *yichou* year, Emperor Taizu issued an edict seeking Master Sanfeng but failed to find him. He then summoned Yuanjing, and upon conversing with him, was pleased. The emperor appointed him Surveillance Commissioner and offered him a residence, which he declined. He was then promoted to Minister of Rites, but again refused, prompting the emperor to praise his lofty integrity.

**The Four Immortals of Taihe**—Lu Qiuyun, Zhou Zhide, Liu Guquan, and Yang Shandeng—were all natives of Chu. In the early Hongwu reign, Master Sanfeng entered Wudang and built a hut on Zhanqi Peak. The four sought him as their teacher, and he transmitted to them the secret of preserving quietude and centeredness. He then instructed Qiuyun to reside at South Cliff, Zhide at the Hall of Meeting Immortals, and Guquan and Shandeng at Purple Cloud Peak. They cultivated in stillness simultaneously and later all attained realization.

**Master Ice Vessel** was surnamed Ming, named Zheng. A native of Neijiang, he was skilled in talismans and incantations, which often produced miraculous effects. During the Yongle reign, Master Sanfeng traveled to Shu and frequently lodged at his home. Ming wished to transmit his methods of talismans and incantations to Sanfeng, who smiled and said, "I shall offer you the Dao—how can you teach me your arts?" He then composed *A Memorial on the Convergence of Dao and Method* and presented it to Ming, who was greatly astonished and begged to become his disciple. After residing together for over a year, Hu Yong visited Master Sanfeng and took Ming away with him; their whereabouts thereafter were unknown.

**Wang Zongdao** was a native of Huaian. He once studied the Dao under Master Sanfeng. In the third year of the Yongle reign, Emperor Chengzu sought Master Sanfeng and ordered Zongdao to be found. He went with Hu Yong, and upon being summoned, was granted a golden crown and crane-feather robe, along with an imperial letter and incense to travel throughout the realm. After ten years without success, he returned and was bestowed the title "Perfected of Perfect Virtue." Later, he entered Mount Lu to gather herbs and vanished without a trace.

**Master Li** was named Xingzhi, a native of Chu. During the Zhengde reign, he entered Mount Taihe and encountered Master Sanfeng, who transmitted to him the method of elixir refinement, enabling him to attain the Dao. He was fond of sitting upright in stillness, composed and dignified, earning him the name "Master Li." He practiced grain avoidance and daily drank a broth of wheat flour, so people also called him "Bran Li." Prince Yongding of Jing, having heard of him with admiration, dispatched an envoy to invite him. He was lodged at the Wudang Palace in Qi, wearing tattered robes and abstaining from food.

The prince repeatedly summoned him to the palace to seek the secret of longevity, but he never responded, merely stating, "For a Confucian, cultivating the self and ordering the household is itself the secret of the Dao." Though lavished with gold and silk, he paid no heed. Later, he took his leave to return home, and the prince sent an attendant to escort him, instructing him to demand a written reply upon completion of his mission. When they reached the boat at Hankou, Master Li suddenly vanished. The attendant hurried the boatman to cross the river, and midstream, he suddenly saw Li lying upon the water and crossing. When the attendant reached the shore, Li had also arrived, only to disappear again. The attendant rushed to the mountain and found Li sitting on a perilous cliff, clapping his hands and singing. Soon after, Li shouted to the attendant, "Convey my thanks to the prince—Li shall not return again." As the attendant sought the promised written reply, Li vanished in an instant. Later, the prince sent another attendant to the mountain, who was told that Li had undergone *shijie* (corporeal liberation). On the return journey, the attendant again saw Li holding a begging bowl, moving as swiftly as if flying. Before long, the prince, through Qian Zongzheng’s memorial, nearly lost his state, and only then did he realize Li’s words had not been spoken lightly.

Having encountered Master Sanfeng on Mount Emei, he attained the subtleties of his Dao. Later, he was appointed as Intendant of the Yongbei Circuit in southern Yunnan, but immediately requested to retire to care for his parents, though his petition was not granted. Soon after, he was appointed Vice Commissioner of River Conservancy for the entire province of Henan. Taking the opportunity to return home for a visit, he achieved *dan*-completion and underwent *shijie*. He was styled "Perfected Adept of Universal Penetration." He collated *The Essential Mysteries* and composed *The Authentic Biography of Sanfeng*, *Manifest Traces*, and other chapters that have been transmitted to later generations. He was born in the year *jiachen* of the Kangxi reign, on the eighteenth day of the tenth month, at the hour of *shen*.

To this day, the Clear Radiance Pavilion on Danxia Peak of Mount Lingyun in Jiazhou remains the place where, in his spare time from official duties, he secretly cultivated his spirit and refined the elixir. Within it stands the Hall of the Numinous Mountain, where a plaque records the names of several hundred elders from Jiannan who celebrated his longevity, all hailing him as the benevolent and pure Perfected Master of Universal Penetration, who cultivated himself and governed others.

As for Master Baibai, his surname and given name remain unspoken. His dwelling lay amidst the mountains and waters of Qingcheng, Great Emei, and Jiazhou. He played the zither, read books, and was deeply fond of Laozi and Zhuangzi. In the early years of the Daoguang reign, he met Master Zhang Sanfeng on Mount Sui, who transmitted to him the mysteries of *jiaogou* and the Mysterious Female, as well as the Great Talisman of the Golden Crucible. Later, he encountered the Pure Yang Patriarch, from whom he learned the subtleties of gathering medicinal substances. Resolved to cultivate with utmost dedication, he daily conversed with two or three recluses, discussing misty peaks and evaluating waters and rocks. His worldly ambitions had grown as cold as ice.

His writings include *The River Chart and Luo Writing: An Illustrated Exegesis of the Changes*, *The True Meaning of the Dao and Its Virtue*, and *The Inner Chapters of the Round Isles*, which elucidate the stages of inner and outer alchemy in ways unprecedented in the ancient immortals’ classics. When idle, he blended with the world and harmonized with its light, silently embracing the profound mysteries. He is listed in the lineage of the immortals.

chunks.original_text: 余十舍者，沈万山弟子也。 少好施与，万山以幼女妻之，传以丹砂点化，丰饶与妇翁相颉顽。 其文余蕙刚，为西平侯沐春继室，亦善黄白之术，盖家传也。 事见本集中『余氏父女传』。 陆德原者，吴人也。 家故清微，慕神仙之学。 沈万山先生见之，知为道器，遂传以玄微妙旨，并为黄白给之，其家遂足。 与顾阿瑛、李鸣风相往来，诗坛酒社，东南士大夫称其富而好礼。 洪武初，尝助军粮二万斛，既闻，太祖有『不及江南富足翁』之句，因慨然曰：『祸端至矣』。 及时携琴披衲，改装黄冠而遁。 阿瑛闻之，亦削发为僧。 鸣凤弃家园、携妻子，泛舟江湖。 其后江南大族籍没者无算，人始信其见几云。 明阳先生者，刘其姓，光烛其名。 仁慈恭敬，富而好礼，以善为当为，不求福报，达者高之。 尝从白白子游，得清净守中之旨，遂结庵于大江之湄，云水盘桓，不迹城市。 没后数载，忽降一诗云：『人去空山鹤影单，回观尘海雾漫漫。 仙家不昧虚灵体，一路清风到石坛。 』自是云朋霞友，咸谓其不灭也。 所着有《金丹诗》若干篇，尚存于其弟遁园处。 拳技派 王渔洋先生云，奉勇之技，少林为外家，武当张三丰为内家。 三丰之后，有关中人王宗，宗传温州陈州同州同明嘉靖间人。 故今两家之传，盛于浙东。 顺治中，王来咸字征南，其最着者，靳人也。 雨窗无事，读《聊斋》李超始末，因识于后。 又云，征南之徒，又有僧耳，僧尾者，皆僧也。 正讹

The Ten Lodgings Recluse was a disciple of Shen Wanshan. From youth, he was fond of charity, and Wanshan gave him his youngest daughter in marriage, transmitting to him the art of cinnabar transmutation. His wealth then rivaled that of his father-in-law. His daughter, Yu Huigang, became the second wife of Xiping Marquis Mu Chun and was likewise skilled in the arts of alchemy, these being family traditions. The account appears in the "Biographies of the Yu Father and Daughter" in this collection.

Lu Deyuan was a man of Wu. Though his family had long been of modest means, he aspired to the study of immortals. When Shen Wanshan met him, he recognized his aptitude for the Dao and transmitted to him the subtleties of the profound mysteries, along with alchemical wealth, which then sufficed his household. He associated with Gu Aying and Li Mingfeng, and among the literary gatherings and wine societies of the southeast, scholars praised him as wealthy yet refined. In the early Hongwu reign, he once donated twenty thousand *hu* of military grain. Upon hearing of this, the Taizu Emperor remarked, "Not even the prosperous elders of Jiangnan could match this," whereupon Lu sighed, "The seeds of disaster have come." Soon after, he took up his zither and donned a monk’s robe, disguising himself as a Daoist priest and fleeing. When Gu Aying learned of this, he too shaved his head and became a monk. Li Mingfeng abandoned his estate, taking his wife and children to drift upon the rivers and lakes. Later, when countless great families of Jiangnan were confiscated, people began to trust in his foresight.

Mingyang Xiansheng bore the surname Liu and the given name Guangzhu. Kind, reverent, and wealthy yet refined, he did good as it ought to be done, seeking no reward. The enlightened esteemed him highly. Once, he traveled with Baibaizi and received the teaching of "preserving tranquility and abiding in the center." He then built a hut by the great river, wandering among clouds and waters, never setting foot in the cities. Several years after his passing, he suddenly descended with a poem:

*"Man gone, lone crane’s shadow in the empty hills,
Gazing back, the dusty sea is veiled in mist.
The immortals’ numinous essence never fades—
A path of pure wind leads to the stone altar."*

Thereafter, his cloud companions and rosy friends all declared him undying. His work, *Poems on the Golden Elixir*, survives in several volumes, still held by his younger brother, Dunyuan.

**Fist Arts Lineage**
Wang Yuyang Xiansheng said: "In the arts of valor, Shaolin represents the external school, while Zhang Sanfeng of Wudang is the internal school. After Sanfeng, there was Wang Zong of Guanzhong, who transmitted the art to Chen Zhoutong of Wenzhou—a man of the Jiajing era. Thus, the transmission of both schools flourished in eastern Zhejiang. During the Shunzhi reign, the most renowned was Wang Laixian, styled Zhengnan, a man of Jin. On rainy days with nothing to do, I read the tale of Li Chao in *Strange Tales from a Chinese Studio* and thus recorded this afterward."

He further noted: "Among Zhengnan’s disciples were Seng’er and Sengwei, both monks. Correcting errors."

chunks.original_text: 三峰采战之说，多为丹经历鄙，然非祖师之《玄要篇》也。 尝阅《神仙鉴》，刘宋时有张山峰者，号朴阳子。 未入道时，曾授人以房中彻女方，天帝恶之，终于草岛游仙。 何一阳仙姑游华山，曾见其金丹秘诀，悉备于身，因无天诏，难升玉阙，深溉惜焉； 据此则知『山峰』二字，声音相近之讹也。 且祖师所作《金丹论》亦云：『行御女之术者，是犹披麻救火、飞蛾扑灯。 』细按此言，自不妄讥矣。 又三峰者，乃旁门之名，不但刘宋时张三峰也。 阴道中有三峰采战，俗人不知，遂以《玄要篇》等诸旁门，是以耳闻为目见，未读丹经者也。 三峰之术，有宋张紫阳、陈泥丸诸老仙翁皆已斥之，祖师乃元人，不待辨也。 单言此术由来，《参同契》所谓『阴道厌九一』者是也。 九一之谬即御女之方，分上中下三峰，采人精气，托号泥水金丹，伯阳以前已有此术矣。 故《玄要篇》云：『有为者，非采战提昅之术，九一动摇之法』。 即祖师亦辟三峰之谬，复何言哉！ 又尝阅《神仙鉴》，彭祖称太清景明三峰真君，而御女之术实起于彭祖，采补房中，祸丧屡娶。 后为殷王拘系，欲杀之，盖天律谴之也。 中途脱逃，乃入华山归正云。

The theories of "Three Peaks" bedroom arts are often dismissed as vulgar in Daoist elixir manuals, yet these are not the *Mysterious Essentials* of the Patriarch. I once read in the *Mirror of Immortals* that during the Liu-Song dynasty, there was a man named Zhang Shanfeng, styled Boyangzi. Before he entered the Dao, he taught others the methods of bedroom arts to "penetrate the woman’s chamber." The Heavenly Emperor despised this, and he ultimately became a wandering immortal on a grassy isle. The Immortal Lady He Yiyang, while traveling on Mount Hua, once saw his secret golden elixir formulas, all of which he carried on his person. Yet without the Heavenly Edict, he could not ascend to the Jade Palace, and she deeply lamented this. From this, we know that "Shanfeng" (Mountain Peak) was a phonetic corruption of his name. Moreover, the Patriarch’s *Discourse on the Golden Elixir* also states: *"Those who practice the arts of bedroom intercourse are like one who dons hemp to extinguish fire or a moth that dashes into a flame."* Examining this carefully, we see that such criticism is not groundless.

Furthermore, "Three Peaks" is a term for heterodox schools, not limited to Zhang Shanfeng of the Liu-Song era. Within the "yin path," there exists the "Three Peaks" bedroom arts, but the vulgar do not understand this and thus conflate the *Mysterious Essentials* and other heterodox texts, mistaking hearsay for firsthand knowledge—these are those who have never read the elixir classics. The "Three Peaks" arts were already repudiated by the Song-dynasty immortals Zhang Ziyang and Chen Niuwan, and the Patriarch, being a man of the Yuan, need not even address it.

To trace the origins of this art: it is what the *Can Tong Qi* refers to as *"the yin path abhors the nine-and-one."* The error of the "nine-and-one" is precisely the method of bedroom intercourse, dividing the body into upper, middle, and lower "peaks" to absorb others’ essence and qi, falsely styling it as the "Mud-and-Water Golden Elixir." Such practices existed even before [Wei] Boyang. Thus, the *Mysterious Essentials* states: *"The path of effort is not the arts of bedroom intercourse, the techniques of 'lifting and stirring,' or the methods of 'ninefold agitation.'"*

The Patriarch also refuted the errors of the "Three Peaks"—what more need be said? I once read in the *Mirror of Immortals* that Peng Zu was titled the "True Lord of the Three Peaks of Grand Clarity and Radiant Brilliance," yet the arts of bedroom intercourse truly originated with him. His methods of "absorption and supplementation" in the bedchamber led to repeated disasters and marriages. Later, he was imprisoned by the King of Yin, who sought to execute him—this was the Heavenly Law’s judgment. Midway through his captivity, he escaped and entered Mount Hua to return to the true path.

chunks.original_text: 三丰祖师诞期，据梦九所作本传，则系元定宗二年四月初九日也。 乃各处所传，又有作三月初八、十月初十者何故？ 大抵仙佛降世，举凡得道成真，飞身朝驾，其吉期不一而足。 有如普陀大士、孚佑帝君，每岁斋辰，几于逐月皆有，然祝大士者，毕竟以二月十九为正，庆孚佑者，终当以四月十四为真。 兹于祖师诞期，亦以本传为主，余皆附存集中，使敬祖师者随时致虔，如大士、孚佑之斋期，亦美事也。 别传谓祖师为元末明初人，而不知为宋末元初人也。 尝对万三自叙云：『延佑初，余年六十七。 』逆而数之，正在元定宗之初年、宋理宗之淳佑年也。 元运北起，祖师生辽东，入元之版籍，故称为元人。 汪作原传谓其降生于定宗丁未，与祖师自叙相合，真乃不谬也。 明胡忠安公濴访三丰祖师，系永乐中事，世有误作成化者。 李雨村《诗话》云：『祥符寺在绵竹小西门外，有明嘉靖九年王汝宾刻礼部尚书胡濴成化四年访张三丰诗碑』云云。 按《明纪》永乐五年丁亥，正胡濴至绵竹时也。 今刻于天王殿后，板壁上有三丰所书『翔符禅院』四字，笔势飞动，以『祥』作『翔』，或者曾至此欤？ 钱文端公陈群所着《香树斋集燕九日王新庄观灯诗》，有『仙携邋遢来空碧，人立秋千望比红』之句，注云：『张三丰与邱长春同时，访道后皆仙去。 』愚按：长春先生访道于金朝，出世甚早，不与张祖同时也。 但汪仙作传，谓祖师制居时，有邱道人相访之事，祖师成道后，于元至正初遨游西山，复遇长春子，促膝谈心。 尔时邱真人阐化元朝，正有同时显道之事，若曰同时访道，则未也。 俗本载祖师原名君宝，及观《神仙鉴》，始知『宝』本作『实』，鲁鱼相误，有如是者。 并按『君实』二字，似字非名。 暨阅陆俨山《玉堂漫笔》，乃知祖师名通号玄玄，君实其字也。 天师之后，曾寓凤翔宝鸡县之金台观。 詹事府主簿南阳张朝用尝识之，见其行足不履地。 胡忠安公荐朝用为均州知州，同访不遇。 又有密勅，云淮安王宗道曾与三丰学仙，令觅同往。 三年召见，赐宗道金冠鹤氅，奉书香遍游天下，越十年，竟不遇还。 又按祖师之父俗本以『子安』为讳，亦似字非名，及读梦九所藏列传，乃知『居仁』其名，『子安』其字，『白山』其号也。 羽流抄本有《三丰供状》一篇，确系诬词，语亦鄙俚，不可不辨。 其状云：『供状道童一佰余岁岂尚称童张三丰，年二十八岁，辽阳人氏。 有父张子安，所生第五子。 自幼眼疾，舍送碧宫，投师礼傅。

The birthdate of Patriarch Sanfeng, according to the *Biography* composed by Meng Jiu based on his dreams, falls on the ninth day of the fourth month in the second year of Emperor Dingzong of the Yuan. Yet why do various transmitted accounts record it as the eighth day of the third month or the tenth day of the tenth month? Generally, when immortals and buddhas descend into the world, their auspicious dates for attaining the Dao, achieving transcendence, or ascending in flight are manifold. Take the Great Bodhisattva of Mount Putuo or Lord Fuyou—each year, their vegetarian feast days occur nearly every month. Yet those who venerate the Bodhisattva ultimately regard the nineteenth day of the second month as the true date, while those who celebrate Lord Fuyou ultimately hold the fourteenth day of the fourth month as authentic. Here, too, we take the *Biography* as the primary source for the Patriarch’s birthdate, while preserving the rest in the collected records, allowing devotees to offer reverence at any time, just as they do for the feast days of the Bodhisattva and Lord Fuyou—a commendable practice.

Some alternative traditions claim the Patriarch lived between the late Yuan and early Ming, unaware that he was in fact a figure of the late Song and early Yuan. He once recounted to Wan San: *"In the early years of the Yan You era, I was sixty-seven."* Counting backward, this places him precisely in the early years of Emperor Dingzong of the Yuan and the Chun You era of Emperor Lizong of the Song. The Yuan dynasty arose in the north, and the Patriarch, born in Liaodong, was registered in the Yuan census—hence his designation as a man of the Yuan. Wang Zuo’s original *Biography* states that he was born in the *dingwei* year of Emperor Dingzong, aligning with the Patriarch’s own account—truly without error.

Minister Hu Yong’an of the Ming, Hu Ying, sought out Patriarch Sanfeng during the Yongle era, though some mistakenly place this in the Chenghua period. Li Yucun’s *Poetry Talks* records: *"At Xiangfu Temple outside the small west gate of Mianzhu, there is a stele inscribed in the ninth year of the Jiajing era by Wang Rubin, Minister of Rites, with a poem by Hu Ying from the fourth year of the Chenghua era, seeking Zhang Sanfeng."* However, according to the *Ming Annals*, the fifth year of the Yongle era (*dinghai*) was when Hu Ying arrived in Mianzhu. Today, on the wooden wall behind the Hall of the Heavenly Kings, four characters—*"Xiangfu Chan Yuan"*—are inscribed in the Patriarch’s hand, the calligraphy soaring and dynamic. Since *"xiang"* replaces *"xiang"* (祥), might he have once visited this place?

Minister Qian Wenduan, Chen Qun, in his *Fragrant Tree Studio Collection*, includes the poem *"On the Ninth Day of the First Month, Watching Lanterns at Wangxin Village"*, with the lines: *"The immortal, ragged and trailing, arrives in empty azure; / The people stand on swings, gazing at crimson."* The annotation reads: *"Zhang Sanfeng and Qiu Changchun were contemporaries, both later becoming immortals after seeking the Dao."* In my humble opinion, Master Changchun sought the Dao during the Jin dynasty and emerged much earlier—he was not contemporaneous with Patriarch Zhang. However, Immortal Wang’s *Biography* records that during the Patriarch’s reclusive years, a Daoist named Qiu visited him, and after attaining the Dao, the Patriarch roamed the Western Mountains in the early years of the Zhizheng era, where he again encountered Master Changchun, engaging in heartfelt conversation. At that time, Master Qiu was propagating the Dao in the Yuan dynasty, and there were indeed instances of their teachings appearing simultaneously. But to say they sought the Dao together would be incorrect.

Popular versions claim the Patriarch’s original name was Junbao, but upon consulting the *Mirror of Immortals*, I discovered that *"bao"* was originally *"shi"*—a case of the characters for *"lu"* (鲁) and *"yu"* (鱼) being mistaken for one another. Moreover, the two characters *"Junshi"* appear to be a courtesy name rather than a given name. Later, in Lu Yanshan’s *Jottings from the Jade Hall*, I learned that the Patriarch’s name was Tong, his style Xuanyuan, and *"Junshi"* his courtesy name. A descendant of the Heavenly Master, he once resided at Jintai Abbey in Baoji County, Fengxiang. Zhang Chaoyong, Registrar of the Court of Imperial Sacrifices from Nanyang, once met him and observed that his feet never touched the ground. Minister Hu Yong’an later recommended Zhang Chaoyong as Prefect of Junzhou, and together they sought the Patriarch but did not encounter him. There was also a secret imperial edict stating that Wang Zongdao of Huaian had studied immortality with Sanfeng, ordering him to search for the Patriarch and accompany him. After three years, Wang was summoned to court, granted a golden crown and crane-feather robe, and sent with incense and letters to travel the world. Ten years later, he returned without having met the Patriarch.

Further, popular accounts give the Patriarch’s father’s name as *"Zi’an"*, which also seems to be a courtesy name rather than a given name. Upon reading the *Biography* preserved by Meng Jiu, I learned that his father’s name was *"Juren"*, his courtesy name *"Zi’an"*, and his sobriquet *"Baishan."* Among the Daoist manuscripts, there is a *"Confession of Sanfeng"*—clearly a slanderous fabrication, its language vulgar and base, and it must be refuted. The confession states: *"I, Zhang Sanfeng, a novice of over a hundred years—though still called a novice—am twenty-eight years old, a native of Liaoyang. My father is Zhang Zi’an, and I am his fifth son. From childhood, I suffered from eye ailments and was sent to the Jade Palace to become a disciple under Master Fu."*

Later, he once again wandered through Huguang and cultivated his nature and refined his truth at Tianzhu Hermitage in Xiangyang Prefecture. It states: *"Now, by the grace of the Yongle Emperor’s esteemed invitation to honor Daoist teachings, I can no longer conceal the truth, and what I have confessed is real."* This was clearly fabricated by fangshi and Daoist adepts to seek glory, yet they unwittingly slandered him instead. During the Yongle era, our Patriarch remained deeply secluded, as even the *Ming History* attests—how could he have submitted a confession to the court, self-promoting and parading before the imperial gates? Even the *Immortal’s Mirror* records his ascension in the Golden Hall, but this was merely a brief moment of discourse to demonstrate the indestructibility of the yang spirit. Later, upon examining Meng Jiu’s authentic copy, I found only a memorial from Hu Guang, and my long-standing doubts were finally resolved.

**Appendix: Memorial from Hu Guang**
The Memorial of Your Servant, Hu Guang, Academician Reader-in-waiting, humbly states: The perfected immortal Zhang Sanfeng was a native of Liaodong. Profound in Daoist arts and endowed with divine powers, he dwelled in reclusion on Mount Wudang, embodying the spirit of Chen Tuan. He may be reverently sought, but his presence cannot be commanded. With the Emperor’s august journey to emulate Guangchengzi in seeking the true Dao, your servant dared not conceal the truth and thus respectfully submitted this memorial.

There is also *A Brief Record of the Western Ocean*, which recounts the tale of Jin Bifeng’s visit to Nanjing to seek the Patriarch. It claims the Patriarch’s name was *Shoucheng*, a native of Jurong, who once served as a clerk in the county yamen before abandoning his brush to become a Daoist at the Chaotian Palace in Xishan Daoist Monastery. Through cultivation, he attained the rank of earthly immortal. Bifeng, ordered to seek out Minister Hu, presented him to the enlightened sovereign, who proclaimed him a celestial immortal, thereby confirming his ascent to the Great Luo Heaven. This is merely a novelist’s embellishment using borrowed names—nothing more than fiction.

Some may ask: Why was he called *Shoucheng* and said to be from Jurong? The answer: Without such details, the stage would lack its requisite dialogue and cues. Between the Yuan and Ming dynasties, the Patriarch authored many works. His poetry is collected in *Cloud and Water Anthology*, and his prose comprises several pieces, all preserved in Meng Jiu’s collection.

The *Mirror of Immortals* further records that Hu Guang presented the Patriarch’s Daoist poems, titled *Essentials of Swift Attainment*, including works such as *"The Rootless Tree,"* *"Song of the Great Dao,"* *"Song of Lead Refinement,"* *"Poem of the Jade Flower,"* two stanzas of *"Lichun Courtyard,"* *"Inscription Left at Qingyang Palace,"* *"Song of Golden Elixir’s Return,"* and *"Song of the Perfected Immortal’s Dao Attainment."* In recent times, transmitted copies have become increasingly muddled. For instance, the *Mysterious Essentials* carved by Zhang Lingji of Xiangyun Cave and Deng Lingmi originally contained *"Thirty-Six Poems on the Golden Elixir"* to symbolize the 360 degrees of the celestial sphere, but these have been reduced to sixteen, with the rest scattered and disordered. All Daoist sentiments have been excluded from publication, as the compilers evidently never saw the complete collection. Some common manuscripts surpass the Zhang and Deng editions in comprehensiveness but mistakenly include poems by Lü Dongbin. This compilation has been meticulously gathered and cross-referenced with Meng Jiu’s authentic copy, striving to restore its original form. Would the Patriarch approve?

Respectfully noted by Chang Yi. **Category: Manifestations**

chunks.translated_text:
Shen Wansan of the Ferry

Shen Wansan was a great fisherman of Qinhuai. Kind-hearted and fond of charity, he initially lived in modest comfort. In the nineteenth year of the Zhizheng era, he suddenly encountered a Daoist immortal—his bearing lofty, his form like a tortoise, his bones like a crane’s, with large ears, round eyes, and a height exceeding seven feet, his long beard bristling like a halberd. He wore a crescent moon cap, carried a blade and measuring rule, and donned a bamboo hat and patched robe through all seasons, never adorning his appearance. He could travel over a thousand *li* in a day, consuming a *sheng* or *dou* of food at a time, or fasting for months on end while his countenance grew ever more radiant.

Wansan found him extraordinary and often simmered fresh fish and warmed wine, inviting him to drink on the reed islets. Whatever the immortal needed, Wansan supplied to the utmost. One evening, as they drank beneath the moon, the immortal asked, *"Do you wish to know my origins?"* Wansan respectfully entreated him, whereupon the immortal tossed back his beard and laughed, *"I am Zhang Sanfeng."* He then recounted the tale of his mundane and transcendent existence, his cultivation and attainment of the Dao, before bursting into hearty laughter.

Hearing this, Wansan prostrated himself in reverence, calling him *"Patriarch,"* and begged for instruction. *"This humble one’s wish is only to relieve suffering,"* he said. *"I dare not hope for wealth or longevity."* The Patriarch replied, *"Though I dare not recklessly transmit the true teaching, neither do I wish to seal the Dao in silence. I have long seen into your heart—let me act on your behalf."*

Thereupon, they prepared medicinal ingredients and chose an auspicious day to begin the refinement. After forty-nine days, when they opened the crucible, the lead and mercury had each followed their own course. The Patriarch sighed in dismay, while Wansan blamed his own lack of karmic affinity. He exhausted his savings and even sold his boats and nets to fund the work. Midway through, the mercury suddenly flared like wildfire, burning away the thatched roof. Wansan lamented his meager fortune, and the Patriarch urged him to abandon the effort. Yet the couple bore no resentment and insisted on continuing, though their resources were depleted. They even considered selling their young daughter. The Patriarch feigned ignorance, secretly pleased by their resolve, and allowed them to proceed.

He then instructed them to prepare cinnabar-coated mercury. Summoning the couple before him, he took a small amount of the elixir, flicked a speck from his fingernail into the heated mercury, which instantly congealed like earth. With dead mercury, he transmuted copper coins into silver and gold, promising them longevity. The Patriarch then gathered a portion of the elixir’s essence and, before departing, advised, *"The *qi* of royal destiny surges in the southeast. We shall meet again in the southwest."* He then entered the Ba region.

With this, Wansan established his family’s fortune. He set up a furnace and refined the elixir on a grand scale, becoming the wealthiest man in the world within a year. Whenever he encountered the poor or distressed, he generously provided for them. Merchants borrowed his capital to trade, and his influence spread across the land. The world called him the possessor of a *"treasure-gathering basin,"* for his wealth flowed inexhaustibly.

At that time, the world was in chaos, ravaged by war. Fearing calamity, Wansan destroyed his alchemical furnace and utensils, styling himself the *"Daoist of Three Mountains."* To this day, the street in the southwest of Nanjing City marks his later residence. The Huìtóng Inn stands on the site of his former home, and the land by the rear lake was once his garden.

chunks.original_text: 《仙鉴》评：『外丹成，为内丹之助。 』然真道难闻，千举万败，人每以三丰为口，实至受诳不悟，当思己有万山福量，乃可遇之，苟或不然，愿且置是。 寓金台观 元至正丙午年，宝鸡金台观，有道翁者貌若百余岁，忽于九月二十七日自言辞世，留颂而逝。 士民杨轨山置棺殓讫，临窆柩有声如雷，发之复生，跃起谓轨山曰：『吾张三丰也。 天师后裔，幼好学道，今吾大丹已成，神游天海。 吾子善人也，难得难得。 』遂教以避世延年之术，寻携轨山同去。 圆通子曰：『世人尽如轨山，则路无暴骨矣。 如此方便人，仙真安得不度』。 隐太和山 洪武初，祖师入太和山，于玉虚宫畔结庵冷坐。 庵前古木五株，阴连数亩，云气滃然，故尝栖其下，猛兽不噬，鸷鸟不抟。 人咸异之，衲衣垢弊，皆号为邋遢张。 有问其仙术，竟不一答，问经书则津涎不绝口。 登山轻捷如飞，隆冬卧雪中，鼾齁如雷。 常语太和乡人曰『兹山异日当大显』。 道士邱元靖叩其出处，始识为三丰祖师。 请为弟子，遂传以道妙。 《神仙鉴》评：『左道旁门最能惑人，如箭射虚空，还复坠地。 惟觅得真种子，潜修密炼，至丹成果熟，寒暑不能侵，阴阳不能贼，纵横自在，来去随心，方为实际。 』如三丰所者，所当景仰。 寄常遇春 洪武二年己酉六月，常遇春进攻大兴州，直拔开平，追奔数百里，大获全胜，遂清蓟北。 秋七月，师次柳河州，遇春得疾，谓众将曰：『予生时有老翁至门付一函，云：﹁煌煌尾宿，矫矫虎臣，和中遇主，柳下归神。 ﹂前曰：﹁张真人三丰自五台寄书﹂，又是此数字，今至柳河州而病，吾其逝矣。 』寻卒于军年三十四，去年戊申，帝初即位，亦尝钦问四十二代天师张冲虚，曰：『北征如何。 』天师曰：『朝廷有福，大将归真。 』
chunks.translated_text:
*The Immortals’ Mirror* remarks: "The completion of the external elixir aids the internal elixir." Yet the true Dao is rarely heard of, and for every thousand attempts, there are ten thousand failures. People often invoke [Zhang] Sanfeng’s name, but most are deceived without realizing it. One must first possess the vast fortune of ten thousand mountains before encountering such a path—otherwise, it is best to set it aside.

**Dwelling at Jintai Abbey**
In the *bingwu* year of the Zhizheng era of the Yuan (1366), at Jintai Abbey in Baoji, there lived an elderly Daoist whose appearance suggested over a hundred years. On the twenty-seventh day of the ninth month, he suddenly announced his departure from the world, left a verse, and passed away. The scholar and commoner Yang Guishan prepared a coffin and completed the encoffining. As the casket was about to be interred, a sound like thunder erupted, and the lid burst open—he revived, leaping up to address Guishan: "I am Zhang Sanfeng. A descendant of the Celestial Masters, I devoted myself to the Dao from youth. Now my great elixir is complete, and my spirit roams the celestial seas. You, sir, are a good man—rare indeed, rare indeed!" He then taught Guishan the arts of evading the world and prolonging life, and soon after, took him away together.

Yuántōngzǐ observed: "If all in the world were like Guishan, no bones would lie exposed on the roads. Such a compassionate man—how could the immortals not ferry him across?"

**Concealed on Mount Taihe**
At the beginning of the Hongwu era (1368), the Patriarch [Zhang Sanfeng] entered Mount Taihe and built a hut beside Yuxu Palace, where he sat in cold meditation. Before the hut stood five ancient trees, their shade spanning several *mu*, their canopies wreathed in mist. He often rested beneath them, where fierce beasts did not devour and birds of prey did not strike. People marveled at him, calling him "Tattered Zhang" for his filthy, ragged robes. When asked about immortal arts, he never answered, but if questioned on the classics, he discoursed endlessly. He ascended mountains with the lightness of flight, and in the depths of winter, he slept in the snow, snoring like thunder. He often told the villagers of Taihe: "This mountain shall one day achieve great renown."

The Daoist Qiu Yuanjing inquired about his origins and only then recognized him as the Patriarch Sanfeng. He begged to become his disciple, and Sanfeng transmitted to him the wondrous arts of the Dao.

*The Mirror of Divine Immortals* comments: "Heretical and peripheral teachings most easily delude people—like arrows shot into empty space, they inevitably fall back to earth. Only by finding the true seed, cultivating in secret, and refining until the elixir is complete and the fruit ripe, can one become impervious to cold and heat, beyond the reach of yin and yang, moving freely and coming and going at will. This is the true attainment." Those like Sanfeng are worthy of reverence.

**Letter to Chang Yuchun**
In the sixth month of the *jiyou* year of the Hongwu era (1369), Chang Yuchun advanced on Daxing Prefecture, captured Kaiping, and pursued the fleeing enemy for hundreds of *li*, achieving total victory and pacifying the north of Ji. In the seventh month, his army reached Liuhe Prefecture, where Yuchun fell ill. He addressed his generals: "When I was born, an old man came to my door and handed me a letter, saying: *'Radiant Tail Star, mighty tiger minister, harmonious meeting with the lord, beneath the willows the spirit returns.'* The envelope read: *'A letter from Zhang Zhenren Sanfeng of Wutai.'* These same words appear again—now that I have reached Liuhe Prefecture and fallen ill, I know my end has come." Soon after, he died in the army camp at the age of thirty-four.

The previous year, in *wushen* (1368), when the Emperor had just ascended the throne, he had respectfully inquired of the forty-second-generation Celestial Master, Zhang Chongxu: "What of the northern campaign?" The Celestial Master replied: "The court is blessed; the great general shall return to the Dao."

The Prince of Shu, Chun—twelfth son of the Grand Progenitor, enfeoffed as Prince of Shu—was also named Chun (or sometimes mistakenly recorded as Cao). During the Hongwu reign, the Grand Progenitor invested his son Chun as Prince of Shu. At that time, the Two Rivers region had long been pacified, its people tranquil and flourishing. Suddenly, an old man appeared, his spirit whole and visage ancient, moving as swiftly as if he flew. One day, clad in a formal cap and broad sash, he appeared before the prince with graceful ease and spoke of entering the Dao. The prince did not heed him, yet marveled inwardly at the elder’s vigor and wished to retain him. The old man laughed and recited:

*"Why seek the swift path of Zhongnan’s peaks?
To me, your longing weighs no more than goose down."*

The prince esteemed his resolve. One day, the old man said to him: *"Though your fief is fine, you must cultivate a retiring heart and empty mind to preserve yourself from misfortune. I am Zhang Sanfeng. Soon I shall wander the vast expanse with the immortals of the sea isles."* The prince composed a poem to send him off, including the lines:

*"My master has deeply grasped the art of the Marquis of Liu,
Nurturing stillness in the cinnabar field to guard the Valley Spirit."*

He did not detain him, and the Patriarch departed. Some say that among the later princes—such as Prince Gu, Sui, and Prince Liao, Zhi—many failed to retain their fiefs, while the Prince of Shu alone dwelled in peace and prosperity, all thanks to the Patriarch’s counsel.

After meeting the Prince of Shu, Chun, the Patriarch roamed the vast lands of Sichuan, Guizhou, and Yunnan, his cloud chariot unbound by fixed abode, his manifest traces most numerous, never lingering in stillness upon any single mountain. Some claim that upon first entering Chengdu and finding the Prince of Shu indifferent to the Dao, he withdrew to the Xiang-Ye region, dwelling on Mount Wudang for twenty-three years before one day setting forth on his wanderings, departing with a flick of his sleeve.

Yuantongzi, reading this passage, inscribed a quatrain:

*A white-haired immortal once entered the tent,
Met yet unrecognized—what could be done?
A few weighty words to the prince he imparted,
Preserving his fief in abundant repose.*

chunks.translated_text:
In the Hongwu reign, the Patriarch traveled to Shu and lodged at the residence of Commander Jiang of the Imperial Guards. His movements were enigmatic, yet none recognized him. He always wore a broad-brimmed bamboo hat, so large that it passed unimpeded even through narrow doorways, fastened with an iron-wire cord of exquisite workmanship. From dawn to dusk, he sat upon a flat boulder, and once, breaking a withered plum branch and planting it in the earth, it took root at once, its blossoms all drooping downward—hence the old name in Chengdu for such trees: "Water-Reflecting Plum."

At the Kaiyuan Monastery in Kuizhou’s western city, the former abode of Chan Master Liaoxiu of the Tang, the Patriarch arrived in the early Ming. Befriending the monk Guanghai, he stayed at the monastery for seven days. Upon parting, he presented a poem and left behind a pair of straw sandals and three pieces of aloeswood. Later, Guanghai offered the poem and these two items to Emperor Wen, who in return bestowed a jade ring and a *kāṣāya* embroidered with a thousand Buddhas. These remain enshrined in the monastery as treasures of the age.

Recorded in the *Gazetteer of Chengdu Prefecture* and the *Gazetteer of Kuizhou Prefecture*.

chunks.original_text: 洪武十七年甲子，帝以华夷宾服诏求真人张三丰，莫知所往。 明年春复强其弟子沈万三敦请，了不可得，又召邱元靖入朝。 祖师因呈一诗，并嘱邱曰：『奏语明天子，谓吾将遨游海外矣。 』其诗云：『流水行云不自收，朝廷何必苦征求，从今更要藏名姓，山北山南任我游。 』帝览而纵之，寻拜邱为监察御史，赐美室均不受，邱可谓不忘师教也。 《神仙鉴》有三诏之事，而无寄诗一段。 圆通子曰：『严子陵，其吾师之前身耶。 』 滇南践约 洪武中，京城自洪武门至水西门坍坏，下有水怪潜窟，筑之复颓，帝向忌沈万三，年命相同而大富。 召谓曰：『尔家有盆能聚宝，亦能聚土筑门乎？ 』万三不敢辨，承命起筑，立基即倾者三，乃以丹金数片，暗投其内，筑之始成，费盖巨万。 帝尝欲犒军，召万三贷之，曰：『吾军百万，但得一军一两足矣。 』万三如数输之，帝瞰其无困苦状，由是欲除之，罪以他事，议流岭南。 万三遂轻身携妻奴去，而委其家赀。 未几命再徒于云南，既至滇，万三无聊，忽有弓长翁者传云『践约来会』，万三请见，则三丰祖师也，祖师笑曰：『犹记东南气盛，西南相见之语乎？ 』万三爽然，因与炼天元，服食大药，明年始成，万三与全家饵之，皆能冲举。 圆通子曰：『撒手赀财，即成上仙，其施济已多矣。 』 游鹤鸣山
