Regardless of noble or base, wise or foolish, old and frail or young and strong—so long as one accumulates hidden virtue, practices benevolence and compassion, and fulfills loyalty, filial piety, trustworthiness, and sincerity in the human Dao, the Dao of Immortality is naturally not far away. One must also thoroughly understand yin and yang, deeply fathom the workings of creation, discern truth from falsehood, obtain the correct qi of yin and yang, and seek the true origin of lead and mercury. Only then can one transform the bones and attain longevity, dwell in the celestial realm of unending light, enjoy the scenery of eternal spring, and endure as long as Heaven and Earth, shining as brightly as the sun and moon—this is truly the proper affair of a great man.

As for heterodox paths and deviant practices—such as controlling women to absorb yin essence, refining the Three Yellows, or ingesting the Eight Minerals—these are all fruitless side doors. Some advocate massage and daoyin exercises, exhalation and inhalation techniques, or the cultivation and consumption of medicinal herbs as methods of nurturing life. Though these may temporarily dispel illness, they cannot escape the inevitable decline of old age and the exhaustion of destiny, and will only be ridiculed by the enlightened. Master Boduan said: *"The method of breath retention, if one can forget all scheming and extinguish all thoughts, may also lead to samadhi and spirit departure."* Yet essence, qi, and spirit belong to yin, and their dwelling is difficult to secure, often subject to the suffering of displacement. There are also techniques claiming to replenish qi and blood through inhalation, known as methods of "drawing and adding to extend life." These may help avoid illness and prolong years, preserving health and vigor, but if one seeks to ingest and nurture the embryonic Immortal, they will surely fail. All other heterodox paths and deviant practices are truly heresies within our Dao—what are they worth?

Some argue that human life and death are all predetermined by fate, and that none can defy destiny to escape death. Yet they fail to consider that fortune is sought by the self, destiny is forged by the self, and hidden merit can extend one’s years. Those who study longevity need only take hidden virtue as the foundation and the Golden Elixir as the application—thus even destiny may be escaped.

I reverently recall our Most High Dao Ancestor and the successive Perfected Saints, who, moved by a heart of loving-kindness and a vow to broadly deliver all beings, expansively inaugurated the Mysterious Teachings and secretly transmitted the Immortal formula known as the Golden Elixir. From beginning to end, they thereby fully revealed the celestial mechanisms and greatly disclosed the primordial mysteries. Within it, the wondrous practices of conduct—three periods and three barriers, nine zithers and nine swords, medicinal materials and ritual implements, fire phases and talismanic charts—have all been elaborated in full. Each should diligently study the various scriptures to return to the root of one’s nature and destiny.

Though my discourse is common, its principles are most refined—what is said is true and not false. If one obtains this without doubt or suspicion, one may proceed with practice and begin cultivation. Even without encountering an enlightened teacher or good friend, upon obtaining this text, it is as if the teacher or friend stands before you, enabling sudden awakening to the supreme Dao. Compared to other circulating elixir scriptures, all align with the same principle, leaving nothing obscure.

Truly, this is the compassionate vessel across the sea of suffering and the luminous torch guiding the lost. Though the path may be arduous, one must not fear difficulty and settle for ease. Furthermore, after embracing the Golden Elixir, one should retreat to secluded grotto-heavens and conceal oneself in blessed lands. Do not flaunt alchemical gold and silver before the court, becoming a forerunner for false adepts. Conceal or reveal yourself to deliver beings, awaiting the celestial decree to ascend in broad daylight. Only by not displaying one’s talents can one become a supreme Perfected of the highest rank—one who endures through ten thousand kalpas without decay.

Later fellow practitioners, ponder and take heed.

chunks.original_text: 长篇巨观，首探大道之源，而讲生人之理，与人生老病之故，引彼回头向道，修正治平，如古来英雄神仙，身名两树，忠孝两全，非同杨、墨、隐、怪。 使人知此道亦儒道也，养汞培铅，无异乎居仁由义。 韩、朱辟二氏，只辟二氏之假徒，更为通论。 外扫旁门邪径，一归于穷理尽性以至于命之道，振聋发聩之洪响，经天纬地之大文。 中篇 天地之间，至灵至贵者，人也； 最忙最速者，时也； 可大可久者，金丹也。 惜人多溺于功名富贵场中，爱欲恩情之内，狼贪不已，蛾扑何休，一朝大限临身，斯时悔之何及！ 惟其甘分待终，就死而已。 谁知有长生不老之方，谁悟有金丹灵药之妙，诚可借哉！ 此金丹灵药，非世间之所无有，非天上之不可得者，只在于同类中求之，乃生身固有之物也。 简而且易，至近非遥。 余尝有《金丹赋》记之，词极朗鬯，今追忆其中假云：『夫造金丹者，始则借乾坤为玄牝，学造化于阴阳。 识二八之相当，知坎离之互藏。 候金气之满足，听潮水之汪洋。 继则看铅花于癸后，玩月夕于庚方。 制刀圭于片晌，罢龙虎之战场。 唤金公而归舍，配玉女而入房。 』果能此道矣，虽愚必明，虽柔必强。 先儒曰：『圣人不言易，以滋人之惑； 亦未尝言难，以阻人之进。 』若人用意追求，殷勤修炼，自必入圣超凡，长登寿域，永享无穷之乐也，岂小补哉！ 且人为功名富贵，亦有备极穷苦而后可成者。 若以劳苦之心，易而为修炼之心，将见九还到手，万劫存神，以比功名富贵，孰短孰长耶？ 仲尼曰：『不义而富且贵，于我如浮云。 』又曰：『其为仁矣，不使不仁者加乎其身。 』不仁不义，莫甚于狂贪妄想。 胡氏曰：『志于道则外物不足以累其身。 』《悟真》曰：『若会杀机明反复，始知害里却生恩。 』是知欲求还丹，必先绝欲。 欲求绝欲，勤杀机者，刻刻有灵剑在手，外欲乍乘。 急须就起杀机，勿容纵意，久久纯熟，对境无心，即可行反本归根之道。 《易翼》曰：『终日干干，反复道也。 』反复之道，得长生之果证也。 人胡不勉而行之？ 万物如草木之汇，犹能归根反本。 以历岁时，人为万物之灵。 动至死地，是反不如草木也，能不愧乎？ 夫此反本归祸之道，又非邪径旁门之说也。 世人以德行为先，阴功力本，察阴阳选化之机，求玄牝乾坤之妙，辨二八坎离之物。 定金花水月之时，施降龙伏虎之威。 明立命生身之处，其间致虚守静，他主我宾，日月交光，戊己为用，则丹成反掌矣。 《易》曰：『男女媾精，万物化生。 』人有此身，亦因父母而得，倘无父母，身何有乎？ 故作金丹之通，与生身事同，但顺则成人，逆则成仙，顺逆之间，天地悬隔，祗要逆用阴阳，自然成就，并非邪径旁门也。 兹余所论，大泄真机，皆列圣口传心授之旨，人能照此下手行持，自能夺天地玄妙之功，穷鬼神不测之奥，诚金丹之口诀也。 除此之外，再无别传。 先贤云：『圣人未生，道在天地； 圣人已往，道着六经。 』予之末论，虽不敢与圣经相比，亦可为问道之正途，如拨云雾而见青天，似剪荆棘而寻大路。 坦然无碍，豁然有门。 学者若能专心研究，自然默契仙缘，幸勿轻易视之也。 万金难换，百宝难求，勿示非人，尚其重之。
chunks.translated_text:
This grand and expansive work first explores the source of the Great Dao, then expounds the principles of human life and the causes of birth, aging, sickness, and death, guiding others to turn their heads toward the Dao, rectify their conduct, and govern with peace—just as the heroic immortals of antiquity, who cultivated both fame and the body, achieving loyalty and filial piety, unlike the heretical teachings of Yang Zhu, Mo Di, or the recluses and eccentrics. It makes clear that this Dao is also the Confucian Dao, where nurturing mercury and cultivating lead differ not from dwelling in benevolence and following righteousness.

Han Yu and Zhu Xi refuted the two schools (Buddhism and Daoism), but they only rejected the false disciples of those traditions; here, a more comprehensive discussion is offered. It sweeps aside heterodox paths and deviant byways, returning wholly to the Dao of exhausting principle, fulfilling nature, and attaining destiny—a resounding call that awakens the deaf and a monumental text that orders heaven and earth.

**Middle Section**
Between heaven and earth, the most numinous and noble is humanity; the most fleeting and swift is time; and that which can be vast and enduring is the Golden Elixir. Yet most people drown in the pursuit of fame, wealth, and power, or entangle themselves in love, desire, and worldly attachments, endlessly greedy like wolves or ceaselessly drawn like moths to flame. When the great limit arrives, how can regret avail them then? They resign themselves to awaiting death, knowing nothing of the method for longevity and agelessness, nor the wondrous efficacy of the Golden Elixir’s divine medicine. How lamentable!

This Golden Elixir’s divine medicine is not something absent from the world, nor is it unattainable in the heavens. It is sought only among its kind—an innate substance of the living body. Simple and easy, near rather than distant. I once composed a *Rhapsody on the Golden Elixir* to record it, its verses luminous and resonant. Now recalling its lines:

*"To forge the Golden Elixir,
First borrow heaven and earth as the Mysterious Female,
Learn the transformations of yin and yang.
Recognize the correspondence of the two eights,
Know the mutual concealment of Kan and Li.
Await the fullness of the metal qi,
Listen to the vastness of the tidal waters.
Then observe the lead blossoms after Gui,
Admire the moonlit evening in the Geng direction.
Wield the knife and spatula in an instant,
Cease the battlefield of dragon and tiger.
Summon the Metal Lord to return home,
Pair the Jade Maiden in the chamber."*

If one truly masters this Dao, even the foolish will become wise, and the weak will grow strong. As the former Confucians said: *"The sage does not speak of ease, lest it confuse people; nor does he speak of difficulty, lest it deter their progress."* If one pursues it with intent and cultivates diligently, one will surely enter sagehood, transcend the mundane, ascend to the realm of longevity, and eternally enjoy boundless joy—how could this be a small benefit?

Moreover, in the pursuit of fame, wealth, and power, some endure extreme hardship before success. If one redirects the heart that labors for such things toward cultivation, one will soon hold the Ninefold Return in hand, preserve the spirit through ten thousand kalpas, and compare this to fame and wealth—how short the one, how long the other!

Confucius said: *"Wealth and honor gained through unrighteousness are to me like floating clouds."* He also said: *"To practice benevolence is to prevent the unbenevolent from affecting one’s person."* Nothing is more unbenevolent or unrighteous than reckless greed and delusion. Master Hu said: *"One who is devoted to the Dao is not burdened by external things."* *Awakening to Reality* states: *"If one understands the mechanism of killing and its reversals, one knows that harm gives rise to grace."* Thus, to seek the Returned Elixir, one must first sever desire. To sever desire, one must diligently wield the mechanism of killing—keeping the spiritual sword ever at hand. When external desires arise, swiftly invoke the killing mechanism, never indulging the mind. With long practice, one becomes indifferent to circumstances and can proceed on the path of returning to the root and reverting to the origin.

The *Wings of the Book of Changes* says: *"All day long, acting with vigor—this is the Dao of reversal."* The Dao of reversal is the fruition of attaining longevity. Why do people not strive to practice it? Even the myriad things, like the grasses and trees, can return to the root and revert to the origin, enduring through the seasons. Humans, the most numinous of the myriad things, move toward death—are they not then inferior to grasses and trees? Can one not feel shame?

This path of returning to the root and reverting to the origin is no heterodox byway or deviant path. The world values virtue and conduct first, with hidden merit as the foundation. One examines the mechanisms of yin-yang transformation, seeks the wonders of the Mysterious Female and heaven-earth, distinguishes the substances of the two eights and Kan-Li, determines the timing of golden blossoms and water-moon, and deploys the power of subduing the dragon and taming the tiger. By clarifying the place where life and destiny are established, and through emptying the self and guarding stillness—where the other is host and the self is guest—with the radiance of sun and moon intersecting and the earthly branches Wu and Ji in use, the Elixir is completed as easily as turning the palm.

The *Book of Changes* says: *"When male and female unite their essence, the myriad things are transformed and born."* Humans receive this body from their parents—without them, how could one exist? Thus, the method of making the Golden Elixir is the same as the process of birth, except that following the natural course produces a human, while reversing it produces an immortal. Between following and reversing, heaven and earth stand far apart. One need only reverse the use of yin and yang, and success comes naturally—this is no heterodox byway or deviant path.

What I have discussed here boldly reveals the true mechanism, all drawn from the oral transmissions and heart-to-heart instructions of the successive sages. If one acts accordingly, one can seize the mysterious power of heaven and earth, plumb the unfathomable depths of ghosts and spirits—this is truly the oral formula of the Golden Elixir. Beyond this, there is no other transmission.

The former worthies said: *"Before the sages were born, the Dao resided in heaven and earth; after the sages passed, the Dao was recorded in the Six Classics."* Though my humble discourse does not dare compare to the sacred scriptures, it may serve as the proper path for seeking the Dao—like parting the clouds and mist to see the blue sky, or cutting through the brambles to find the great road. It is open and unobstructed, suddenly revealing a gateway. If scholars devote themselves to its study, they will naturally and silently align with the karmic conditions of immortality. Do not regard it lightly.

It is worth more than ten thousand gold, rarer than a hundred treasures. Do not show it to the unworthy—cherish it well.

chunks.original_text: 《悟真篇》云：『学仙须是学天仙，惟有金丹最的端』。 此篇专讲金丹外药，而金液内药亦次其中矣。 反反复复，总劝人及时省悟，炼己求铅。 觉世婆心，传神简上。 旧赋一假，句句口诀，有志者再求口诀中之口诀，则还丹不难矣。 下篇 一阴一阳之谓道，修道者修此阴阳之道也。 一阴一阳，一性一命而已矣。 《中庸》云：『修道之谓教』。 三教圣人，皆本此道以立其教也。 此道原于性、本于命。 命犹令也，天以命而赐人以令也； 性即理也，人以性而由天之理也。 夫欲由其理，则外尽伦常者其理，内尽慎独者其理。 忠孝友恭，衷乎内也，然着其光辉，则在外也； 喜怒哀乐，见于外也，然守其未发，则在内也。 明朗朗天，活泼泼地，尽其性而内丹成矣。 大欲全其令，则殷勤顾之者此令，依法用之者此令。 存心养性，此顾命之勤劳也； 集义生气，此用令之法度也。 炼气化神，炼神还天。 复其性，兼复其命，而外丹就矣。 吾愿后之人修此正道，故直言之。 修道以修身为大，然修身必先正心诚意。 意诚心正，则物欲皆除，然后讲立基之本，气为使焉，神为主焉。 学者下手之初，必须知一阳初动之候，真铅始生之时。 其气迅速如电，而不能久居于先天，霎时而生癸水，顷刻而变经流，迨至生形化质，已属后天而不可用矣。 昆仑之上有玄门，其窍甚小，阴阳会合时，不许动摇，待其情性相感，自然彼我相通。 凡有形质者，不能升入窍内，夫惟真气橐钥，乃能进于窍内也。 故圣人直指先天一炁，冲开此窍。 又曰：『修行之径路，可以续命延年，修真而全真，无来无去，不生不灭。 』今之愚人，闻说有用生阳之道者，却行御女巧诈之本，正如披麻救火、飞蛾扑灯，贪其美色，胡肆纵横，日则逞力多劳，夜则恣情纵欲，致使神昏炁败，髓竭精枯，犹不醒悟，甘分待终。 古之贤人不然，忠孝两全，仁义博施，暗行方便，默积阴功，但以死生为念，不以名利关心，日则少虑无思，夜则清心寡欲，以此神全炁壮，髓满精盈。 每叹凡躯，如石中之火，似水上之沤。 未闻道者急求师，已闻道者急求药。 又能广参博采，信受奉行，求先天之大药，寻出世之丹方，忙忙下手速修，惟恐时不待人。 夫道者，岂是旁门小技，乃至人口传心授，金液还丹之妙道也。 非定息二乘之法，乃最上一乘之道，以有为入无为，以外药修内药。 以已而求彼，以阴而配阳，以铅而投汞，以炁而合神。 无为者，非防危守城之方，温养冰浴之事，乃得丹之后，脱胎神化之功也； 有为者，非采战提吸之术，九一动摇之法，乃安静虚无之道，守雌不雄，寂然不动，感而遂通，此即末得丹之前，炼己筑基之事也。 有为无为，体用之始终。 已见于此； 内药外药，出处之法相。 又详于彼。 外药者，在造化窟中而生； 内药者，在自己身中而产。 内药是精。 外药是炁，内药养性，外药立命，性命双修，方合神仙之道。 大修行人欲求先天外药，必炼己以待阳生，用神炁炼成慧剑，采金水匀配柔刚。 古人采药进火，全凭此物。 除七情之患，去五贼之害。 若无炼己以去贼之患害，则不能常应常静，魂魄焉能受制？ 情欲岂不相干？ 若要入室施功，临炉下手，则外火虽动，而内符不应。
chunks.translated_text:
*The Awakening to Reality* states: *"To learn immortality, one must learn celestial immortality—only the Golden Elixir is most certain."* This text focuses on the external medicine of the Golden Elixir, while the internal medicine of the Golden Liquid is also encompassed within it. Repeatedly and earnestly, it urges people to awaken in time, refine the self, and seek the Lead. Its compassion for the world is as if inscribed on the spirit tablet—an old admonition, yet every line is a secret oral instruction. Those with aspiration may further seek the oral instruction within the oral instruction, and the Returned Elixir will not be difficult to attain.

---

**The Following Section**

That which is called "one yin, one yang" is the Dao. Those who cultivate the Dao cultivate this Dao of yin and yang. One yin and one yang are nothing other than one nature and one life. *The Doctrine of the Mean* says: *"To cultivate the Dao is called teaching."* The sages of the Three Teachings all based their teachings on this Dao. This Dao originates in nature and is rooted in life.

Life is like a decree: heaven bestows upon humans its mandate as a command. Nature is principle: humans follow heaven’s principle through their nature. If one wishes to follow this principle, then externally fulfilling ethical norms is its principle, and internally practicing vigilant solitude is its principle. Loyalty, filial piety, friendliness, and reverence reside within, yet their radiance shines outwardly. Joy, anger, sorrow, and delight manifest externally, yet when guarded before they arise, they remain within. The sky is bright and clear, the earth is lively and free—fulfilling one’s nature, the internal elixir is accomplished.

To fully preserve one’s mandate, the diligent care given to it is this mandate, and the method of employing it is this mandate. Cultivating the mind and nurturing nature is the diligent labor of preserving life. Accumulating righteousness to generate qi is the method of employing the mandate. Refining qi to transform spirit, refining spirit to return to heaven—restoring one’s nature and simultaneously restoring one’s life, the external elixir is achieved.

I wish for those who come after to cultivate this true Dao, and so I speak plainly. In cultivating the Dao, cultivating the body is paramount, yet to cultivate the body, one must first rectify the mind and make the intent sincere. When intent is sincere and the mind is rectified, all worldly desires are eliminated. Only then can one discuss establishing the foundation: qi as the agent, spirit as the master.

At the outset of practice, scholars must recognize the moment when the first yang stirs and the time when true Lead begins to emerge. Its qi is swift as lightning, unable to long abide in the prenatal state. In an instant, it generates Water of Gui; in a moment, it transforms into flowing channels. By the time it takes form and materializes, it already belongs to the postnatal and is no longer usable.

Above Kunlun, there is a mysterious gate, its aperture exceedingly small. When yin and yang unite, no movement is permitted. One must wait for their emotions and nature to resonate, and naturally, self and other will communicate. All that has form cannot ascend into the aperture—only the true qi, like a bellows, can enter within. Thus, the sage directly points to the prenatal qi, surging to open this aperture.

It is also said: *"The path of cultivation can extend life and prolong years, refining the true to preserve the whole. It is without coming or going, without birth or extinction."* Yet today’s foolish people, upon hearing of the method that employs the yang of life, instead practice the deceptive arts of bedroom techniques. This is like wearing hemp to fight fire or a moth flying into a flame—coveting beauty, they indulge recklessly. By day, they exert themselves and labor excessively; by night, they indulge in passion and lust, causing their spirit to dull and qi to scatter, their marrow to deplete and essence to wither. Still, they do not awaken, willingly awaiting their end.

The worthies of old were not like this. They fulfilled both loyalty and filial piety, broadly practiced benevolence and righteousness, secretly performed kind deeds, and silently accumulated hidden merits. They regarded life and death as their sole concern, never allowing fame or profit to occupy their minds. By day, they minimized thoughts and worries; by night, they purified their minds and reduced desires. Thus, their spirit remained whole, their qi robust, their marrow full, and their essence abundant.

They often lamented the mortal body as fire within stone or bubbles upon water. Those who have not heard the Dao should urgently seek a teacher; those who have heard it should urgently seek the medicine. They should broadly study and widely adopt, faithfully receive and practice, seeking the great medicine of the prenatal and searching for the elixir formula of transcendence. They should hasten to begin practice, ever fearful that time waits for no one.

The Dao is not some minor technique of side doors—it is the wondrous Dao of the Golden Liquid Returned Elixir, transmitted orally and received in the heart. It is not the method of the Two Vehicles of fixed breathing, but the supreme Dao of the One Vehicle. Through effort, one enters effortlessness; through external medicine, one refines internal medicine. With the self, one seeks the other; with yin, one matches yang; with Lead, one joins Mercury; with qi, one unites spirit.

Effortlessness is not the method of guarding against danger or holding the city, nor the practice of warm nurturing or icy bathing. It is the work of shedding the embryo and transforming the spirit after obtaining the elixir. Effort is not the techniques of sexual arts or the methods of ninefold movement. It is the Dao of tranquil emptiness, guarding the feminine without aggression, still and unmoving, yet responsive when stimulated. This is the task of refining the self and establishing the foundation before obtaining the elixir.

Effort and effortlessness mark the beginning and end of substance and function, as has been shown here. Internal medicine and external medicine are the methods of origin and manifestation, further detailed elsewhere.

External medicine is born within the womb of creation; internal medicine is produced within one’s own body. Internal medicine is essence; external medicine is qi. Internal medicine nurtures nature; external medicine establishes life. Only when nature and life are cultivated together does one accord with the Dao of immortality.

Great cultivators who seek the prenatal external medicine must refine the self to await the arising of yang. They use spirit and qi to forge the sword of wisdom, gathering the Water of Metal and harmonizing softness and hardness. The ancients, in gathering medicine and advancing fire, relied entirely on this.

Eliminate the afflictions of the seven emotions and dispel the harms of the five thieves. Without refining the self to remove the harms of thieves, one cannot constantly respond and remain still. How can the hun and po be controlled? How can emotions and desires not interfere?

If one wishes to enter the chamber and apply the work, to approach the furnace and begin practice, then although the external fire moves, the internal tally does not respond.

chunks.original_text: 只因刚柔末配，以此慧剑无锋，群魔为害，心神不宁，欲念杂起。 故乃逐境飘流，致使汞火飞扬，圣胎不结。 如使炼己纯熟，则心无杂念，体若太虚，一尘不染，万虑皆空，心死则神活，体虚则气运，方许求一阳之道、二候之功。 还丹容易，炼己最难！ 凭慧剑剖破鸿蒙，舒匠手凿开混沌。 却用阴阳颠倒之法，水火既济之道，乃行地天交泰，使阳居下，火必照上，令阴在上，水能润下，只要苦行忍辱，身心不动，己之性若住，彼之气自回。 人能如此，便得守雌不雄，寂然不动，感而遂通之效也。 太极将判之闲，静以极而末至于动。 阳初复而未离乎阴，候此真先天炁降，以法追摄，送入黄庭之中。 日运己汞，包固周密，汞气渐多，铅气渐散，合丹于鼎。 又须调停真息，周流六虚，至声寂而意合，乃气匀而脉住，丹始凝结。 待圣胎气足，十月功圆，脱胎神化，降生婴儿，调之纯熟，出入纵横，往来无碍，不被群魔引诱，只待九转功成，面壁之时，炼精则化炁，炼神则化虚，形神俱妙，与道合真，此大丈夫功成名遂之时也。 是道古人不传于世，盖缘愚人信之不笃，行之不勤，而且反生诽谤，是以秘而不传。 予自得遇至人以来，述此修身秘要，以警觉后学。 同志者各加黾勉，共陟仙都。 此篇穷性命之真，发圣贤仙佛之理，本本原原，如疏如注。 有为无为之序，内药外药之分，养胎脱胎之妙，尽着简编，观止已蔑以加矣。 玄机直讲此祖师删改前人之作，以示人者，故附入全集 炼丹火候说二篇 夫功夫下手，不可执于有为，有为都是后天，今之道门，多流此弊，故世间罕全真； 亦不可着于无为，无为便落顽空，今之释门，多中此弊，故天下少佛子。 此道之不行，由于道之不明也。 初功在寂灭情缘，扫除杂念，除杂念是第一着筑基炼己之功也。 人心既除，则天心来复； 人欲既净，则天理常存。 每日先静一时，待身心都安定了，气息都和平了，始将双目微闭，垂帘观照心下肾上一寸三分之间必寻有活动气处，方不落空，方不执滞，不即不离，勿忘勿助，万念俱泯，一灵独存，谓之正念。 斯时也，于此念中，活活泼泼，于彼气中，悠悠扬扬，呼之至上，上不冲心，吸之至下，下不冲肾，一阖一辟，一来一往，行之一七、二七，自然渐渐两肾火蒸，丹田气暖，息不用调而自调，气不用炼而自炼。 气息既和，自然于上中下不出不入，无来无去，是为胎息，是为神息，是为真橐钥、真鼎炉，是为归根复命，是为玄牝之门、天地之根。 气到此时，如花方蕊，如胎方胞，自然真气熏蒸营卫，由尾闾，穿夹脊，升上泥丸。 下鹊桥，过重楼，至绛宫，而落于中丹田，是为河车初动，但气至而神未全，非真动也，不可理他。 我只微微凝照，守于中宫，自有无穷生机，所谓养鄞鄂者此也。 行之一月、二月，我神益静。 静久则气益生，此为神生气、气生神之功也。 或百日，或百余日，精神益长，真气渐充，温温火候，血水有余，自然坎离交媾，乾坤会合，神融气畅，一霎时间，真气混合。 自有一阵回风上冲百脉，是为河车真动。 中间若有一点灵光觉在丹田，是为水底玄珠，土内黄芽。 尔时一阳来复，恍如红日初升，照于沧海之内。
chunks.translated_text:
Only because hardness and softness remain unbalanced, the sword of wisdom lacks its edge, and demonic forces wreak havoc, disturbing the heart and spirit, giving rise to scattered desires. Thus, one drifts with circumstances, causing mercury and fire to scatter, and the sacred embryo fails to form.

If self-refinement is mastered, the heart harbors no stray thoughts, the body becomes like the Great Void—unstained by a single speck of dust, all concerns dissolved. When the heart dies, the spirit lives; when the body is empty, qi circulates. Only then may one seek the Dao of the first yang and the work of the two celestial periods.

Returning the elixir is easy; refining the self is most difficult! Rely on the sword of wisdom to cleave open the primordial chaos, wield the craftsman’s hand to chisel through the undifferentiated. Then employ the method of inverting yin and yang, the Dao of harmonizing water and fire, so that earth and heaven unite in harmony. Let yang dwell below, and fire will naturally rise; let yin rest above, and water will naturally descend. Only through enduring hardship and practicing forbearance, keeping body and mind unmoved—when one’s nature abides, the other’s qi will return of itself.

If one can do this, one attains the effect of guarding the feminine without striving, remaining still and serene, responsive yet unobstructed. At the moment before the Supreme Ultimate divides, stillness reaches its extreme yet has not yet given way to movement. Yang first revives but has not yet parted from yin. Await the descent of this true prenatal qi, then use the method to gather and guide it into the Yellow Court. Daily, refine one’s mercury, enclosing it securely. As mercury qi gradually accumulates and lead qi gradually disperses, the elixir coalesces within the crucible.

One must then regulate the true breath, circulating it through the six voids, until sound fades and intent unites—only then do qi harmonize and pulses settle, and the elixir begins to congeal. Wait until the sacred embryo’s qi is full, the ten-month work complete, the embryo transformed and the infant born. Nurture it with skill, so that its comings and goings are unobstructed, and it remains unswayed by demonic temptations. Only after the ninefold transmutation is perfected and the time of wall-facing arrives—refining essence into qi, refining spirit into emptiness—do form and spirit become wondrously one, merging with the true Dao. This is the moment when the great man’s work is accomplished and his name established.

This Dao was not transmitted by the ancients to the world, for fools lack steadfast belief and diligent practice, and instead slander it. Thus, it was kept secret. Since encountering the perfected one, I have set forth these essentials of self-cultivation to awaken later learners. Let those of like mind exert themselves together and ascend the immortal’s capital.

This text exhausts the truth of nature and life, revealing the principles of sages, immortals, and buddhas—rooted in origins, clear as commentary. It distinguishes the sequence of action and non-action, the division of internal and external medicine, the subtleties of nurturing and delivering the embryo, all laid out in these pages. Nothing more need be added.

The profound mechanism is directly expounded here, as the patriarch revised earlier works to instruct others. Thus, it is appended to the complete collection as two essays on the firing times of elixir refinement.

In beginning the work, one must not cling to action, for action belongs to the postnatal. Many in today’s Daoist circles fall into this error, hence few in the world attain authenticity. Nor should one fixate on non-action, for non-action leads to stagnant emptiness. Many in today’s Buddhist circles succumb to this flaw, hence few in the world become true disciples of the Buddha. The failure of this Dao to spread lies in its obscurity.

The initial work lies in extinguishing emotional attachments and sweeping away stray thoughts. Removing stray thoughts is the first step in laying the foundation and refining the self. Once the human heart is cleared, the celestial heart returns; once human desires are purified, celestial principle abides. Each day, first still the mind for a time, until body and mind are settled, breath and qi harmonized. Then gently close the eyes, lower the gaze, and inwardly observe the space one inch and three fen between the heart below and the kidneys above. Only by finding the place where qi stirs can one avoid falling into emptiness or clinging to stagnation—neither grasping nor abandoning, neither forgetting nor forcing. All thoughts vanish, and only the solitary spirit remains: this is called right mindfulness.

At this time, within this mindfulness, be lively and free; within that qi, be leisurely and unhurried. Exhale to the upper, but not so far as to disturb the heart; inhale to the lower, but not so far as to disturb the kidneys. With each opening and closing, each coming and going, practice for one or two weeks, and naturally the two kidneys will steam with fire, the qi of the cinnabar field will warm. Breath need not be regulated, for it regulates itself; qi need not be refined, for it refines itself. Once qi and breath harmonize, they naturally neither exit nor enter, neither come nor go in the upper, middle, or lower—this is called embryonic breathing, spiritual breathing, the true bellows and furnace, the return to the root and revival of life, the mysterious female’s gate, the root of heaven and earth.

At this stage, qi is like a flower just budding, like an embryo just forming. Naturally, true qi steams and nourishes the constructive and protective energies, ascending from the coccyx, piercing the spine, rising to the mud-pill palace. Descending the magpie bridge, passing the multi-storied tower, it reaches the Crimson Palace and settles in the middle cinnabar field—this is the initial stirring of the river chariot. But though qi arrives, spirit is not yet complete; this is not the true stirring, so do not attend to it. Simply maintain gentle inward focus, guarding the central palace, and boundless vitality will arise. This is what is meant by nurturing the bud.

After one or two months of practice, the spirit becomes ever more still. With prolonged stillness, qi increasingly generates—this is the work of spirit generating qi and qi generating spirit. After a hundred days or more, vitality flourishes, true qi gradually fills, and with the gentlest firing, blood and water become abundant. Naturally, kan and li unite in marriage, qian and kun converge, spirit merges with qi, and in an instant, true qi blends as one. Suddenly, a whirlwind rises, surging through the hundred channels—this is the true stirring of the river chariot. If a single point of numinous light is felt in the cinnabar field, it is the mysterious pearl beneath the water, the yellow sprout within the earth.

At this time, the first yang revives, like the red sun rising over the vast sea.

Eliminate the afflictions of the seven emotions and dispel the harms of the five thieves. Without refining the self to remove the harms of thieves, one cannot constantly respond and remain still. How can the hun and po be controlled? How can emotions and desires not interfere?

chunks.original_text: 如雾如烟，若隐若见，则铅火生焉。 方其乾坤坎离末交，虚无寂灭，神凝于中。 功无间断，打成一团，是为五行配合。 至若水火相交，二候采取，河车逆转，四候得药。 神居于内，丹光不离，谓之大周天，谓之行九转大还也。 此时一点至阳之精，凝结于中，隐藏于欲净情寂之时。 而有象有形。 到此地位，息住于胎，内外温养，顷刻无差，又谓之十月功夫也。 又 夫静功在一刻，一刻之中，亦有炼精化气、炼气化神、炼神还虚之功夫在内，不独十月然也。 即一时一日、一月一年皆然。 坐下闭目存神，使心静息调，即是炼精化气之功也。 回光返照，疑神丹穴，使真息往来，内中静极而动，动极而静。 无限天机，即是炼气化神之功也。 如此真气朝元，阴阳反复，交媾一番，自然风恬浪静。 我于此时将正念止于丹田，即是封固火候。 年月日时，久久行此三部功夫，不但入圜十月也。 故曰：运之一刻，有一刻之周天； 运之一时一日、一月一年即有一时一日、一月一年之周天也。 然一刻中，上半刻为温，为进火，为望，为上弦，为朝屯，为春夏； 下半刻为凉，为退符，为晦，为下弦，为暮蒙，为秋冬。 一时则有上四刻、下四刻之分，即一日一月一年，皆同。 此之谓攒簇阴阳五行，一刻之功夫夺一年之气候也。 到此乃是真空真静，或一二年至十年百年，打破虚空，与太虚同体，此为炼神还虚之功也。 前功十月既满，须时时照顾婴儿。 十步百步，千里万里，以渐而出，倘或放纵不禁，必致迷而不返。 仙经曰：『神入气成胎，气归神结丹』，所谓『一点落黄庭』是也。 但人杂念少者得丹早，杂念多者得丹迟。 此法简易，奈人不肯勇猛耳。 若能恒久行持，必然透金贯石，入水蹈火，通天达地。 再行积功累行，服炼神丹大药，必然形神俱妙，白昼飞升，全家拨宅，此又在功德之浅深何如耳。 设或不服神丹，只顾阳神冲举，回视旧骸，一堆尘土，夫亦白日羽翰，万劫长存，可与宇宙同春者矣。 返还证验说 七返九还之法，下手兴功。 先将上窍阳里真阴，入内金鼎气海之中，与下窍真阳配合。 阳里真阴，即是自家元神，属三魂； 下窍真阳，即是身中元气，属七魄。 其先后二气一合，则坎离自交，魂魄混合，神气凝结，胎息自定，每日如外夫妇交情美快，切不可着他，水火自然既济，发运四肢，如外火之生焰焰相似，只要水火均平，此是小周天。 火候调和熏蒸，喉息倒回元海，则外阳自然入内，真火自然上冲，浑身苏软，美快无穷，腹内如活龙动转升降，一日有数十样变化。 婴儿姹女，自然成合，此是采阴补阳一节。 修炼玉液还丹，即筑基炼己，积内法财，终日逍遥，昼夜常明，乃长生久视之初阶也。 世人常借五谷养命，数日不食，则气饥死矣； 若人年老，下元亏损，骨髓俱空，不能胜五谷之气，是五谷能养人，亦能杀人也。 若会内外交接，水火既济，气血逆流，五脏气合，脾胃开畅，食入腹中，亦能化气生精养神。 人果能得下手天机，直候骨髓盈满，腹脐如孕妇人一般，却不是有胎形相，不过是气满精盈神全而已。 如果三全，则真煅炼，调神炼虚，大丈夫功成名遂之时也。 奉劝学人，参访宗师，苦求至人，抉破一身内外天机，明白下手速修，炼己待时，候一阳至。
chunks.translated_text:
Like mist, like smoke—now hidden, now visible—then lead-fire is born. When qian and kun, kan and li have yet to unite, in utter emptiness and quiescence, spirit congeals within. With unbroken effort, all is forged into one mass—this is the harmonizing of the Five Phases.

When water and fire merge, the second stage of gathering begins; the river chariot reverses its course, and in the fourth stage, the medicine is obtained. Spirit dwells within, the radiance of the elixir never departs—this is called the Great Celestial Cycle, the practice of the Ninefold Great Return.

At this time, a single point of utmost yang essence congeals within, concealed in moments of desire stilled and passion quelled. It takes on form and shape. Having reached this stage, breath abides in the embryo, nurtured within and without without the slightest lapse—this is also called the ten-month work.

Moreover, within a single moment of stillness, there lies the work of refining essence into qi, refining qi into spirit, and refining spirit to return to emptiness—not only in ten months. Even within an hour, a day, a month, or a year, it is the same. Sitting with eyes closed, concentrating spirit, calming the heart and regulating breath—this is the work of refining essence into qi. Turning the light inward, focusing spirit in the cinnabar field, allowing true breath to come and go, stillness within reaching its extreme and stirring, movement reaching its extreme and returning to stillness—this is the work of refining qi into spirit.

Thus, true qi returns to the origin, yin and yang revolve and repeat, uniting once more. Naturally, wind subsides and waves grow calm. At this moment, I fix my right mindfulness upon the cinnabar field—this is sealing the firing process. Practicing these three stages of work over months, days, and hours, one does not merely enter the ten-month enclosure.

Thus it is said: In a single moment of circulation, there is a Celestial Cycle for that moment; in an hour, a day, a month, or a year of circulation, there is a Celestial Cycle for that hour, day, month, or year. Yet within a single moment, the first half is warmth, advancing fire, the waxing moon, the upper crescent, the dawn of *zhun*, spring and summer; the latter half is coolness, retreating tally, the waning moon, the lower crescent, the dusk of *meng*, autumn and winter. An hour is divided into the first four moments and the last four, and so too are a day, a month, and a year. This is called gathering and clustering yin and yang, the Five Phases—within a single moment’s work, seizing a year’s qi and seasons.

Having reached this point, it is true emptiness, true stillness. After one or two years, or ten or a hundred, shattering the void to become one with the Great Void—this is the work of refining spirit to return to emptiness.

Once the ten-month work is complete, one must constantly tend to the infant. Step by step, mile by mile, gradually emerging—if one is careless or unrestrained, one may become lost and never return. The immortal scriptures say: *"Spirit enters, qi forms the embryo; qi returns, spirit coalesces into the elixir"*—this is what is meant by *"a single point falls into the Yellow Court."*

Yet those with fewer distracting thoughts attain the elixir sooner, while those with many attain it later. This method is simple, yet people lack the courage to persevere. If one can practice with constancy, one will surely pierce metal and stone, tread water and walk through fire, ascend to heaven and descend to earth. With further accumulation of merit and cultivation of conduct, refining the great medicine of spirit and elixir, one will attain perfection of both form and spirit, ascending in broad daylight with one’s entire household. This depends on the depth of one’s merit.

If one does not refine the spirit elixir but only allows the yang spirit to ascend, looking back at one’s old body as but a heap of dust—even so, one may take wing in broad daylight, enduring for ten thousand kalpas, coeval with the cosmos in eternal spring.

**On the Verification of the Return**

The method of the Seven Returns and Nine Reversions begins with work. First, the true yin within the upper yang orifice is drawn into the inner golden crucible of the qi sea, where it unites with the true yang of the lower orifice. The true yin within yang is one’s own original spirit, belonging to the three *hun*; the true yang of the lower orifice is the original qi within the body, belonging to the seven *po*. When these two qi merge, kan and li naturally unite, *hun* and *po* blend, spirit and qi congeal, and embryonic breathing stabilizes. Each day, like the joy of conjugal union, one must not cling to it—water and fire naturally achieve harmony, circulating through the four limbs like an external fire kindling into flame. Only when water and fire are balanced is this the Small Celestial Cycle.

When the firing process is harmonized and steaming, breath reverses course back to the original sea—then external yang naturally enters within, true fire naturally surges upward, the whole body softens with boundless bliss, and within the abdomen, a living dragon stirs, ascending and descending with countless transformations in a single day. The infant boy and maiden girl naturally unite—this is the stage of gathering yin to supplement yang.

Refining the jade liquid and returning the elixir is the foundation of refining the self, accumulating inner dharmic wealth. One abides in carefree ease, luminous day and night—this is the first step toward longevity and eternal vision. Ordinary people rely on the five grains to sustain life; going without food for days, they perish from qi hunger. If one is aged, with the lower origin depleted and marrow empty, unable to bear the qi of the five grains, then the five grains can nourish but also kill.

If one masters the inner and outer union, achieving harmony of water and fire, the reversal of qi and blood, the convergence of the five viscera’s qi, and the opening of the spleen and stomach—then food entering the abdomen can also transform into qi, generate essence, and nourish spirit. If one truly grasps the celestial mechanism of beginning, waiting until the marrow is full and the navel swells like a pregnant woman’s—though there is no actual fetal form, only qi full, essence abundant, and spirit complete—then with these three in fullness, one proceeds to true refinement, regulating spirit and refining emptiness. This is the time of a great man’s achievement and fulfillment.

I urge students to seek out a lineage master, earnestly pursue the perfected ones, and uncover the celestial mechanisms within and without the body. Clearly understand the swift method of beginning practice, refine the self and await the moment, and wait for the arrival of the first yang.

chunks.original_text: 择地入室，炼此龙虎大丹。 必要僻静鸡犬不闻之处，外边又要知音道友，不要一个闲杂人来到，恐防惊散元神。 先言和光同尘，今言僻静处，何也？ 炼己于尘俗，养气于山林，是入室兴功，下手之时也。 要超凡入圣，岂是小可的事？ 必须要一尘不染，万虑俱忘，丝毫无挂，一刀两断，永作他乡之客，终无退悔之心。 持空炼神，守虚炼性，浑身五脏筋骨气血，都化成青气，专心致志，演神纯熟，成形受使，星回斗转，随心所变，直养得浑身无有皱纹，如蜘蛛相似，上七窍生光，昼夜常明。 身如太虚，才是正时候，方可求仙道。 这应验气满神全，法财广大，方可炼大丹，才叫做一个丹客。 工夫既得，时候自至，七窍光明，三阳开泰，神剑成形，趁水顺风发火，雷轰电闪，方夺外天机，下手擒拏，采吾身外真铅，以龙嫁虎，驱虎就龙。 若会攒簇，不失时节，湛然摄起海底之金，即开夹脊，上泥丸，落入水晶宫之内，与木汞配合，不过半刻，攒簇已定，真火冲入四肢，浑身骨肉火烧刀割相似，最难禁受，就是十分好汉，到此无一分主张。 防危虑险，冰浴身心，水火既济，顷刻间浑身如炒豆子一般相似，一齐爆开，浑身气血，都会成形说话，就在身上闹成一堆。 舌根下又有两穴，左为丹井，右为石泉，此正是廉泉穴，随骨脉一齐开下，肾水上涌到如外水泉一般，咽纳不完，嗞味甚异，比糖蜜更不相同。 又其至妙者，临炉下手之初，地将产其金莲，天亦垂乎宝露，忽然一点真汞下降，透心如冰凉，即运一点神火，随之攒簇于交感宫内，浑然湛然，如千千战鼓之鸣，万万雷声之吼，又即是自己一身百脉气血变化，休要惊怕，只要踏罡步斗，执剑掌印，这里正是凶恶处，三回九转，降帅召将，如此防顾，于虚空中或见龙虎相交，天地交泰，日月交宫，见众仙诸佛，工夫到此，诸境发现，切不可认他，恐着外邪。 既认元神，汞铅相投，三日才生大药，三日里最难过，遍世界都是邪境，四面神号鬼哭，八方杀气狼烟，此正是大开关工夫，到此十个九个都吓杀了，心不可有恐怖，盖己虽化成神，却是阴神，阴神最灵，能千变万化，诸境为害，他岂肯善善降伏，前人说得好：『你会六通神，方才脱生死； 你若不会六通神，休想成道混沌。 』又至三十时辰二日半，气气相通，气满至极，忽然活泼泼地逆出太阳流珠，脱壳入口，百万龙神，尽皆失惊，此是元阳真丹药，入口始知我命不由天也。 古仙云：『这回大死今方活』』，又云：『一战而天下平』，即是此等地位，这才是天地交泰，日月交宫。 真阳之药到口，顷刻周天火发，骨胎化作一堆肉泥，阳神脱体，撒手无碍，专心致志，持空养虚，以空养神，以虚养心，随心变神。 夫万物皆天地生发吾，万神朝拜而宾服，厌居尘世，通遥蓬岛，自有三千玉女奉侍，终日蟠桃会上，饮仙酒，戴仙花，四大醺醺，浑身彻底玲珑，海底龟蛇出现，万神受使，才是真铅真汞颠倒，浑身紫雾毫光，瑞气千条，是五龙大蛰法也。 炼之百日，玄关自开，婴儿显相，龟蛇出现，自然蟠绕，学者到此地位，口中才干得外汞。 炼之六个月，体似银膏，血化白浆，浑身香气袭人，口中出气成云，此是灵丹成熟，一块干汞，人服之永不死矣，亦能治死人返活。
chunks.translated_text:
Select a secluded chamber and refine this Dragon-Tiger Great Elixir. It must be a place of profound stillness where no cock crows nor dog barks, and outside, only trusted fellow Daoists should be present—no idle or unfamiliar person may approach, lest the primordial spirit be startled and dispersed.

Earlier I spoke of harmonizing with the world, yet now I speak of seclusion—why? To refine the self amid worldly dust and nurture qi within mountain forests is the moment to enter the chamber and commence practice. To transcend the mundane and enter sainthood—how could this be a trifling matter? One must be unstained by a single speck of dust, free from all cares, utterly unencumbered, cutting all ties as if severing with a blade, forever a wanderer in a foreign land, with no thought of retreat or regret.

Hold emptiness to refine spirit, guard the void to refine nature. Let the five viscera, sinews, bones, qi, and blood of the entire body transform into azure qi. With single-minded devotion, cultivate spirit to perfection, shaping it to obey command. As stars revolve and the Dipper turns, it will change at will. Nurture it until the body bears no wrinkles, like a spider’s form, with the seven orifices radiating light, luminous day and night. When the body becomes like the Great Void, only then is it the proper time to seek the Dao of immortality.

This verifies that qi is full and spirit complete, with abundant dharma wealth—only then can the Great Elixir be refined, and one may truly be called an alchemist. When the work is accomplished, the time will naturally arrive. The seven orifices shine with light, the Three Yangs flourish, and the spirit-sword takes form. Seizing the moment like sailing with wind and tide, one ignites the fire with thunderous roars and lightning flashes, capturing the celestial mechanism beyond the body. At the outset, one seizes and grasps, gathering the true lead from beyond the self, marrying the Dragon to the Tiger, driving the Tiger to join the Dragon.

If one knows how to gather and concentrate without missing the proper moment, the golden essence from the sea-bottom is suddenly drawn up, opening the spine’s passage to ascend to the Mud Pill Palace, then descending into the Crystal Palace, where it unites with the Wood Mercury. In less than half a moment, the gathering is complete, and true fire surges into the four limbs. The entire body’s bones and flesh feel as if scorched by fire or sliced by a blade—this is most difficult to endure. Even the bravest, at this point, will have no control.

Guard against danger and peril, bathing body and mind in ice. When water and fire achieve harmony, in an instant the whole body crackles like roasting beans, bursting open all at once. The body’s qi and blood coalesce into form and speech, clamoring as if gathered in a throng.

Beneath the tongue lie two cavities: the left is the Elixir Well, the right the Stone Spring—this is precisely the Lianquan point. As the bone meridians open, kidney water surges upward like an external spring, impossible to swallow completely, its taste strange and unlike sugar or honey.

Yet the most wondrous moment comes at the outset of tending the furnace: the earth yields its golden lotus, and heaven bestows its precious dew. Suddenly, a drop of true mercury descends, piercing the heart like ice. One then directs a spark of spirit-fire to gather and concentrate it within the Chamber of Union. All at once, it resounds like a thousand drums in battle, roars like ten thousand thunders—yet this is merely the transformation of the body’s hundred meridians, qi, and blood. Do not be alarmed. One must tread the Dipper’s steps, wield the sword, and clasp the seal. Here lies the most perilous point. Three revolutions, nine turns—summoning generals and subduing marshals. With such vigilance, one may witness in the void the Dragon and Tiger in union, heaven and earth in harmony, the sun and moon conjoined. One may see hosts of immortals and buddhas. When the work reaches this stage, myriad visions appear—do not mistake them, lest external demons take hold.

Once the primordial spirit is recognized and mercury and lead unite, after three days the Great Medicine is born. These three days are the most difficult to endure. The entire world becomes a realm of demonic illusions: wailing spirits on all sides, murderous vapors and war smoke in every direction. This is the great opening of the passes. Nine out of ten are terrified to death at this stage. The heart must remain fearless. Though the self has transformed into spirit, it is still yin spirit—yin spirit is most cunning, capable of infinite transformations, and myriad visions may assail. How could it willingly submit? As the ancients said: *"Only when you master the six penetrations can you escape birth and death; if you do not master the six penetrations, do not dream of attaining the Dao in primordial chaos."*

After thirty hours—two and a half days—qi flows unimpeded, reaching its fullness. Suddenly, the living pearl of the Greater Yang reverses its course, leaping from its shell into the mouth. A hundred thousand dragon spirits are struck with awe. This is the true yang elixir of primordial yang. Only upon tasting it does one realize that *"my fate is not ruled by heaven."*

The ancient immortals said: *"Only after this great death does one truly live,"* and *"With one battle, the world is pacified."* This is that very stage—the harmony of heaven and earth, the union of sun and moon. When the true yang medicine enters the mouth, in an instant the fire of the celestial cycle blazes forth. The skeletal frame melts into a mass of flesh, and the yang spirit departs the body, free and unobstructed. With single-minded devotion, hold to emptiness and nurture the void, using emptiness to nourish spirit, the void to nourish the heart, allowing the heart to transform spirit at will.

All things under heaven are born of me; all spirits pay homage and submit as guests. Weary of dwelling in the dusty world, one roams the Peng Isle at leisure. Three thousand jade maidens attend, and daily one feasts at the Peach Assembly, drinking immortal wine, wearing immortal flowers. The four great elements intoxicate, the entire body becomes utterly translucent. The tortoise and snake of the sea-bottom emerge, and ten thousand spirits obey command. Only now are true lead and true mercury inverted, the body enveloped in purple mist and radiant beams—a thousand auspicious vapors. This is the Great Hibernation of the Five Dragons.

After a hundred days of refinement, the Mysterious Pass opens of itself, the infant manifests, and the tortoise and snake appear, naturally entwined. Only at this stage may the adept gather external mercury. After six months of refinement, the body becomes like silver paste, blood transforms into white nectar, and the entire being exudes a fragrant aura. The breath from the mouth forms clouds. This is the maturation of the numinous elixir—a lump of dry mercury. Whoever consumes it will never die and can even revive the dead.

ssence abundant, and spirit complete—then with these three in fullness, one proceeds to true refinement, regulating spirit and refining emptiness. This is the time of a great man’s achievement and fulfillment.

I urge students to seek out a lineage master, earnestly pursue the perfected ones, and uncover the celestial mechanisms within and without the body. Clearly understand the swift method of beginning practice, refine the self and await the moment, and wait for the arrival of the first yang.

chunks.original_text: 炼之十个月，阳神脱体，一身能化千万身，只候十二月，夺尽天地全数，阳神已就，浑身出入，只万四千阳神，步日月无影，入金石无碍，入水不溺，入火不焚，刀兵不能伤，鬼神不能测，变化无穷，已成真人也。 浑身气候，无不是真药，鸡餐成凤，犬食成龙，此理鬼神也难明，若不见过这样言语，必不信大药金丹也。 造化工夫，三回九转。 七返八还，火候细微，攒簇口诀，只三五日间，把天地都颠倒过。 都是自然，人身造化阴阳，亦是自然。 却要体天地造化，方可成就。 事从做过见过，从试应验到自然处，工夫虽是一年，火候细微只在百日之内，动静凶恶只在几日，一时里得内外攒簇，顷刻湛然，圣胎成就。 产黍米之珠，吞入腹内，周天火足，脱胎换骨，只是要持空养虚，余皆自然。 今人果得明师指示，先炼己于尘俗，积铅于廛市，攒年簇月，攒日簇时，大定之中只在一刹那间，不出半个时辰，把天地都颠倒过，运火十月之工，体天地自然之法，若不能死中求活，焉能逃出三灾大难哉！ 服食大丹说 三清俸禄，玉皇廪给，非先圣贤哲，焉能受得？ 如许旌阳、葛仙翁、殷真君等八百余家，俱是成道之后，方炼服食，以度群迷。 仙云：『内丹成，外丹就』，此古人得正传。 先积精累气，收积内外法财。 养得气满神全，金光出现，昼夜常明，如是则吾身内丹成，而吾身外丹亦发相矣。 凡看书不可按图索骏，学者于昼夜常明之时，药苗已生，方可采吾身外之药，配吾身中之雌雄，以得金丹入口，周天火候发现，顷刻湛然，撒手无碍，才是金蝉脱壳，默朝上帝，中遇仙举，受其天禄，万神朝礼，能折天补地，摘星握月，驱雷转斗，呼风唤雨，举意万神，使觑天地如手掌相似，这福德胜三辈天子，智慧胜七辈状元，到这般时候，方可炼服食金丹。 此丹如黍米一粒，落于地则金光烛天，方名神丹。 若不通神，敢说是外丹服食！ 此理奥妙，天机深远，金种金，银种银，外边无有别灵神。 此黄白之术，不是凡间金银，为母遏气，果得正传，能产先天大药，认得黄芽白雪，此为黄白，方可为母遏气，以炼神丹。 但是金银水药，都属后天，且又不知真阴真阳同类，万万无成。 慨世学者，真假不辨，不遇正人，都是盲修瞎炼，实修性命之士，若末遇真师，且潜心看书。 大吉圣丹书，不空说一字，妄言一句。 只是后人不识邪正，又不知圣贤书中都是隐语譬喻，遭遇庸师。 执认旁门，毒药入心，又无通变。 似是而非，自高自是，声音颜色，拒人千里之外，则高人望望然去之，况仙圣乎！ 学者未遇正人时，当小心低意。 积功累行，遇魔莫退，遭谤勿嗔，重道轻财； 一遇正人，笃志苦求，快破一身内外两个真消息，忽然醒悟诸书，才不为人迷惑。 若是志大君子，实心为命，扫尽旁门，重正心猿，重立志气，低心下意，经魔历难，苦求明师，穷取生身受气初。 初者，是元始祖气，此气合着一点真阳真阴。 夫真阳真阴，产于天地之先，混元之始，这颗灵明黍米宝珠，悬在虚空，明明丽丽。 但未有明师指破的人，如在醉梦相似，离此着着，都是旁门。 此灵明宝珠，于虚空之中，包含万象，潜藏万有，发生万物，都是这个。
chunks.translated_text:
After ten months of refinement, the yang spirit departs the body, and one body can transform into a thousand or ten thousand. Only after twelve months does it seize the full tally of Heaven and Earth, the yang spirit now perfected. The entire body moves in and out as fourteen thousand yang spirits, stepping through sun and moon without shadow, entering metal and stone without obstruction, entering water without drowning, entering fire without burning. Blades and weapons cannot harm it, ghosts and spirits cannot fathom it. Its transformations are boundless—it has become a true person.

The entire body’s qi and signs are nothing but true medicine. A chicken that eats it becomes a phoenix, a dog that consumes it becomes a dragon. This principle is so profound even ghosts and spirits struggle to comprehend it. Without having encountered such words, one would surely not believe in the great medicine of the golden elixir.

The work of creation and transformation undergoes three revolutions and nine cycles. Seven returns and eight reversions—fire timing is subtle. The oral instructions for gathering and assembling take only three to five days to overturn Heaven and Earth entirely. All is natural; the yin and yang of the human body’s creation are also natural. Only by embodying the creation of Heaven and Earth can one achieve success.

The matter must be personally experienced and tested until it reaches the state of naturalness. Though the work spans a year, the subtle fire timing lies within a hundred days, and the critical moments of movement and stillness, danger and ferocity, occur within just a few days. In an instant, internal and external forces converge, and in a moment, clarity arises—the sacred embryo is accomplished. It produces a pearl like a grain of millet, which, when swallowed, completes the fire of the celestial cycle. Shedding the husk and changing the bones requires only maintaining emptiness and nurturing the void; the rest unfolds naturally.

If one truly receives guidance from an enlightened teacher, one first refines the self amid the dust of the world, accumulating lead in the marketplace. Gathering years into months, months into days, days into hours—within the great stillness, it all occurs in a single instant, no more than half an hour, overturning Heaven and Earth. After ten months of firing, one embodies the natural law of Heaven and Earth. If one cannot seek life within death, how can one escape the three great calamities?

**On the Consumption of the Great Elixir**
The emoluments of the Three Pure Ones, the provisions of the Jade Emperor—how could those who are not sages and worthies receive them? Like Xu Jingyang, Master Ge, Yin Zhenjun, and over eight hundred others, all attained the Dao before refining and consuming the elixir to deliver the deluded.

The immortals say: *"When the inner elixir is complete, the outer elixir manifests."* This is the true transmission of the ancients. First, accumulate essence and amass qi, gathering the inner and outer dharmic wealth. When the qi is full and the spirit complete, golden light appears, shining day and night without cease. Only then is the inner elixir of one’s body complete, and the outer elixir of one’s body also manifests.

One must not read books by matching them to diagrams like seeking a steed. Only when the medicine sprouts during the time of unceasing brightness day and night may the adept gather the outer medicine of the body, pairing it with the inner yin and yang to obtain the golden elixir. When it enters the mouth, the fire of the celestial cycle ignites, and in an instant, clarity arises—releasing the hand without obstruction. This is the golden cicada shedding its husk, silently ascending to the Emperor on High, encountering immortal ascension, receiving celestial emoluments. Ten thousand spirits pay homage, able to mend Heaven and patch Earth, pluck stars and grasp the moon, command thunder and turn the Dipper, summon wind and call rain. With a single thought, ten thousand spirits obey, making Heaven and Earth appear as one’s palm. This fortune surpasses that of three generations of emperors, this wisdom exceeds that of seven generations of top scholars. Only at this stage may one refine and consume the golden elixir.

This elixir, like a grain of millet, when dropped to the ground, illuminates the sky with golden light—only then is it called the divine elixir. Without spiritual attainment, how dare one speak of consuming the outer elixir! This principle is profound, the celestial mechanism deep and distant. Gold begets gold, silver begets silver—there is no other numinous spirit beyond this. This art of the yellow and white is not the gold and silver of the mortal world. As the mother restrains qi, if one truly receives the correct transmission, one can produce the primordial great medicine. Recognizing the yellow sprout and white snow—this is the yellow and white, the mother that restrains qi to refine the divine elixir. However, all gold, silver, water, and medicine belong to the postnatal realm. Without knowing the true yin and true yang of the same kind, success is utterly impossible.

Alas, scholars of the world cannot distinguish truth from falsehood and do not encounter true masters. They are all blindly cultivating and recklessly refining. Those who truly cultivate life and destiny, if they have not yet met an authentic teacher, should quietly study the texts.

The *Great Auspicious Scripture of the Divine Elixir* does not utter a single empty word or a single false sentence. It is only that later generations fail to recognize orthodoxy and heterodoxy, unaware that the words of sages and worthies are all hidden metaphors. They encounter mediocre teachers, cling to side doors, and let poisonous doctrines enter their hearts without adaptability. Seeming right but wrong, they are self-important and self-righteous, their voices and expressions repelling others from a thousand miles away. Thus, the lofty depart in disdain—how much more so the immortals and sages!

Before encountering a true master, the scholar should be humble and cautious, accumulating merit and virtue. When facing demons, do not retreat; when slandered, do not grow angry. Value the Dao and disdain wealth. Upon meeting a true master, devote oneself wholeheartedly to seeking, swiftly breaking through the two true mechanisms within and without. Suddenly, one awakens to all the texts and is no longer deluded by others.

If one is a gentleman of great aspiration, sincerely devoted to life and destiny, sweeping aside side doors, firmly settling the mind-monkey, resolutely establishing will and qi, humbling the heart and lowering the intent—enduring demonic trials and hardships, earnestly seeking an enlightened teacher—one must exhaustively pursue the origin of the qi received at birth. The origin is the primordial ancestral qi, which unites with a single point of true yang and true yin.

True yang and true yin are born before Heaven and Earth, at the beginning of the primordial chaos. This luminous pearl, like a grain of millet, hangs in the void, radiant and resplendent. Yet without an enlightened teacher to point it out, one remains as if in a drunken dream. Departing from this, all is heterodoxy. This luminous pearl in the void contains all phenomena, conceals all existence, and gives rise to all things—all is this.

chunks.original_text: 一粒黍米说 此物在道门中，喻真铅真汞。 一得真得，不可着于乾坤、日月、男女上，只于已身内外，安炉立鼎，炼己持心，明理见性之时，攒簇发火，不出半刻时辰。 立得黍米玄珠，现于曲江之上。 刀圭入口，顷刻一窍开百脉齐开，浑身筋骨，五脏血肉，都化成气，与外水银相似。 到此时候，用百日火功，方有灵妙，一得永得，无有返还，住世留形，炼神还虚，与道为一矣。 此物在佛门中，说是真空真妙觉性。 下手端的，炼魔见性，片晌工夫，发起三昧真火，返本还元，一体同观，大地成宝，霞光万道，五眼六通，炼金刚不坏之身，了鬼神不测之妙也。 此物在儒门中，说是无极而太极。 依外天地而论，无极是天地周围，日月末判之前，四维上下，混混沌沌，如阴雾水气，直至时到气满相激，才是太极。 是时也，日月既生，清浊自分，在上为天，在下为地，天之清气为纯阳，地之浊气为纯阴。 雨露从天降，是阳能生阴； 万物从地生，是阴能生阳。 天地是个虚无，包藏无穷尽、无边际。 天之星宿神祗，动静转轮，各有方位，地下万物，按四时八节，自然发生，总论只是虚空。 夫日月是天地之精，上照三十三天，下照九极万泉，东西运转，上下升降，寒暑往来。 日是纯阳之体，内含一点真阴之精，属青龙、姹女、甲木、水银、金马、三魂，即是外； 月是纯阴之体，内含着一点真阳之气，属白虎、婴儿、庚金、朱砂、玉兔、七魄，即是内。 人身造化同天地，故人身亦有真日月，道在迩，人何求之远也！ 三魂属性，性在天边； 七魄属命，命在海底。 内外通来『性命』两个字，了却万卷丹书。 性属神是阴，命属气是阳，故曰：『一阴一阳之谓道』，千经万卷皆是异名，然真性命及幻法象，若不得真传，则又不可知耳。 仙云：『四大一身皆属阴，未知何物是阳精』，又云：『涕涶精津气血液，七般灵物总属阴』，乃后天渣质之浊阴，非真阴也。 真阴与真阳相对，真阴既不知，焉能知真阳乎？ 今之学者，不惟不知真阳，亦且不知真阴，若知真阴，亦必知真阳矣。 不遇明师，焉能猜度！ 学者穷取一身中天地人三才之妙，穷一身内外真炉鼎之端的，及一身内外阴阳之真消息。 如不得旨，一见诸书异名，心无定见，执诸旁门，无有辨理。 既不知穷理，则心不明，心既不明，则不能见性，既不见性，焉能至命？ 古人云：『只为金丹无口诀，教君何处结灵胎！ 』 登天指迷说
chunks.translated_text:
A grain of millet—
In the Daoist tradition, this is likened to true lead and true mercury.
Once truly attained, it must not be sought in Heaven and Earth, sun and moon, or male and female,
but only within one’s own body, setting up the furnace and establishing the crucible,
refining the self and upholding the heart.
When principle is illuminated and nature is perceived,
gathering the fire in an instant, within half a moment,
the mysterious pearl of the millet-grain appears above the winding river.
With a single dose taken, in an instant one aperture opens and a hundred meridians align;
the sinews and bones of the entire body, the five viscera and flesh,
all transform into qi, resembling external mercury.
At this stage, a hundred days of firing effort bring forth numinous wonders—
once attained, it is forever held, with no return.
Abiding in the world while preserving form,
refining spirit to return to emptiness,
one becomes one with the Dao.

In the Buddhist tradition, this is called true emptiness and the wondrous awakened nature.
The proper method begins with refining demons to perceive nature;
in a brief moment, the true fire of samadhi arises,
returning to the origin and restoring the root,
unifying all in a single vision.
The great earth becomes treasure,
radiant with ten thousand rays of rosy light,
the five eyes and six penetrations manifest,
and the indestructible vajra-body is forged,
completing the unfathomable mystery beyond ghosts and spirits.

In the Confucian tradition, this is spoken of as the Supreme Ultimate emerging from the Non-Ultimate.
Considering the external Heaven and Earth,
the Non-Ultimate is the vast expanse surrounding Heaven and Earth,
before the separation of sun and moon,
the four directions and above and below,
a state of primordial chaos like yin mist and watery qi.
Only when the time arrives and qi fills to the point of mutual excitation does the Supreme Ultimate arise.
At that moment, sun and moon are born,
clear and turbid separate—
above becomes Heaven, below becomes Earth.
Heaven’s clear qi is pure yang,
Earth’s turbid qi is pure yin.
Rain and dew descend from Heaven—yang generates yin;
the myriad things arise from Earth—yin generates yang.
Heaven and Earth are but emptiness,
encompassing the boundless and infinite.
The stars and deities of Heaven move and turn in their fixed positions;
the myriad things of Earth follow the four seasons and eight solar terms,
naturally arising—
all, in essence, is but emptiness.
The sun and moon are the essence of Heaven and Earth,
illuminating the thirty-three heavens above and the nine abysses and ten thousand springs below,
revolving east and west, ascending and descending,
the cycle of cold and heat.
The sun is the body of pure yang,
containing within a single point of true yin essence—
associated with the Azure Dragon, the Maiden, Wood of Jia, mercury, the Golden Horse, and the three hun-souls, which are external.
The moon is the body of pure yin,
containing within a single point of true yang qi—
associated with the White Tiger, the Infant, Metal of Geng, cinnabar, the Jade Hare, and the seven po-souls, which are internal.

The workings of the human body mirror those of Heaven and Earth;
thus, the human body also possesses true sun and moon.
The Dao is near—why seek it afar?

The three hun-souls pertain to nature, which resides at the edge of Heaven;
the seven po-souls pertain to destiny, which lies at the bottom of the sea.
The interplay of internal and external gives rise to the two words: *nature* and *destiny*—
comprehending these, the myriad volumes of alchemical texts are resolved.
Nature pertains to spirit and is yin;
destiny pertains to qi and is yang.
Thus it is said: “The Dao is called the unity of yin and yang.”
The thousand scriptures and ten thousand volumes are but different names for this.
Yet true nature and destiny, along with illusory phenomena,
remain unknowable without true transmission.

The immortals say:
“The four great elements of the body all belong to yin—
what, then, is yang essence?”
And again:
“Tears, saliva, essence, fluids, qi, blood, and marrow—
these seven numinous substances all belong to yin,”
for they are the turbid yin of acquired dregs, not true yin.
True yin stands opposite true yang—
if true yin is unknown, how can true yang be known?
Scholars today not only fail to know true yang,
but also remain ignorant of true yin.
Yet if one knows true yin, one must also know true yang.
Without encountering an enlightened teacher, how can one fathom this?

Scholars must exhaustively seek the wonders of the three talents—Heaven, Earth, and Humanity—within their own bodies,
discern the proper furnace and crucible within and without,
and grasp the true workings of yin and yang within and without.
Without attaining the essential teaching,
upon seeing the varied names in texts, the mind lacks certainty,
clinging to heterodox paths without discernment.
Failing to comprehend principle, the heart remains unilluminated;
with an unilluminated heart, one cannot perceive nature;
without perceiving nature, how can one attain destiny?
The ancients said:
*“Only because the golden elixir lacks oral transmission,
how can you be taught where to congeal the numinous embryo?”*
This is the *Guide to Ascending Heaven, Dispelling Delusion*.

which unites with a single point of true yang and true yin.

True yang and true yin are born before Heaven and Earth, at the beginning of the primordial chaos. This luminous pearl, like a grain of millet, hangs in the void, radiant and resplendent. Yet without an enlightened teacher to point it out, one remains as if in a drunken dream. Departing from this, all is heterodoxy. This luminous pearl in the void contains all phenomena, conceals all existence, and gives rise to all things—all is this.

chunks.original_text: 道也者，生天地，育万物，放之则包罗虚空，敛之则退藏于密，两仪、日月、五行，都是道中之造化耳。 物物各具一太极，即道也。 人人心上有先天，亦道也。 五行顺而生人生物，五行逆而成仙成佛，故云：『五行顺则法界火坑，五行逆则大地七宝』。 这五行之精，秘于四大形山不内不外之密处，只是百姓日用而不知耳。 民可使由之，顺行也； 不可使知之，逆行也。 夫鱼在水中，不知其为水也； 人居气内，不知其为气也。 此譬喻当潜心究竟，回光返照，明心见性，果证仙佛，复何难哉！ 今人学道，个个自卖聪明，自夸伶俐，自称会家，终无了悟。 又有一等小根盲人，见先圣所言外阴阳、外炉鼎、外药物，执迷子女为鼎器，则又可哀已也。 某见酷好炉火者，百无一成。 又以轩辕铸九鼎而成道，以为必用鼎器九人，谬之甚矣，尝见有进过五七鼎亦无成就者。 且人念头一动，先天淳朴即散，先天既丧，后天虽存，究何益于身心，不过聊存其四大而已。 这样下愚，岂知天不言而四时行、百物生之妙哉！ 夫人身造化同乎天地，但不知天何得一以清、地何得一以？ 且又不知主张造化的是谁？ 若能以清静为体，镇定为基，天心为主，元神为用，巧使盗机，返还天真，归根复命，岂患不至天地圣位。 至用文鼎一节事，万无此理。 假使有缘之士，得遇真师，先行玉液还丹，炼己和光，操持涵养，回光返照，此即见性明心之事也。 既见其性，更求向上之事，乃金液还丹，情来归性，直到真空地位，大用现前，龙女献一宝珠，金光发现，至此方为一得永得。 亥子之交，剥复之间，于太阳初动兴功时，手探月窟，足蹑天根，回风混合，从此有百日功灵之妙，此金液还丹，乃阴阳五行之大道也。 除此玉液金液、性命双修、清静自然之道，余皆旁门小法。 某于一身内外。 安炉立鼎，攒簇口诀，药物火候细微已得，不知虚空法度，便去入室，行外药入腹大事，发火行功。 到秘密处，有虚空万神朝礼，仙音戏顶，此事鬼神难明，怎奈因自己不能炼己于尘俗，末得积铅于市廛，气脉又未甚大定，基址也未得三全，理虽融而性未见，故万物发现凶险，心神恍惚，不能做主，又因外边无知音道侣护持看守，触其声色，惊散元神，激鼎翻炉，劣了心猿，走了意马，神不守舍，气不归元，遭其阴魔。 何为阴魔，我不细言，后学不知。 皆因真阳一散，阴气用事，昼夜身中，神鬼为害，不论睁眼合眼，看见鬼神来往，即耳中亦听得鬼神吵闹，白日闲觉犹可，到晚来最难过，不敢静定一时，我身彼家海底命主，兑金之戊土冲返，五脏气血皆随上腾，身提不着他，杀身丧命，真乃鬼家活计也。 某乃暂弃前功，遵师训指，大隐市廛，积铅尘俗，摄情归性，杀机返覆，自幼至老被天地人物盗去的天真，今于虚无中尘色内，却要夺盗返还于我天性之中，方得元精、元气、元神之三全，至是乃心明理融，理融见性，身心大定，五行攒簇，才去行上等事而了大道。 想前代贤哲，多有中道而废，皆因未曾炼己持心，金来归性，以至二候得药，于四候进火之时，不知虚空法度，粗心大意，是以白玉蟾有『再砍秋筠节』之叹焉。 谁知虚空消息，至微至凶至恶，若是擒捉不住，定不饶人。
chunks.translated_text:
The Dao/Way gives birth to Heaven and Earth, nurtures the myriad things—when released, it encompasses the vastness of empty space; when gathered, it retreats into profound concealment. The Two Modes, sun and moon, and the Five Phases are but the transformations within the Dao/Way. Each thing possesses a Supreme Ultimate, which is the Dao/Way. Within every person’s heart lies the primordial, which is also the Dao/Way. The Five Phases flow in sequence to give rise to humans and beings; when reversed, they produce immortals and buddhas. Thus it is said: *“When the Five Phases flow in sequence, the dharma-realm becomes a fiery pit; when reversed, the great earth yields its seven treasures.”* The essence of the Five Phases is hidden in the secret place of the four great elements—neither within nor without—yet people use it daily without awareness.

The people may be made to follow it, for this is the sequential flow; they cannot be made to know it, for this is the reversed flow. Fish dwell in water yet do not know it as water; humans reside within qi yet do not know it as qi. This analogy demands deep contemplation: turn the light inward, illuminate the heart, and perceive nature—how then could attaining the fruition of immortals or buddhas be difficult? Yet today’s Dao-seekers, each claiming cleverness, boasting of wit, and styling themselves as adepts, never attain true awakening. There are also those of shallow roots and blind eyes who, upon hearing the sages speak of external yin-yang, external furnaces and crucibles, and external medicines, cling to the delusion that women are the crucibles—how pitiful indeed!

I have observed those who ardently pursue the furnace and fire, yet a hundred fail to achieve one success. Some cite the Yellow Emperor’s casting of nine tripods to attain the Dao/Way, mistakenly believing that nine women must be used as crucibles—how utterly misguided! I have seen those who have progressed through five or seven crucibles yet still achieve nothing. Moreover, the moment a thought arises, primordial simplicity scatters; once the primordial is lost, even if the posterior remains, what benefit does it bring to body and heart? It merely sustains the four great elements. Such fools know nothing of Heaven’s silent operation—how the four seasons proceed and the hundred things flourish!

The human body’s transformations mirror those of Heaven and Earth, yet who knows how Heaven attained its singular clarity or Earth its singular stability? And who governs these transformations? If one can take stillness as the body, stability as the foundation, the celestial heart as the master, and the primordial spirit as the function—skillfully employing the mechanism of reversal to restore primordial truth, return to the root, and recover destiny—how could one not ascend to the sacred rank of Heaven and Earth?

As for the matter of employing a literary crucible, there is no such principle. If a person of karmic affinity encounters a true teacher, they should first practice the *jade liquid return to the elixir*, refine the self, harmonize the light, and cultivate through introspection—this is the work of perceiving nature and illuminating the heart. Having perceived nature, one may then seek the higher work: the *golden liquid return to the elixir*, where emotions return to nature, until reaching the state of true emptiness, where great function manifests. The Dragon Girl offers a single precious pearl, and golden light appears—only then is there an attainment that endures.

At the juncture of *hai* and *zi*, between *bo* and *fu*, when the first stirring of the Great Yang arises, one reaches into the moon’s cavern with the hand and treads upon the celestial root with the foot, merging the returning wind—from this arises the wondrous efficacy of a hundred days’ work. This is the *golden liquid return to the elixir*, the great Dao/Way of yin-yang and the Five Phases. Apart from the dual cultivation of nature and destiny through the *jade liquid* and *golden liquid*, and the Dao/Way of stillness and spontaneity, all else are but side doors and lesser methods.

I have established the furnace and crucible within and without my own body, mastered the oral instructions on gathering and refining, and understood the subtleties of medicine, fire, and timing. Yet, unaware of the celestial principles, I entered seclusion to undertake the great work of ingesting the external medicine and kindling the fire. At the secret juncture, when the empty space of the myriad spirits pays homage and celestial music plays above the crown, this matter is beyond even the comprehension of gods and ghosts. Alas, because I had not refined myself amidst the dust of the world, nor accumulated lead in the marketplace, my qi and vessels were not yet fully stabilized, and my foundation was not yet complete. Though principle was harmonized, nature remained unseen. Thus, myriad perils arose, the heart and spirit grew distracted, and I could not maintain control. Without a knowing companion to guard and protect me externally, the slightest sensory disturbance startled my primordial spirit, overturning the crucible and disturbing the furnace. The restless mind-monkey and wayward intent-horse fled, the spirit failed to guard its abode, and qi did not return to the origin—plunging me into the realm of yin demons.

What are yin demons? I shall not elaborate, for later learners would not understand. It is because the true yang scatters and yin qi takes control that, day and night within the body, spirits and ghosts wreak havoc. Whether eyes are open or closed, one sees ghosts and spirits coming and going; even in the ears, one hears their clamor. By day, idle moments are bearable, but at night, it becomes unbearable—one cannot remain still for even a moment. The life-master at the sea of qi in the body, the *dui*-metal’s *wu*-earth, surges upward, and the five viscera’s qi and blood follow, rising beyond control. The body cannot be subdued, and life is forfeit—truly the work of ghostly hands.

I temporarily abandoned my previous efforts, following my teacher’s guidance to conceal myself in the marketplace, accumulate lead amidst worldly dust, gather emotions back to nature, and reverse the mechanism of destruction. From youth to old age, the primordial truth stolen by Heaven, Earth, and beings—I now sought to reclaim it from the emptiness within worldly dust and return it to my celestial nature. Only then were the three treasures—primordial essence, primordial qi, and primordial spirit—complete. At last, the heart was illuminated, principle harmonized, nature perceived, the body and heart stabilized, and the Five Phases gathered. Only then could I proceed to the higher work and complete the great Dao/Way.

Reflecting on the sages of former times, many abandoned their practice midway, for they had not refined the self or stabilized the heart, nor had they returned metal to nature. Thus, when they obtained the medicine in the second phase and proceeded to the fourth phase of firing, unaware of the celestial principles and acting with carelessness, even the White Jade Toad lamented *“cutting the autumn bamboo again.”* Who realizes the subtlety, peril, and ferocity of the empty space’s workings? If one cannot seize and subdue it, it will surely not spare them.

If the practitioner discerns the two true workings—within and without the body—with perfect clarity and no obstruction, then they may proceed to nurture and refine, shedding selfishness and restoring the celestial principle. Thus, the work of returning the elixir becomes most simple and effortless. All day, one gathers the Yellow Sprout beyond the body, awaiting the primordial Jade Liquor—this is precisely the wondrous awakening of "drinking wine and wearing flowers" to attain immortality.

As for the state of primordial undifferentiation, there is no intention, no insistence, no fixation, no self; whether living or dying, one forgets both people and things. Like an idler who neglects livelihood, wandering streets and alleys, delighting in sights and soothing the heart, lingering in brothels and taverns, sitting in wordless oblivion—how could this not astonish and perplex the world? To gather the environment and accumulate lead, employing both method and wealth—how could this not invite the ridicule and slander of the vulgar?

Therefore, one must rely on powerful families in great metropolises for external protection, perceiving the Dao in plain sight while concealing one’s light and obscuring one’s traces. The immortals say: *"To covet the treasure of heaven, one must use the wealth of the world."* The treasure of heaven does not refer to the sky above but to the dwelling of the Nine Yang Cauldron within the body—thus did the Yellow Emperor cast the Nine Tripods and ascend. Yet deluded fools, upon hearing the words *"treasure of heaven,"* fixate on the sun and moon in the sky, taking the moon’s emergence in the *geng* direction as true water and true lead, using their eyes to measure degrees and gather it; or at the sun’s rise in the *mao* hour, they likewise employ their eyes to gather it as true fire and true mercury.

The heavens above and earth below, *qian* and *kun*, *kan* and *li*, the inner and outer furnaces of male and female—these are all metaphors for the inner and outer yin and yang of one’s own body, without any actual form of male or female. The immortals say: *"Whatever has form is all delusion."* The returning elixir has no substance—how profound are these words!

Those in the world who cultivate goodness never engage in harming others for personal gain. What men and women in the cosmos rely upon to live without dying is none other than this single point of yang essence. How could one who seeks immortality steal a woman’s essence to benefit their own body? How does this differ from those who kill? Moreover, the ancient sages spoke of *"that household’s male and female,"* *"the two families,"* *"the two nations,"* and *"the inner and outer furnaces"*—if one does not receive the correct transmission, how few will avoid misinterpretation?

I once encountered an enlightened teacher who, through direct instruction and personal guidance, revealed the two true workings within and beyond the empty space. Daring not keep this secret for myself, I transgressed the prohibitions to pass it on. The creation of heaven, earth, and humanity; the scriptures of the Three Teachings; the medicines and firing times; the union of sun and moon; the measures of waxing and waning—all these I have fully disclosed, not through written words but through true speech, so that practitioners may avoid the errors of misguided cultivation. Wherever this book resides, spiritual beings guard it. If one without affinity chances upon it, it will be no more than the blind singing empty verses.

The Great Way of the Golden Elixir is rarely encountered even in ten thousand kalpas—*"tramping in straw sandals yet finding nowhere to seek, yet gaining it without effort."* If the practitioner can nurture this square inch of the heart amidst haste, turmoil, displacement, and hardship, preserving it without loss, then the celestial principle is restored. Once the celestial principle is restored, one may then seek the higher work of ingesting the external medicine, and in an instant, become serene, shedding the mortal coil and transforming the bones, merging entirely into a single golden light, transmuting the great earth into treasure.

The body generates another body beyond itself; the yang spirit departs the form, embracing emptiness and nurturing the void—this is the Great Hibernation of the Five Dragons, attaining boundless freedom and transcending the three kalpas of wind, water, and fire, no longer subject to birth, aging, sickness, death, or suffering. Yet people today do not cultivate the Way but instead covet external elixirs and alchemical concoctions—this is the height of delusion.

This chapter is the concluding section of *Mysterious Essentials*, a general discourse on the sentiments of the Dao. *"Guiding the Lost to Ascend Heaven"* is the overarching title for the verses on the Dao’s sentiments. The closing line—*"if seen by the unworthy, it is but the blind singing empty verses"*—makes clear that this is a general discourse on the Dao’s sentiments.

**Commentary on the *Nine Augusts’ Elixir Canon: Dragon-Tiger Lead-Mercury Treatise***

The Daoist Lord’s discourse on the extraction and replenishment of dragon-tiger lead and mercury is intended for those of the future with roots and affinity to begin their practice here. Though it is said, *"Only immortals can become immortals,"* I insist that *"even mortals can become immortals."* The only fear is not understanding the principle of the Golden Elixir—then one truly enters hell to become a beast.

This dragon pertains to yang; once yang is lost, all becomes yin. This tiger pertains to yin; within yin lies the treasure, which is a single yang. The dragon is the mysterious pass of the self; the tiger is the mysterious gate of the other. The dragon is lustful, yet I do not leak—adding a drop of water to a bit of earth forms the character *yao* (瑶), becoming the supreme treasure of Jade Liquor. The tiger is voracious, yet I do not leak—adding the true fire to the character *jian* (柬) forms *lian* (炼), gathering the supreme treasure of Golden Liquor.

Tiger, tiger, tiger—fear not your gaping maw and fanged jaws, striking terror into hearts and souls. I possess the hand of the tiger-tamer, reducing you to emptiness within form and form within emptiness. With the dragon’s playful touch, I make you the meeting of dragon and tiger amidst wind and clouds, unafraid that you will not yield your tiger cub from the tiger’s den, entering my Three Fields.

Dragon, dragon, dragon—though you are a creature of lust and desire, I possess the hand of the dragon-subduer. Fear not your endless transformations—I use Nezha’s vajra ring to bind you, extracting your sinews to fashion a golden belt for nurturing nature and connecting life, worn always. How could you not then approach the True One of the Great Ultimate to request the unparalleled Dharma-door of the True One, merging with me into the Great Way of primordial unity?

chunks.original_text: 铅即两弦之铅，汞即我身天地之汞，有日月之光明，天地才成地天泰，不为天地否，人身自父母生来，原有一汞一铅，男女交媾之理，故曰『干为父，坤为母，男女媾精，万物化醇』，『易为先天之太极』。 人不明此一理，只把汞去投铅，生男生女，不把铅来投汞，成佛成仙。 这个铁馒头打得破，何难为三丰中之三丰也。 注吕祖《百字碑》 养气忘言守， 凡修行者，先须养气。 养气之法，在乎忘古言守一。 忘言则气不散，守一则神不出。 诀曰：缄舌静，抱神定。 降心为不为。 凡人之心，动荡不已。 修行人心欲入静，贵乎制伏两眼。 眼者心之门户，须要垂帘塞兑。 一切事体，以心为剑，想世事无益于我，火烈顿除，莫去贪着。 诀云：以眼视鼻，以鼻视脐，上下相顾，心息相依，着意玄关，便可降伏思虑。 动静知宗祖， 动静者，一阴一阳也。 宗祖者，生身之处也。 修行人当知父母未生之前，即玄化也。 一身上下，乾坤八卦，五行四象，聚会之处，乃天地未判之先，一点灵光而成，即太极也。 心之下，肾之上，仿佛之内，念头无息所起之处，即是宗祖。 所谓动静者，调和真气，安理真元也。 盖呼接天根，吸接地根，即阖户之谓坤、辟户之谓干。 呼则龙吟云起，吸则虎啸风生，一阖一辟，一动一静，贵乎心意不动，任其真息往来，绵绵若存。 调息至无息之息，打成一片，斯神可凝，丹可就矣。 无事更寻谁。 若能养气忘言守，降伏身心，神归炁穴，意注规中，混融一炁，如鸡抱卵，如龙养珠，念兹在兹，须臾不离，日久工深，自然现出黍米之珠，光耀如日，默化元神，灵明莫测，即此是也。 真常须应物，应物要不迷。 此道乃真常之道，以应事易于昏迷，故接物不可迷于尘事。 若不应接，则空寂虚无。 须要来则应之，事去不留。 光明正大，乃是不迷，真性清静，元神凝结。 诀曰：着意头头错，无为又落空。 不迷性自住，性住气自回。 凡人性烈如火，喜怒哀乐，爱恶欲憎，变态无常，但有触动。 便生妄想，难以静性。 必要有真惩忿，则火降。 真寡欲，则水升。 身不动，名曰炼精，炼精则虎啸，元神凝固； 心不动，名曰炼气，炼气则龙吟，元气存守。 意不动，名曰炼神，炼神则二气交，三元混，元气自回矣。 三元者，精、气、神也； 二气者，阴阳也。 修行人应物不迷，则元神自归，本性自住矣。 性住则身中先天之气自回，复命归根，有何难哉！ 诀曰：回光返照，一心中存，内想不出，外想不入。 气回丹自结，壶中配坎离。 修行人，性不迷尘事，则气自回，将见二炁升降于中宫，阴阳配合于丹鼎，忽觉肾中一缕热炁上冲心府，情来归性，如夫妇配合，如痴如醉。 二气絪缊，结成丹质，而炁穴中水火相交，循环不已，则神驭炁、炁留形，不必杂术自长生。 诀曰：耳目口三宝，闭塞勿发通。 真人潜深渊，浮游守规中。 直至丹田气满，结成刀圭也。 阴阳生反复，普化一声雷。 功夫到此，神不外驰，气不外泄，神归炁穴，坎离已交，愈加猛烈精进，致虚之极，守静之笃，身静于杳冥之中，心澄于无何有之乡，则真息自住，百脉自停，日月停景，璇玑不行，太极静而生动，阳产于西南之坤。 坤即腹也，又名曲江。
